ex.xv: "Aba, yaw kinga nganang. Marndi wurdyaw kayawbaye kadberre warreh," yimeng ngalbu Ngalwakadj bedberre.
ex.xe: “Oh, I saw a young crocodile. It might bite our kids” Ngalwakadj told them.

ex.xv: "Kandadju kundad dja ngamarrwedoweng." "Aba, minj won, ngaye mak ngamarrwedoweng."
ex.xe: "Give me a [turtle] leg, because I'm hungry” “No way. I can't give you any. I'm hungry too."
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

sn.de: Oh, oh no, the thing is, no way (conveys that the speaker is shocked or wants to contradict something that has been said).

ex.xv: Kore manyunkurr, adjbud kayo.
ex.xe: On the island, there is a beach.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’

ex.xv: Ngaye ngadjawayhme nuye bu ngayime "Adju baleh wam nawu Nabangardi?"
ex.xe: I ask him, I say “I don’t know, where did Nabangardi go?”.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Is it?; maybe; I don't know!
Said after a joke which provides mild embarrassment to the hearer.

ex.xv: Bu korroko duruk bokenh Adjumarlarl dja Omwarl benemwam karrikadbeh kukku benehboyawani.
ex.xe: The two Ancestral Dogs Adjumarlarl and Omwarl came [to the Gunbalanya area] from the west, looking for water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation, Adjumarllarl and Omwarl Story

sn.de: Name of a male ancestral dog being, who travelled with the female Ancestral dog Omwarl through the area around Gunbalanya. The name is from the Mengerr language but Kunwinjku speaking residents of Gunbalanya are familiar with the story of these two dogs. The name has been also spelt Adjumarllarl but there is no linguistic basis for a rl+l sequence in either pronunciation or syllable structure. However, the Adjumarllarl spelling is now largely an accepted convention.
Kind of hibiscus. As for the Grewia species, the bark of this hibiscus is used to make string and the young stems are good firesticks.

ex.xv: Nawu korroko bininj birriyuhyungki birrimulewarreni bu bedda kunwok bedberre kore birriwokdi. Yika manbu kunwok mankang kuberrkbeh dja yika kore kurrulabeh. Wanjh bolkkime bininj birriwern kabirribebbehwokdi manbu kunwok bedberre. Yiman Amurdak dja Wardadjbak makka kuberrkbeh birriwokdi. Dja manbu Yibadjdja dja Marrkku makka wanjh kumekke ngalengman kore kabirrihni bolkkime bininj manbu kunwok kumekke kabirridjalwokdi.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors all spoke to each other in their own languages. Some languages came from inland areas, and others from saltwater areas. Still today, people each talk their own languages. Amurdak and Wardadjbak for example were spoken in inland areas. Iwaidja and Marrku are still spoken where the speakers of those languages live.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

re: place name in the Gunbalanya township

ex.xv: Nawu manimunak wirlarrk djang kahdjangdi kore kaddum kuwardde Arrkuluk.
ex.xe: There is a sacred site for Magpie Goose eggs on the top of Arrkuluk rock.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Name of the hill on the southern side of Gunbalanya township in Mengerrdji language country.

re: place name in Birrirddak Creek region
sn.de: Hill on the western side of the entrance to Birraduk [Birrirddak] Creek valley, directly south of the Gunbalanya-Nabarlek road. This site has the same name as the hill at Gunbalanya and is therefore sometimes called ‘Arrkuluk number two’.

re: goodness me, 'oh how dear it is'

ex.xv: Awurd, mayh namekke ngan­kodjborledke Kawk Kabim Djang
ex.xe: So dear to me is that bird, its call reminds me of the sacred night heron dreaming.
ex.so: Nabarlek Band song (Terrah Guymala)

ex.xv: Yika mak ngarriyime "awurd" bu nangale nawu kare djarre wanjh ngarrikongibun, dja mak bininj nawu karrowen, wanjh ngarriyime "awurd warre mankang mandengeyi".
ex.xe: We might say “fv: Awurd” (“Oh that dear man/woman”) if someone goes far away and we feel sorry for them, or for example if someone dies we might say "Awurd (oh that poor man/woman) it’s a terrible thing, they had a car crash".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: An interjection used to express emotional attachment, dearness.

ex.xv: Yirrolkka ba karrire.
ex.xe: Get up so we can go.

ex.xv: Ba minj birrinayinj nganabbarru yoy, wanjh manwurrk biwayhkeng.
ex.xe: But they didn't see a buffalo sleeping there until a bush fire woke him up.

ex.xv: Ngabardbabang.
ex.xe: I have a sore knee.

ex.xv: Baleh yimi bu yimimbabangni?
ex.xe: How long has your eye been sore?

ng: a kind of adjective which can take predicate prefixes (pronominal and nominal)

re: carry with a stick over shoulder

ex.xv: Yidjirribiwo ba ngababbulibun djenj.
ex.xe: Tie the fish up (passing vine or string through the gills) so I can carry them on a stick.

ex.xv: Karrimadjbabbulibun.
ex.xe: Let's carry our swag on a stick over our shoulder.

sn.de: Carry a load attached to a stick over the shoulder, especially fish.

ex.xv: Bu ngurridirri ngaleng kaburriwe wanjh ngudda yibabma.
ex.xe: If you're going to play, she'll throw it (the ball) and you've got to catch it.

ex.xv: Mongerrk-Mongerrk birriyameng nawu bininj birriyuhyungki, wanjh birrikukkinjeng kore kunak. Kunmurrwirn nuye bu dolkani wanjh birribabmangi, birriyawoyhkinjeyi kore kunak ba bu minj yawoyhmarnburrimeninj.
ex.xe: The Ancestors speared Mongerrk-Mongerrk, and burned his body on a fire. As scraps of his charred skin floated up into the air from the fire, they caught them and burned them again, so he couldn't re-form himself.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Catch an object which has been thrown, launched etc.

re: pull in, reel in (e.g. fishing line)

ex.xv: Yiyarlbabbabmang werrk!
ex.xe: Quick, pull in the line!

sn.de: Reel in, pull in (e.g. a fishing line or rope).

ex.xv: Birribadbom nabuyika benuk.
ex.xe: Then they speared another bush turkey.
ex.so: Garlngarr, Victor, ‘Mamik dja Nakodjok benekang’, in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: Dja kunubewu bolkkime wanjh nganang bu yiman kayime kurrung darnkih wanjh kabindibadkan kabirriwarlbun.
ex.xe: Well I notice at the moment, probably because it’s coming up for build-up season, they’re taking them hunting a lot.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Verb prefix indicating that one action follows another, possibly as a consequence. So, then, afterwards, as a result, in that case, with good reason, etc.

ex.xv: Korroko bininj birrirey djalakkiradj dorrengh kore kuwardde birriyawani birrinani birridanjbuni nawu badbong.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would take spears into the escarpment looking for short-eared rock wallabies, and when they saw them they would spear them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Badbu djalkurrmerrinj ngayi ngabengkan... I know!
ex.xe: Yes, that's right, I know it put itself there, I know that.

sn.de: Exactly right!, absolutely! That's what I mean!

ex.xv: Badbu djal ngaleng werrk ngunnang, wanjh ngunkukbawon.
ex.xe: When she [an emu] spots you first [before you see her], well she'll run away from you.

ex.xv: Badbu kondabu ngarrinankah arribukkayi manekke.
ex.xe: If we see some here, we should show it to him.

ex.xv: Baddumang ngarrikebnarren.
ex.xe: We are looking at our faces in the mirror.

ex.xv: Warlirr kundung karrirung, kunekke kadberre karrirung, dja baddumang kabirrikarrme, baddumang kabirrikarrme kune kayime kakolhdebebme, kakolhdebebme, soon kabirrikarrme, glass, mirror, soon kabirrikarrme kadberre yiman muddikang rerri. Bokenh kabenekarrme, glass baddumang kukak kabirribebme.
ex.xe: When the sun is hot, when we get really hot, then they have pieces of glass and when plants start sending out new growth [just before rain comes] then they [spirit beings] have pieces of glass and they take us away in something like a motor vehicle. They are in pairs with their pieces of glass and they appear at night.
ex.so: Jimmy Bungurru (first language was Ndjébbana).

bw: From Makassarese patomang ‘compass’. Note also Ndjébbana baddúmang ‘swimming goggles, glass, mirror’. Also Iwaidja badumang (or bathumang) and Mawng patumang ‘glass, mirror’

ex.xv: Bu korroko wanjh larrwa dja badj birriwungmi dja bolkkime larrk.
ex.xe: In the old days people used to smoke long Macassan pipes and European style pipes too, but not any more.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

bw: most likely an English loan but note Makassarese patti 'chest, case' and kalling 'tin, can' and cf Iwaidja patjukaling 'large container, drum' and Burarra bajikala 'long smoking pipe'.

ex.xv: Kundulk mandubang birrilawkmangi birridjedmi birrimarnbuni manberlnginj, manbadjan dja manyaw wanjh birribekkani manmak wanjh bonj.
ex.xe: They would peel the bark off ironwood branches and carve them into clapsticks, a large one and a small one, hear that they sounded good and that was it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manbu manbadjan makka rungkal. Manu manyaw makka rarrk.
ex.xe: The large external lines are the outlines, the small lines are the hatching (within the painted figure).
ex.so: Joey Nganjmirra

sn.de: Big one, large, main part. When two things are conceived of as existing in a greater-lesser, main-subordinate or parent-child relation, 'badjan' describes the greater or parent part. The lesser or child part is referred to with 'yaw'.

ex.xv: Kunwardde ngakodjbadjdji.
ex.xe: I bashed it on the head with a rock.

ex.xv: Ngad bininj ngarringun manbu badjdjo ngarrire ngarrinan manrakel wanjh ngarrikarung ngarrimang kaluk mankuk ngarringun minj ngarrikinje mandjoleng ngarringun.
ex.xe: We Aboriginal people eat bush radishes, we go and we see its leaves then we dig it up and eat it raw. We don't roast it and eat it cooked.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Small herbaceous plant which has an edible radish-like tuber.

bw: possibly from Makassarese pacco 'Arum colocasia R., a plant with roots which are edible after cooking'. Cf Bajau pacco 'taro, Colocasia esculenta'. Also Mawng badjdjung 'yam type'.

ex.xv: Manbu mannjam makka mankuyeng birridjirridjbuni kore kurrula birridjobdjobkeyi birrikinjeyi kore banikkin nakimuk badjdjukkali.
ex.xe: The intestines (of the sea turtle) are very long, people used to wash them in the salt water, then chop them up and cook them in a large drum.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngahni Mamardawerre kaluk ngarrurrkmirri kunngobarn bu ngamarnbun, dja mak ngarriwen nawu ngarrimarnbun manbu badjkid nawu ngaye ngarridanginj.
ex.xe: I live at Mamardawerre and I work making things out of pandanus, there are lots of us here making baskets, me and my sisters.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra, quoted in Hamby, Louise (ed.), Twined Together: Kunmadj Njalehnjaleken, Injalak Arts and Crafts, Gunbalanya, 2005, p. xiii

sn.de: Basket. This word usually refers to a non-traditional basket, such as coiled baskets. The coiling technique was introduced to Arnhem Land by missionary Greta Matthews in the 1920s, but was traditionally used by southern Aboriginal people along the Murray River.

ex.xv: Nawu kunmadj ngarringeybun badjubadju nawu kaddumkah kabirridjongburren.
ex.xe: The piece of clothing that we call 'badjubadju' (a shirt) is something people wear on their upper body.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu kunboy karribakke wanjh karrinan nawu djak kabebmerren kore kuboybeh.
ex.xe: If we break a termite mound, we see the white ants coming out from inside the mound.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yimarnebakke mankarre ngundukkan, nawu Balanda.
ex.xe: If you break their law they'll put you in handcuffs, the white people.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006. Kunkarre changed to mankarre.

ex.xv: Djimarr benbakkeng yawurrinj mandule bedberre.
ex.xe: Djimarr created a song for/about the young men.

sn.de: Compose a song about a person or incident, be able to perform (orally) or recite something.

ng: This construction is of the form SUBJ/OBJ-break.

ex.xv: Bu yibawon bakki kamak wanjh.
ex.xe: It would be good if you gave up smoking.

ex.xv: Yuwn yikilekme wardi kabakme.
ex.xe: Don't touch it or it might break.

ex.xv: Yibalderrehmen!
ex.xe: Move over! [so there’s room for me to squeeze in].

ex.xv: Nungka balwam kore mankabo bu dungyibmiyibmi darnki.
ex.xe: He went out to the river when it was almost sunset.

sn.de: Trajectory in space away from a static speaker and/or hearer or, in third-person-based narrative, on the protagonist's current position.

ex.xv: Yibalre / Yibale!
ex.xe: Keep going!

ex.xv: Kundulk makkah kabalhdulkdarlkan.
ex.xe: That stick is floating along down the river.

ex.xv: Ngabirlidombom ngarohrokmeng dja baldjalwurlhmeng.
ex.xe: I tried to put the fire out, but it kept starting up again.

ex.xv: Balabbala kanjdji.
ex.xe: Under the table.

ex.xv: Wirndilk kaworrbalabala.
ex.xe: The Haemodorum coccineum plant has flat leaves.
ex.so: Nadjamerrek, Lofty Bardayal, Russel, Jeremy & Garde, Murray, ‘A Preliminary List of Kundedjnjenghmi Plant Names’, NLC, Kabulwarnamyo, 2003

ng: Normally appears in noun or verb constructs, e.g. 'mandulkbalabala', 'a flat piece of wood'.

ex.xv: Baladj ngakengeme wardi ngankurlbayakwon.
ex.xe: I'm frightened of leeches, they might finish up my blood.

ex.xv: Kunkare Ngalngarridj wam kunngobarn mangihmangi, kani baladjdji dja manmarli.
ex.xe: One day Ngalngarridj went gathering pandanus, carrying a bag and a hooked stick.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Ngalngarridj Marebu Marnbom’, Oenpelli School and Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Gunbalanya, 1975

sn.de: Bag, string bag or cloth bag.

ex.xv: Ngalkurrng nganbalakbun. 'Ngayi won daluk,' kayime.
ex.xe: (My) cousin (MMBDD) will give me her daughter in marriage. She'll say, 'I'll give the girl to you.'

ex.xv: Barrk ngarringeybun nawu ngad bininj ngarriwinjku ngarrikukburlerri dja birrikukbele balanda kabirringeybun 'black wallaroo'.
ex.xe: Us Kunwinjku Aboriginal people say 'barrk', but non-indigenous people, white people, call it a 'black wallaroo'.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Barrk djukerre. Nakka duwa Balang. Balang Belinj.
ex.xe: The black wallaroos are of the duwa moiety and the male is Balang subsection and the female is Belinj.

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Ngalburlanj wam kore kubolkbalay.
ex.xe: Ngalburlanj went to a place very far away.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: La name nawaran yingeybun wardi kangeybekkan bonj ngunbawon kare kelekele. Namekke. Kukkelekele namekke. Nawaran. Ngunbekkan. Kunwok kabekkan. Yiman bininj nakka, kunwok kakarrme. Kangeybekkan nawu balay kangimen nawu kururrk cave munguyhmunguyh marrek mak ngarrngalke.
ex.xe: If you utter the name of the Oenpelli python [when hunting it] then it will be too late and it will leave you behind and go off in fear. That's it. It is a very timid animal the Oenpelli python. It can hear your speech. It is like a human and has its own language. It can hear its name and will take off a long way and go inside a cave and you'll never find it.
ex.so: Jimmy Kalarriya, in file ‘Kalarriya Nawaran’ recorded by Murray Garde.

ex.xv: Ngudda baleh yihdi?
ex.xe: Where have you been?

ex.xv: Maladj, baleh ngundihmarneyimeng? Oh ngandihkaybom ngamarrewedowen ngarrowen .
ex.xe: Maladj, what did they say to you? Oh, they refused to give me any [food]. Now I'm really starving.

ex.xv: Bale kayime?
ex.xe: What's (s)he saying?

ex.xv: Minj baleh karriyime.
ex.xe: There's nothing we can do. [or] What can we possibly do/say?

ex.xv: Bale ngayimiwon?
ex.xe: How do I do this?

ex.xv: Bu balekeno yimdurndeng?
ex.xe: When are you coming back?
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunngol mimbalhmeng dird.
ex.xe: The clouds have blocked the moon.

se.de: Close door or block off an entrance.

ex.xv: Yibalay djarreh.
ex.xe: Keep on going for a long way.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kare kaddum wanjh Duleburreni Ngaldaddubbe Djabidj Bakoluy kare konda kabalhdurndeng kaddum kabale mani anbolh kadumeyoken ngaleng bono.
ex.xe: It goes upstream to the places Duleburreni Ngaldaddubbe and Djabidj Bakoluy and here it keeps going back up to where the river meanders into a wide outer bank.
ex.so: Lofty Bardayal Nadjamerrek (Kundedjnjenghmi)

ex.xv: Yibaldjalay munguyh.
ex.xe: Just go away for good.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Keep going, continue moving, go (in a direction away from the speaker).

ng: Composed of bal + re, but usually shortened to 'bale' in casual speech.

ex.xv: Bambam ngalengman kore kundulk kabelebelbme, manboykerlk.
ex.xe: 'Bambam', black termite mounds, can be found stuck against the base of trees. They are a relatively soft type of termite mound.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birriboymangi manbu kunboy manboyburlerri kangeyyo bambam wanjh birriwilkdengi.
ex.xe: They would gather bits of black termite mound, called 'bambam', and use it to cook them (the olive pythons).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Type of black termite mound, usually found on the side of trees and favoured for use in ground ovens.

ex.xv: Makka ngarridi manekke kunj yiman ba kahre manbambarr kabidbun, yah ngarriyame.
ex.xe: We stand there in them (the gullies) and if the kangaroos go up the narrow gully then we spear them.

sn.de: Dead end valley or narrow gully which are the sites chosen for fire drives to trap kangaroos which become trapped and injured by fire and can then be easily speared.

re: shine with bright colour or brightness, glisten

ex.xv: Djadberlhberl nawu kakarlangbarme.
ex.xe: That red-shouldered parrot, the one with the brightly coloured shoulder.

ex.xv: Ngudda yingurlme yire, ngayi ngabarme ngare, ngayi yiman mankalarr.
ex.xe: You move as a dark form, I go with a bright shining body, I am like the ghost gum (a Kuninjku kunborrk genre song text).

sn.de: Shine, glisten, be bright or brilliant in colour (either in terms of lightness or in hue), be vivid.

ex.xv: Birrihbang.
ex.xe: Wild people (violent or quick to anger).

ex.xv: Kundjikurdubuk djang kundjak nabang.
ex.xe: The sickness dreaming site at Kundjikurdubuk is dangerous.

ex.xv: Manu kari yikurrmeng manbang ngandjenbom.
ex.xe: This curry powder you put [in the food] is so powerful it has burnt my tongue.

sn.de: Food that is either poisonous or 'cheeky', i.e. leaves a burning sensation in the mouth or is very strong in taste (salty, bitter, too sweet, too much chilli etc).

ex.xv: Aa Bangardi bimbom bu ngabbard nganbimbukkang Bangardi ngayiken nadjorrorlam
ex.xe: There are paintings by a man of Bangardi subsection which my father showed me, Bangardi, a man related to me of Djorrorlom clan.
ex.so: JK

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Manbulu Karri ngalengarre Bangardidjan ngal-Marrirn.
ex.xe: Manbulu Karri (a place) belongs to her, Bangardidjan of the Marrirn clan.
ex.so: Kevin Buluwana

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.

ur: Kunwinjku = ngalkamarrang, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi =bangirn, E (synonym)=bangœrn, Kundjeyhmi = alkamarrang

ex.xv: Daluhdaluk kabirrire kabirrimang mankodjbang bu bangkerreng kayimerran.
ex.xe: Women go and get water peanuts in the late wet season.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Late wet season, the last rains of the wet season (April-May), 'knockemdowns' (late storms which 'knock down' the tall spear grass.
Person of mixed Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal descent.

bw: From: from Makassarese kayo bangko 'mangrove sp., whose bark is used to boil trepang to give a red colour'.

ex.xv: Yuwn yibangmeyarlkilekme.
ex.xe: Don't touch the (fishing) line yet.

ex.xv: Ngadjadj, bu ngarrbalre kore kakkak, yuwn kanbangmemulewan, yidjalbawo kaluk ngalengman kadjawayhme.
ex.xe: Uncle, when we go to see grandma, don't introduce me to her straight away, leave it and let her ask.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj dja Nakodjok Benewam Djenj’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ng: an aspectual prefix on verbs with the sense of 'before time in topic frame'

ex.xv: Kunbang birribonguneng birribangminj wanjh.
ex.xe: They drank alcohol and then they become violent.

ex.xv: Djakku kakan banikin bele, kabiwon Nabulanj.
ex.xe: Lefty [nickname] is carrying a white pannikin, he’s going to give it to Nabulanj.
ex.so: ‘Lesson 13: Djurra ‘L’’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

sn.de: Enamel metal cup or mug, pannikin.

ex.xv: Kanudbanj.
ex.xe: It's smells rotten.

sn.de: Smelly, smelling of something, odorous (pleasant or malodorous).

Cross cousin who is considered an affine e.g. brother-in-law, sister-in-law, MBD, MBS, MMBDS, MMBDD. Borrowed from Kriol, which in turn is likely borrowed from another Top End language. Used as term of reference and address.

ex.xv: Konda bedman na-Barabba, Kurrkdjurle, kunred nuye Wamud na-Barabba, nawernwarre ngarduk Kurrkdjurle. Kunred nuye Mimburrng.
ex.xe: This [land] here belongs to the Barabba clan, this place Kurrkdjurle was for Wamud of the Barabba clan who was my eldest brother, Kurrkdjurle [was his place]. His country was Mimburrng [an estate name].

sn.de: Name of a duwa moiety Kune and Dangbon speaking patriclan from central Arnhem Land.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji bikebbadjdji mandjad la ngalbuyika ngalbu bibarlanbom, wanjh djalwohmankang.
ex.xe: He hit one woman hard, straight in the face. He hit the other woman, but he didn't manage to hit her hard, and she just fainted.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 132

ex.xv: Ngad ngarrikarrme mankare mankarre kerrngekenh wanjh ngarribarlanhmang.
ex.xe: We have the old law from the very beginning but we are letting it go [losing it].
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 260

ex.xv: Nganbarlankebdoy.
ex.xe: He nearly punched me.

sn.de: ‘Almost’, ‘nearly happened but didn’t’, ‘be about to’. When prefixed to the verb to get barlanhmang the meaning is ‘let go of, lose control of, fail to take hold of’. In Kune it can appear as a free form.

se.de: Let go of something, lose something, not hold something properly.

ex.xv: Kukbarli.
ex.xe: Crooked body/crippled/object out of shape.

ex.xv: Mimbarli.
ex.xe: Cross-eyed/having an off-centred iris.

ex.xv: Wanjh kumwam, ngandjawam ngadberre nawu ngarridanjbik ngarrihdi: Ngalngarridj June, ngaye, Ngaldengebarli Ngalkodjok.
ex.xe: Then he came and asked the three of us who were there, June, myself, and that Ngalkodjok with the bandy legs.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yibiwkeng, bonj barlidanj.
ex.xe: You've bent it, it's crooked now.

ex.xv: Benebokenh kohbakohbanj benewam benehmangi mandem. Benemey benebarlkeng, ngalkudji yimeng, "yimray ngarrdokme ngabarlkeng ngayembu".
ex.xe: Two old women were gathering waterlily roots. They filled up their bags, and one of them said "Come here, let's go, mine is full already".
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew ‘Kuhni bu Kunkare Birrihwarlbuni’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

sn.de: Fill up a container to capacity.

ex.xv: Malalam yiman kayime yibengkan mandjoh yiman kayime manu, kabirrimarnbun njamed, barlkkan.
ex.xe: In dry hill country where you can find Acacia difficilis, they use that timber to make boomerangs.

sn.de: Sacred boomerangs used in pairs as musical instruments in various ceremonial contexts.

ex.xv: Karriborrahkendong rowk wanjh barlmeng karriyirrurndeng.
ex.xe: Let's fill up all the containers with water and then take them back full.

ex.xv: Kabolhbarlungme.
ex.xe: The track curves around.

ex.xv: Kukbarlungmeng.
ex.xe: It has twisted around [e.g. a crocodile swerving to catch a fish].

ex.xv: Mahni karribarlungmen!
ex.xe: We turn off here!

sn.de: Change course, turn and travel in another direction, turn off a track.

ex.xv: Barnangarra kakeyo kaluk kukak kayawan nawu djenj dja kordbolbok dja nawern nawu mayh kilekilelh.
ex.xe: It sleeps in the daytime, then in the nighttime it looks for fish and frogs and many other small animals.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation, Bokorn (spangled grunter) story.

ex.xv: Ngurribarndin!
ex.xe: Stay up there!

ex.xv: Ngadedjbarndi manih.
ex.xe: I'll sit up on this [chair].

sn.de: Be high up, be situated in a high place.

ex.xv: Barndol kukdahdadjmiken.
ex.xe: The carpet python has striped blocks of colour.

ex.xv: Ngalbu barndol ngalkka kabirringun kore kubolkbubuyika.
ex.xe: In other places, the people eat carpet pythons.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yibarnamen wardi duruk kangun.
ex.xe: Put it up high otherwise the dogs might eat it.

sn.de: Place in a high position, hang up.

Long wooden-headed 'shovel-spear', with bamboo shaft and head having an exceptionally long (>320mm) broad, leaf-shaped blade of ironwood (Erythrophleum chlorostachys) although today the points are typically fashioned from hammered steel.

ex.xv: Mani kunwardde Marrirn ... Barrbinj kure kakbi, Marrirn koyek.
ex.xe: This rock is Marrirn [clan country] ... and Barrbinj is to the north, Marrirn clan is east of that.

ex.xv: Yirridjdja rowk nanu wanjh Kumarrirnbang-beh kare bolk kunengkunu bolk-Barrbinj kadjale kanjdji kabolkbuyika kure nabuyika Marrirn.
ex.xe: It's all yirridjdja moiety country from here at Kumarrirnbang to that Barrbinj country there and it goes right downstream to another [discontiguous] Marrirn estate.

sn.de: Name of a yirridjdja moiety patriclan in the lower Liverpool River region.

ex.xv: Bu benebebmeng kured wanjh beneworrhmeng benewilkdi nawu kalawan dja mandem dja manu barrdjungka benekinjeng kore kuyirrke dja nawu mankung benedelengbarnnameng kore balabbala.
ex.xe: When they got back to camp they made a fire and cooked the goanna in the ashes and the water lily seeds on the coals and put the honey they had gathered up in the roof of the shelter.

sn.de: The sprouting seeds of the waterlily, edible raw or cooked.

ex.xv: Ngurridolkka barrhbom!
ex.xe: Get up you mob, the sun's up!

sn.de: Sunrise, the appearance of the sun at dawn.

ex.xv: 'Kanwo', bimarneyimeng ngalu ngalbadjan 'kanwo kunkod ba ngabarrhburren.' Barrhburrinj wanjh yonginj ngaleng.
ex.xe: 'Give me some', said the mother, 'give me paperbark so I can cover myself [to use as a blanket]. She covered herself over and she slept.

se.de: Cover self, be a canopy of vegetation.

ex.xv: Mibbarr nungkah kabun nawu dabuno kangun karrowkke, kabarrhke 'dek' kukebyih.
ex.xe: The white bellied sea eagle breaks the [emu] egg to eat it, 'crack' it smashes it open with its beak.

sn.de: Crack or split open an OBJ, burst.

ex.xv: Milhbarrhmeng namekke murrika.
ex.xe: That car has a smashed windscreen.

ex.xv: Ngardbakan nakka karohrok yiman karnubirr. Bu ngarridjare kuk ngarringun wanjh kunwardde ngarridong kabarrhme wanjh ngarringun
ex.xe: Saltwater mussels are similar to freshwater mussels. If we want to just eat them raw, we hit them with a rock, they split open and we can eat them like that.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Shatter, crack or split, burst open.

ex.xv: Nakidjkidj kakarrme barrk kelebuk nuye.
ex.xe: Nakidjkidj spirits keep black wallaroos as pets.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kunrodjbe kabirribarung wanjh delek kabirribimbun kore dolobbo nawu mayh njale nawu kunj djenj dja nawern.
ex.xe: Let's paint ourselves with pipe clay and dance.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Smear, paint, cover a surface with a wet or viscous substance. This word can be contrasted with bimbun, which means to paint a picture, draw or write.

se.de: Smear oneself with ochre or other substance.

ex.xv: Yoh yoh bonj bonj karrikaybun, karrikaybun baw!
ex.xe: Yes, yes, that's it, that's what we shall do, let's not give any to her, we'll refuse to give any, quiet now [she's coming]!

ex.xv: Wurdurd bawh, wokyak!
ex.xe: Hey kids, shush, be quiet!

ex.xv: Bawh, ngurringurdmen! Bulanj kabiwokmang Balang!
ex.xe: Shush, be quiet all of you! Bulanj is making a voice recording of Balang!

ex.xv: Yuwn ngurrikilekme, ngurribawo!
ex.xe: Don't touch it, leave it alone!

ex.xv: Ngandibawong.
ex.xe: They left me.

ex.xv: Nakimuk nganbawon.
ex.xe: They [the trousers] are too big, they're falling down off me.

ex.xv: Bakki ngabawong.
ex.xe: I've given up smoking.

sn.de: Give up a previous habitual activity, stop.

se.de: Leave something to someone, pass something on to someone.

ex.xv: Nanikud ngarrikarrmi and bawurl ngarrikarrmi nawern.
ex.xe: We had goats, and lots of chickens too.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Manme nganebayahme karrewoneng.
ex.xe: We'll buy some food for ourselves.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Wanjh bikodjbayeng biyibkeng kanjdji wanjh bikani kanjdji bidjalngani [bidjalkani] kurorre baybay.
ex.xe: Then it [the rainbow serpent] swallowed her head first and took her deep down into the earth.
ex.so: The example phrase comes from some texts Peter Carroll has deposited with AIATSIS.

ex.xv: Daluk baybayken.
ex.xe: Women’s internal reproductive organs.

ex.xv: Ngalengman baybaywi djahdjalburrbuni.
ex.xe: She knew within herself, was convinced of it.
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace & Rowe, Meryl (eds), 'Karriburlume God: Kunwinjku Song Book', Gunbalanya, 1985, p. 7.

ex.xv: Nganbidbaye.
ex.xe: It's biting my finger.

ex.xv: Birribayerrinj duruk.
ex.xe: The dogs were fighting (biting each other).

ex.xv: Njale ngunbayeng?
ex.xe: What's the matter? What’s happened? [lit. “What’s bitten you?”]

sn.de: Cause an illness, cause pain, cause fright etc.

ex.xv: Birribebbehwam.
ex.xe: They each went on their own.

ex.xv: Ngarrbenbebbewon.
ex.xe: Let's give to each of them.

ex.xv: Mankung nawu yiman kayime kabebbengeybuyika nawu mankung kardderre lorlbban nabiwo njalenjale.
ex.xe: The varieties of honey for example each have a different name, such as kardderre, lorlbban, nabiwo and so on.

ng: This verbal prefix has a distributive function which can include spatial separation. The 'distributive share' (see Evans 2003:497) can be focused on an intransitive or transitive subject but in some cases for the latter, also on the object and verb.

ex.xv: Yibebkemen bakki nguddangke ngawungme!
ex.xe: Take out your tobacco and I'll have a smoke!

sn.de: Take out, bring out, reveal, cause to appear.

ex.xv: Wamuddjan nganemarren ngarridj la ngarridjdjan ngabebke.
ex.xe: I'll get married to a woman of wamuddjan subsection and I'll have (produce) children of ngarridj and ngarridjdjan subsection.

ex.xv: Birrbebmeng.
ex.xe: They're here (they have arrived).

ex.xv: Dungbebmeng.
ex.xe: The sun is up.

ex.xv: Yibebmen!
ex.xe: Go outside!

sn.de: Go/come out of an enclosure or dwelling.

re: third person plural exclusive oblique possessive pronoun

ex.xv: Dabborrabbolk kunwok bedberre.
ex.xe: The language of the ancestors.

ex.xv: Ngadmanwali karrikan bedberre.
ex.xe: It's our turn to take it for them.

ex.xv: Wardi yiyolyolme bedberre Balanda.
ex.xe: Explain it for those non-Aboriginal people.

ng: can express a benefactive function when there is no benefactive applicative [i.e.-marne-] in the verb complex. The first sense expresses basic possession of a noun

re: third person augmented direct free pronoun

ex.xv: Bedda Nakorrkko benekabokurrmeng.
ex.xe: The Nakorrkko [ancestral father and son heroes] placed the creek there.

ex.xv: Kunekke kabirriyime bedda.
ex.xe: That's the kind of thing they [those people]  do.

ex.xv: Karribedjekmerren delek karriborrkke.
ex.xe: Let's flick ourselves with white ochre and dance.

sn.de: Apply paint to a surface, flick a liquid or viscous substance. Also used for the process of applying paint during screen printing (e.g. at Injalak Arts and Crafts in Gunbalanya).

ex.xv: Nawu Mimih nakka yiman ngad bininj djaying, dja bedman djal kuwarde kuwarderurrk kabirriyo.
ex.xe: It's said that Mimih spirits are similar to us people, but they live by themselves in rocky country in caves.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nakka bukka bedberre bedman na-Buyhmi.
ex.xe: That [land] there belongs exclusively to the Buyhmi clan themselves.

ng: This is a pronoun of the emphatic series (there being three kinds of free-standing pronouns: direct, oblique and emphatic). Evans

ex.xv: Minj kangun djenj, la birriberhkeng wanjh bonj nguneng.
ex.xe: He wasn't allowed to eat fish and then they lifted the restriction (by smoking him) and it was OK for him to eat it then.

sn.de: Ritually cleanse a place or person by swatting with smoking ironwood leaves, for example after witnessing a sacred ceremony.

ex.xv: Kunmalaworr mandubang kabirrimang wanjh kabirridjangberhke kabirribolkngeyhngeybun. Wanjh kadjangyalarrme.
ex.xe: People get an ironwood branch and swat the sacred site with it, calling out the names of places (where they want to find plentiful game). Then the djang spreads out from there (and goes to those places, increasing the animals/fish etc).

ex.xv: Delek birriburriwemeninj dja kunmalaworr birriberhberhkemeninj kuwukku, o kure djenj kabimdi djenjken.
ex.xe: They would throw white clay (into the water) and thrash the place with leaves in the water or similarly at the fish increase site they would strike the paintings of fish with leaves.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Perform increase ritual which involves swatting a particular site with a branch of ironwood leaves, and asking for plentiful game, fish etc.

ex.xv: Minj kangun djenj, la birriberhkeng wanjh bonj nguneng.
ex.xe: He wasn't allowed to eat fish and then they lifted the restriction and it was okay for him to eat it then.

ex.xv: Bukbuk karribekkan kawokdi kayime bukbuk bukbuk bukbuk.
ex.xe: We hear the pheasant coucal calling out “book-book, book-book, book-book”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yibekka wanjh.
ex.xe: Listen to him/her.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bekkarrinj nungan kunkurlah nuye kahbuyikahmen wanjh yimerranj madj.
ex.xe: He felt his skin becoming different and he became an octopus.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Consider, think about before making a decision.

ex.xv: Nganbelbme.
ex.xe: It's sticking to me.

ex.xv: Belbminj.
ex.xe: Stuck together.

sn.de: Stick together (as in one surface to another).

ex.xv: Kukbele.
ex.xe: White skinned person.

ex.xv: Kunngolbele.
ex.xe: White clouds.

ex.xv: Manbobele.
ex.xe: Clear water.

se.de: Become white or brighter in colour.

ex.xv: Bele ngandengekarrme.
ex.xe: I've got a cramp in my leg.

ex.xv: Duruk kumwam benmenebelenghmeng, dja yakminj.
ex.xe: A dog came and licked them, then disappeared.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Drink leaking or dripping fluid, lick up.

ex.xv: Mak bu kadjalbuleyo munguyh, wanjh kunmayorrk kamre mankimuk, kabuleworlhme rowk bu kabolkbelewon.
ex.xe: When there's ash lying on the ground for a while, a big wind will come and blow it away and clean up the area.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Make something clean or clear, remove dirt from something.

ex.xv: Kabirriwunghme, everywhere kare manekke kundolng. Kabenkinjekinje wanjh rerrih kabirribekkan kabirribeleyerrkan yiman. Bele kabenmang.
ex.xe: Yes, when they inhale [marijuana], that smoke goes everywhere inside. It makes them hot and then they feel like they are getting numb all over. It makes them numb.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Barrk djukerre. Nakka duwa Balang. Balang Belinj.
ex.xe: The black wallaroos are of the duwa moiety and the male is Balang subsection and the female is Belinj.

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Ngamokbelngdanj.
ex.xe: The swelling on my sore has gone down.

ex.xv: Kandiddjawa yiwilkdeng karung kalurlme. Kaluk karriwilkmang kabuhme kabelngdan wanjh.
ex.xe: You put a damper in the coals and it cooks and swells up. We get it out and it when it's cooled the swelling subsides.

sn.de: Subsiding of a swelling, go down.

ex.xv: Marrek bekkan, wurdurd kandibengbun.
ex.xe: I can't hear you, those kids are making too much noise.

ex.xv: Ey, kanbengbun!
ex.xe: Hey, you're offending me (i.e. Don't talk to me about my sister).

sn.de: Offend or say something improper to somebody, particularly to talk with a man about his sister or to a woman about her brother.

ex.xv: Yimray kanbengdayhke.
ex.xe: Come and let me know.

ex.xv: Ngudda ‘young people’ wanjh ngudda bu ngurribengdayhmen wanjh ngurribolknahnan. Ba bu ngarridowerren, ngarriyakmen, wanjh ngudda ngurribolknahnan.
ex.xe: You young people, you should realise you can look after the place. So then when we die, when we’ve gone, you’ll be able to look after the place.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Remember something, be reminded of, realise.

ex.xv: Yibengkan konda Kurrurldul yibengkan kahyo Balang, la kaddum djang kahdi.
ex.xe: You know here at Kurrurldul where Balang lives, well upstream from there is that sacred site.

ex.xv: Nakohbanj Tommy yimeng kabibengkan namekke skipper kore kabbala, kangeyyo Burray.
ex.xe: Old Tommy said he remembers the skipper of the boat, his name is Burray.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Bolkkime minj nangale kabengkan bu kamarnbun manbu bokko larrk.
ex.xe: These days nobody knows how to make barbed spears.
ex.so: Andrew Mankgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Know how to, be able to.

ex.xv: Med kabengkan.
ex.xe: Wait, she'll think about it.

ex.xv: Nawamud benmarneyimeng nawu daluhdaluk "Yuwn wurdurd kabirrire kunih bu wardi kabirribengkokan dja kungarrewern".
ex.xe: Nawamud told the women "The children shouldn't go there, they'll get lost, there's lots of thick jungle".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalbulanj bimarneyimeng Ngalkodjok "Nawu nakudji duruk bengkokang, wam nuk baleh".
ex.xe: Ngalbulanj told Ngalkodjok "One of the dogs must have gotten lost, I don't know where it went".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yibengkokan bu kanhmarneyime!
ex.xe: You must be out of your mind, talking to me like that!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Be confused, lose one's way, lose one's mind, be drunk.

ex.xv: Dulkelorrkkelorrken benbengmayahkeng birribengwabom birrimayahmeng.
ex.xe: Dulkelorrkkelorrken (the Tree Spirit) has made them confused and disoriented and they’ve gotten lost.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dja nawu yika ngad ngarriyime birrimayalidjad dja mak birrikodjkuludjad, dja yika mak nawu yiman birrimayaliwarre minj kabirriwernhburrbun, yiman kabirrihdjalbengmayahme.
ex.xe: With some people we can say they think well, they are clever, and with others, its like they can’t think well, they don’t know much, it’s as if they get confused.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Be confused, unable to think clearly.

ex.xv: Dja ngabengmidjdanj, ngaye ngayahwurdni.
ex.xe: But I've forgotten, I was very young at the time.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: A: Nangale? B. Nawu nanih bengwarr.
ex.xe: A: Who? B. This one here, the stupid one.
ex.so: Quoted in Garde, Murray, ‘Culture, Interaction and Person Reference in an Australian Language’, John Benjamins Publishing Company,  Amsterdam, 2013, p. 252

sn.de: Heedless person, one who doesn’t pay attention or take sensible advice, stupid person, unable to learn.

ex.xv: Kanhbengwarrewong, arribengwarreminj arridjalni arriburrbun Balandakenh.
ex.xe: It has destroyed our well-being, we have gone crazy just sitting in one place only knowing non-Aboriginal culture.

sn.de: Send mad, distract, annoy (due to disturbance, noise, irritation etc).

ex.xv: Kanhbengwarrewong, arribengwarreminj arridjalni arriburrbun Balandakenh.
ex.xe: It has destroyed our well-being, we have gone crazy just sitting in one place only knowing non-Aboriginal culture.

sn.de: Become annoyed or seriously irritated, develop dementia, become mad or insane, start to do stupid things.

ex.xv: Korroko nawu dabborrabbolk minj ngandiwoyinj ngalbu benuk bu ngarringuyinj. Ngandimarneyimi ngahli mayh benuk minj ngurringun ngaldjamun. Benuk kakarrekan ceremony manbu Mardayin.
ex.xe: In the past, the Old People didn't give us any bush turkey to eat though. They used to tell us we don't eat this bird, it's taboo because it's part of the Mardayin ceremony.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Australian bustard or plains turkey, often referred to as a ‘bush turkey’.

ex.xv: Kabindihberddjobke bukka, dja konda larrk.
ex.xe: They practice circumcision over there [in the east], but not here.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 123

sn.de: Circumcise. This is a less polite word than the synonym lakkayenwon.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji ngalkohbanj bernelkani baladjdji kore kukarlang.
ex.xe: An old woman was carrying a bag over her shoulder.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunyirrk kabernalkan.
ex.xe: She's carrying a dilly bag on her shoulder.

sn.de: Carry by handle over the shoulder.

ex.xv: Name kanmulewan berrebberreb bu ngarriwarlbun.
ex.xe: That masked plover sings out and lets animals know that we are approaching when we go hunting.

ex.xv: Berrebberreb ngad duwa.
ex.xe: The masked lapwing is for us duwa moiety people.

sn.de: Masked lapwing, also known as the masked plover or spur-winged plover.

ex.xv: Nakka duruk yaw ngardduk. Ngayi werrk ngaberrebburrinj.
ex.xe: That puppy is mine. I was first to claim it.

ex.xv: Kanyingkihberrebbom.
ex.xe: He claimed us from the start.

ex.xv: Nganberrebbom manme.
ex.xe: He promised to give me food.

ex.xv: Kumekke nganemarrinj ngalbu ngandiberrebbom Mary Lilinjdji.
ex.xe: That's where we got married, me and Mary Lilinjdji, who had been promised to me.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Promise to give a woman or girl in marriage.

ex.xv: Berrerdberrerd karrinan kabarndi kore kundulk manyende yika karrolkan kare kubuyika mayh kayawan.
ex.xe: We see Rainbow Bee Eaters sitting on tree branches, or flying off somewhere else to look for insects.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentaton

ex.xv: Kondah kore karrihni dja borledmikenh kore Nimbabbirr dja bewh kurredjdubbe kabbal kabolkngeyyo Wurrmarninj.
ex.xe: On the other side of Nimbabbirr from where we are here, and further down to the very end of the floodplain, that place is called Wurrmarninj.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Ancestral being, said to be the progenitor of mako 'didjeridu'.

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalyawkyawk kayawkan wanjh ngarrimarneyime bibbidj minj ngarringeybun, warddi kabikebkadjung bu kabenekebrohrok. Dja bibbidj ngarrimarneyime ba kornkumo kabikebkadjung bu kabenekebrohrok.
ex.xe: When a girl has a child, we call it 'bibbidj', we don't use it's name, otherwise it will end up looking like its mother. We call it 'bibbidj' so it will look like its father. (In Kunwinjku culture it is considered preferable that a child takes after its father in terms of looks).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nani yina bobbidj, la ngabidbun wanjh ngarradje.
ex.xe: Look at that wild honey, alright I'll climb up and cut it out.

ex.xv: Birribidbuni kundulk kore kurrula darnkih.
ex.xe: They used to climb a tree close to the river.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Korroko muddikayakni… Dja bolkkime muddika kabirribidbun.
ex.xe: There were no cars in the old days… Nowadays they can all get in vehicles.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Get into or onto a raised object, e.g. a vehicle.

ex.xv: Bu kurrula kabobidbun wanjh minj karrinan ngalbu karndjawarra.
ex.xe: When the tide comes up, we don't see any mud crabs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nganbidbom, ngakurlahlurlmeng.
ex.xe: It caused a blister on my hand, my skin was swollen.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Rise, rise up. Can refer to the action of many things that rise, such as blistering.

ex.xv: Bu kunwok Kunwinjku ngarriyime mayh ngarriwarlbun. Dja bu ngarriyime mayh ngarrire ngarribidbun karrkad wanjh nakka kore ceremony yiman Kunabibi mandjamun manbu bininj ngadberre.
ex.xe: In the Kunwinjku language, we say that we hunt mayh (animals). But when we say we’re going up to a mayh, in that case it means we’re going up to a ceremony, like Kunabibi or another sacred event of ours.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Leave camp to enter a ceremonial place.

ex.xv: Bu kinga birridulubom doweng wanjh birrikukbidbuyhweng kore kurlabbarlbeh.
ex.xe: When they had shot the crocodiles, they lifted the dead animals out of the billabong.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Muddika kabindibidbuyhwe kabirridjarrkre.
ex.xe: They give them a lift in the car, and they all go together.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Give someone a lift (in a car etc).

ex.xv: Ngarrbenbidbuyhwe kore mayh.
ex.xe: We send them to ceremony.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bininj nawu biddjuyimeng wanjh wurlhmeng manbu kabolkwolkan.
ex.xe: The man pressed the button and turned on the torch.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Biddurangkan kabobuhme.
ex.xe: Dolphins blow water [from their blow-holes].

sn.de: Generic term for two dolphin species; 1. Australian snubfin dolphin, 2. Australian humpback dolphin.
sn.sc: Orcaella heinsohni (Australian snubfin dolphin), Sousa chinensis (Australian humpback dolphin).

ex.xv: Bidjurdu kabidjibbidjibme karrinan.
ex.xe: We can see a whirlwind spinning around

sn.de: Turn, spin, rotate etc. Manipulate with the hands in a circular motion eg. stir, mix (with an implement), fasten a bolt, screw on a lid. etc.

ex.xv: Kanbidyikarrme ngarrwayhke nanih.
ex.xe: Help me lift this up.

ex.xv: Karribidyikarrmerrimen.
ex.xe: Let's help one another.

ex.xv: Kabindibidyikarrme daluhdaluk bu kabirriyawmang.
ex.xe: They are midwives.

ex.xv: Bik kabolkarung kabolkwarrehwarrewon.
ex.xe: Pigs dig up the ground and damage the country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kondah djenj karrurndeng, kamre konda konda kamre kondah karrurndeng, minj kabidbun kurih, only dunbuhmanj kabidbun en ngardderrhwo modjarrkki kabidbun kaddum bad konda djenj karrurndeng namarnkol barrhmanj, njarlkan, karlerrh, bikkurr karrurndeng konda kumekke djal bonj karrurndeng.
ex.xe: This is where the fish go back - they come up to here and then go back. They can't climb up [the bar of boulders at the waterfall], only sooty grunter can, short neck turtles, fresh water crocodiles can climb up to the higher area but here the fish go back: barramundi, saratoga, archer fish, long toms, black eel-tailed catfishes, there's nothing they can do, they just go back.

sn.sc: Neosilurus spp., egs. Neosilurus ater, Neosilurus argenteus, Neosilurus hyrtlii, but also Cinetodus froggatti, Anodontiglanis dahli.

ur: Kunwinjku = makurl, namardaka, Kundjeyhmi = binjdjarrang, ganbaldjdja

ex.xv: Kodjbila ngarrikodjdahkendi bu ngarrikeyo.
ex.xe: We put our heads on a pillow when we sleep.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Djabayéna Kawarréya mankuken mani manbolh. Bilem ngarribidbuni.
ex.xe: Here at Djabayéna Kawarréya it is an important place. We used to pull our bark canoes up [out of the river here].

sn.de: Bark canoe made from stitching together a folded piece of Eucalyptus tetrodonta bark.

ex.xv: Birribimbuni bim kurdukadji kore kunburrk bedberre.
ex.xe: They painted pictures of emus on their bodies.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: There is an image, word etc, to be (of images, words etc).

ex.xv: Kabirribimbun mayh mimih djenj dja nawern.
ex.xe: They paint animals, Mimih spirits, fish and lots of different things.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yibengkan Kodjok nawu bimbohbimbom?
ex.xe: Do you know that man of Kodjok skin who used to be an artist ('used to paint')?

sn.de: Draw, paint or otherwise use markings to create a picture.

ex.xv: Yingeybimburren!
ex.xe: Write your name!

ex.xv: Ngandihbimmangi munguyh, ngangudjwarreminj.
ex.xe: They were always taking pictures of me, I got tired of it.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Take photo with camera (still or moving film).

ex.xv: Nahni nabarlek karribimnan kabimdi kore kuwardderurrk.
ex.xe: We see paintings of rock wallabies in rock shelters.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Look at a picture, see an image.

ex.xv: Ngarrbenbukkani Kunwinjku ngarrbimbuni djurra. Ngarrimarnbuni, ngarrbihbimbuni wurdwurd birribimnani.
ex.xe: The two of us used to teach them Kunwinjku, we would write it. We used make books, we used to write them for the kids to read.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Minj djurra ngabimnayinj.
ex.xe: I'd never seen writing on paper before.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yibimngeybu.
ex.xe: Read the sentence out for me.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Minj birriwernhbimngeybuyinj. Birribimwakwani.
ex.xe: They couldn't read out the words properly. They didn't know the letters.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Read aloud, read out (a word, sentence etc).

ex.xv: Bininj yameng kunj.
ex.xe: The man speared a kangaroo.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, 'Bininj Yameng Kunj', Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

ex.xv: Ngalkudji ngalkohbanj kuni ngalkangila wanjh ngaleng kangeyyo kurdukadji kaluk ngaleng wanjh bininjni korroko wanjh yerre mayh yimerranj.
ex.xe: There was an old lady whose skin name was Ngalkangila and now we call her emu, a long time ago she was really an old lady. [Wildfire Band song text].

ex.xv: Nawu bininj dja balanda kabirrimang nawu mayh wanjh kabirrikelebukwon kakelebukmen kabirrimarnbun kelebuk mayh bedberre.
ex.xe: Both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people get animals and tame them, and make them into pets.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manbu birddurrk makka wurd manwarddeyahwurd dja manwarddebele.
ex.xe: Quartz stones are small and white.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Quartz, stone tool or point made from quartz.

ex.xv: Birdikelk.
ex.xe: Soft beeswax.

ex.xv: Birdirayek.
ex.xe: Hard beeswax.

ex.xv: Birriwurlhkeyi kunak wanjh nawu djebuyh birlikengemi manbu kunak kumkolungi birribuni birrikani birrikinjeyi birringuni.
ex.xe: They would light a fire, and the possum would be scared of the flames, so it would come down and they would hit it, then take it to cook and eat.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngandibukkani how bu ngandiburdebmi - kunak ngarribirlumarnbuni, en ngarrimarnbuni kunrurrk kore ngarriyoy.
ex.xe: They taught us how to rub sticks to make a flame and how to make shelters to camp in.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Flame, fire, torch. This term is always incorporated into verbs, e.g. birlikan, 'to carry a fire stick'.

ex.xv: Wolbu kambirlikadjung.
ex.xe: The bugs are attracted to the light.

ex.xv: Mandjewk nganbom ngadberre, ngurdulmeng la birlibirliwern ngarrinang.
ex.xe: The rain fell on us and there was thunder and we saw lots of lightning.

sn.de: Light of a fire, an electric light or of lightning.

se.de: Carry a fire stick, torch, light etc.

ex.xv: Karribirlikan.
ex.xe: Let's take torches.

ex.xv: Yukkuyukku kabirlihbirlikan.
ex.xe: The firefly carries light.

sn.de: Carry fire or light, take a torch.

ex.xv: Andy bimbom komrdaw, narin la birlmu.
ex.xe: Andy drew a long-necked turtle, a snake and a barramundi.
ex.so: 'Nakimuk Djurra: a Big Book', Marrkolidjban School, 1993

sn.de: Generic term for Silver Barramundi, adult.

ex.xv: Bu Kudjewk wanjh birringimi kuwarderurrk birriyoy dja mandjewk dja birndu.
ex.xe: In the wet season they moved into caves to stay, because of the rain and mosquitos.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Mosquito. There is a djang totemic site for the mosquito near Marrkolidjban.

ex.xv: Ngalbu birndu ngalkka mayhmayh karrinan kore kabbal bu kudjewk dja kurrung karrolkarren karrinan mirndewern.
ex.xe: We see glossy ibis on the floodplain in the wet season, and we see lots of them flying in the build-up season.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Glossy ibis (which is black and has a beak like a mosquito proboscis thus the polysemy).

ex.xv: Birradjdja ngarringuni… ngarrikurrmi, ngarribuni wanjh yoy. Manwerrk manu rey warreka.
ex.xe: We used to eat rice…  we used to put it there and thresh it. The husks would fly off all over the place but the rice would stay where it was.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Clear the ground of vegetation, make a clear space to sit down or camp, sweep.

ex.xv: Konda kadjakdung, la kuni korroko birrhmeng.
ex.xe: It's raining here but over there the clouds have already cleared.

sn.de: (Of weather, clouds) clearing of clouds after rain or a storm.

re: place name in Birrirddak Creek region \de Riverine savanna area to the east of where the Nabarlek road crosses Birraduk [Birrirddak] Creek and leading southeast to the valley entrance. A creek flows through the area, surrounded by sandstone outliers. It has significance as an Aboriginal walking route (Bininj manbolh) as well as being a camping and fishing area. The topographic map place name of ‘Birraduk Creek’ is derived from Birrirddak.

ex.xv: …en Kabo Kaworrkdjubmirri, kahre ngamed kore Djimerre ya. Kuredkuken arriyongoyoy. Ngalengman kanjdji kadjale. Koreh bukka manberrk manekke kaberrkyirriyo makka Birrirddak, konda kakarri, kawukkarri nanu Birrirddak.
ex.xe: …and Kabo Kaworrkdjubmirri which goes on to Djimerre, yeah. We camped in these important camping places. Downstream the sites continue. But in the open savanna area, where all the savanna forest is located, that’s Birrirddak, to the west (of the previously mentioned sites). Birrirddak is to the west (of Kabo Kaworrkdjubmirri and Djimerre).
ex.so: Kundedjnjenghmi

ex.xv: Birrkala kabirrimarnbun kore kundulk mandubang.
ex.xe: Ceremonial boomerangs are made from ironwood.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Sacred boomerangs used in pairs as musical instruments in various ceremonial contexts. Not used for hunting in West Arnhem Land.

ex.xv: Kakebbirrkarren.
ex.xe: He's sticking his finger up his nose.

ex.xv: Bu korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey birridjuhmi kore kuronj birribobirrkani birriyawani kedjebe.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would go into the water, then poke around in the water with their hands looking for file snakes.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Place finger or hand into something.

ex.xv: Kumekke kaddum benehdjalbarndi, benmenebirrkukuhmeng benmenedjalbirrkukuhmeng. Ngalkudji bikebbaddji mandjad la ngalbuyika ngalbu bibarlanhbom, wanjh djalwohmankang.
ex.xe: The two of them were up in the tree, and he threw sticks at them. He hit one woman hard, straight in the face. He almost hit the other one, but she fainted with fright and fell down.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 132

ex.xv: Ngalkohbanj bimarneyimeng ngalbu wurdyaw "Yimka ngardduk manbu kundjabarrk wardi kundulk ngamang birrkukuhme."
ex.xe: The old woman said to the child "Bring my bag here, or I'll get a stick and chuck it at you".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu Nakorrkko benebokenh benedjalbirrkukuhmeng manbu barlkkan bu benemarnbom manbolh kuri kore walem.
ex.xe: The two Nakorrkko ancestors threw boomerangs to make a path, down there in the south.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Throw something at someone, an animal etc. This word refers specifically to throwing blunt projectiles such as sticks, rocks or boomerangs.

ex.xv: Biwudj namak bu ngarringun bu ngarrire ngarriwarlbun manimunak djilikuybi ngarriyawan.
ex.xe: The green pygmy goose is good eating, when we go hunting magpie geese or whistle ducks we look for pygmy geese as well.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Some speakers also refer to the pink-eared duck as biwudj.

ex.xv: Kaboyo.
ex.xe: Water lies there / there is water.

ex.xv: Manbomak.
ex.xe: good drinking water.

ex.xv: Minj kabirrire kabirribongun kunbang.
ex.xe: They don't go and drink alcohol.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Water or other liquids. Incorporated form of the word water, which appears when it forms part of other words.

Kind of wild honey or 'sugar bag' which is found in tree hollows and has a crumbling cerumen or brown resinous wax which is not favoured for tool and artifact production. The honey of this bee is much relished. The base of the hive, called ngeyhno is made from a harder cerumen which can be used for material culture production although other honey type hives are preferred.

ex.xv: Bu kurrula kabobidbun wanjh minj karrinan ngalbu karndjawarra.
ex.xe: At high tide, we don't see any mud crabs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kabobidbun wanjh kankebngun.
ex.xe: The water rises up and drowns us.

sn.de: Water rise up (e.g. flood, start of wet season).

ex.xv: Ma bonj bobo.
ex.xe: OK, that’s all, bye.

ex.xv: Yikah mak kabbal ngarrirey bu ngarribuni kalawan, ngarrimarmeyimi, "Bobo!". Kalawan, kunekke ngurriyimen "Bobo" wanjh kakurrmerren kalawan. Ngurrire ngurribun.
ex.xe: Or, sometimes, we would be go out on the floodplains getting goanna, and we would say to the goannas “Goodbye!”. If you say goodbye, the goanna will just stay still for you, then you can go and kill it.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Mandudjmi karung wanjh bod kawernmen.
ex.xe: When the green plums are ripe, it is the time when there are many flies.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey manberrk birriyawani birridulknani kaddum birrinani mankung bod kahboddolkan wanjh birridulkrderdmi birriwodjburriweyi birrimonbuhmi, wanjh birrimangi nawu yiwk dja mandabu birrirawoni birridahkendongi kore billycan.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would go into the forest searching [for honey], looking up at the trees. When they saw honey bees flying around they would chop down the tree and open it up, then they would get the liquid honey and pollen sacs and put them all together in a billy can.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Native honey bees of the Tetragonula (previously Trigona) and Austroplebeia genera.
sn.sc: Tetragonula mellipes, Austroplebeia magna, Austroplebeia essingtoni

ex.xv: Munguyh benehdjalkarungi kaluk wanjh kukku kumbobebmeng benebiddjuhmeng kunbid berrewoneng kore benekaruy wanjh beneboddanj benebonguyinj.
ex.xe: They just kept on digging, and when they reached water they washed their hands from all the digging, then they crouched down and drank the water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Crouch down, hunch over, bend down.

ex.xv: Karrinan bu kabukmen kabodowen kore kabbal bu Kurrung duninjh kayimerran.
ex.xe: When the real build-up season starts, we see the floodplain drying up and the water receding.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kabodowerren rowk manbu kukku kukudji kukku karribongun kore manlabbarlkimuk dja kore njilhmi kaboyo kore ngarribobengkan korroko dabborrabbolk ngandibolkbukkang.
ex.xe: All the water dries up [in the dry season], we can only drink water from large billabongs and springs, places we know to find water that the old people showed us in the past.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Recede (of water in a water body), dry out.

ex.xv: Manbu mandjabu korroko dabborrabbolk birrimangi kunyarl kore manbornde mandedjmad kunyarl dja kore kundulk manbudbud kunyarl. Wanjh birribokdengi kunyarl birrimarnbuni wanjh mandjabu birrimarnbuni.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors would make fish traps by getting fibre from banyan roots or kurrajong bark. They would roll the fibre into string, then make fish traps from it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Spin or plait string. This often involves rubbing fibres from the inner bark of trees on the upper thigh, then rolling two strands of string together to make two-ply twine.

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh wakkidj benehweyi.
ex.xe: Two women were fishing.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Ngunebokenh.
ex.xe: You two.

ex.xv: Yika mak bu nganabarru karribokkan wanjh karribokkadjung karribekkan ngarradj kawokdi kabimulewan namekke nganabarru.
ex.xe: Sometimes when we're tracking a buffalo, we follow its tracks and we hear a cockatoo calling out, which gives away the buffalo's position.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bokko birrimarnbuni manbu kunyidkenh bu birridurreni.
ex.xe: People used to make barbed spears for fighting.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Spear type with many barbs running along the shaft.
Spangled grunter. These fish form schools and migrate to breed in the early wet season or after the first storms of kunumeleng.

ex.xv: Kurlabakku kawk bokung nawu kabirrirohrok kabirriyawan djenj kabirrini kore kukadjid yika kabirribarndi kore kundulk kabirrimadbun djenj.
ex.xe: The pied heron, the rufous night heron and the black bittern are all similar, in that they all hunt fish by standing on the bank or up in a tree, waiting for the fish to go past.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu njale karringun karribawon kore kunrurrk wanjh karrinan nawern djak bu kanome dja kabolkan.
ex.xe: If we're eating something and we leave it in the house, then ants will smell it and lots of them will come after it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Follow after something, come after something.

ex.xv: Ngabolkbawong kunred ngardduk / Dja ngabenbawong bininj ngardduk / Ahwurd ngaye, ahwurd / Ngabolkbawong kunred Ngardayun
ex.xe: I have been away from my homeland for so long / And away from my people for so long / I am feeling sad, so sad / I miss my home Ngardayun
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Leave a place, with the connotation of staying away for a long time or for good. Abandon a place.

ex.xv: Nabangardi dja Nawamud beneyimeng konda kunred wanjh bolkdoweng ngad ngadberre, bu balanda birrimwam birribolkbom dja birribolkwarrewong.
ex.xe: Nabangardi and Nawamud said “This place of ours has been destroyed, when white people came they dug the place up and ruined it”.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Conduct earthworks, dig tunnels or mine, create environmental damage, destroy a place, create the landscape of a place.

ex.xv: Wurdwurd kabirribolkbun.
ex.xe: The children are making a lot of noise.

sn.de: Make a racket, make a noisy disturbance.

ex.xv: Bolkdoweng konda.
ex.xe: This place is boring.

sn.de: Place become boring with nothing of interest happening.

ex.xv: Nabangardi dja Nawamud beneyimeng konda kunred wanjh bolkdoweng ngad ngadberre, bu balanda birrimwam birribolkbom dja birribolkwarrewong.
ex.xe: Nabangardi and Nawamud said “This place of ours has been destroyed, when white people came they dug the place up and ruined it”.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu kabirribolkbun kunred karrowen, kunred bu karribolkdowen namekke story nuye ngadberre ngad, nawu kumekke tribe namekke tribe nawu Mirarr namekke.
ex.xe: If they damage the place, the country there will die, the country and us with it and the story will die, that is the tribe called the Mirarr people.

ex.xv: Yoh bolkkime kamkan.
ex.xe: Yes, he's bringing it now.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 34’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

ex.xv: Dja bolkkime larrk minj nangale kadjuhme kinga nawern kahyo kore manlabbarlkimuk kahboyo wardi kanbaye kanbun.
ex.xe: But nowadays no-one gets into the water at the big billabong, there are lots of crocodiles and they would bite and kill us.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: A: Baleh kabirrini? B: Ngabenkayhmeng korroko, bonj birribolkmaddi.
ex.xe: A: Where are they? B: I've already called them but they're staying where they are.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji wurdyaw Ngaldjawonj / bolkbawong kunred ngalengarre / Bolkmaddi kore Manginburru bedberre
ex.xe: There is a little girl from a Jawoyn clan / who left her country / And who has stayed for a long time on Manginburru land
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Ngaldjawonj ‘The Jawoyn Girl’’, from the Album ‘Maningburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Stay at home, stay at a place, refuse to come when called.

ex.xv: Bu ngabolkmang kured ngambun ke.
ex.xe: When I get home, I'll call you.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu benebolkmey kumekke kunred Nitmiluk beneyibmeng kanjdji kurorre dja benebawong manbu manlabbarl kahlabbarlyo kore kanjdji kabenehyo kumekke wanjh ngalbu Ngalyod bokenh kabenehyo munguyh kore manlabbarl.
ex.xe: When they reached Nitmiluk, they sank down into the earth and left behind a waterhole there. They're still there underneath the water, those two Rainbow Serpents are still there in the waterhole.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Reach a place, get to a place.
Be on the watch for, look out for.

ex.xv: Kaluk wurdurd ngadberre / kabirribolknahnan kondah kunred ngadberre.
ex.xe: When we pass away our children / will carry on looking after this land for us.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Manginburru’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Care for country, look after a place, caretake a place.

ex.xv: Minj kawernhbolknan djarre.
ex.xe: He’s short-sighted (he can't see very far).
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Ngaye ngawam ngabidbom kuwardde / Ngabolknang bu dungyibmeng / Wanjh ngabolkkongibom kunred ngadberre.
ex.xe: I went to the top of the rock and looked around / When I saw the sun go down I felt sad / Because this is where the people lived a long time ago.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Manginburru’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009 (Loose English translation from album cover).

ex.xv: Kondanjh kandimarnekorrkke warde ngurrikorrkke ngurrinan ba ngabolknan ba kamak ngare wanjh ngare ngayame.
ex.xe: Look here and try and lance my sore so I can get up and go look at that place and spear it (a kangaroo).

sn.de: Look at a place, survey surroundings.

ex.xv: Kunred kabolkngeyyo Bobongki, manbowern dja mandjimdjimwern.
ex.xe: The place called Bobongki has a lot of water and water pandanus.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Ngaye ngabolkngeyyo kunred Maburrinj / Ngadolkkang ngadanginj dja ngabolknang
I am the country Maburrinj / I stood up and looked around at my many places
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ’Maburrinj (The lonely place called Maburrinj)’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Be called (of a place), name of a place is.

ex.xv: Bonbon kabirringun djenj nawu kilekilelh.
ex.xe: Cormorants eat small fish.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu bongka ngarringeybun nawu yiman djanay kakukyime nungan kuwarde kaddum kukorlh kayo.
ex.xe: Rock monitors look similar to yellow-spotted monitors, but they live up in rocky country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Long-tailed rock monitor, also known as the black-palmed monitor.

ex.xv: Ngarre kab kukku ngarrbongun.
ex.xe: Let's go and drink some water.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Birrimey kunbang bedberre wanjh birridjalbonguneng.
ex.xe: They got their grog and just kept drinking.

ex.xv: Bonj yakminj.
ex.xe: Finished, all gone!

ex.xv: Wanjh birridokmeng kured. Bonj.
ex.xe: Then they went home. The End.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: The end (used at the end of a story or narrative).

ex.xv: A: Yidjare marnekan? B: Bonj, kamak, ngakan.
ex.xe: A: Do you want me to take it for you? B: No, it's OK, I'll take it.

ex.xv: Kabenengeyboken, bonj kangeyboken.
ex.xe: They've got two names, just two names.

ex.xv: "Yuwn yikan mankukyahwurd makka" "Bonj warribo ngadjalkan ngakinje ngangun. Bonj bu mankukyahwurd"
ex.xe: "Don't take that yam, it's too small". "Whatever, I'll take it anyway and cook it up and eat it. Doesn't matter if it's small".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: That's all, just, just like that, it's OK just like that. Marker used to delineate or limit.

ex.xv: Wanjh duhkeng, duhkeng. Bonj bohborrolkang.
ex.xe: He lanced it and lanced it (an infected wound) and then the fluid burst out.

sn.de: Finally, in the end. Marker used to indicate the end of a process.

ex.xv: Djalmey kundulk yiman bonj kunekke kayime.
ex.xe: He just went and got a stick which was about 'there' (demonstrates size), this big !

sn.de: Marker used to describe the size, shape, extent etc. of something.

ex.xv: Ngabidbonjdjek.
ex.xe: My fingers are cold.

ex.xv: Nanih nawu wurdwurd might be kabirridjordmen minj kabirrire kabirribongun kunbang, or petrol kabirribonome or kundalk kabirriwunghme, larrk.
ex.xe: So when those kids grow up they probably won't drink, or sniff petrol or smoke grass, no way.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bu kudjewk mandjewk nawern kadjakdung wanjh kabore kore mankabo.
ex.xe: When it rains a lot in the wet season, the water flows in the rivers.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kandibukkan ba ngaborlbme.
ex.xe: You show me so I will learn it.

sn.de: Learn, become familiar with something eg. language, a skill.

ex.xv: Ngarriborlbmeng di.
ex.xe: We've got used to drinking tea.

ex.xv: Ngudda yiborlbmeng ngarduk.
ex.xe: You've got used to me.

sn.de: Get used to something or someone.

ng: Takes possessive pronoun if the object is human.

ex.xv: Borlborl karrulkngun, kurrambalk kawarrewon.
ex.xe: Termites eat wood and destroy houses.

ex.xv: Ngaborledkeng nawu djenj, wanjh ngayawoyhyerrkang ngamadbom korroko wanjh nganang ruy, wanjh ngawayhkeng.
ex.xe: I turned over the fish and sat down again, waited a while, then when I saw that it was cooked I pulled it out (of the hot coals).
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

ex.xv: Birrikodjkurluborledkeng.
ex.xe: They changed their minds.

sn.de: Turn over to other side, change.

ex.xv: Yimborledmen kanmirrkma!
ex.xe: Turn facing me!
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Bolkkime wurdwurd nahni yiman birribuyikaminj, borledmeng kadberre.
ex.xe: Nowadays the kids are different, they’ve changed on us.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Warde borledmiken yiyawan.
ex.xe: Try searching on the other side.

ex.xv: Borliblib karrinan Kudjewk Kurrung Bangkerreng Wurrkeng Kurnumeleng bu baleh karrire karribekkan kawokdi kangeyburren kayime borliblib borliblib borliblib.
ex.xe: We see the Magpie Lark in the wet season, dry season, late wet season, late dry season and build-up season - wherever we go we hear its call, calling out its name “borliblib borliblib borliblib”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Australian Magpie-lark. The word also describes the call of the Magpie-lark, which is said to ‘call its own name’.

ex.xv: Bininj dja daluhdaluk kabirrire kabirriyawan kore kukku kabirribobirrkan kabirrimang borlokko kedjebe ngalmangiyi kore kuronj.
ex.xe: Men and women go looking for water pythons in the water, they poke their hands into the water and pull out the pythons, file snakes and long-necked turtles.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Water python and possibly also the freshwater keelback.
sn.sc: Bothrochilus fuscus (previously known as Liasis fuscus), Amphiesma mairii

ex.xv: Bu kabirrikodbarrename, wanjh mandulkdjarrkkarlang kabirridadjke, kabirridulkdjabname. Wanjh yerre borlorl kabirriwarnamkurrme. Wanjh kunkod dja dolobbo kabirribarrkbun.
ex.xe: When people make a paperbark shelter, they cut forked trees and stick them upright into the ground. Then they place crossbeams across them, and then put bark over the structure.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Post or beam used in house or shade shelter construction. In shelter construction this is typically the horizontal crossbeam, in contrast to the forked sticks it rests between (karlang).

ex.xv: Nangale ngunbornang?
ex.xe: Who is your father?

ex.xv: Beywurd bornarrinj.
ex.xe: He fathered a child (for himself).

ex.xv: Bolkmelmeng mankole mey kolhmibom borndok kamak rowk.
ex.xe: He placed his foot down, got his spear and tested it with his spear thrower; everything was fine.

ex.xv: Balmey kunworr kurlba borndungi.
ex.xe: Then he got some leaves and was wiping off the blood with them.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 34’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

ex.xv: Kano manburrba ngaborndurren.
ex.xe: Give me the cloth, I'll wipe myself.

ex.xv: Nawu daluhdaluk manbu kunyarl kabirrimang kore kundulkbeh manbu manbudbud marrabbi manbornde dja mankarralarlhmanj wanjh kabirriborolhme bu kabirrimarnbun djerrh dja walabi.
ex.xe: Women get fibre from trees, kurrajong, sand palm, banyan and bush peanut trees, then they rub the fibres on their thigh and roll them together into string to make bags and fish nets.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Spin or plait string (hair or string/rope). This involves rolling two strands of inner bark fibres in one direction over the thighs then rolling back in the opposite direction to twist the two strands together into two-ply string.

ex.xv: Wurdurd yuwn ngurriborrkbun wardi ngunbaye.
ex.xe: Kids, don't play with it, it might bite you.

ex.xv: Korroko birriwayini birriborrkkeyi kore mamurrng dja kore mulil.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would sing and dance at Mamurrng ceremonies and public feasts.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Yawkyawk dja yawurrinj kabirrire kabirriborrkke kore disco.
ex.xe: Girls and boys go dancing at the disco.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Duruk yaw kabirriborrkkirri.
ex.xe: The puppies are jumping around playfully.

ex.xv: Nawu nakudji wurdyaw borrkkirri kore kudjurle.
ex.xe: The child was playing in the shade.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mak mayh mayh kabirriborrkkirri bu kunkawoleh kayimerran. Kabirringudjkadjurren, kabirriwohbayerren.
ex.xe: Animals also play around, in the late afternoon when the day cools off. They chase each other around and bite each other playfully.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu baleh kabirriyime, yibendjalwokborrkwa. Yuwn yibalborledme yibenmarneyime wanjh kunekke ngurridurren, o ngurridangwerren.
ex.xe: If they say anything, just ignore them. Don’t turn around and speak to them or you'll end up fighting or arguing.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Nakudji wurdyaw yimeng "Ngaye borrkwan bu kandjurrkkan yimankek ngaye ngamang njalehnjale ke".
ex.xe: The child said "If you ask me to go and get something for you, I won't do it".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalbu daluk bimarneyimeng ngalbuyika daluk "Ngudda kanborrkwam ngaye, minj ngarrrawinj bu djawam".
ex.xe: One woman said to another "You ignored me, we didn't go when I asked you".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Ignore, disregard, not do what someone asks.

ex.xv: Kawardeboyboyyo.
ex.xe: There is a rock lying flat.
ex.so: Evans, Nick, Mayali vocabulary gathered 1986-1988 from native speakers for Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Gagudju Association

sn.de: Lie flat, to lie on one’s stomach.

ex.xv: Nabulanj wam mankung kore nang boyen.
ex.xe: I guess people assigned a skin name to buffalo in recent times, it's from a different place.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Recently, before, in the recent past, some time ago but with the sense of a more specific point in time and not a time in the very distant past.

se.de: In recent times, over the last few months/years with the sense of a recent length of time extended over a continuous period.

ex.xv: Boywek karrinan kore kunrurrk kurrambalk karrihyo karrinan kahbarnbarndi.
ex.xe: We see geckos in the houses where we live, sitting up on things.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Northern knob-tailed gecko, prickly knob-tailed gecko.

ex.xv: Bu ngayahwurdni.
ex.xe: When I was a child.
