ex.xv: Ngayolyolme bu namarrkon djang.
ex.xe: I'll tell a story about lightning dreaming.

ex.xv: Bu ngudda.
ex.xe: That's up to you.

ex.xv: Bu yinan kelebuk yuwn yibun.
ex.xe: If you see a tame animal, don't kill it.

ex.xv: Budjdjulung kaburriwe, kabarrhme.
ex.xe: He throws a bottle and it smashes.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bolkkime nawu budjiked karrikarrme nawern karri kore kurehrered kadberre kore karrihyo.
ex.xe: Nowadays we have lots of cats on our lands where we live.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kunkurra kabuhme, darnki mandjewk kadjakdung.
ex.xe: The wind is blowing, soon it's going to rain.

ex.xv: Nangale kabuhme mako?
ex.xe: Who's going to play the didjeridoo?

ex.xv: Med ngaladminj, ngarrbuhme.
ex.xe: Hang on, I'm hot, let's take the breeze.

ex.xv: Bukminj rowk kamak karridjowkke.
ex.xe: It's all dry, we can cross OK.

ex.xv: Birndu kangun dumdum dja yehyeng nawu kayo kare kore kukku kukadjid dja kore kubuk.
ex.xe: The glossy ibis eats beetles and all kinds of things that live in the water, the sand and the shallows.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Bukbuk karribekkan kawokdi kayime bukbuk bukbuk bukbuk.
ex.xe: We hear the pheasant coucal calling out “book-book, book-book, book-book”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngarrnan, marrek ngarrnan, yika yiyo yibukirribun Wakkewakken o ankung.
ex.xe: We see it, not really see it, sometimes when you sleep you will dream and see the Wakkewakken or the honey.

ex.xv: Yimankek mununminj, bonj, wanjh ngarriwam. Bukka Arrkuluk.
ex.xe: When it was dark enough , that was it, off we went. Over there by Arrkuluk.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: That probably, over there probably, might be, thing.

ex.xv: Wardi kanbukkan bale kayime.
ex.xe: Try and show me, what do you do?

ex.xv: Kabukkarren nawu kundjak karrihkarrme kuburrk kadberre.
ex.xe: Symptoms which are manifest when we have physical illness.

ex.xv: Bu kurrung manbu kabbal kabukmen.
ex.xe: In the dry season, the floodplain dries up.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kabirridakurrme manbu kunngobarn kabukmen wanjh kabirrimarnbun nawu badjkid.
ex.xe: They put the pandanus out in the sun, it dries out and they make baskets from it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Dry up (of bodies of water), dry out (of plants etc), evaporate.

ex.xv: Yibekkang kukak bolkrokahrokang? Ngarringeybun bula.
ex.xe: Did you feel the earth shaking last night? We call that bula.

sn.de: Earthquake; also the name of a Jawoyn ancestral being and concomitant religious cult in which earthquake and subterranean fire feature as part of apocalyptic beliefs.

ex.xv: Baw, ngurringurdmen! Bulanj kabiwokmang Balang!
ex.xe: ‘Would you people be quiet! Bulanj is recording Balang!’
ex.so: Quoted in Garde, Murray, ‘Culture, Interaction and Person Reference in an Australian Language’, John Benjamins Publishing Company,  Amsterdam, 2013, p. xiv

ex.xv: Kaluk Bulanj bimarnedjareni ngaleng bu yiman birrimarrimeninj namekke. Bulanj nawu walk bikang yibengkan laik ngarrbinmarneyime 'Nani yikan kureh ba bininj yibinmang yibinreydurndeng ba karriyakwon.'
ex.xe: Another man of Bulanj subsection coveted her, (the boy's mother, a woman of Kodjdjan subsection), and wanted to marry her. Bulanj was going to accompany the boy to be circumcised according to the custom, like when we ask 'You take the circumcision candidate (to another group of people in a distant location) so that you will retrun with lots of people to complete the ceremony.'

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Bu anyungki, makka djal Bininj duninj bawokyimi like old people
ex.xe: In the beginning, she (emu) was a human being and she talked, she was an old woman, old people, … of the ngal-Kangila subsection and the Wurrbbarn clan.
ex.so: Djnj

ex.xv: Ngali bininjni ngalu ngurrurdu borledkerrinj nahni birridolkang kungol, ngalih wanjh ngale birribawong kukurlk kawake. Bulanjdjan ngal-Wurrbbarn. Yo. Ngalnguyakimuk Bakkarda (Kardbam), Wurrbbarnbulu, Burnungku, Warrayhngu, Kamal.
ex.xe: This emu was once a human being and... all the people here associated with her changed into animals (points to a painting illustrating

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Yimarneyimen kabularrbun.
ex.xe: Tell him to delete it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngayeh ngayakwon story ngawernhbularrbun, ngare, ngare wanjh kuwadda, ngahdurndeng.
ex.xe: I'm going to finish telling all this information completely and then I'm off, I'm going back home.

ex.xv: Bolkbawong wam manberrk yawani manme mangi dahkendongi ngalengarre manme kore bulbbe.
ex.xe: She left that place and went into the bush looking for food, which she collected in her dilly bag.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Dilly bag tightly woven from light fibres.

ex.xv: Kubuldjdjarn yikurrmen.
ex.xe: Put it in the middle.

ex.xv: Kabuldjarn.
ex.xe: It's deep.

se.de: Ethnonymic reference: ‘the people from the middle/central regions’. This is one of several terms of this nature that indicate the place of origin of a person ideally through their matriline.

ex.xv: Nahni bininj kukbele kangeyyo Paddy Cahill nawu kumwam kondah Kunbarlanja kondah durrkmirri manme dudjengi dja djarrang dja bulikki benhbukkani bininj ngad nawu birrikukburlerri.
ex.xe: That white man named Paddy Cahill came to Gunbalanya, he was working here planting vegetables and he also showed the people horses and cattle, us Aboriginal people.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Beneyimerranj mahni manlabbarl manbardmo karri. Mandulkkimuk kahdi kore bulkayh.
ex.xe: Those two [Yawkyawk spirits] became that billabong, with waterlilies on it. There is a big tree in the middle of it.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 172

ex.xv: Bu bulkkidj duninjh ngurridjare wanjh ngurrimray karridjarrkbidyikarrmerren.
ex.xe: If you really want it, come and let’s all help each other [to make it happen].
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bumabuma minj karrinan kore kubolkwarlah kuberrk. Nungan kadjalyo kore kuwarderurrk kaddum kuwarde.
ex.xe: We don't see ghost bats out in the open. They just stay in caves up in the rocks.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Daluk bikang biyiwam Bumabuma marnburrinj warlang wanjh.
ex.xe: He took the women, went with her and then turned himself into a bat.

sn.de: Mythical hero ancestor who turned into a bat.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji bikebbadjdji mandjad la ngalbuyika ngalbu bibarlanbom, wanjh djalwohmankang.
ex.xe: He hit one woman hard, straight in the face. He almost hit the other one, but she fainted with fright and fell down.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 132

ex.xv: Kunberl nganmarnebom.
ex.xe: He broke my arm.

ex.xv: Ngalyod kumwam kanjdjibeh kurorre benbom birriwern bininj nawu birrihyoy kumekke.
ex.xe: The Rainbow Serpent came up from under the earth and killed all the people who were there.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manbang manekke ngandjenbom.
ex.xe: That food's strong, it burnt my tongue.

ex.xv: Manih kundulk yekke kanguybun.
ex.xe: This tree produces flowers in the dry season.

ex.xv: Mandjewk nganbom ngadberre.
ex.xe: The storm fell on us.

sn.de: Suffer effects of a storm, be rained on.

ex.xv: Kaluk kukak kabirribun delebon birriyimeng.
ex.xe: They said they would ring up by phone tonight.

ex.xv: Manbu mankare bungkul, manwern kakarrengeyyo. Yiman nangale karrowen wanjh kabindimarnekayhme nawu bungkul kabirriwayini, bu kabirrire kabirridahdahme.
ex.xe: There are many old songs with different names. For example when someone passes away they go and sing, calling out things relating to their clan while clapping clapsticks.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Genre of dance and music associated with people living to the south-east and east of the Arnhem Land plateau including Rembarrnga, Burarra and all Yolngu groups. Used in opposition to the musical genre called kunborrk in Bininj Kunwok.

bw: From Eastern languages, e.g. Burarra = bunggul, Yolŋu Matha = buŋgul

sn.de: Term used to refer to a blind person or someone who can't see well, a substitute for using the person’s name.

ex.xv: Kabenebunjhmarren.
ex.xe: They are kissing each other.

ex.xv: Burarr namak mayh bu ngarringun yiman kalawan karohrok.
ex.xe: Water goannas are good to eat, just like other goannas.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu kukku kayo nakka kunngey bokenh bu ngarringeybun burarr dja durrbu dja nayahwurd nakka djerlih.
ex.xe: We have two names for those (goannas) that live in the water, 'burarr' and 'durrbu', and the smaller type we call 'djerlih' (Mitchell's water monitor).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Social category based on ceremonial grouping of the following subsections; ngarridj/ngarridjdjan, bangardi/bangardidjan; kamarrang/kamanj, balang/belinj.

ex.xv: Korroko kundjakkorl birriburdebmi birrinami wurlhmi manbu kunak.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would rub fire sticks together to start a fire.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Rub quickly back and forwards between the hands such as in the use of fire sticks.

ex.xv: Kanudbore buriburi.
ex.xe: There is a greenish pus discharge [from an infected wound].

sn.de: Mould or other rotting substances with a greenish hue.

ex.xv: Kukbulerri.
ex.xe: Black (skinned) person.

sn.de: Grub, moth larvae, adult moth; tiny ant sp.

ng: The semantic connection between the two senses of this word is that  the various insects described as ‘burlng’ are believed to bite humans and cause infections such as boils.

ex.xv: Burlukkurri kayo kore kukku kubak dja kukih.
ex.xe: Eels live in the water, amongst the water weeds and in the mud.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kabirriburlume nawu namekbe yawurrinj.
ex.xe: They praise that boy.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Mimburlurlhmeng.
ex.xe: Swollen eye.

ex.xv: Kaburlurlhme yiman kayime balloon.
ex.xe: It swells up like a balloon.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mayh ngarriyakwong, bonj burnbom.
ex.xe: We completed the ceremony and now it's finished.

ex.xv: Bonj wanjh, ngurriburnbu wurdwurd. Ngurrikeyo, karrikeyo.
ex.xe: OK that's it, cut it out kids. Go to sleep, let's all go to sleep.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Daluhdaluk nawu dabborrabbolk kabirriburrbun manbu manrakel mankinjdjek dja karrbarda.
ex.xe: Older women know [how to distinguish] the foliage of long yams and cheeky yams.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Med, ngaburrbun.
ex.xe: Wait, I'm thinking.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yawkyawk bokenh beneburrinj.
ex.xe: Two young girls had a fight.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Yimburriwemen!
ex.xe: Chuck it over here to me!

ex.xv: Bikukburriweng.
ex.xe: She pushed him down.

sn.de: Throw, chuck, throw away, push down.

ex.xv: Kaboburrk.
ex.xe: The water is deep.

ex.xv: Ngad bininj ngarringun manbu badjdjo... ngarrire ngarrirakelnan ngarrirakelburrknan wanjh ngarrikarung.
ex.xe: We Aboriginal people eat bush radishes... we go and we see the leaves, we recognise the leaves and we dig them up.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngawernhburrkburrknang manekke English manbu kunwok.
ex.xe: I really understood English.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Recognise, understand (literally, 'see the shape' or 'see the main substance' of something).

ex.xv: Burrkyak, minj korroko ngunnayi, djalbolkkime bu kerrngekkenh duninj ngunkuknan.
ex.xe: No, she's never seen you before, she’s going to see you in person for the first time now.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj dja Nakodjok Benewam Djenj’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Birriyawam birrikayhmeng burrkyak.
ex.xe: They looked for him and called out, but to no avail.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine, ‘Nakudji Wurdyaw Bengwabom’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

sn.de: It was no use, nothing happened, to no avail.

ex.xv: Djal burudjang bibom.
ex.xe: He just hit him for no reason.

sn.de: Without purpose or cause, lacking a motivation, with no specific intent.

ex.xv: Birribadbom nabuyika benuk.
ex.xe: Then they speared another bush turkey.
ex.so: Garlngarr, Victor, ‘Mamik dja Nakodjok benekang’, in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: Kernalk bokenh ngalbu ngalmudbele dja ngalbuyika ngalmudburlerri.
ex.xe: There are two types of ibis, the one with black feathers and another one with white feathers.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu karrkkanj nakka mayhmayh yiman marram dja nungan kukbuyika.
ex.xe: The brown falcon is a bird like the whistling kite, but it looks a bit different.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nakka banikkin melkbuyu.
ex.xe: The inside of that tin is rusty (not shiny).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Battery karrowen wanjh muddika kamimbuyumen minj kawernhbolkwolkan.
ex.xe: When the battery dies, the car's lights become dim and don't light up the surroundings anymore.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karrayo.
ex.xe: It's lying in the sun.

sn.de: Feather, feather like crest and tail on the rainbow serpent.

ex.xv: Kunngey kakarrme danjbik bu ngarringeybun. Komorlo kabakaba dja dabberrk dja ngaldjalkudji ngalbu mayhmayh.
ex.xe: It has three names that we call it by. Komorlo, kabakaba and dabberrk, but they all refer to the same bird.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: White egret, a name derived from the bird’s plume.

ex.xv: Bu kabirriwurlhke djarre wanjh kundolng manekke kamarnburren dabberrk.
ex.xe: If people make a fire a long way away, the smoke forms a plume in the sky.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Plume of smoke, can be used as a signal e.g. that someone is on their way.

ex.xv: Manbu karrbarda mandule dja kunborrk bu korroko nakudji nakohbanj dabbolk Nakangila Nabarrbinj marnbom.
ex.xe: An old Nakangila skin man of the Barrbinj clan made the Long Yam song cycle, a long time ago.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kabenedabbolk.
ex.xe: They're friends.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birringuni nawu dolek.
ex.xe: In the old days, people [our ancestors] used to eat wood grubs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Ancestors, the 'Old People'. The human ancestors of present-day people, as opposed to mythological Ancestors.

ex.xv: ‘Oh barrk bolkki ngarduk kunj ngarrabke’ ngarriyime.
ex.xe: 'Oh I'm going to close in that black wallaroo there, a kangaroo for me' we say.

ex.xv: Benedjalwam bu kunred djarre benerrabkeng kumekke.
ex.xe: They kept going to places far away in order to close in on him there.

ex.xv: Ngalbu makkakkurr ngalka ngalkimuk mayhmayh ngalbu ngalengman kadjalngun djenj... Dabborrabbolk birrirey birridabkeyi kore kurrubbe yiman kayime Mandjaworlbidji wanjh birribuni kundulk birrimangi birrikerribuni wanjh birringuni.
ex.xe: The pelican is a big bird that eats fish. In the old days, people would herd them into a closed-off area like Mandjaworlbidji (the 'Big Waterfall' at Gunbalanya) and kill them, gather wood and cook them in a ground oven.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nabulanj bimarneyimeng Nakangila "yimray kandabke kore manbolh". Wanjh Nakangila yimeng "Ngamre, dabke kore manbolh nan".
ex.xe: Nabulanj said to Nakangila "Come and meet me halfway, on the road". And Nakangila said "I'll head over then and meet you there".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Barrk kare kukku kabongun kore kahboyo, wanjh bininj kare kabidabke kore kukku kaboyo wanjh kabiyame.
ex.xe: The black wallaby goes to the waterhole to drink, and the man goes and comes across it there and spears it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dabuno karrabukabun.
ex.xe: They sit on the eggs.
ex.so: Mick Kubarkku, quoted in Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 48

ex.xv: Bolkkime karrbennan kalawan dja dadbe kabeneburren wanjh kalawan kakarrme.
ex.xe: Now when we see a goanna and a brown snake fighting, the goanna will always win.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bininj nawu nakurdang wanjh kabinan nawu Daddubbe bu kabebme kukak kayimerran.
ex.xe: ‘Clever men’ can see Daddubbe spirits when they come out at night.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu Daddubbe nakka nungan kahyo kore kuwardderurrk yiman kayime mimih bu kabirriyo kore kuwardderurrk.
ex.xe: The Daddubbe spirit lives in caves, just like Mimih spirits which also live in caves.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mimih nangarradjku, Daddubbe namardku.
ex.xe: The mimih spirits are of nangarradjku moiety but Daddubbe is namardku moiety.

sn.de: Daddubbe spirit, often depicted in paintings with an amputated leg. Said to live in escarpment country and be similar to Mimih spirits, though they are short and stocky, as opposed to Mimih which are tall and very skinny.

ex.xv: Kabindibukkan bu mako kabirridadjke kabirrimarnbun.
ex.xe: They show them how to cut (trees for) didjeridus and how to make them.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Diledadjkerren.
ex.xe: Abruptly interrupt urination.

re: stop, cessation of a process or phenomena

ex.xv: Mandjewk karradjme wanjh karrimang.
ex.xe: When it stops raining we can get it.

ex.xv: Kandadju kundad dja ngamarrwedoweng.
ex.xe: Give me a (turtle) leg, I'm starving.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Baladjdji nang kahdarlkan manbu manme dahkedahkendi mankinjdjek, wanjh yimeng, "Ngurrimray, ngurrinan... Minj mak njale karrahkendi. Manme manu yakminj".
ex.xe: He saw the dillybag, which had been filled with cheeky yams, floating  in the water, and said "Come and have a look... There's nothing in there, the food is gone".
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 190

ex.xv: "Nahni marebu ngunedahkendi." "Kek", beneyimeng, wanjh benemey benehdahkendi.
ex.xe: "That mat is for you two to sit on." "Really?" they said, and they took it and sat on it.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Ngalngarridj Marebu Marnbom’, Oenpelli School and Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Gunbalanya, 1975

sn.de: Be inside or within the boundary of something, e.g. a container. Sit, sleep or lie on or in something e.g. a mat, blanket, canoe or car.

ex.xv: Yiborrahkendo!
ex.xe: Fill up the water (container).

ex.xv: Yimarnek kamrayinj la Ngarridj birrahmeng.
ex.xe: She was going to come but Ngarridj wouldn't let her.

sn.de: Block an action, refuse permission, stop someone from doing something.

ex.xv: Kabirridakurrme kore kurrungbang kadayo kabukmen.
ex.xe: They put it out in the hot sun, it lies there in the sun and it dries out.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngahli daluk Ngalyangdoh dja dalkken ngalengarre benewam benehwarlbuni kukak.
ex.xe: That woman Ngalyangdoh and her dingo went off hunting at night.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh benewam ngalmangiyi kore kabbal.
ex.xe: Two women went looking for long-necked turtles on the floodplain.
ex.so: Nabobbob, Rose, ‘Kunbidkudji Kunwok’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Daluk kakarrme.
ex.xe: He's married (he has a wife).

ex.xv: Merlbbe daluk ngalkka nabininjkobeng ngalengarre warradjangkal.
ex.xe: Merlbbe is the female agile wallaby, and her mate is the male agile wallaby, warradjangkal.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: JM: Njamed dangarrk. Yoh, ka-yo, yiman dayno. KL:Yoh, dangarrk ka-ngerrhmirri, Mardayin. Ka-rung kandji.
ex.xe: JM: They are whatsit, dangarrk. Yes, they are like round [shapes]. KL: Yes, the dangarrk give off light and are Mardayin [sacred]. They burn under [the water].
ex.so: John Mawurndjul and Kay Lindjuwanga from Maningrida Arts and Culture bark painting documentation, June 1994. Recorded by Murray Garde and on file ‘Mawurndjul Texts’.

sn.de: A glowing water plant or other mystical light phenomenon that appears in water bodies and is associated with the Mardayin ceremony.

ex.xv: Yirrangbalhmen!
ex.xe: Close the door!

ex.xv: Yirrangbalhmerrimen!
ex.xe: Close your mouth!
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Close a door, window or opening, shut one's mouth.

ex.xv: Kumunun wanjh ngandidangbalhmi.
ex.xe: At night they used to lock us in.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Lock someone in, shut someone in.

ex.xv: Beneburriweyi madjawarr durndengi djabdangeni kore benedanginj.
ex.xe: The two of them were throwing spears, but the spears were bouncing back and coming to stand upright in the ground where the two of them were standing.

ex.xv: Ngarridanginj wanjh ngarrikoluy.
ex.xe: We stopped and got down (from the truck).

sn.de: Stand, reach a standing position, come to a standstill.

re: come to live in a place

ex.xv: Bu korroko ngarranginj, bu mandjewk mandjewk ngadjaldi munguyh.
ex.xe: I came here to live a long time ago, for many years and I'll stay here always.
ex.so: Margaret from Manmoyi in Gerhalter translation

sn.de: Come to live in a place.

ex.xv: Mongerrk benbenenang daluk bokenh. Bedda benedanginj.
ex.xe: One day, Mongerrk saw two women. They were sisters.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Nawamud kumekke kunred danginj wanjh kunuka kaborndokdi.
ex.xe: Nawamud was born in that place, that’s his birthplace.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Minj karribukkan bu kayahwurd. Kadjalle kadjawurrkdangen bu kabidbun.
ex.xe: We won’t teach him when he’s too young. When he grows some whiskers, then he can go up to the ceremony ground.

ex.xv: Ngurringeynamerrimen, wanjh ba membership ngurriyimerran, dja ngurringeydangen kore djurra.
ex.xe: Sign your names, so you'll become members and your name will appear on the list.
ex.so: Adjumarllarl Aboriginal Corporation community newsletter, 2015

sn.de: Grow, appear, come to be, become. Form of the verb -di ('there is, stand') that implies the process of coming into being, literally 'standing up'.

ng: this idiomatic sense being a semantic extention of the verb to stand is also only represented by the past perfective form -danginj

ex.xv: Nganedanginj.
ex.xe: We are siblings / we are brothers / we are sisters.

ex.xv: Birridanginj.
ex.xe: They are all siblings.

ex.xv: Ngarriwen nawu ngarrimarnbun manbu badjkid nawu ngaye ngarridanginj.
ex.xe: There are lots of us here making baskets, me and my sisters.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra, quoted in Hamby, Louise (ed.), Twined Together: Kunmadj Njalehnjaleken, Injalak Arts and Crafts, Gunbalanya, 2005, p. xiii

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan kabimarneyime wurdyaw ngalengarre nawu nayahwurd "Ngaye dangkenwon manme".
ex.xe: A mother will tell her young child "I'm going to put the food in your mouth".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan kabidangkenwon kundjikka ngalengarre nawu wurdyaw barrken.
ex.xe: The mother gives her young child the breast.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Put something in someone's mouth, feed someone.

ex.xv: Yimankek benwoyi dja burrkyakni benkoweyi. Kaluk bu birribalrlobmi darnkih wanjh ngalbu Kurdukadji djaldangkenworreni ngalengman deleng. Wanjh wurd birridurndengi kunmarrwe.
ex.xe: She pretended she was going to give them some, but she was just teasing them. When they ran up to her, the Emu would just put the food into her mouth, and they went back hungry.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, p. 8

ex.xv: Wurdyaw birrimarneyimeng nungan dangkenworrimen manme bu kangun ba kaburrbun.
ex.xe: They told the child to feed himself, so he could learn how to do it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Put something in one's mouth, feed oneself.

ex.xv: Dulklorrkkelorrkken nakka yiman nayuhyungkih kabirriyo kore kundulk manlohlorrk kore kurrangmaye kundulk kore Ankung Djang.
ex.xe: Dulklorrkkelorrkken spirits are like creation Ancestors, they live in hollow trees, where the trees have an opening, in Honey Dreaming country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Opening, entrance, mouth, lid (of cave, basket, room, didgeridoo etc).

se.de: The area just outside of the entrance to a rock-shelter; just beyond the overhang of a rock-shelter, typically a domestic space associated with a rock- shelter.

sn.de: Strict, strict person, one who can speak strongly.

ex.xv: Nanih nawu Djabbo, dja Dird, benedangwerreni, bu dabborrabbolk ngandimarneyolyolmeng.
ex.xe: Djabbo the Quoll had an argument with Dird the Moon. The old people told us the story.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 120

ex.xv: Mandengeyi danjbik wam kore Kunnanj.
ex.xe: Three cars went to Kunnanj.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 19’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981.

ex.xv: Wurdwurd birridanjbik birriwam djenj.
ex.xe: Three children went fishing.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

ex.xv: Birriburdebmi danjbikkah, dja yika kunkarrngbakmeng, wanjh wurlhmi manu kunak.
ex.xe: They would rub it [the fire stick] back and forth three or four times, and the fire would start.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ’Korroko Bu Bininj Birrimarnbuni Kunak’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

ng: If referring to people, the prefix 'birri-' is often added to make 'birridanjbik', 'the three of them'.

ex.xv: Nawakadj dja Nabulanj benewam djenj benehdanjbuni kubbunj benehkani.
ex.xe: Nawakadj and Nabulanj went spearing fish with a canoe.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj Dja Nabulanj Benewam Djenj’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre.

sn.de: Kill, spear, especially with a multi-pronged 'fish wire' spear.

ex.xv: Yiman kayime Mukkamukka, Kubarrakahbul, ... yibekka kadjale Dorddjam, Kukarddak, Nganbelk, kadjale ngamed Mikalkborloh, Kornobolo Kawanjkerri, Miwurlkwurlk, kadjale Midjuyh kaddum Burddjinnguk, Miwakkawilk, Bobuneyi, koyek kadjale Bulubbulu, Kukalal, Walmidji, kadjale Kubarrakahbul manekke barrimraworrinj anbu na-Dankorlo [na-rrankorlo] ngamed konda, Mukkamukka, Nangalakardbam, manekke na-Marrirn.
ex.xe: Like Mukkamukka, Kubarrakabbul ... it goes on to Dorddjam, Kukarddak, Nganbelk, further to whatsit Mikalkborloh, Kornobolo Kawanjkerri, Miwurlkwurlk, further to Midjuyh up to Burddjinnguk, Miwakkawilk, Bobuneyi, east further to Bulubbulu, Kukalal, Walmidji, then to Kubarrakahbul. That’s where they join together with the Dankorlo and here at Mukkamukka and Nangalakardbam,

sn.de: Name of a Kuninjku patriclan from the Tomkinson and lower Mann Rivers district.

ex.xv: Nahni kunj kangeyyo ngorlomorroh, kaluk kadi yiman kayime kore kubolkdarleh.
ex.xe: That kangaroo is called "ngorlomorroh" (Northern nail-tail wallaby), and it lives in dry areas.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nang kayerrkan kore mandulkdarleh
ex.xe: He saw there was some [wild honey] in a dead tree
ex.so: Kunwinjku texts collected by Peter Carroll, on file at ASEDA

ex.xv: Baladjdji nang kahdarlkan manbu manme dahkedahkendi mankinjdjek.
ex.xe: He saw the dillybag, which had been filled with cheeky yams, floating [empty] in the water.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 190

ex.xv: Karridarnhnan.
ex.xe: Let's have a close look at it.

ex.xv: Nawu kinga kumhdjalwam darnkih kore ngalmekbe daluk kore ningihni.
ex.xe: The crocodile just came right up close to where that woman was sitting.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Kordbolbok ngarribekkan kawokdi kukak kamulewan mandjewk bu darnkih kadjakdung.
ex.xe: When we hear frogs at night, it means that it’s going to rain soon.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kahkorodarrhme.
ex.xe: Part of the snake’s body is sticking out of its hole.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kalawan kakebdarrhme kumidjno.
ex.xe: The goanna's nose is poking out of the burrow.

ex.xv: Nawu djenj namardaka dja marrngunj kore kanjdji kukku kabirriyo kudjorlok. Kabirringimen wanjh kabirridjawurrkdakadarrhme.
ex.xe: Eel tailed catfish live in holes under the water. They go inside and we can see their whiskers sticking out.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu kunkanj kabirrikerribun wanjh kunkod manu kabirribarrkbun wanjh kunkurlk kabirridudjeng. Kaluk bu kabirrinan kunkod kadarrhme, wanjh kabirriyawoyhdudjeng kunkurlk.
ex.xe: When people cook meat in ground ovens, they cover it with paperbark and then put soil over the top. If people see a bit of paperbark sticking out, they'll put some more earth on top.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunubewu benedarrkid. Kunubewu benedoweng.
ex.xe: Maybe the two of them are alive. Maybe they're dead.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Nungka karrarrkid.
ex.xe: He is alive.

ex.xv: Ngarribokkadjuy nganabbarru wanjh ngarribebmeng kure darrkid ngarrinang.
ex.xe: We followed the buffalo tracks until we arrived and actually saw it (the buffalo).

ex.xv: Yirrmeng rowk wanjh mey daweng, dayohdayoy dayonginj rowk darlehminj.
ex.xe: She split it all [the pandanus leaves] into strips, then put them in the sun to dry. They lay there in the sun and all dried out.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Ngalngarridj Marebu Marnbom’, Oenpelli School and Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Gunbalanya, 1975

sn.de: To put something out in the sun, dry something in the sun.

ex.xv: Dedded kunmud kabirrimudmang kabirrikurrme kore djerrh wongkorr mardayin kunmadj.
ex.xe: People get lorikeet feathers and weave them into sacred dilly bags for the Mardayin ceremony.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Wanjh kunu Mamik bibayeng deddel.
ex.xe: And Shorty got bitten by a black ant there.
ex.so: Garlngarr, Victor, ‘Mamik dja nakodjok benekang’ in ‘Kunwinjku Stories’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

ex.xv: Birridedjbuni birrinjamduhkeyi birribebkeyi mannjam kundurddu kudiw kunbalem dja njalehnjale rowk kore kunj kunjam.
ex.xe: They would cut open the kangaroo, make an opening in its belly and pull out the stomach, heart, liver, fat and everything else inside.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Cut open the guts of a kangaroo during cooking.

ex.xv: Ngaleng nalkbom, nalkbom dja dedjdjingmey wayihwayini.
ex.xe: She cried and cried, then began to sing.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 132

ex.xv: Ngaldedjdjumbung ngalkka.
ex.xe: That short woman.

ex.xv: Banikkin dedjlarrk.
ex.xe: A cup without a bottom, a cup with a big hole in the bottom of it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Without a base, missing its bottom.

ex.xv: "Kankukwo kunwardde." "Minj ngakarrme kunwardde, dja dedjlahlarrk nawu baladjdji."
ex.xe: "Give me some money." "I don't have any money, the bag is empty."
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dedjlarrkminj nawu bakki.
ex.xe: All the tobacco is gone.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Empty, with nothing in the bottom (e.g. of a bag), finished down to the last piece.

ex.xv: Kabirridirri budbol wanjh nakudji nawu kadedjmelme manbu budbol wanjh kadolkayhwe djarreh kare.
ex.xe: They play football, and someone kicks the ball and sends it flying a long distance.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mamamh ngamngimen dja mandjewk nganhbun ngabonjdjekdoweng ngahdeldelme.
ex.xe: Grandpa let me come in, I'm getting rained on and I'm freezing and shivering.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manih delek ngukmak, kakukbarme duninj.
ex.xe: This white clay is 'good shit' (of the rainbow serpent), it really is very bright.

sn.de: White ochre or clay, kaolin, huntite.

ex.xv: Kadjalbodelengkurrme kabongerdkendi wanjh.
ex.xe: The water goes in until it is full.
ex.so: Nadjamerrek, Lofty Bardayal & Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘A Kundedjnjenghmi Wordlist of Eco-zone Terminology’, Northern Land Council Caring for Country Unit, 2007

sn.de: Contents. Nominal suffix which indicates the idea of contents being held within a container of some kind.

ex.xv: Dalukdeleng beneburrinj?
ex.xe: Was it only the two women [and not men] who were fighting?

ex.xv: Wanjh ngadman deleng bu ngarrinahnarren / Minj nangale ngankongibun bu konda kamre, ahwurd, ahwurd.
ex.xe: We look after ourselves / No one feels sorry for us, no one is staying here, we are sad, we are sad.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ’Maburrinj (The lonely place called Maburrinj)’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Only, just, nominal suffix 'exclusive involved participant'. Only me, just each other, all by ourselves etc.

se.de: Take contents in a container, vehicle etc.
Get or pick up a container/bag etc. with contents in it.
Put contents in container, put luggage in vehicle etc.

ng: Free noun in the form of delengno (with the third person possessor suffix -no only in Kuninjku, Kune and Kundedjnjenghmi dialects) and has the sense of 'contents (of a container)'. In a second sense the word appears as a suffix on core nominals with the sense of 'exclusive involved participant' (see Evans 2003:154). Incorporable in verbs such as delengkan, delengmang, delengkurrme, delengdahkendong

ex.xv: Bu kabbal karrire wanjh kunkih karrikihmelme wanjh kandelkke kunkih.
ex.xe: When we go onto the floodplain and step in the mud, the mud splashes us.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Splash or spill fluid on something.

ex.xv: Kanwohdenghke.
ex.xe: You're delaying me (i.e. I want to go).

ex.xv: Bu yiman wurdwurdbubuyika mak kabirridurren, wanjh karrbendenghke o karrbenmarneyime “Yuwn ngurrimarneyidngalkerren”.
ex.xe: If other kids start arguing with them, we stop them, or we tell them “Don’t go looking for trouble for yourself.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Cause an object to stop or slow down, delay someone, stop someone doing something, hinder someone.

ex.xv: 'Parachute' kabebme wanjh kakukdenghme manekke.
ex.xe: The parachute appears and it (the aircraft) comes to a stop.

ex.xv: Karridjalkukdenghme munguyh.
ex.xe: We're stalled, we're not moving forward (no-one is co-operating or taking decisive action).
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Stop moving (of large objects), be stalled (also figuratively).

ex.xv: Yiderrehkemen darnki kodbarre.
ex.xe: Move it away (and put it) close to the house.

sn.de: Move something away (or if -mderrehke, movement is towards speaker).

ex.xv: Yiderrehmen!
ex.xe: Move away a bit.

ex.xv: Yimderrehmen!
ex.xe: Come closer.

ex.xv: Karridubberrong yiman bolkkime karridi, karridubbedoy wanjh. Dja bu bewh wurd karribalderrehme.
ex.xe: We don’t know which way to go at present, as we are now, we're stuck. We need to make progress.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yuwn ngurriwernhre kunrayek kore Balanda. Bokenh ngurrirlobmen. Ngad kadberre mak kunwok ngurrikarrmen rerrih, yuwn ngurriwe, la ngurrire kore kunkukbele, burrkyak. Marndi bewh ngurrihderrehme djarreh ngurrikarrebarlanhmang manbu ngad kadberre.
ex.xe: Don’t dedicate yourself to the Balanda way of doing things. You must run with both. You must also hold on to our own language as well. Don’t discard it and go to the white language, no. If you move too far away (from our traditions), you'll lose the Law, our law.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Move forward, make progress (towards a plan or goal etc), move on, move away.

ex.xv: Bindimarneyimeng, “Ngurriderrehmen ngudda ngurrikukbele ngurriderrehmen wardi bu ngadman bininjwi.”
ex.xe: They’ve said to them, “Right, you just move on. You white people move on, its our turn" (to get the jobs, etc).
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Make way, make room, move on.

ex.xv: Med yirrin!
ex.xe: Stay there, wait. (lit. you sing. stand imper.)

ex.xv: Dingihdi.
ex.xe: He stood there for some time.

ex.xv: Minj diwirrinj.
ex.xe: She wasn't there.

ex.xv: Ngudda bale yihrri?
ex.xe: Where have you been?

ex.xv: Yekke kabalemdi [kunj], yekke nakka bonj.
ex.xe: In yekke season [kangaroos] are fat, certainly in yekke season.

sn.de: Be present (especially temporarily or in a phase).

ex.xv: Bale yiyime kela? Ngunehdi?
ex.xe: What kinship relationship are you to Kela? Do you call him brother-in-law?

sn.de: Be in affinal relationship with someone.

se.de: Reduplicated form of 'di' meaning to stand or be somewhere for some time.

sn.sc: Cartonema spicatum, Cartonema trigonospermum (Altman also records Cartonema parviflorum as didjkala).
sn.sy: mardidjdjad is the duwa name. Didjkala is the yirridjdja name

ex.xv: Dilebang nakka djenj kilekilelh yiman nadjirrkku dja kukbuyika. Korroko nawu dabborrabbolk birringuni nawu dilebang.
ex.xe: Rainbow fish are small, like glassfish but different. In the old days, people used to eat them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Various kinds of rainbow fish and hardyheads e.g. Banded rainbow fish, Mariana's hardyhead. Some speakers also include the spotted blue-eye or the delicate blue-eye.

ex.xv: Djal bimwi yuwurrinj yiman delek bolkki ngahbimbom wolewoleh kunekke ngayimeninj kunkudji dilh dilh dilh.
ex.xe: There was only (solid figure) images in white ochre like I use today and like I painted before with dots, one by one, dot dot dot.
ex.so: Mick Kubarkku, on file “Transcript of cassette RA93-2” by Murray Garde, 1993.

sn.de: The action of making a dot.

ex.xv: Yoh dilhdilhmeninj la ngaleng Mardayin birrirarrkwemeninj mankarre nawu nadjamun 'old fashion one'.
ex.xe: Yes, he used to paint dots but for Mardayin ceremony they used 'rarrk' (cross hatching) which was the old fashioned way.

ex.xv: Bonbon kabirringun djenj nawu kilekilelh yiman marrngunj burd djakolk nawern nawu djenj kare kore kukku kubowinjku. Karrbennan birriwern kore kukku kabirridjuhmiyindi kabirridimhme kanjdji kore kukku kabirriyawan djenj kabirridanjbun kundang bedberre wanjh kabirringun.
ex.xe: Cormorants eat small freshwater fish, like baby eel-tailed catfish, spangled grunter and purple spotted gudgeon. We see lots of them in the water, diving down under the water to look for fish and spearing them with their beaks and eating them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

re: stand or be somewhere for a long time

ex.xv: Wam nang kabenehbokyo, wanjh med dingihdi burrbuhburrbuni.
ex.xe: He went and saw that their footprints were there, then stood there a while thinking.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nabangardi bidbom kuwardde’, in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

sn.de: Stand or be somewhere for some time, a long time (reduplicated form of ‘di’, to stand or be).

ex.xv: Ngad karrinjilngmak bu dird kabolkwolkan, wanjh karribolknan bu kukak, nungka kayawoyhmimbimen.
ex.xe: We are happy when the moon lights up the sky, so we can see at night. The moon comes back to life [every night].
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 120

ex.xv: Nanih nawu Djabbo, dja Dird, benedangwerreni, bu dabborrabbolk ngandimarneyolyolmeng.
ex.xe: Djabbo the Quoll had an argument with Dird the Moon. The old people told us that story.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 120

ex.xv: Ngamadbom nakudji dird.
ex.xe: I waited one month.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Dirdko karrire.
ex.xe: Let's go by moonlight.

ex.xv: Bu dirdko wanjh kabirriwaralnarren, yiman kayime mak kundung bu koyek dja karrikad bu kadungdi wanjh kabirriwaralnarren.
ex.xe: By moonlight people cast a shadow ['see their own shadows'], just like when the sun is in the west or the east.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu ngarriyime dirdngukmak wanjh kunu dird kabolkwolkan bu ngarrire, yiman kayime bu
ex.xe: When we say 'dirdngukmak', that means when the moon is bright enough to light our way at night.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kuhni dirdngukmak dja karrire ngarrbek karriyawan.
ex.xe: There's a bright moon, let's go hunting echidnas.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wurdurd beh ngurridirri kandibengbun.
ex.xe: You kids go and play over there, you're driving me crazy.

ex.xv: Ngarrbek dja Ngalmangiyi benemdolkkang kakbibeh.
ex.xe: The Echidna and the Long-necked Turtle came down from the north.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Ngudda yiyawnahna, dja ngaye ngawarlbun ngarrku.
ex.xe: You look after the kid, and I’ll go hunting for us.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

sn.de: And. Can link both nouns and clauses.

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalkordow ngalka mayh ngadberre bu ngarringun bu korrokoni dja bolkkime larrk.
ex.xe: The egret is one of the animals we used to eat, but not any more.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngurrurdu korroko dolkani rey kaddum kaluk bininj benebokenh yimankek beneyameninj dja larrk.
ex.xe: One day the Emu flew up into the air, two men tried to spear her but without success.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu Kudjewk wanjh birringimi kuwardderurrk birriyoy dja mandjewk dja birndu.
ex.xe: In the wet season they moved into caves to stay, because of the rain and mosquitos.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yiman nawu koyek nakka wanjh bindiyameng dalukkenh daluk bindikilekmi bindiberlmangi wanjh kunekke bindiyameng nawu birribuyika Djabbani.
ex.xe: There in the east, that’s where they speared them because they were interfering with women, sexually exploiting the women and so that’s why they speared those foreigners, those Japanese.

ex.xv: Nanih nawu Djabbo, dja Dird, benedangwerreni, bu dabborrabbolk ngandimarneyolyolmeng.
ex.xe: Djabbo the Quoll had an argument with Dird the Moon. The old people told us that story.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 120

ex.xv: Wanjh nakudji yimeng njalekenh manbu mankole ngarrburriwe kamdurndeng kadjabdan kore kubodme ngarrku. Wanjh bu benebalwam djarrehwurd benenang ngalbu Ngalyod kahyo wanjh benedurndi kured.
ex.xe: One of them said “Why does the spear end up landing [sticking into the ground] behind us when we throw it?”. Then when they went a little further they saw that the Rainbow Serpent was there, and they went home.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: To stick into the ground, to end up standing upright.

ex.xv: Kadjabdi lorrkkon.
ex.xe: The bone pole is standing upright.

sn.de: Stand upright, be standing, an elongate object standing on its base.
Travel directly to the destination without stopping, "straight up kare".

ex.xv: Nahni djenj djabel korroko nawu dabborrabbolk birringuni yiman nadjirrkku dja bolkkime minj ngarringun.
ex.xe: People used to eat mouth almighty fish, just like they used to eat glassfish, but these days we don't eat them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yirrulkdjabnamen wanjh yirrukka midjikked.
ex.xe: Place some sticks in the ground and tie up your mosquito net.

sn.de: Place an elongate object on its end, place into the ground (such as a pole or a stick).

ex.xv: Djaddedde kangun kunmalaworr. Kubolkwern ngarrbennan.
ex.xe: Grasshoppers eat leaves. You can see them anywhere.

ex.xv: Burarr nang djaddi nayahwurd. Binjolhmeng.
ex.xe: A goanna saw the small frog. It swallowed him.
ex.so: ‘Djaddi na-yahwurd’, Maningrida Literature Production Centre, Maningrida, 1994

ex.xv: Mandjewk ka-djakdung djaddi 'noise' kamarnbun 'kodwong-kodwong'.
ex.xe: In the wet season the frogs make noise 'gotwong-gotwong'.

sn.de: Green Tree Frog, also generic for all frogs.

ex.xv: Nawu bininj djadmudni wam korroko, dja wanjh bolkkime mey daluk.
ex.xe: The man was single for a long time, but now he's found a wife.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Djak nganbayeng.
ex.xe: An ant bit me.
ex.so: Dakgalawuy, Nancy, ‘Wurdyaw dirrihdirri’ in ‘Kunwinjku Stories’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

ex.xv: Bu njale karringun karribawon kore kunrurrk wanjh karrinan nawern djak bu kanome dja kabolkan.
ex.xe: If we're eating something and we leave it in the house, then ants will smell it and lots of them will come after it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey kore kudjorlok manlabbarl birrinani djakarna kangun djenj wanjh birridanjbuni djalakiradj.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would go down to the billabongs and see jabirus eating fish, and they would spear them with multi-pronged spears.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Black-necked stork, also known as the jabiru. Associated with the yirridjdja moiety.

ex.xv: Bu kudjewk kayimerran mandjewk nakimuk kadjakdung.
ex.xe: When the wet season starts, heavy rains fall.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Minj ngad karrinan nawu Nakurrurndilhba birridjalkudji kabirrinan nawu marrkidjbu nawu birrikurdang.
ex.xe: We can’t see Nakurrurndilhba spirits, only clever men with special powers can see them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Only, just. Exclusively one thing and not another.

ex.xv: Bedman mak morlehmorlenj djal kunmekbe rerrih, mankarre bokenh bu kabirrikadjung laik- mahni bu kunkukbelekenh, mahni kunkukburlerrikenh.
ex.xe: It's just the same for the women - there are two laws they have to follow: one black, one white.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Nja, ten dollar djal bonj, wardi kanmarneyakwon.
ex.xe: Here you are, here's ten dollars and that's it, or you'll clean me out.
ex.so: Evans, Nicholas (ed.), How to write Kundjeyhmi, prepared for the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Gagudju Association.

sn.de: That's all, exactly, just. Adverb which indicates the extent of something.

ex.xv: Yidjalbun.
ex.xe: Keep hitting it.

ex.xv: Djal munguyh kabenedjarrkdi.
ex.xe: They just stay together permanently [as a couple].
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Keep on doing something, just keep doing something etc. Adverb of duration which indicates that an action or situation is continuing or repeating for some time.

ex.xv: Ngamdjalbom.
ex.xe: "Yuwn yikan mankukyahwurd makka" "Bonj warribo ngadjalkan ngakinje ngangun. Bonj bu mankukyahwurd"

ex.xv: "Don't take that yam, it's too small". "Whatever, I'll just take it anyway and cook it up and eat it. Doesn't matter if it's small".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wanjh nunganwali wurdyaw kamayhmakmen - kadjalre nawu kambun mayh. Kaluk minj bidlarrk kamdurndeng.
ex.xe: The child in turn will become a good hunter, he just goes and gets an animal, and he never comes back empty handed.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Just, anyway. Do something for no specific reason, purpose or intent, do something despite reasons not to, do something freely without restrictions or limitations.

ng: Prefix on verbs, noun-adjective compounds, adjectives, numerals and locations. When it restricts nouns, it is a separate word rather than a prefix. Despite being a complex word, the semantic range of 'djal' is very similar to 'just' in English, so speakers of either language should find the translation fairly intuitive. It can mean 'only' (just the women and not the men), 'exactly' (that's just the thing, just ten and no more). 'keep on doing, continuously' (he just stayed there), 'for no particular reason' (I just decided to come along') or 'despite reasons to the contrary' etc ('I just did it anyway').

ex.xv: Danjbom djalaban.
ex.xe: He speared it with a 'djalaban' type spear.
ex.so: The example phrase comes from texts Peter Carroll has deposited with AIATSIS

sn.de: Multi-pronged spear, similar to 'fish wire' spear except the points are made from hardwood.

ex.xv: Bolkkime nawu djalakiradj karrimarnbun nawu balanda marnbom wire. Karridjobke karrimarnbun dad danjbik kunubewu kunkarrngbakmeng nawu wire dad. Karrimang mankole wanjh karridadname nawu dad djalakkiradj.
ex.xe: These days we make fishing spears out of wire, a non-indigenous material. We cut it and make three or four prongs, then we cut spear shafts and fasten the prongs onto them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: 'Fish wire' spear, wire. Spear with three or four sharpened metal prongs at the end, used for fishing or hunting smaller animals such as aquatic birds. A similar spear with barbed wooden prongs is known as mandanj and is considered to be the more traditional prototype for djalakiradj.

bw: Evans writes that this comes from Malay "tali kəras" meaning "taut line". "This would presumably refer to the way in which the string holding the prongs in place must be pulled taut". Yolngu Matha = djalakaritj 'spear with long thin steel prongs, used for fishing'

ex.xv: Ngad ngarridjalama, Kundjalama ngarriwokdi.
ex.xe: We people of Djalama clan speak our own clan dialect called Kundjalama.

sn.de: Name of a number of patriclans in the upper Kumadderr (Goomadeer) River district.

ex.xv: Korroko nawu dabborrabbolk birribimbuni kore dolobbo wanjh birrirey birriyawani djalamardi. Wanjh birrimangi birrikani kured, birridongi yika birribayeyi birrikerlkwoni. Wanjh birribarungi nawu dolobbo birribimbuni njale.
ex.xe: In the old days, when people wanted to paint on bark, they would go looking for tree orchids. They would get them, take them home and pund them up, or chew them to make them soft. Then they would paint something on the bark (using the orchid as fixative).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Tree orchid. The juice from the base of the plant was used as a fixative for ochre pigments on bark, stone or body decoration.
A plant with edible tuber but leaves similar to the orchid.

ur: Kuninjku = yarlkkan, Kundjeyhmi = njarlkkan, Jawony= nyarlkan (ground orchid)

ex.xv: Nawu djalangkarridj-djalangkarridj bu kabirrinan nawu dabborrabbolk wanjh kabirriyime bonj wanjh djenj kamulewan.
ex.xe: When people see dragonflies, they say that means there are fish (ready to be caught).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Djalarr djang bedberre birri-Madjba.
ex.xe: The centipede is a dreaming for Madjba (Jawoyn) clan people.

ex.xv: Yidjalay.
ex.xe: Keep going further.

ex.xv: Nawu Nawamud bimarneyimeng Nangarridj mah ngudda wanjh yidjalay kurih kakbi.
ex.xe: Nawamud said to Nangarridj "OK, you just keep on going north then".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mah yidjalay munguyh yidjalmarnbu.
ex.xe: OK just keep on doing it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ng: from imperative form of djal+re > djal+ray

ex.xv: Yidjalay.
ex.xe: Keep going further.

ex.xv: Bu bininj kabirriwohre kunbarnangarrakuyeng yiman malamalaywi kabirridedjdjingmang kabirridjale kadungborledme bu kabaldungyibme.
ex.xe: When people walk around all day, for example they might start in the morning and keep on going until the afternoon and the sun starts to go down.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu bininj kabiwabun nabuyika bininj wanjh kadjalkukyakmen minj nangale kabingalke. Kunekke birrikurduyimi korroko nawu dabborabbolk bu bindiwabuni namarndekah wanjh birridjalkukyakmeni minj mak birridurndeyi kore kured dja wanjh birridjaley kore kuwardderurrk munguyhmunguyh.
ex.xe: When a man curses another man, the other man just disappears, nobody can find him anymore. That's what people used to do in the old days, they would sing people over to the evil spirits, and they would just disappear and not come back home, they would just go on into a cave and stay there forever.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ng: An abbreviation of 'djal'+'re’. Conjugated like 're', e.g. kadjale (he/she keeps going), yidjalay (keep going!), birridjaley (they would keep going), ngadjalwam (I kept going).

ex.xv: Wanjh nawu ngalmangiyi dja kedjebe nakka benewilkdi wanjh benehni benehmadbuni wanjh bu djolengminj wanjh benewayhkeng benedjalkmey benenguneng wanjh beneworrkminj.
ex.xe: Then they cooked the long-necked turtles and file snakes in the ground oven, sat and waited a while, and when they were done they lifted them out, cut them up, ate them and were full.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine N, ‘Ngalbadjan dja Ngalyaw’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Oenpelli, 1975

sn.de: Cut into pieces, slice in half.

ex.xv: Ngabendjalwohkan wurdurd.
ex.xe: I'll take the children for the time being [until you return].

ex.xv: Manmekbe ngadjalwohyolyolmeng bonj, la ngaburnbun.
ex.xe: That's all I had to say, I'll stop now.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Just do some little thing, just do something temporarily, for the time being, only, nothing more.

ex.xv: Karridjalohwamwi karrikowerrinj.
ex.xe: We just went there for nothing, we were under an incorrect belief (that something could be obtained there).

sn.de: For no purpose, to no result.

ex.xv: Yidjongburren djalawarra!
ex.xe: Put on those trousers!

re: hit or throw something against something

ex.xv: Ngalbininjkobeng nabininjkobeng benewam kalawan benehyawani wanjh benengalkeng nawu kalawan. Ngalbininjkobeng yimeng "Mah yima yidjambarrhmang".
ex.xe: A husband and wife went looking for goannas, and they found one. The wife said "Okay, grab it (by the tail) and smash it against something" [this is the usual way to kill a goanna].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngandjambarrhdjambarrhmang muddikang.
ex.xe: The truck is throwing me around.

sn.de: Hit something against something else, lift and throw OBJ down with force.

ex.xv: Nadjamun minj karriyolyolme.
ex.xe: That's secret/sacred, we don't talk about that.

se.de: A sacred water body, sacred water hole.

ex.xv: Manme manbu mandjan.
ex.xe: Bland food, food that's not very sweet.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Manbu manbodjan ngarriyime makka minj kakarrme nawu mankung namanjmak. Nawu mankung ngarriyime minj manbomanjmak. Dja manbodjan.
ex.xe: We can describe honey that's not very good as 'manbodjan' ('liquid that's not sweet'). It's not good honey, it's a bit flavorless.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Yellow spotted monitor which is a goanna similar in size (up to 1 metre) to kalawan Varanus gouldii but with different colour and skin patterning.

ex.xv: Nguddu yidjandi ngadberre!
ex.xe: You’re bludging off us!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Bludge off other people, e.g. hang around waiting for offers of food, asking for money or cigarattes.

ex.xv: Nawu Manimunak wirlarrk djang kahdjangdi kore kaddum kuwarde Arrkuluk.
ex.xe: There is a sacred site for Magpie Goose eggs on the top of Arrkuluk rock.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Place of religious significance where the spiritual essence of a totemic being, plant, animal or other emblem resides in a particular location.

ex.xv: Djalarr djang bedberre birri-Madjba.
ex.xe: The djalarr centipede is a dreaming for Madjba (Jawoyn) clan people.

se.de: There is a sacred site, a sacred site exists.
Place oneself as djang, said when an ancestor becomes a sacred site.

ex.xv: Durlmangkarr konda kadjangdi Kudjaborrng. Barrk kumekke djang kayo. O njamed nawaran.
ex.xe: The Durlmangkarr clan have a dreaming place here at Kudjaborrng. There is a black wallaroo dreaming or whatsit, an Oenpelli python dreaming there.

sn.de: Have a sacred site or totemic emblem.

ex.xv: Nakudji wam djangkang, nang dungyibmeng wanjh keleminj.
ex.xe: A man went out hunting, saw that the sun had set and became frightened.

ex.xv: Manmakkawarri djang kahdjangdi kondah kore Kunbarlanja. Korroko dabborrabbolk nawu kondah kunred bedberre birrirey kunworr mandubang birrimangi birriwodbuni birridjangweyi wanjh kolungi kore manlabbarlkimuk nawu nawern djenj manmakkawarri.
ex.xe: There is a sacred site for the Catfish here in Gunbalanya (a rock not far from the billabong). In the old days, the people from this area would go and hit the rock with ironwood branches as an increase ritual, and lots of catfish would go down into the billabong.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Be stuck, locked in a position.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngawarnyak makka yaldanj, minj ngadjare.
ex.xe: I don't want that waterlily root, I don't like it.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

se.de: Love somebody, want to see somebody.

ex.xv: Bu korroko nakka mandanj birrimarnbuni kundulk birrimirrhmarnbuni. Wanjh kore mankole birridjarlkkennami wanjh djenj birridanjbuni.
ex.xe: In the old days people would make mandanj type spears. They would sharpen small pieces of wood and attach them to a spear shaft and spear fish.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Key yidjalkkennamen kure murrika.
ex.xe: Put the key in the car [in the ignition].

ex.xv: Kandjalkkenname kuburldjarn.
ex.xe: Put me in the middle [of a queue, or a line of dancers].

ex.xv: Konda ngadjalkkennamerren.
ex.xe: I'll put myself in the middle [of the queue].

sn.de: Fork in branch. Larger Y-shaped forked branches are used as a ladder to climb trees. The fork is laid against the tree and you climb up.

se.re: in the fork of the branch
se.de: In the fork of the branch.

ng: Often the locative prefix ku- is attached kudjarnngal ‘in the fork of the branch’.

ex.xv: Nabulanj wam kabbal wanjh nawu djarrang dja nganabbarru mirndeyarlarrkeng.
ex.xe: Nabulanj went down to the floodplain, and all the horses and the all buffalo ran off and dispersed (as he walked near them).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wam djarreh wanjh mandjewk kumhwam nayahwurd wanjh yerre kimukminj.
ex.xe: He went a long way away and it started to rain a little, then the rain got heavy.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Minj kawernhbolknan djarreh.
ex.xe: He’s short-sighted, he’s suffering from myopia.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Far, distant, a long way away.

ex.xv: Wanjh bu benebalwam djarrehwurd benenang ngalbu Ngalyod kahyo wanjh benedurndi kured.
ex.xe: Then when they went a little further they saw that the Rainbow Serpent was there, and they went home.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalyawk djarrirnmey kadberre. Minj kumrawinj karridjarrkwarlbuyi.
ex.xe: The girl went off in another direction, she didn't come hunting with us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngudda yidjarrirnmey ngadberre.
ex.xe: You didn't come with us, you went with the other mob.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kabarrarndjarrirnmang.
ex.xe: The two gorges intersect then fork away in different directions.

ex.xv: Karridjarrkre.
ex.xe: Lets all go together.

ex.xv: Yaw djarrkno.
ex.xe: Twins.

ex.xv: Wanjh Nawakadj wam benhyawani, benngalkeng, bendjawam, "Ngudda ngurriyameng djarrang?"
ex.xe: Then Nawakadj went looking for them. He found them and asked them "Did you manage to spear a horse?".
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

se.de: Ask each other, ask oneself, reflect.

ex.xv: Wurdyaw bidjawam kornkumo ngalbadjankah, djawayhmeng, "Karrard baleh wam?”
ex.xe: The child asked his father about his mother, he asked “Where’s mum gone?”
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Nawu ngundidjawayhme yibenngeykurrme
ex.xe: Friend Requests (on Facebook)

ur: Burarra jawina 'crewman, associate, co-worker in subordinate role', Iwaidja jawirna 'friend', Maung djawirna 'friend'.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji wurdyaw Ngaldjawonj / bolkbawong kunred ngalengarre / Bolkmaddi kore Manginburru bedberre
ex.xe: There is a little girl from a Jawoyn clan / who left her country / And who has stayed for a long time on Manginburru land
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Ngaldjawonj ‘The Jawoyn Girl’’, from the Album ‘Maningburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

ex.xv: Konhda Nanguluwurr barriyoy Nadjawonj, kabolkbuk.
ex.xe: Jawoyn people slept here at Nanguluwurr, it's a dry place.

sn.de: Jawoyn, the Jawoyn language and people, whose traditional country is centred on the southern part of the Arnhem Plateau and surrounding areas such as Katherine and Barunga.

ex.xv: Korroko bininj bokenh benedanjbom benekinjeng benenguneng benedoweng djaying bu birrimulewam.
ex.xe: In the past two people speared one, cooked it and ate it and they died. That's what people say.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Supposedly, apparently, they say. Introduces falso complements of reportative verb. 'That's what the claim is...'

ex.xv: Nakka maydbi bedberre, old man nakka kabengkan Wamud. Nakka djaying bedberre Wurrbbarn.
ex.xe: It [a place] might belong to them, old man Wamud will know. It possibly belongs to the Wurrbbarn clan.

sn.de: Possibly, might be, whether or not, (introduces predicates whose epistemic status is uncertain).
Expresses lack of commitment or uncertainty to the truth value or otherwise of a reported claim. 'Apparently'.

ex.xv: Djaying ba-rayinj kurih.
ex.xe: I thought he was going to come (but he didn't) (Kundjeyhmi).

sn.de: Address term used by a woman to her children (of both genders) or a man to his sister’s children.

ex.xv: Namarden bolkdjedmeng kure Kukkurr.
ex.xe: The Lightning Spirit carved out that place at Kukkurr (Kukkurr is a large red cliff on the eastern bank of the Liverpool river).

sn.de: Scrape with a tool; carve or sculpt.

ex.xv: Ngarridjekmeng ngarridoweng ngarribodmedadjmeng.
ex.xe: We laughed until it hurt and we doubled over.

ex.xv: Nakudji nakimukkenh borrkkeng wanjh karridjekmeng.
ex.xe: One fat man danced and we laughed (at him).

ex.xv: Nakodjok dja Nawamud benewam Kunnanj, djenj benehmangi.
ex.xe: Nakodjok and Nawamud went to Kunnanj, catching fish.
ex.so: Galamirnda, Barbara N., ‘Nakodjok Dja Nawamud Benewam Kunnanj Djenj’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, 1975

ex.xv: Daluk benebokenh benewam djenj wakkidj.
ex.xe: Two women went fishing with fishing lines.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: Fishing (when combined with the verb re, 'to go'). (Literally 'go for fish').

ex.xv: Djerrh korroko birrimarnbuni manmekenh bu birriwarlbuni nawu morlehmorlenj.
ex.xe: In the past, women used to make dilly bags for gathering fruits and vegetables.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: String bag (looped or knotted) with string woven from a great variety of plant fibres including Acacia difficilis, Acacia latifolia, Brachychiton diversifolius, Brachychiton megaphyllus, Clerodendrum floribundum, Ficus virens, Hibiscus arnhemensis, Pandanus spiralis, Pandanus aquaticus, Planchonia careya and Sterculia quadrifida.

ex.xv: Doy kunwardde djerrkdanj, barrabarrhmeng.
ex.xe: [The boat] hit the rocks, capsized and broke up.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 246

ex.xv: Kadungdjerrkdan.
ex.xe: The sun is sinking.

sn.de: Tip onto side, capsize, start to sink.

ex.xv: Djibdjib kaboydjabdi.
ex.xe: There is a black termite mound standing there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Termite mound, black. These are freestanding termite mounds and very hard, so they are not favoured for use in ground ovens.

ex.xv: Name nungan djenj kangun djidjnguk nakka.
ex.xe: Those djidjnguk spirits eat fish.

ex.xv: Djidjnguk nakka dedjdjumbung murrngrayek dja nabang warridj.
ex.xe: Djidjnguk spirits are short and strong, and dangerous too.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Dwarf spirit being. Some are said to inhabit the honey dreaming country in Mok clan estate.
Willy wagtail. Possibly also the grey fantail.

ex.xv: Kabiyawdjikkawon.
ex.xe: She's breast-feeding the baby.

ex.xv: Birriwern wurdwurd birriwam birrihmangi kundalk birrihbakkeyi njamed mayadjdja dja djilidjilih birribayeyi.
ex.xe: Lots of children went and were breaking themselves pieces of grass to chew on, bush sugarcane.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu kabirriwohre kore kudahdadalk wanjh wanjh kabirringalke djilihdjili, kukku kabokarrme, wanjh kabirridalkbayehbaye kukku kabirribongun.
ex.xe: When people walk around in grassy areas they find bush sugar cane, which has juice in it, so they bite the grass and drink the juice.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Kind of cane grass sometimes referred to as 'bush sugar cane' because of the sugary juice it contains. Some speakers say that mayadjdja is sweet grass that has ripened and has plenty of juice whilst younger grass without much juice is called djilidjilih.

ex.xv: Nganere djilikuybi nganedulubun, dja manimunak.
ex.xe: We're going to shoot Whistle Duck and Magpie Goose.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 40-43

ex.xv: Djimurruko kunkurra kabun koyekbeh.
ex.xe: In the east wind season the wind blows from the east.

sn.de: Wind which blows from the east.

ex.xv: Djirddudjirddu kabirridong wanjh kakebdjowhme.
ex.xe: They pound the sedge grass and the end becomes soft (so they can use it as a brush).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: A grass sp. used to make tiny brushes for painting cross-hatching on bark paintings.
Long dorsal fin of saratoga fish which is also used to make paintbrushes.

ex.xv: Nangale djirdmey kunmadj ngarduk?
ex.xe: Who stole my clothes?

ex.xv: Ngarrihyoy Nimbuwa mankabo ngarridulubuni kinga ngarrikurlahbuni djirla ngarrikurlahkani Kunbarlanja.
ex.xe: We were camping at Nimbuwa creek and hunting crocodiles. We would salt the skins and carry them back to Gunbalanya.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, biography section.

sn.de: Most larger quails e.g. stubble quail, brown quail, chestnut-backed button-quail.
sn.sc: Coturnix pectoralis, Coturnix ypsilophora, Turnix castanota

ex.xv: Yika kunyarl dja kundulk bu kabirridjirribiwon nawu djenj.
ex.xe: People carry fish with either a stick or a string through the gills.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: A stick or string used to carry fish, being inserted through the gills and out of the mouth.

ex.xv: Djirrihdiddid kakukyime yiman kaldurrk dja ngahli ngalkukyahwurd.
ex.xe: The kingfisher looks like a blue-winged kookaburra, but it has a smaller body.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Generic term for most kingfishers (sacred kingfisher, red-backed kingfisher, forest kingfisher, mangrove kingfisher and azure kingfisher).
sn.sc: Todiramphus (Halcyon) sancta, Todiramphus (Halcyon) pyrrhopygia, Todiramphus (Halcyon) macleayii, Halcyon senegaloides, Alcedo azurea

ur: Kune = djurk, Kundjeyhmi, Kundedjnjenghmi = djirrirdirdi, Kundedjnjenghmi = djuk 'azure kingfisher (only)'

ex.xv: Minj kawurrme murrikang karridjirrkkan.
ex.xe: The car won't start, let's push it.

ex.xv: Bikukdjirrkkang.
ex.xe: She pushed him.

ex.xv: Arrbenmadbom burrkyak. Minj nangale bininj kumrawinj ngadbu djirrkkayinj nganabbarru ngadberre.
ex.xe: They are under duress from all directions — this way and that way.

se.de: Place under duress, force someone to do something.

sn.de: Cut; cut off, end (a process or activity).

ex.xv: That bolkno, Warlang Karrulkkarrme, Dedjbang kadjobme, beh duwa.
ex.xe: That place Warlang Karrulkkarrme, and then at Dedjbang, that’s where it finishes, [i.e. the border between two clan estates] and that's duwa moiety country this way.

sn.de: Finish up, cut off, come to an end.

ex.xv: Kore kunred Djurlka kore kubolkmayirrkulidj kunred ngaye ngayime karrardwarrekenh bukka Djodj kadjangdi.
ex.xe: At Djurlka in Mayirrkulidj clan country, which is my mother’s country, there is a centipede sacred site.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kangurdke kore karridjohme bu karribarurren nawu delek kukodj, kadjale kanjdji kurrenge.
ex.xe: It stops us from coughing when we rub [a special white ochre] over ourselves from head to foot.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 196, additions Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kubarrarndjokko.
ex.xe: A narrow passage.

ex.xv: Kunak kabendjokkohmikan kunj.
ex.xe: The fire herds all the kangaroos together into a narrow place [where they can be speared]

ex.xv: Kunj kabarridjokkohmikan.
ex.xe: They herd the kangaroos into a narrow place.
ex.so: Kundedjnjenghmi

ex.xv: Kunak kabandjokkohmikan kunj, kabandjokkome kabandjirrkkan kure
ex.xe: The fire herds the kangaroos together and presses them into a narrow place where there are people waiting ahead [to spear them].
ex.so: Kundedjnjenghmi

sn.de: Herd together into a narrow place (as when hunting animals).

ex.xv: Djoleng nakka.
ex.xe: He’s a real pro.
ex.so: Ray Nadjamerrek, referring to ‘Batman’ the helicopter pilot.

ex.xv: Yidjongburren djalawarra!
ex.xe: Put on those trousers.

ex.xv: Wurrakkak benedurrinj Nimbuwa wanjh Wurrakkak mey karramalk bidjuddjobkemeninj dja larrk nawu karramalk djord djorddolkang bolkngadji.
ex.xe: Wurrakkak and Nimbuwa fought, and Wurrakkak took a stone axe and tried to cut off Nimbuwa's head, but it didn't work and the axe head flew off and buried itself in the ground.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Wurrmarninj kadjordmen kore kabbal.
ex.xe: Red lilies grow on floodplains.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Djordohdjordminj nawu ngarridudji.
ex.xe: The ones we planted have all grown up.

se.de: Bring something or someone up, raise a child, make something grow, cultivate.

ex.xv: Mandjewk kamankan, nganbowon kukku / Kamarnbun kadjordmerren kundalk kundulk
ex.xe: The rain falls to give me some water / To make the trees and grass grow.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, 'Maburrinj', from the Album ‘Maningburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Collective or plural sense of grow; 'they are all growing'.

ex.xv: Kornkumo doweng wanjh ngadjadj nuye bidjordmiweng.
ex.xe: His father died and so then his mother's brother raised him.

ex.xv: Kunkanj, wirlarrk, kundjikkakurrk, djenj, dja nawern nawu namakmak kabendjordmiwe, yun ngurrbenwon kandidjdjawa dja tea makka manwarre.
ex.xe: Meat, eggs, breast milk, fish, all those good foods are what grows them [children] up strong. Don’t give them flour and tea, that’s bad.
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace, untitled book, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

sn.de: Raise someone from a child, 'grow im up'.

ex.xv: Kunkare wurdyaw djorlkmeng, dja ngalbadjan kornkumo beneni kured, dja nungan wam. Wam kore kungarrebuldjarn, wanjh dulknang mandulkkimuk.
ex.xe: One day a long time ago, a child ran away. His mother and father were at home, and he set off alone. He went to the middle of the forest, and saw a big tree.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly W, ‘Kunkare Wurdyaw Djorlkmeng’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1975

ex.xv: Ngad wanjh silly ngarriyimeng, kunkudjikenh bu ngarridjorlkmeng.
ex.xe: Well, we had been silly that one time when we ran away.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Run away, head off somewhere without others’ knowledge, run off and get lost.

ex.xv: Ngarduk kokok ngayi ngadurndeng ngamang kaluk ba kabun kadjudbakke kure kuronj nungka yimeng djahwodjahwong.
ex.xe: I'll go back and get my big brother so he'll go and kill it and break its neck (the crocodile) somewhere there in the water.

ex.xv: Korroko nakka nakka kabidjudbakke ngadberre Ubarr ngayih dorrengh.
ex.xe: Already him, he is leading our Ubarr ceremony, me included.

sn.de: Be an expert in ceremony or law, lead or control a ceremony.

ex.xv: Albininjkobeng kundjudbakbakke (Kdj).
ex.xe: Your wife's playing up on you.

sn.de: An idiom meaning (wife) deceive (husband), play up behind back of (husband).

ex.xv: Djudju nganmarnengalkeng.
ex.xe: I've got a toothache.

ex.xv: Ngakarrme djudju kore kuyidme.
ex.xe: I've got an ache in my tooth.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Korroko nawu dabborrabbolk bu birridoweni djudju kore kuyidme, wanjh birrimangi mandudjmi kunmalaworr, bu birriwolngwoni kore kunak, wanjh birringarlbakkinjerreni. Yika mak birrimangi kuybuk, birrikebkinjeyi werrk wanjh yerre birringarlbakkinjerreni. Wanjh ngurdmi nawu djudju munguyhmunguyh.
ex.xe: In the old days when our ancestors had a toothache, they would gather green plum leaves, start them smoking in the fire, then burn their cheeks with them. Or sometimes they also used banksia cones, lit the end of them, and used that to burn their cheek. Then the toothache would stop.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngandengedjurrudjudmeng.
ex.xe: It poked my feet all over [walking on spiky vegetation].

ex.xv: Yun yikanemdjudmerren!
ex.xe: Don't poke things into your ear!

ng: the noun being spiked is incorporated as a verbal prefix

ex.xv: Bimimdjuhkeng.
ex.xe: She washed his eyes.

ex.xv: Kandimimdjuhkeken.
ex.xe: Eye drops.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Dja bolkkime larrk minj nangale kadjuhme kinga nawern kahyo kore manlabbarlkimuk kahboyo wardi kanbaye kanbun.
ex.xe: But these days no-one gets into the water at the big billabong, there are lots of crocodiles and they would bite and kill us.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Be in water, get into water, shower, bathe.

bw: from either Makassarese colo? 'match' or from Malay or Bajau sulu 'torch'.

ex.xv: Kebkuyeng kumoken, ngahbimbom. Nakang kondanj Kubumi, Kabarrebarre, kebkuyeng kaluk dolobbo djumbung.
ex.xe: I've painted the freshwater crocodile with its long snout. It lives here at Kubumi and Kabrrebarre and has a long snout but the bark I've painted it on is too short.

ex.xv: Ngandidjumdoy.
ex.xe: They call me kakkak (mother's mother/mother's mother's siblings or a woman's daughter's children or a man or woman's sister's daughter's children).

sn.de: Call someone matrilineal grandkin, i.e. the kin term kakkak, ie. mother's mother and mother's mother's siblings and recipricol.
Ritual manager, person in opposite moiety to moiety affiliation of ceremony and also person whose mother is a traditional owner of an estate of land.

ex.xv: Wurlebmeng yiman kumekke djunj bayehbayeng.
ex.xe: He swam and acted like he was swallowing the water bubbles.
ex.so: Quoted in Comrie, Bernard (ed.), ‘Language Contact and Documentation / Contacto lingüístico y documentación’, De Gruyter Mouton, Berlin, 2015, p. 295

sn.de: Make bubbles, for example an animal underwater making bubbles which rise to the surface.

ex.xv: Biddjurdu.
ex.xe: Chopped off finger.

ex.xv: Daddjurdu.
ex.xe: leg amputated/one legged person.

ex.xv: Badjkid kabirrimarnbun dedjdjurduhdjurduh.
ex.xe: They make baskets with round bases.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dedjdjurduhdjurduh.
ex.xe: Fat / nice and fat (buffalo, pig, kangaroo etc).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karrire Kunburray bolkbukkan kadjurrhbume kumekke.
ex.xe: We'll go to Kunburray and I'll show you the waterfall there.

sn.de: Waterfall. This is expressed as a verb in Bininj Kunwok languages.

ex.xv: Mahni yidjurrkdjurrkmeng.
ex.xe: You've just made this too quickly [without care].

sn.de: Do an action quickly, with haste, quick 'slap up' e.g. poor quality artwork.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngakeleminj, ngaye ngamarneyimeng Yirawala, 'Ngudda kanhdjurrkkani bu ngayameng.' Ngaye ngayidduy.
ex.xe: I was scared. I told Yirawala ‘You were pressuring me to spear him’. I was angry.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 198

ex.xv: Yawurrinj, yun yalmo ngurriborrkke, ngurridjurrkwo, ngurriwernhmelmen!
ex.xe: You young men, don't dance quietly, but really get into it and stomp hard!

ex.xv: Birrimarrwe doweng rowk, wanjh birrinang manme kambebmeng, birridjurrkwong.
ex.xe: Everybody was hungry and then they saw the food (tucker truck) arrive and they were all excited.

ex.xv: Ma ngarrbendjurrkwon yawurrinj.
ex.xe: Come on, let's go and stir those guys up, get them going.

ex.xv: Bu korroko dabborrabbolk birrikarrmi kunwardde manbu manmeken bu birridongi dja birringirrihngirrihmi. Makka wanjh djurrubuk manyaw birringeybuni dja manbu manbadjan manwarddebalabbala.
ex.xe: In the old days, people had rocks for pounding and grinding food. They called the smaller rock [held in the hand] 'djurrubuk', and the for the base they used a large flat rock.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Stone hammer or pounder used to grind and pound food, typically on a flat portable stone, bedrock or in grinding hollows.
