ex.xv: Nabininjkobeng bidungi ngalbininjkobeng nuye bimarneyimi kunwok kunwarre. Wanjh nawu narangem benedanginj ngaldaluk wanjh yidduy dulkmey bibuyi ngaldaluk. Dja ngalbu ngaldaluk rlobmeng ngalkohbanj bidjurrukang.
ex.xe: The husband was swearing at his wife, saying bad words to her. The woman's brother got angry at her as well, and went to hit her with a stick. But the woman ran away, and an old woman shielded her.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Take someone and shield them, protect someone.
Grind (to produce a flour or pulp).

ex.xv: Mayhmayh nawu kangeyyo mibbarr kabarndi kore kurrulk kore mankabo wanjh bu djenj kanan wanjh karrolkan kadjuyime namekke djenj.
ex.xe: The bird called mibbarr (white-bellied sea eagle) stays up in trees by the river, then when it sees a fish it flies down and clutches it in its claws.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Press, push, squeeze, massage, grasp, clutch.

ex.xv: Bininj nawu kare manbolh kahdi, bu kadjare kare kore kubolkkimuk wanjh muddika kadjuyme kare.
ex.xe: When a man is on the road and wants to go into town, he sticks out his thumb and hitches.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakka djuymeng muddika wam.
ex.xe: He hitched a lift, he's gone.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Point, stick out one's thumb (when hitchhiking).

ex.xv: Doddorok kabenekukrohrok korlobok dja ngahli doddorok ngalengman kuwardde kani.
ex.xe: The rock pigeon, is similar to the diamond dove, but lives in escarpment country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: A: Bonj ngarrokme. B: Ma yirrokmen!
ex.xe: A: Well I'll go home now. B: Ok you go home.

sn.de: Set out, get going, start walking.

ex.xv: La ngarridokme ngarriyingkihdi. Nawu dokmeninj wanjh diwirrinj.
ex.xe: So we would go ahead and stand there beforehand [before fires were lit]. Those who would go on ahead would just stay there.

ex.xv: Kanmarnedokmedokmen yimmadjngorrkngorrka, kumekke yirrahkenwe kumekke ngarryo.
ex.xe: [song text] You go on ahead for me and get [my] swag; lay it out on the ground there and we will sleep there.

sn.de: Go ahead, go first (leaving others behind), overtake.

ex.xv: Bedda kabirridokme nawu balanda, dja ngad bininj larrk.
ex.xe: The Balanda are getting ahead, but we Aboriginal people, no.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

se.de: Move ahead quickly, get a move on.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji daluk bidjawam nawu muddika kakanemkarrme, bimarneyimeng "Kamak bu yidokmiwe nawu nakohbanj kore kured, kadokme kore kured".
ex.xe: The woman asked the person driving the car "Can you take the old man home? He's heading back home".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birringuni nawu dolek.
ex.xe: In the old days, people used to eat wood grubs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Larvae of various insects which lives in timber including witchetty grubs and various large species of termites.

ex.xv: Benenang kumdolhmeng kinga.
ex.xe: They saw a crocodile come up from under the water.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

ex.xv: Larrk, marrek mardayin birribimbuyi, ya nadjamun and ngarrikerrnge and ngarrikernge ngarridolhmeng djang ngarribimbun, ngarribimbom and ngalyod and njalehnjale.
ex.xe: No, they didn't paint Mardayin ceremony designs, they are sacred, but we, the new generation have appeared and we paint sacred dreamings such as rainbow serpents and what have you.

sn.de: Born, appear as a new generation.

ex.xv: Kurrkabal dolkang kore Injalak kanjdji djangkurrmerrinj wanjh kadjangdi kurrkabal djang.
ex.xe: The Long Tom fish jumped down to the base of Injalak hill and placed itself there, so now there is a Long Tom sacred site there.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kaborrolkan.
ex.xe: The water is boiling, the water/fluid is rising up.

ex.xv: Kunkare Ngalwamud benkang yawkyawk, birriwarlbom kalawan dja mankung. Birriwam, wanjh ngalkudji nang kahboddolkan.
ex.xe: Long ago Ngalwamud took some young women and they went hunting for goanna and bush honey. They went along and one of them saw bees flying around.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 28-31

ex.xv: Kareh kanjdji kahdungyo kahkakyo wanjh karridolkkan kunukka six o'clock.
ex.xe: Maybe when the sun is still down, when it’s night, we’ll get up then - six o’clock.
ex.so: http://bininjgunwok.org.au/2013/batchelor-course-birriyakwong/

sn.de: Get up, arise; from lying down to sitting or sitting to standing, get out of bed.

ex.xv: Madjinbardi ngarridolkkang ngarriwam, ngarridjalwam Pine Creek - kurrenge.
ex.xe: We set off from Madjibardi and went all the way to Pine Creek - on foot.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Set off, set out on a journey.

ex.xv: Yingarna kumdolkkang kore kurrulabeh kore kakbi.
ex.xe: Yingarna came from the ocean in the north.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dolobbo ngabimbun.
ex.xe: I'll do a bark painting.

ex.xv: Bu korroko duninjh nawu dabborrabbolk birrimangi nawu dolobbo kundjurle birrimarnbuni kore birriyoy bu kudjewk.
ex.xe: In the old days people used to get bark and make shelters with it, where they would live in the wet season.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Bark of Eucalyptus tetrodonta used for hundreds of uses, today one of the most popular being for bark paintings.
Extinguish a fire, put out flames.

ex.xv: Dombom.
ex.xe: He turned it off.

ex.xv: Hey nakka nangale wokdombom, hello… wokdombom… hello?
ex.xe: Hey, who disconnected the line, hello… it’s disconnected, hello?
ex.so: Quoted in Garde, Murray, ‘Culture, Interaction and Person Reference in an Australian Language’, John Benjamins Publishing Company,  Amsterdam, 2013, p. 211

sn.de: Turn off something eg. light, radio, engine.

ex.xv: Murrikang birridorrinj.
ex.xe: The cars crashed into one another.

ex.xv: Birrikodjdorrinj.
ex.xe: They hit their own heads (in grief).

sn.de: Hit one object against another, crash against something.

ex.xv: Namarrkon kamarnbun kangurdulme kamayhke dja kandong bininj.
ex.xe: Namarrkon makes thunder and lightning and strikes people.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Marla nakka nabang bu kanbaye dja kandong kunberd ngalengarre.
ex.xe: Scorpions are dangerous if they bite you, they strike you with their tail.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Yo birridoy mandudjmi. Ya birrikang kondanj dabborrabbolk wanjh ngandibukkang ngadberre wanjh ngarrihdoy manih manbu kunwardde.
ex.xe: Yes, they used to pound the green plums. The old old people used to take them here and they showed us and we pounded up that Buchanania obovata fruit.

ex.xv: Dord nakka kahdjangdi kore Malirrku karrkad manberrk kabolkngeyyo Ngilikurrkbung.
ex.xe: There is a head louse sacred site at Malirrku, up in the forest at a place called Ngilikurrkbung.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

se.de: Look for lice, check someone for lice.

ex.xv: Nahni wurdyaw nakka ngabekdordidordi.
ex.xe: That child has curly hair.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Manrakeldordidordi kadukkan kore kundulk bu kabidbun kaddum.
ex.xe: The twining vine wraps around the tree and climbs upwards.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Blengked karridorname.
ex.xe: Let's fold up the blankets.

ex.xv: Birrikurlahdaweyi kurrungbang birrikurlahkurrmi kurlahdayoy kurlahbukmeni. Wanjh birrikurlahdornami.
ex.xe: They would put the hides out in the hot sun, where they would lie until they dried out. Then they would fold them up.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Coil up, lay in coils (e.g. a snake).

ex.xv: Birrikakrey duruk dorrengh birrirey birrikebkani duruk nomi ngalbu ngarrbek wanjh birrinani birrimangi ngalbu ngarrbek birrikani kured.
ex.xe: They would go out at night with a dog, which would smell out an echidna and they would see the echidna it and take it home.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngad dorreng.
ex.xe: Us and everyone else.

ex.xv: Donald dorrengh birrirey school.
ex.xe: They all went to school, Donald too.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: With, accompanied by, together with, including.

ex.xv: Bu kabirridowen daluk bininj wurdwurd wanjh mandubang kunworr kabirrimang kabirrirurrkwolngwon kundolng dorrengh.
ex.xe: If people die, women, men or children, then people get ironwood leaves and use them to ritually cleanse their house with smoke.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Using, with. Indicates the instrument used to carry out an action.

ex.xv: Delek birribarurreni nawu bininj daluk wurdwurd birriborrkkeyi delek dorrengh.
ex.xe: Men, women and children would smear themselves with white clay and dance covered in white clay.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Lobmeng kunnalk dorrengh nalkbuni bu lobmi. Djahdjallobmeng benmarnebebmeng namud ngalengarre.
ex.xe: She was running with tears in her eyes, crying as she ran. She kept running until she came to her family.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ng: This is used in similar senses to 'with' in English, and can mean together with ('with his dog'), using ('speared the fish with a spear') or having/possessing/wearing etc ('meat with lots of fat').

ex.xv: Mongerrk benbenebom daluk bokenh wanjh benbenekukdahkendoy kore baladjdji nawu yibarlirrng wanjh benbenedorrorrkeyi.
ex.xe: Mongerrk hit the two women, put them in his string bag and was pulling them along.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yidjare marnedorrorrke Bridge Autos?
ex.xe: Do you want me to tow you to Bridge Autos?
ex.so: Evans, Nicholas (ed.), How to write Kundjeyhmi, prepared for the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Gagudju Association.

ex.xv: Yekke wanjh kayawdorrorrke kawohre.
ex.xe: In the cool dry season the adult (emu) leads the chicks around.
ex.so: Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : Indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 14

ex.xv: Yiman kabirriwoknan kabirridorrorrke Namayhkurdihwarr Kundedjwarre kabirriwokdi.
ex.xe: Just like when they sing out to the ancestors they tell a long story in Kundedjwarre clan lect and use the word Namayhkurdihwarr.

ex.xv: Ngaye kebdjined ngadoweni.
ex.xe: I was sick with a head cold.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kunubewu benedarrkid. Kunubewu benedoweng.
ex.xe: Maybe the two of them are alive. Maybe they're dead.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University

ex.xv: Dird karrowen.
ex.xe: The moon is waning.

sn.de: Diminish, recede. Used in various constructions where something 'shrinks down to nothing', e.g. the moon waning, water receding, a sore healing.

ex.xv: Karrowen nakka.
ex.xe: He's really laughing hard.

ex.xv: Bakki ngarridowen.
ex.xe: We're starving for tobacco.

ex.xv: Ngakombukdowen.
ex.xe: My throat is dry.

ex.xv: Ngad wanjh karriyakmerren karridowerren. Bedda kabirribalwohrnan.
ex.xe: We will all be dead and gone, and then they will look after it (the country) in turn.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yolk mak kabebme kore ngad kunburrk kadberre bu karridowen dja kore mayh kadowerren kanudmen.
ex.xe: Maggots come out of our bodies when we die, and also when animals die and rot.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nangale dowkkeng?
ex.xe: Who fired that shot?

ex.xv: Nakudji birrikorndowkkeng wanjh mimborledmeng doweng.
ex.xe: They kicked one in the groin [busted his balls], his eyes rolled and he collapsed.
ex.so: Iyuna, James, 'Birriburrinj', Maningrida, N.T.: Maningrida Community Education Centre, 1990.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey kore kudjorlok manlabbarl birrinani djakarna kangun djenj wanjh birridanjbuni djalakkiradj dja bolkkime mako karridulubun karridowkke manbu balanda marnbom.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would go down to the billabongs and see jabirus eating fish, and they would spear them with multi-pronged spears. But these days we shoot them with guns, we fire guns made by non-Indigenous people.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Fire a gun, cause to explode.
Explode, the discharging of a gun, the bursting of a balloon.

se.de: Raise dust, cause an 'eruption' of dust.

re: father-in-law, also MMM(B) and (Z)DDS; FFM(B) and (Z)SSS

ex.xv: Manu Kudjaborrng wanjh kumekke bibayeng ngalyuhyungki doydoy ngaldurlmangkarr.
ex.xe: Kudjaborrng is the place where the ancestral woman my MMM a Durlmnagkarr clanswoman was bitten by the Oenpelli python.

sn.de: Father-in-law; especially reciprical referent term for uncle and nephew when they are in an actual or classificatory in-law relationship but also MMM(B) and (Z)DDS; FFM(B) and (Z)SSS. Amongst dialect groups the class of kin designated as doydoy can vary. In Kundjeyhmi it includes FFM, FMF and MFF.

ex.xv: Ngakebdubbe.
ex.xe: My nose is blocked.

ex.xv: Manberrkdubbe.
ex.xe: Dense forest, difficult to walk through.

ex.xv: Kawarddedubbe.
ex.xe: Rough dissected sandstone country with many large boulders making travel very difficult or impossible.

ex.xv: Ngadjarlandubbe.
ex.xe: I am unable to urinate. [djarlan 'bladder’ dubbe 'blocked']

ex.xv: Yikanemdubbe!
ex.xe: Can't you hear?

ex.xv: Yiberddubbe!

sn.de: Dysfunction of physical or sensory faculty.

se.de: In a densely forested area, in a dead-end or blocked off space.

ng: 'Dubbe' has a similar range of meaning to 'thick' in English, which can mean both dense and impassable (a thick forest), and wide or stubby as opposed to thin and pointy (thick end of the wedge). Both of these senses lead to the idea of something being dysfunctional or lacking acuity (thick-witted, a voice thick with emotion, a thick accent).

ex.xv: Karridubbedong minj bale karriyime.
ex.xe: We can’t pass through, it’s impenetrable, what can we do?

sn.de: Be unable to pass through a place, e.g. because of impenetrable rock or vegetation.

ex.xv: Karridubberrong yiman bolkkime karridi, karridubbedoy wanjh. Dja bu bewh wurd karribalderrehme.
ex.xe: We don’t know which way to go at present, as we are now, we're stuck. We need to make progress.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Be blocked or stuck, be unable to progress with a particular issue.

ex.xv: Med, ngabengdubberranj.
ex.xe: Hang on, I've forgotten (can't think of it).

ex.xv: Ngakebdubberranj.
ex.xe: My nose is blocked.

sn.de: Become dense or blocked, become dysfunctional (of physical senses); become blunt (of cutting blades).

ex.xv: Duberrk nawu doweni wanjh ngalng birrimarnbuni kunkomkenh nawu morlehmorlenj bu Wubarr yoy wanjh birrikomdukkarreni kore kukom bedberre wanjh birriyiborrkkeyi namekke duberrk ngalng dorrengh. Dja bu karrire manberrk karrirednan nawu djuwe karrinan nawern duberrk ngalng.
ex.xe: When snails die and leave their shell behind, women used to make necklaces from the shells and dance with them in the Wubarr Ceremony. If we're walking around the forest, we sometimes see lots of snail shells in the bower of djuwe, the Great Bowerbird
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Land snail, the shell of which was traditionally used to make necklaces or dog collars.

ex.xv: Nawu bininj daluk wurdyaw ngad karrikukburlerri bu bolkkime karridowen wanjh kandidudjeng kore kurorre.
ex.xe: Nowadays when Bininj people die, men, women or children, we're buried in the ground.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngarridudjengi manme.
ex.xe: We used to plant vegetables.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Manme birringeybuni ngadberre, manu, bu kundulk kore barnemdi, dja manu kanjdji dudjendi yiman kayime karrbarda, mankinjdjek, mankongkong kandirakelbukkani.
ex.xe: They would tell us the names of foods, the kinds that grow on trees, and the sorts that are under the ground, like long yams, round yams and Ipomea tubers. They would teach us about the plants.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Aa nakka wam dudmey manimunak!
ex.xe: He went and got a big mob of geese!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu bininj yimeng "Ngaye dudmang rowk ngudberre".
ex.xe: The man said "I'll come and pick you all up" [to take you to the ceremony, etc.]
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Djenj barrirdurdmey kalerrh, bikku, kanbaldjdja.
ex.xe: They got a big mob of fish, long-toms, catfish and eel-tailed catfish.
ex.so: (Kundedjnjenghmi)

sn.de: Get a lot of something, pick up a lot of people etc. Get a big mob of something valuable e.g. game, fish, fruit.

ex.xv: Kukmey kunj mudkinjeng. Wanjh njamduhkeng mey kundurddu kundiw kundayken dja mannjam.
ex.xe: He took the kangaroo and singed its fur off. Then he opened up its belly, taking out its heart, liver, kidneys and stomach.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, 'Bininj Yameng Kunj', Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

sn.de: Puncture, make a hole in something, penetrate.
Punctured (eg. a tyre), have a hole, container with leakage.

ex.xv: Karrimang nawu kunj karribardngorrowke karribiddukkan.
ex.xe: We get a kangaroo and break its leg joints, then tie its limbs together (to facilitate cooking).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Tie up, wrap with string/rope or cloth, tie a knot.

ex.xv: Wanjh yimankek birrikuyinkelelobmerrinj Ngalyod bennanganang kunberd bendukkang rowk.
ex.xe: Then they tried to run away in fear but the Rainbow Serpent was watching them and she wrapped her tail around them.
ex.so: Quoted in Carroll, Peter, 'The old people told us : verbal art in Western Arnhem Land' (Thesis), University of Queensland, 1996

sn.de: Grab with arms and hold tightly, coil around (e.g. python).

ex.xv: Balanda yimarnekarrewarrewon wanjh ngundukkan djamun.
ex.xe: If you break the Balanda law, the police will put you in handcuffs.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

se.de: Tie something onto oneself, put something on (cloth etc), coil oneself up (snake etc).

ex.xv: Manburrba yidedjdukkarrimen!
ex.xe: Tie up your naga!

ex.xv: Duberrk nawu doweni wanjh ngalng birrimarnbuni kunkomkenh nawu morlehmorlenj bu Wubarr yoy wanjh birrikomdukkarreni kore kukom bedberre wanjh birriyiborrkkeyi namekke duberrk ngalng dorrengh.
ex.xe: When snails die and leave their shell behind, women used to make necklaces from the shells, tie them around their necks and dance with them in the Wubarr Ceremony.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Benebokenh Ngalyod benemhwam kore wadjbudbeh benewam Katherine Gorge Nitmiluk. Bu benehrey benehdjarrkrey darnkih wernkih wanjh benedukkarrinj kunbardmo berrewoneng benebardmodukkarrinj kore kanjdji manbu kukku kahbodjurrhbume kore kunred kabolkngeyyo Marlkawo.
ex.xe: Two Rainbow Serpents came from the sea to Katherine Gorge, Nitmiluk. They travelled together very close to each other, then they entwined their bodies under the waterfall at the place called Marlkawo.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Birribuyika minj balemane birribebmeninj, bonj birriruy birridoweng
ex.xe: Some of the others had no where to get away and so in the end were burned, writhing to death.

sn.de: Tie self into a coil (snakes), entwine, writhe.

ex.xv: Benewam dja benengalkeng namekbe donkey yaw dukkayindi kuberrk kore manbolh.
ex.xe: They went and found the young donkey tied up outside in the street.
ex.so: Etherington, Steve, ‘Jesus doweng dja yawoyhdolkkang’, Bible Society Australia, 2011, p. 1 [From Mark 11:4]

sn.de: Bound up, tied up with string/rope.

ex.xv: Nabulanj wam kore kured bidulkkimey Nawakadj nawu dulkkiyoy wanjh bikang kore clinic.
ex.xe: Nabulanj went home, picked up Nawakadj who was lying there ill and took him to the clinic.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Sick. A verb prefix appended to words such as 'dulkkingalme' (start to get sick).

ex.xv: Minj nangale kawarddeburriwe, karrulkbakke, manme kangun dja kabongun kukku kumekke kunred. Marndi bedmanwali kabirridulkkimankan.
ex.xe: Nobody throws rocks, breaks the trees, eats the fruit or drinks the water in that place. Otherwise they would get sick themselves [like the Ancestors who got sick there].
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 156

ex.xv: Wernhdulmukminj nawu mandjewk.
ex.xe: The rain got very heavy.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Kohbahkohbanj birriyolyolmi ngadberre, ngandimarneyimi, “Mahni mankarre mandulmuk.”
ex.xe: The old people used to tell us, and they would say, "This is the really important Law".
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngardduk kundjak kahdulmukmen.
ex.xe: My sickness is getting worse.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Birrihdulubuni nawu nganabbarru djarrang dorrengh.
ex.xe: They would shoot the buffalo from horseback.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dengedulubom.
ex.xe: Punctured tyre/foot.

ex.xv: Madjanngalkkubeh Yidakdakbeh kawanjdjadduluburren kure Djabulu.
ex.xe: [Heading upstream] from Madjanngalkku and Yidakdak there is a confluence of small tributaries at Djabulu.

ex.xv: Birndu kangun dumdum dja yehyeng nawu kayo kare kore kukku kukadjid dja kore kubuk.
ex.xe: The glossy ibis eats beetles and all kinds of things that live in the water, the sand and the shallows.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Beetle, various kinds of scarab beetles and darkling beetles.

ex.xv: Dunbuhmanj nakka kanjkimuk kanjmak bu ngarringun.
ex.xe: The black bream has a lot of meat on it, it's good eating.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Sooty grunter, also known as black bream.

uv: Kundedjnjenghmi syn.= nakerdmi, Kundjeyhmi= nakerdmi, kalarrk

ex.xv: Kunwarre benhmarneyimi bedberre, benhdungi bedberre.
ex.xe: He used to talk hard to them, go crook at them.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Speak roughly, swear, get angry with someone, scold.

ex.xv: Minj karrire kurrenge dja dungbangminj. Dja bonj karribawon kaluk malaywi karrire bu karrungnelk.
ex.xe: We can't go on foot now, it's too hot. Let's leave it until tomorrow, in the early part of the day.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Become very hot and sunny (of weather), get towards the middle of the day when the sun is hottest.

ex.xv: Dungbidbom.
ex.xe: It’s morning.

sn.de: Sun rising up (over the course of the morning).

re: movement of the sun across the sky
sn.de: Movement of the sun across the sky.

ex.xv: Werrk dungwam.
ex.xe: Hurry up, time is gone.

ex.xv: Yika mak kabindimunkewe bu kundung kamhdungre kabindimunkewe kabirrihdirri kabirridjalre yika munguyhmunguyh minj kabirrimdurndeng.
ex.xe: When the time comes (for recess at school) and the teachers send them out to play, some of them just run off, they don't come back.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Larrk, dungwarreminj. Kaluk malaywi kanere.
ex.xe: No. It's too late today. Tomorrow we will go, the three of us.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 60-63

sn.de: Get too late (usually used in the past tense, as in “it’s too late now”).

ex.xv: Nakudji wam djangkang, nang dungyibmeng wanjh keleminj.
ex.xe: A man went out hunting, saw that the sun had set and became frightened.

ex.xv: Ngadedjmang ngayolyolme Yingarna daluk ngalu kure kumdanginj kadungyibme, benkang wurdyaw nawern, beyken ngorrkang wurdyaw.
ex.xe: I'll tell you a story about Yingarna, a woman who come here from the west (where the sun sets). She carried many children, in a large number of string bags.
ex.so: Thompson Yulidjirri, quoted in Hamby, Louise (ed.), Twined Together: Kunmadj Njalehnjaleken, Injalak Arts and Crafts, Gunbalanya, 2005, p. 26

ex.xv: Wurdurd ngurrina ngaleng kabengkan kaborrkke duninj.
ex.xe: Look you kids she knows how to dance the proper way.

ex.xv: Woybukki duninj
ex.xe: Really true.

ex.xv: Korroko duninjh.
ex.xe: In the distant past, in the old days, in the Ancestral past

ex.xv: Yimdurnde!
ex.xe: Come back here!

ex.xv: Korroko birridurndi.
ex.xe: They've already gone back.

ex.xv: Minj karridurndeng wanjh.
ex.xe: There's no turning back [we need to go forward, make these ideas happen].
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

se.de: Take or bring someone back, take or bring something back for someone.

ng: In Kune dialect, there is no use of the directional'-m-' marker as in Kunwinjku and Kuninjku. Thus, in Kune, yidurnde! may mean either 'come back' or 'go back'. The meaning is made clear by the context.

ex.xv: Ngarrbenbenedurndiweng kured.
ex.xe: We took the two of them back home.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

ex.xv: Manbu Adjumarllarl nawu bininj kabirriwohrnan, wanjh birridurndiweng bu mandjewk 2012 ni, ba bu bedman bininj kabirrikarrme, dja kabirrinahnan, minj mak kabirriyawoyhnahnan nawu Shire.
ex.xe: The Adjumarllarl store is managed by Aboriginal people, it was retured to them in 2012 so that they could run it themselves. The Shire won't be running it any more.
ex.so: Adjumarllarl Aboriginal Corporation community newsletter, 2015

sn.de: Give back, return ownership to someone.

ex.xv: Yidurndiwemen kunkudji karribekkan.
ex.xe: Rewind it and let's listen to it one more time.

ex.xv: Ngarrikanjbun ngarrikanjdurnme ngarrikurrme dja kunbalem ngarrikinje kore nabuyika banikin wanjh ngarrimang manbu kunkanj dja kunbalem ngarrirawon wanjh ngarringun.
ex.xe: We pound and knead the [pieces of cooked stingray] flesh, then we put it aside and cook the fat in a different drum. Then we take the flesh and the fat, mix them and eat it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Njalekenh birridurrinj?
ex.xe: What were they fighting about?

ex.xv: Bu korroko ni bininj ngad karrikukburlerri birridjareni mankung wanjh birrirey birridjuhmi kore mankabo birridalkdurrkmangi kore mankod kore Wakkewakken wanahwam.
ex.xe: In the old days when Aboriginal people like us wanted bush honey, they would go into the river and pull out water weeds near the base of paperbark trees where the Wakkewakken spirits resided [an increase ritual].
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kundulk ngadedjmaddurrkme.
ex.xe: I'll pull out the trees by the roots.
ex.so: Quoted in Carroll, Peter, 'The old people told us : verbal art in Western Arnhem Land' (Thesis), University of Queensland, 1996

ex.xv: Wardi yirrurrkmen Kamarrang.
ex.xe: Try and get Kamarrang to go with you.

sn.de: Attempt to obtain someone as a companion.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngahdurrkmirri Katherine ngahdjirridjbuni mako ngabenhmarnedurrkmirri army.
ex.xe: I was working in Katherine cleaning guns, working for the army.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

re: ground mark used as directional sign

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrini kore manbehbeberrk, bu birribolkbawoni kore birrihyoy, wanjh durruyuk birrikurrmi. Kaluk nawu birribuyika bininj birrirey bindiyawani kore birrihyoy, wanjh birringalkeyi durruyuk. Namekke yiman benbengdayhkeyi, dja bolkmulewani kore birrirey. Wanjh mandjad bindimunkekadjungi dja bindimarnebebmi.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors used to live in the bush. When they left the place they were camping, they would leave a mark on the ground. Then when others found their campsite, they would see the mark, which would let them know which direction people had gone in. They could follow them and come directly to where they were.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Durruyuk kabirriyorrohme ba kabirriburrbun bale kabirrire.
ex.xe: They make a ground mark by dragging their feet in a line so other people will know where they have gone.

sn.de: Ground mark made by dragging the foot to create a line indicating the direction of travel. This is done when departing a campsite so others who arrive later will know in which direction to go.

ex.xv: Waw, nganbayeng duruk!
ex.xe: Ah, the dog bit me!

ex.xv: Kabirrire kabirribekkan kangokme duruk bu kangalke, ngalekke ngarrbek.
ex.xe: They walk along and hear the dog bark when it finds an echidna.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, 'Nakudji wurdyaw bibayeng duruk', in 'Kunwinjku Stories', Oenpelli Literature Production Centre 1982

ex.xv: Korroko duruk birrikebkani, nomi nawu kalawan, birribuni.
ex.xe: In the old days they used to take a dog when they went hunting, it would sniff out a goanna and they would kill it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Dog, camp dog, wild dog (as opposed to dingo).

ex.xv: Kubolkduwa bukka.
ex.xe: That place is associated with the Duwa moiety.
ex.so: John Mawurndul in ''I am the old and the new': the stories behind the masterworks of John Mawurndjul', www.theguardian.com, 10/07/2018.

sn.de: One of the two patrilineal moiety names, the other being yirridjdja.

ex.xv: Delek nakka kukbele ngarrimang duyh yika nguk ngarrimang.
ex.xe: We can collect white clay when it’s dried out and powdery, and also when it’s wet.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kab ngarre ngarrnan
ex.xe: Let’s go and have a look
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 148

ex.xv: Ngad kabbal konda warddeyak.
ex.xe: We are plains people, there is no stone country here.

ex.xv: Wanjh daluhdaluk kabirrimang kubba bedberre wanjh kabbal kabirrire kabirriyawan ngalmangiyi kabirrimang.
ex.xe: Then women take their turtling sticks and go out onto the floodplain to find turtles [by poking the mud with the sticks].
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kuhni bu kunkare korroko duninjh manbu kabbala Mangkadjarra birrimwam nawu Malayu birribidbom wadjbud kore Nalaberrberr dja mak kore kubolkbubuyika wadjbud.
ex.xe: A long time ago people came here by boat from Macassar, those Malay people arrived on the beach at Nalaberrberr and other beaches too.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

re: place name in Kumadderr river region

ex.xv: Korroko bininj birrini kunred Kabbari / Nawu kunborrk birrikarmi birriborrkkeyi (Wildflower Band, Kabbari (A Place Called Kabbari) 2009) \xe A long time ago people lived on this land Kabbari / They used to have special ceremonies, singing and dancing in that place (Wildflower Band, Kabbari / A Place Called Kabbari, 2009)
Dabborrabbolk nawu birriyuhyungkih birriyolyolmi “Ngalih Ngalyod benbom bininj nawu kumekbe kunred birrihni Kabbari, bu birriborrkkeyi, dja birrihwayini”.
ex.xe: Our ancestors used to say “Ngalyod (the Rainbow Serpent) killed all those people at Kabbari, as they danced and sang”.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: This is the name of an estate (the kunngeybadjan or ‘big name’) which comprises a complex of sites including many djang where the Goomadeer River flows out of the Arnhem Land plateau south of Mamardawerre and Mandilbareng outstations. Associated site names include Namarnde Kalurlkan, Nadjardenj, Nanjiwk, Kalerrh Kumanem, Kunngulukki, Meleyengkobarnrungi, Wurrbbarn, Kunyikuymi, Yimalannga, Kanjarladjkendi, Kabuludjidjmini, Bomarranj, Yiwoban, Yenemarrbara and Nakorrmohkorrmo. Kabbari is best known for the story which concerns Ngalyod’s displeasure with a crying child.

ex.xv: Nahni kabbay, kabirrimang kore kundulkbarndad beh, mandubang kundulk. Wanjh kabirriwirrkme, yerreh wanjh kabirrikinje kore kunak bu kabelebelbme kabirrimarnbun yiman kayime borndok, karramalk, dja wirlam.
ex.xe: Ironwood resin is extracted from the roots of the ironwood tree. People scrape the bark off, then heat the wood over a fire [until the resin comes out]. They use it to stick things together, for example in making spearthrowers, stone axes, and bark rafts.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Resin from ironwood tree roots used to haft axeheads to handles and spear points to their shafts (as well as other uses). The roots of the ironwood tree Erythrphloeum chlorostachys are dug up and broken off. They are then heated over a fire and the resin or gum will exude. The exudate is collected on a stick or rock until it has been exhausted. The resin is highly toxic and the extraction is conducted away from domestic areas.

ex.xv: Manih bus kamrlobme manu mankebkabbungurr.
ex.xe: The bus is coming, the vehicle with the flat front (literally "with a nose like a goby").
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunkare bu bininj ngad daluk dja wurdwurd bu kundjak benmangi yiman kebdjirned, wanjh birrirey birrinani kabo wanjh birrimangi birrikani kukku birridjuhkeyi birribonguni wanjh birrimakmeni.
ex.xe: In the old days, when any Bininj man, woman or child was sick with something like a cold, then they would go looking for green ants, put them in water and drink the mixture and then they’d get better.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Ngarradj nawu kabo nakka, Yarriwurrkkarr, yiman kayime ngad.
ex.xe: The white corella is from the Green Ant matry, Yarriwurrkkarr, just like us.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Green ant. Symbol or totem of the matry (kunkoymud) yarriwurrkarr.

re: outstation in the Liverpool River region

ex.xv: Kabulwarnamyo makka kunred kabolkngeyyo, kore bolkkime bininj kabirrihni. Kerrekenh birribolkngeybuni Norne, wanjh birringeyborledkeng manu kunbolkngey duninjh birribolkngeykurrmeng Kabulwarnamyo. Dja manbu Norne makka djang, mankung djang. Korroko dabborrabbolk birriyimi.
ex.xe: Kabulwarnamyo is the name of a country, where there are currently people living. People used to call it Norne for a while, but they changed the name back to its proper place name, Kabulwarnamyo. 'Norne' is the name of a djang [in that area], it's a sacred area for honey. That's what the old people told us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Kabulwarnamyo, an outstation in the upper Liverpool River region.

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan bimarneyimeng wurdyaw ngalengarre “Yimray kabun”.
ex.xe: The mother said to her child "Come here, I'll hold you".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngad bininj ngarridaddornamerren kumekke wurdyaw ngarriyawkurrme kore kundad ngadberre bu ngarrikabun.
ex.xe: We cross our legs and put our young children on our lap, and hold them like that.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Hold a child close, e.g. on one's lap or lying down with an arm around the child.

ex.xv: Manimunak kakabun wirlarrk.
ex.xe: The magpie goose is sitting on eggs.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kaddakaddambu nakka.
ex.xe: He’s a man of few words.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yika bininj nawu wokkaddumbu minj kawokdi kunwern. Kundjalkudji bu kadjalwokdi wanjh kakudjihme.
ex.xe: Some people are very quiet, they don't talk a lot. They'll just say one thing and stop.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Not talking very much, quiet, taciturn.
Up high, at the top, up, above, in the sky.

ex.xv: Kaddum yiwokdi.
ex.xe: Talk loudly.

ex.xv: Kambirlikadjung birndu.
ex.xe: The mosquitoes are attracted to the light.

ex.xv: Karribolhkadjung.
ex.xe: Let's follow this track.

ex.xv: Ngarrbenyikadjung marradjirikenh.
ex.xe: We follow their custom of the Marradjiri ceremony.

ex.xv: Kabikadjung.
ex.xe: She is in labour.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Used idiomatically in constructions referring to labour and labour pain during childbirth. The person is the object of the verb.

se.de: Follow one another, be of the same tribe.

sn.de: Ackowledgement of receipt, said on being given something.

ex.xv: Kondakah.
ex.xe: On this side.

sn.de: Mother's mother and reciprocal MM,MMB,ZDD,ZDS,FF and also possibly MMBSD, MMBSS. In some dialects of Bininj Kunwok, this term can also refer to one’s FF(Z) and reciprocal.

Term of reference or address for someone in a cross-cousin spouse or spouse's sibling class who is an actual or intended in-law. Kinship classes include certain cross-cousins (FZC, MBC) or second cross cousin (e.g. MMBDD/MFZDS, FFZSD/FMBSS, also a FZDDD/MMMBS).

ex.xv: Birrikakrey duruk dorrengh birrirey birrikebkani duruk nomi ngalbu ngarrbek wanjh birrinani birrimangi ngalbu ngarrbek birrikani kured.
ex.xe: They would go out hunting at night with a dog, which would smell out an echidna and they would see the echidna it and take it home.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Walk around at night, travel at night.

ex.xv: Kala makka kabirrimang kundulkbarndad manbu mandjurndum, dja mandjum wirdilwirdil, dja mak wirndilk, mandjum dja manmim. Wanjh kabirrikinje kunngobarn dorrengh.
ex.xe: People get dye colour from the roots of the Pogonolobus reticulatus bush, from the bulb of Haemadorum brevicauli grasses and also Haemodorum coccineum, bulb and seeds. Then they cook these things up with pandanus [to dye it].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: "Line" kakarrme kure kunngarlabak. Kangarlabakyirriyo kala kala.
ex.xe: [The short-eared rock wallaby] has a line running along its cheeks. The [fur] colour alternates along the cheeks.

sn.de: Colour, or colour producing substances such as natural dye plants used for weaving.

re: place name in East Alligator river region

ex.xv: Kabolkngeyyo bu kunbolkngeybininj Kalarabirr Djowkkeng.
ex.xe: The Aboriginal name for the area is Kalarabirr Djowkkeng.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Cahill's Crossing [downstream from], where the road from Jabiru to Kunbarlanja crosses the East Alligator river, and the surrounding area. The place name literally means 'Where the old woman crossed (the river)', and refers to an Ancestral woman who did 'women's business' at Manbiyarra ('Border Store area') on the east side of the river, before crossing over and placing herself (kurrmerrinj) in Manilakarr country on the west side of the river.The word 'kalarabirr' usually implies that a woman has had many children, but this woman did not have any children.
Eastern curlew (may also include grey plover and oriental plover).

ex.xv: Konda dalukwern, daluk boken, bininj nakka, nuye nabininjkobeng berrewoneng. Kareh kalidjan belinj kareh, ngalbininjkobeng bokenh, nabininjkobeng nakudji.
ex.xe: Here is group of women (in a painting), they are his wives, he is the husband of the two women. Maybe they are of kalidjan and belinj subsection, two wives and one husband.

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety

ex.xv: Kaluk yerre (Kunwinjku) / kaluk rerre (Kuninjku).
ex.xe: Later, after.

ex.xv: Kaluk nan.
ex.xe: See you later.

ex.xv: Bu korroko duninjh nawu karrkkanj nakka bininjni kaluk yerre mayhmayh yimerranj.
ex.xe: A long time ago the Brown Falcon used to be a man, he only became a bird afterwards.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Morlehmorlenj bindikani nawu nanikud kore kabbal birriwohrey birridalknguni. Kaluk bu wolewoleh bindikani bindingimowoni kore yard.
ex.xe: Women used to take the goats onto the floodplain to eat grass. Then in the afternoon they would herd them back into the yards.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nahni kunj kangeyyo ngorlomorroh, kaluk kadi yiman kayime kore kubolkdarleh.
ex.xe: That kangaroo is called "ngorlomorroh" (Northern nail-tail wallaby), and it lives in dry areas.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kaluk bu dungyibmeng, wanjh benekaymi beneyimi 'Nakomdudj, Nakomdudj' kaluk minj benkaymimayi.
ex.xe: Then when the sun was setting, they started calling out 'Nakomdudj, Nakomdudj' but he didn't call back to them.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Karrkanj Yimerranj’ in ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T, 2005, p. 88

sn.de: And, but. Used in senses where one piece of information is added to another, or follows from another. 'And furthermore'.
Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Kamudjkenhyo kumekke, marrek ngarray ba.... helicopter kanire maitbi Kamarrang ngudda banbanibukkan. Ngalyangdoh.
ex.xe: They are rainbow serpents, dreaming beings in the landscape, we can't go there... but perhaps by helicopter I could show you and Kamarrang, that woman there, Ngalyangdoh.
ex.so: Djnj

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Kamarrkawarn makka kunred kabolkngeyyo kunbolkngeyyaw, dja manbu kunbolkngeykimuk ngarringeybun Kodwalewale.
ex.xe: Kamarrkawarn is the name of a place, a smaller locality which is part of the larger estate called Kodwalewale.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Place and outstation community in Kodwalewale estate on the Mann River.

ex.xv: Kondanj nakurrngh ke kunred, ngarrewoneng 'kambani'.
ex.xe: This is your cousin's country which I hold with him in a 'company' relationship.

sn.de: Sharing relationship usually referring to land ownership jointly held by members of different clans.

ex.xv: Yimray ngangalkeng mankung, nanih mankung kahdi kure mikambe.
ex.xe: Come, I've found this honey hive here in this termite mound.

sn.de: Termite mound. Sections broken off can be used as cooking stones in ground ovens.

ex.xv: Kabarlekidyo kambuk djang kayo.
ex.xe: At Kabarlekidyo there is a kambuk crab sacred site.

ex.xv: Kamerlem yaw dorreng.
ex.xe: She's pregnant (with a child).

ex.xv: Kamerlem wanjh kadangmarrhmire.
ex.xe: [The bud] grows large and then opens.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Ready to open, about to open (of buds, seed pods etc).

ex.xv: Yoh kabolkdadjme kumekke bedberre kondabeh bedberre Marlbbarrdji bedman Kamulkbarn beh, bad nakka kabirriyiraworren.
ex.xe: Yes, the boundary for them, the Marlbbarrdji clan is on this side and the Kamulkbarn are this way [indicates downstream], but they all joined together [shared their land].

sn.de: Name of a patriclan with two discontiguous estates (and lineages), one in north-west Arnhem Land and the other near the mouth of the Liverpool River.

ex.xv: A: Yidjare marnekan? B: Bonj, kamak, ngakan.
ex.xe: A: Do you want me to take it for you? B: No, it's OK, I'll take it.

ex.xv: Dolobbo kabirridadjke kabirrimkan kore Injalak Arts Centre kumekke kabirribimbun kabirriweykan kabenwon kunwardde.
ex.xe: They cut bark and bring it to Injalak Arts Centre, where they paint it and get money for it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Take or carry. When used with -m, i.e. ngamkan, yimkan etc. it means 'bring' towards the speaker.

ex.xv: Mandirnku makka manme ngarringun. Bu korroko dabborrabbolk birrimangi mandirnku, wanjh birridjuhkeyi kore kukku bu yoy kunkodjke dja kunbarnangarra. Wanjh birriwayhkeyi kore kukkubeh, wanjh yerre birridongi bu birrimarnbuni yiman kandidjdjawa manlod, wanjh birringuni.
ex.xe: Cycad [seeds] are a food that we eat. In the old days people used to gather them, then soak them in water for a night and a day. Then they would get them out of the water, pound them and make a kind of flour loaf to eat.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bininj nawu nakang kondah kunred.
ex.xe: A local Indigenous person.
ex.so: Adjumarllarl Aboriginal Corporation community newsletter, 2015

ex.xv: Kebkuyeng kumoken, ngahbimbom. Nakang kondanj Kubumi, Kabarrebarre.
ex.xe: I’ve painted the freshwater crocodile, the one with the long snout. It is from a site here at Kubumi and Kabarrebarre.
ex.so: Mick Kubarkku, interview with Margie West and Murray Garde, Yikarrakkal Outstation, 1994

ex.xv: Nawu wayarra nakka namarnde mam ngarringeybun. Wayarra kabirriyime kabirringeybun nawu bininj birrikang koyek nawu nahni ngad Kunwinjku karriwokdi.
ex.xe: 'Wayarra' is a bad spirit. Our word for it is 'mam', but 'wayarra' is what other Kunwinjku speaking people from the east call it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Nakudji wurdyaw dingihdi kore kuwarddekebkale bu darnkih kukwarrhmeninj wanjh bu nganang ngakangebarrhmeng.
ex.xe: A kid was standing at the edge of a cliff and was about to fall down. When I saw that I got a big shock.

ex.xv: Bu bininj kabinan daluk wanjh nawu bininj kakangebarrhme.
ex.xe: When the man sees her, he's amazed and overjoyed [because he hasn't seen her for a long time etc.]
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Get a shock, be amazed, be overcome with sudden emotion.

ex.xv: Karrikangemak.
ex.xe: We are happy.
ex.so: Title of a book by James Iyuna, Maningrida, N.T.: Maningrida Community Education Centre, 1991

ex.xv: Kadjalbodelengkurrme kabongerdkendi wanjh.
ex.xe: The water goes in until it is full.

ex.xv: Ngarduk mawa bu ngarriwam yibengkan bu Kunabibi ngerdkenyoy ngarriwam Namimkabo mani kunrurrk ngarriyoy, kunrurrk. Ngarriyoy kunkare ngarriwam Kunabibi ngerdkenyoy ngarriyikani.
ex.xe: My father’s father came with us here when we slept in this cave here at Namimkabo when we were travelling as part of the Kunabibi, taking the ceremony a long time ago. [literally: the Kunabibi was pregnant with us, i.e. the Rainbow Serpent holds the ceremony participants in her belly when they participate in the ceremony]
ex.so: Jimmy Kalarriya

sn.de: Carry in belly, said when the Rainbow Serpent or other mythological beings swallow people and carry them inside themselves. When people participate in a ceremony they are also seen as being carried in the belly of the Rainbow Serpent.
Nephew or niece, a man's ZS, ZD.

ex.xv: Wurdurd kanjdji, ngurrikengemen!
ex.xe: You boys look down (at the ground) and be fearful.

ex.xv: Dulklorrkkelorrkken daluk, ngalkanemkuyeng, kururrk kayo. Kurrulk, kadjalyo bu kurrulk kawodjbakme yibengkan kayo kanjdjikanjdjibeh nomo kurrulk, kanjdjikanjdji kurrulk bu kayo.
ex.xe: The dulklorrkkelorrkken female spirit being has long ears and she lives inside. She lives in the tree, such as a tree which has a broken trunk, you know, she sleeps inside the tree, not up in it, but inside the hollow log.

sn.de: Downstream, lowlands, area towards the coast or lower down in a drainage basin.

ex.xv: Yimankek bu wolewoleh yimerrangeni ngarrirey wanjh kanjdjikanjdji kunukka kore njamed manlabbarl kunekke djenj ngarrirey.
ex.xe: Sometimes in the afternoons we would go down to the billabong, we would go fishing there.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Lowlands, down near a water course.
Brother-in-law, wife, husband, sister-in-law, MBD, MBS, MMBDS, MMBDD.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw bolknang kahwake kardab kore kakkak keyohkeyoy.
ex.xe: The child looked around and saw a spider crawling around where his grandmother was sleeping.
ex.so: Mangiru, Faith, ‘Kakkak dja Wurdyaw Benewam Mankinjdjek’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, 1976

ex.xv: Kahre:: Bakkarda kabawon kunnguya na-Kardbamken kabolkbawon kamngimen wali Wurrbbarnbuluken wanjh kangimen.
ex.xe: They [the Nakorrkko, referred to by a non-plural subject prefix] kept going for a long way and they leave the Bakkarda yikurrumu estate, that is namely the Kardbam clan estate and then in turn they go into the Wurrbbarnbulu clan estate, then they entered that one.

sn.de: Name of a patriclan with two discontiguous estates and lineages, one of yirridjdja moiety to the north-east of the Arnhem Land plateau and another of mixed moieties in north-west Arnhem Land in the King River region.

ex.xv: Kunyarl ngandengekardmey.
ex.xe: The fishing line caught up my foot.

ex.xv: Wakkidj dulkkardmey.
ex.xe: The fishing line caught up/entangled the tree.

ex.xv: Bolkki nganmarneyimeng, "Ngamre kure ngudda." Kare kurrinj.
ex.xe: Today he said,"I'll come over to your place." Maybe he was lying.

sn.de: Maybe, perhaps, 'I don't know' (said in a high falling tone).

ex.xv: Marla kayo kore kunmarlaworr manwern kayo dja kore mandulkkare karridulkwayhke karrinan marla kahyo dja kore kunkod mankare kabirribawon wanjh marla kare kangimen kanjdji kayo nawu marla yika djodj.
ex.xe: Scorpions live where there are lots of leaves, and when we lift up old logs we see scorpions there. If we leave old paperbark around, then scorpions go under there and live there, scorpions or centipedes.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Mani mankare rerre manu ngadjalngeybom bolkkime.
ex.xe: This (tree) is the same one as that which I just named just now.

sn.de: Same one, same as just mentioned.

se.de: Same place as before or as previously mentioned.

ng: takes a pronominal prefix but in third person singular will take a noun class prefix

ex.xv: Bonj, nawarre, kareminj.
ex.xe: Leave it, it's no good, it's too old.

ex.xv: Bininj kabirrire Karrik, kabirriyawan manbiri. Bu kabirringalke wanjh kabirridanjbun wanjh kunyarl kadororrke dja manbu harpoon kakaridi kore kungalng ngalengarre.
ex.xe: People go to the Garig area (on the coast north of Gunbalanya) and hunt sea turtles. When they find them, they spear them and the turtle pulls the harpoon string behind it while the harpoon stays stuck in its shell.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrinami kebbord kore kukeb bedberre. Kaluk birrimangi kunj kundadmurrng bu bindikebdjudmi, wanjh birrikebkaridi munguyh.
ex.xe: I’ve painted the Djidjnguk spirit, the one who eats fish. You can see here the fish he's got stuck on the end of his spear, including an eel he is holding up. The eel is a kind of fish. You can see the fish he has caught [in the painting]
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Stuck in an object, penetrated into object, stay stuck into something e.g. a hook in the mouth of fish, a spear in the body of prey. Used in verbs such as karidi (be stuck into) and karikarrme (have something stuck, e.g. on the end of one's spear).

se.de: Have something stuck or penetrated on an object (such as a spear).

sn.de: Yellow or mustard-coloured ochre; also may be used to describe things similarly coloured (tan, orangey yellow, mustard colours).

ex.xv: Djirrihdiddid kakukyime yiman kaldurrk dja ngahli ngalkukyahwurd.
ex.xe: The kingfisher looks like a blue-winged kookaburra, but has a smaller body.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ur: Kune = korrow-korrow, Kundjeyhmi = barradja, kaluhkalurrku, kaldukaldurrkku
Kunwinjku = kurrkabal, wurrkabal; Kun-dedjwarre clan lect= ngalkebkarlerrh, Kundjeyhmi = burrukulung

ex.xv: Ngalbu karndjawarra ngalkka ngalengman kore kurrula kadjalyo. Bu kurrula kabobidbun wanjh minj karrinan ngalbu karndjawarra.
ex.xe: Mud crabs just stay near the sea. At high tide, we don't see them though.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Mud crab of salt water habitat.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune = kurruk, Kunwinjku = balalah, karnubirr

ex.xv: Ngaleng kanbukkang yehyeng rowk kahbimdi karramalk kunbarlkbu kundjakkorl ngalmangiyi dja kalawan nawu karrihngun namak mayh nadjalwern.
ex.xe: She [Yingarna] established and taught Aboriginal people about all aspects of our culture such as the use of axes, fire drills and edible animals such as long-necked turtles, goannas and all kinds of good edible foods.

sn.de: Stone axe with hafted wooden handle.
Mother, mum. This is the vocative term, used when talking to one's mother.

ex.xv: Kore kunred Djurlka kore kubolkmayirrkulidj kunred ngaye ngayime karrardwarrekenh bukka Djodj kadjangdi.
ex.xe: At Djurlka in Mayirrkulidj clan country, which is my mother’s country, there is a centipede sacred site.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: One’s mother’s country (or mother’s brother’s country).
Kind of jungle vine, used for making fish traps or armbands and in recent times for the frames of pandanus sculptures.

ur: Kundjeyhmi,Kunwinjku = midjakkurr, Kuninjku = manbarddedde, Kundedjnjenghmi = barddedde

ex.xv: Karrbarda ngarriwilkdeng wanjh ngarringun.
ex.xe: We cook the long yam in the ashes and then eaten.

ex.xv: Bolkki kabirriborrkke karrbarda.
ex.xe: They'll dance 'yam style' dances today.

sn.de: Name of a kunborrk song series sung by Bruce and Barndanj Nabegeyo from Kunbarlanja.
Comb crested jacana (also called lily-trotter or Jesus bird); walks on floating plants. Associated with yirridjdja moiety and the Yabburdurrwa ceremony.

ex.xv: Nawu benuk kadjangdi kore karrikad kore duruk bokenh benemdolkkang benemwam kunred kabolkngeyyo Benukkadjang.
ex.xe: The bush turkey has a sacred site to the west, where the two ancestral dogs came from, a place called Benukkadjang.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yidjalay karrihkarri yibebme.
ex.xe: Keep going west and you'll get there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawakadj dja Nabulanj benewam djenj benehdanjbuni kubbunj benehkani. Nawakadj danjbuni, dja Nabulanj nawu bimarnekarrikmi kubbunj.
ex.xe: Nawakadj and Nabulanj went spearing fish with a canoe. Nawakadj did the spearing, and Nabulanj paddled the canoe for him.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj Dja Nabulanj Benewam Djenj’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre [no date recorded].

sn.de: Paddle a boat with an oar or paddle.

re: swim with fins or fish tail
sn.de: Swim by means of fins or a fish tail.

ex.xv: Nakudji bininj kabimarneyime nabuyika bininj "Ngudda wanjh ngalih daluk yimang". Dja nawu nabuyika bininj kayime "Larrk, minj ngamang". Wanjh nungka kayime "Karriyimen malehmalel ngayimeng".
ex.xe: One man said to another "You're going to get that girl". But the first man said "No, I'm not". Then the other man said "Just joking, I'm kidding around."
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: 'I'm just joking', used as a kind of marker for humour or 'I don't really mean it I'm just joking'.

ex.xv: Birriyibidbuni karrkad birrirerrngmangi.
ex.xe: They would go up to higher ground (away from the floodplain) to gather firewood.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Higher ground, at the top, above the escarpment.

ex.xv: Bu kunwok Kunwinjku ngarriyime mayh ngarriwarlbun. Dja bu ngarriyime mayh ngarrire ngarribidbun karrkad wanjh nakka kore ceremony yiman Kunabibi mandjamun manbu bininj ngadberre.
ex.xe: In the Kunwinjku language, we say that we hunt mayh (animals). But when we say we’re going up to a mayh, in that case it means we’re going to a ceremony, like Kunabibi or another sacred event of ours.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Ceremony ground. Participants in a ceremony are said to 'go up' (bidbun) to a ceremony, and the ceremony ground is said to be karrkad, a 'high place'.

ex.xv: Kakukbame kanmilanmila kodjok, ngudda kurduk bulanj wunwunbu.
ex.xe: The light morph of the brown falcon is called kanmilanmila but you Bulanj are the dark morph wunwunbu.

ex.xv: Bulanj dilib yikarrme?
ex.xe: Bulanj do you have any tea leaves?

ex.xv: Ngandimarneyimeng kunred manih nguddangke bu yiman baleh ngarridowen wanjh nguddangke kunred yiworhnan. Ya yikarrme. Ya ngurrikarrme kunekke yerre birrimarneyimeng Wamud nungka ngakerrngedi wanjh young yimeyimeng.
ex.xe: They said to me that this place belongs to me and that "when we should die, then you have to look after this place. You will own it. You all hold onto it after," they said to Wamud and I was one of the new generation and Wamud was young.

ex.xv: Birringeybom wanjh ngarringeybekkang. Wanjh ngarringeykarrme kunngey nuye.
ex.xe: They said the names and we heard them and so now we keep the names for it.

ex.xv: "Kokok, Kokok yikarrme?" "Woh, ngakarrme, ngakarrme, la yiray."
ex.xe: Brother, brother Are you holding on to it? Yes I've got it, I've got it, you go then.

ex.xv: Yibengkan Kodjok? Bale nakka kahngeyyo? Bulanj bikarrmeng.
ex.xe: You know that Kodjok? What's his name now? He has a son— Bulanj.

ex.xv: Bolkkime karrbennan kalawan dja dadbe kabeneburren wanjh kalawan kakarrme.
ex.xe: Now when we see a goanna and a brown snake fighting, the goanna will (always) win.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngaye ngabimbun manekke Macassar kabbala, kundulk, burrkyak engine, karrurruwi. Minj anchor duninjh dja manwodj kundulk. Bu kunmayorrkkimuk kamre minj kabirrikarrikme.
ex.xe: I will draw that Macassan boat, a wooden one with no engine, only a sail. Not a real anchor, just a log of wood. If a big strong wind comes up, they don't have to paddle.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 246

bw: from Makassarese karoro, a type of sail cloth. Iwaidja= karrurru, Yolngu Matha= garrurru.

ex.xv: Wanjh birribalwam mankuladj birrihkarungi, birrikaruy rowk, wanjh birridurndi kured.
ex.xe: Then they went further and started digging up some spike rushes. They dug them all up, then they went back home.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Awurd, mayh namekke ngankodjborledke Kawk Kabim Djang
ex.xe: So dear to me is that bird, its call reminds me of the rufous night heron dreaming at Kawk Kabim (a place).
ex.so: Nabarlek Band, 'Brown Bird', from the album 'Manmoyi Radio', 2007

sn.de: Rufous Night Heron and also the sound made by this bird.
Silver-crowned friar bird. Also the sound made by the Friar Bird.

ex.xv: Nawu wirlihwirlih nakka manberrk kabirrire kabirrini karrbennan birriwern kabirridolkarren kaddum kabirrire kabirriwokkire kabirriyime wirlih wirlih wirlih bu karrbenkawon.
ex.xe: Galahs live in open forest areas, we see them flying in big flocks up in the sky. When we startle them they fly off calling out “wirlih wirlih wirlih”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Cause an animal to run away in fright, startle an animal.

ex.xv: "Aa ngalkkan ngurribawo, ngalkkan ngurribawo. Minj ngalkka ngurriwon kunj, karrikaybun ngalengmanwali wardi kankaybun manme mandjay". "Yoh yoh bonj bonj karrikaybun, karrikaybun baw."
ex.xe: "Ah, leave her, leave her. Don't give her any kangaroo. Now it's our turn not to give her because she won't give us any of the hypoxis grass". "Yeah, yeah, OK right, let's not give her any, let's not give her, quiet!"

sn.de: Withhold from, refuse to give something to someone, deny someone something.

ex.xv: Kakkak bikayhmi wurdyaw yimeng, "Yimray marndi namarnde ngunmang".
ex.xe: Grandma was calling out to the child, saying "You'd better come back here, or a Namarnde spirit will get you".
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 34’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

sn.de: Call out to someone, yell. This word is also used when someone 'calls out to the Ancestors' when entering a country, for example when bringing a new person who has never been there before.

ng: The direct object of the verb is the person or thing being called out to.

ex.xv: Kunmadj ke.
ex.xe: Your swag/clothes.

ex.xv: Ngakohbanjminj bolkkime. Darnki ngarrowen bad Balanda nungan kebbabi.
ex.xe: I've got old today and I could die soon but those white people are still being persistent (and coming to see me, making requests).

ex.xv: Kebbaldjurri kayawan nuye djenj kore kubuk nawu djenj kilekilelh kangun barnangarra dja kukak.
ex.xe: The spoonbill looks for his fish in the shallow water, those small fish which he eats day and night.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrinami kebbord kore kukeb bedberre. Kaluk birrimangi kunj kundadmurrng bu bindikebdjudmi, wanjh birrikebkaridi munguyh.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors would put nose pegs in their noses. They would take a sharp bone from a kangaroo's leg and pierce their nose, and then leave it stuck there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Nose peg (wooden) or ring (pandanus fibre) placed through a pierced nasal septum as a form of bodily adornment.

ex.xv: Ngangadjihbun munguyh, kunubewu kebdjirned nganhmang.
ex.xe: I keep sneezing, maybe I'm getting a cold.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Nasal mucus. Also used to refer to a cold or flu.

ex.xv: Ngakebkan mayh kure Barlbbanarra wanjh Barlbbanarra kang duruk, duruk kang djalbom mayh...
ex.xe: 'I'm taking the dogs hunting to Barlbbanarra', and so he took the dogs to Barlbbanarra and killed lots of game...

ex.xv: Birrikakrey duruk dorrengh birrirey birrikebkani duruk nomi ngalbu ngarrbek wanjh birrinani birrimangi ngalbu ngarrbek birrikani kured.
ex.xe: They would go out hunting at night with a dog, which would smell out an echidna and they would see the echidna it and take it home.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngalkebmak.
ex.xe: An attractive woman.

sn.de: Look at oneself, e.g. in the mirror.

ex.xv: Ngare ngakebnarren.
ex.xe: I'm going for a piss.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Durndi kore wak yongohyoy kumekke manbu kukku bikebnguneng bikebngakkeng dja nawu birrihdjarrkyoy bonj.
ex.xe: He returned to where the Crow was, and there the water had drowned the Crow and everyone else who lay there.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nahni Wakkewakken kabirriyo kore kundulk mankod kore kukabo kore manbokedjelk.
ex.xe: The Wakkewakken spirits live among the paperbark trees in the river, in the cold water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Cool something down, make something cold.

ex.xv: Ngalkohbanj bidjawam, "Njalekah wanjh yihnalkbun?" Wanjh yimeng nawu namarladj, "Aba manburrangkali ngandikaybom." "Kek”, yimeng ngalbu ngalkohbanj.
ex.xe: The old woman asked him “Why are you crying?”, and the orphan boy said “Oh, they refused to give me any lily corms”. “Is that so?”, said the old lady.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Kek, baleh kore birrimankang?
ex.xe: Oh no, where did they crash?
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: "Wam kuhri dja njilngwarrreminj.". "Kek, dja njalekenh njilngwarreminj?"
ex.xe: "He went over that way, he's in a bad mood". "Oh no, why is he in a bad mood?"
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: "Oh dear", "oh no", "Is that so?" (Said with falling tone).

ex.xv: Kela nuye Nabima, kunred ngamed kaboyo anbu Wurrumulah that Nabima nuye kunred.
ex.xe: It belongs to him, Kela Nabima, that place where there is water, Wurrumulah, that's Nabima's country.

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.
Crocodile's lair or tunnel near the water's edge (of both freshwater and estuarine crocodiles).

ex.xv: Mimih minj kadi kore kuberrk bu mandjewk nakimuk kamre kakele wardi kunmayorrk kabiburriwe.
ex.xe: A Mimih spirit doesn’t stay outside when there’s a storm, they’re afraid, the wind might blow them away.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu bininj dja balanda kabirrimang nawu mayh wanjh kabirrikelebukwon kakelebukmen kabirrimarnbun kelebuk mayh bedberre.
ex.xe: Both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people get animals and tame them, the animals become tame and people turn them into their pets.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nakidjkidj kakarrme barrk kelebuk nuye.
ex.xe: Nakidjkidj spirits keep black wallaroos as pets.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngarriburrinj ngabenkelekelehmeng, wanjh djamun birrikayhmeng ngandukkang.
ex.xe: We were fighting and I made those two scared, so they called the policeman and he came and handcuffed me.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Birrikeleminj.
ex.xe: They were frightened.

ex.xv: Nang nakimuk nayin kahyo, kelewawmeng yimeng, "Waw, waw, waw."
ex.xe: He saw a big snake was there and cried out “Waw waw waw!”
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974.

ex.xv: Kenh ngawarrewong, ngabirliwarrewong.
ex.xe: Oops, I didn't light the fire properly.

ex.xv: Djalbangurrk. Nabang banireyi, Wurrngiyele banireyi, ken Wurrlele.
ex.xe: Djalbangurrk, Nabang in Wurrngiyele I mean Wurrlele estate.

sn.de: ‘Oops’. Often also said when correcting something you have said, ‘I mean’, ‘Whoops I meant to say’ etc.

ex.xv: Moneykenh kabirriyidurren.
ex.xe: They argue about money.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Mawah ngayekenh birridoweng birriyakminj.
ex.xe: My own father’s fathers [‘grandfathers of mine’] have died and gone.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kabirriwernhbolbme kore kunkukbelekenh dja kunu kunkukburlerrikenh, kabindibukkan rowk.
ex.xe: [Kids] should learn both Balanda things and Aboriginal things properly, so they [teachers] should teach it all.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Suffix that indicates association or possession. ‘About’, ‘of’, ‘concerning’ etc. In English many of these concepts are covered by different words but in Kunwinjku the senses of ‘kenh’ are hard to seperate. It could be compared to the genitive case.

ex.xv: Benedanginj beneyerrkang benebolkkaruy kukkukenh.
ex.xe: They stopped, sat down and started digging for water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: In order to, for, for the purpose of (suffix that indicates the purpose of an action).

ex.xv: “Mamam, Djakku nawu nang nakuyengken nayin kore Wuk."
ex.xe: “Grandpa, Lefty [nickname] saw a really long snake at Wuk”.
ex.so: ‘Lesson 15: Djurra ‘-ng’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

ex.xv: Bu kumdungbebmi ngalbadjan dja kornkumo benewam kore mankabo, kumekbe djenj nawernken rey.
ex.xe: When the sun was going down, the mother and father went down to the river. There were lots of fish swimming around down there.

sn.de: Suffix that can be added to adjectives, possibly as a focal marker.

ex.xv: Kulawuddul ngurrikengemen!
ex.xe: You initiates be fearful!

ex.xv: Karrikinje kakerlkdan.
ex.xe: If we cook it, it'll become soft.

ex.xv: "Ah ah, ngakerlkdanj manih ngarrengekerlkdanj minj bale kayime ngare. Ngakarrerlurlmeng rowk, ngarlurlmeng rowk.
ex.xe: "Ah ah, I'm sore, here, my lower leg's sore, what can I do? My leg's swollen, it's all swollen."

sn.de: Become sore or weak. This often refers to something which prevents someone from walking or getting up, a foot or leg injury or a whole body condition.

ex.xv: Kukku kumborrolkang bolkkerlkminj, beneyibmeng kanjdji, wanjh kumekke kabenehni Yawkyawk.
ex.xe: Water came up and the ground became soft, they sunk down and remain there today as Yawkyawk spirits.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, 'yawk yawk' sotory.

ex.xv: Kakukkerlkkerlkmen.
ex.xe: His body becomes soft.
ex.so: Hale, K. 1959. Magical way of killing

sn.de: Straw-necked ibis and also white ibis.

ex.xv: Kumuken namak mayh bu ngarringun. Korroko dabborrabbolk birribuni birrikerribuni wanjh birringuni wirlarrk warridj.
ex.xe: Freshwater crocodiles are good to eat. In the old days, people would kill them, cook them in ground ovens and eat them. The eggs too.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Cook food in a ground oven using antbed kunkerri.

ex.xv: Bu kabenmarneyawdowen wanjh ngalbadjan ngarrikerribun ba kangun nawu mayh dja djenj. Wardi kakanjwarremen bu minj ngarrikerribun ngalbu ngalbadjan.
ex.xe: If women have miscarriages, we have to give the mother a traditional steam bath (to cleanse her) so she can eat meat and fish again. If we don't do this, it would cause all the meat (of the animals in the area) to go bad.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Give someone a traditional steam bath for ritual cleansing, using wet foliage like water weeds placed over hot pieces of antbed. Logs are placed over the antbed and hot coals for the person to lie on and they are covered in paperbark. In this case there is no need to dig a pit and the fire is made on the ground.

ex.xv: Mankerrnge muddikang.
ex.xe: New truck.

ex.xv: Nakerrnge karrukmirri.
ex.xe: A new man is working.

ex.xv: Birrikerrhkerrnge kabirridjare konda kabirringimen kamak.
ex.xe: These new people, they want to come here, it's OK for them to enter.

ex.xv: Bu kerrngekenhni, nawu Shire birrinahnani store
ex.xe: Previously the Shire was running the store
ex.so: Adjumarllarl Aboriginal Corporation community newsletter, 2015

ex.xv: Yibenmarneyimen wurdurd kinga kahyo. Korroko ba kabirrikewkkewkme.
ex.xe: Tell those children there's a crocodile there. I did already but they don't believe it.

ex.xv: Bonj wanjh, ngurriburnbu wurdwurd. Ngurrikeyo, karrikeyo.
ex.xe: OK that's it, cut it out kids. Go to sleep, let's all go to sleep.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Keyohkeyoy kore kudjorlok nawu nganabbarru.
ex.xe: The buffalo was sleeping in a hollow in the ground.
ex.so: Garlngarr, Victor, ‘Mamik dja Nakodjok benekang’, in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: Kunkare kondanjkunu kunred ngalkudji daluk bibayeng nabang nayin yirrbardbard wanjh doweng. Minj burudjang bibayemeninj dowimeninj dja korroko kidni birridanjbom.
ex.xe: A long time ago here at this place, a woman was bitten by a venomous snake, a taipan, and she died. It wasn’t just an accidental incident which killed her because some people had already killed her through sorcery.

sn.de: Under sorcery, spiritually dead though appearing still alive, doomed to die.

ex.xv: Kabirringorrkkidjihkidjikmerren.
ex.xe: People tickle each other's sides.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kidjihkidjikme ngarriyime bu wurdyaw kabirrimarnbun kadjekme. Wanjh kabirrinjamkidjihkidjikme.
ex.xe: 'Kidjihkidjikme' is the word we use when people make babies laugh by tickling their bellies.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Benekaruy benenang kakih wanjh benekarungi djarre, benekaruy benekaruy benenang kunyawurd kambobebme.
ex.xe: They dug and saw that the earth was moist, so they kept digging further, they dug and dug and saw some water coming out of the ground.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

ex.xv: Wurdurd, yuwn ngurrikilekme mako mani.
ex.xe: Children, don't touch this shotgun

ex.xv: Bonbon kabirringun djenj nawu kilekilelh.
ex.xe: Cormorants eat small fish.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Wanjh bu ngayolyolmi munguyh birridjaldjekmi and birriwakwani med. Med nakka wurdwurd
ex.xe: As I was telling them the story they kept laughing all the time, because they didn’t know it. Now, these were very young kids.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

re: send word for someone to come

ex.xv: Ngakimang Nawakadj kamhre konhda karriwokdi.
ex.xe: I’m sending a message for Nawakadj come here so we can all have a discussion.

ex.xv: Bukbuk wirlarrk ngalengarre minj karrimang karriwirlarrkdjirdmang bu karrimang ngalengarre wirlarrk wanjh kahdjalwokdi munguyh wanjh mandjewk kakimang djaying bu dabborrabbolk birriyimeng.
ex.xe: We don’t steal the Pheasant Coucal’s eggs. If we take her eggs she will call out incessantly and might call up the rains, the old people told us.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Send word for someone to come, call someone or something to you, get someone to follow you.

ex.xv: Kabbala mankimuk.
ex.xe: A big boat.

ex.xv: Ngurrikihkimuk.
ex.xe: All you big people...

ex.xv: Nawu Mamik djamun bibuni kunkimuk.
ex.xe: The police were really beating Mamik up badly.
ex.so: ‘Lesson 11: Djurra ‘i’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

ex.xv: Bolkkime kunkukbele ngimeng kunkimuk.
ex.xe: Now the white man’s world has arrived in a big way.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Serious, significant, a lot, 'in a big way'.

ex.xv: Baladj... kabirrikimukmen kore ngadbeh kunkurlba bu kandibaye ngad.
ex.xe: Leeches get big from drinking our blood when they bite us.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Yikimukminj ngudda. Mayh wanjh yibidbun.
ex.xe: You're grown up now. It's time for you to go to ceremony.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Wam djarreh wanjh mandjewk kumhwam nayahwurd wanjh yerre kimukminj.
He went far away and it started to rain, first a little and then it became heavy.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Wanjh bomarnbom manbu kukku bokimukminj bobarlmeng wanjh nawu daluk bokenh benekebngakmeng.
ex.xe: [The Rainbow Serpent] made the water rise up and the two women drowned.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu kukak dird dja kinhkinh kabenedjarrkbolkwolkan.
ex.xe: At night, the moon and stars bring light.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kakanjkinje.
ex.xe: She is cooking meat.

sn.de: Cook, burn, light up a cigarette.

ex.xv: Dabborrabbolkko
ex.xe: Those two old men.

ex.xv: Beneyidko (W), (I= Beneridko).
ex.xe: Those two who are always arguing with each other.

ex.xv: Ngeyko.
ex.xe: Namesake (term of address to someone with the same name).

ex.xv: Yun kandung, nganebeyko.
ex.xe: Don't swear at me, we are a father-son pair.

ex.xv: Birriyawkohyawko.
ex.xe: Numerous mother and child pairs (or technically, numerous adjacent generation matrilineal pairs).

sn.de: Pair of individuals who stand in a particular relationship of commonality with each other.

ng: There is great variation in the plural forms of this noun which dispenses with the noun class prefix. This means the plural form no longer explicitly marks gender (i.e. a group of elderly males, females or mixed gender group).

ex.xv: Wurdyaw bengmayahmeng wanjh bimarnebebmeng nakohbanj, bidjawam nangale ngunemwam, yiddok kornkumo dja ngalbadjan ngurrimwam. Nungka kodjbordehmeng.
ex.xe: A little boy got lost, and an old man appeared and asked him who he had come with, if he had come with his mother and father. But the little boy just shook his head.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Namekke marrkidjbu Ngalyod bedda birridjawam baleh ngalengarre kunred. Djalkodjbordebordehmi. Kaluk birriyimeng Wayirra birribolkngeybom, wanjh kodjdukmeng.
ex.xe: They kept asking that magic man (who was really the Rainbow Serpent) where his country was. But he kept shaking his head. Then eventually when they mentioned the place name 'Wayirra', he nodded.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Kakodjbulu.
ex.xe: She has grey hair.

ex.xv: Larrk, minj ngadjare nganeyo. Kodjbulu.
ex.xe: No, I don't want to sleep with him. He's an old man (he has grey hair).
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, Yirrbardbard story.

sn.de: Grey hair, old person, mature adult.

se.de: Get grey hair, go grey, enter middle age.

ex.xv: That babolknahnani konda banibolknahnani mamamh ngayeken nadjah-.... nangamed Nadjunjdjunj, bad bikani ngalkodjok, kodjdjan karrimen wamuddjan barlmaded.
ex.xe: Those two used to look after this country, my grandfather (mother's father) Nadjunjdjunj and his wife was ngal-kodjok, kodjdjan, I mean wamuddjan, excuse me for referring to my (classificatory) sister.

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Wanjh benedurreni. Wanjh nawu Djakku kodjdjobmeng, bimarneyimeng, "Minj kankimang yerreyerreh…”
ex.xe: So they argued. Then Lefty got offended and told him "You're not taking me any further…”
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 24-27

sn.de: To become sullen, dejected, sulky, offended and uncommunicative.

ex.xv: Namekke marrkidjbu Ngalyod bedda birridjawam baleh ngalengarre kunred. Djalkodjbordebordehmi. Kaluk birriyimeng Wayirra birribolkngeybom, wanjh kodjdukmeng.
ex.xe: They kept asking that magic man (who was really the Rainbow Serpent) where his country was. But he kept shaking his head. Then eventually when they mentioned the place name 'Wayirra', he nodded.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Ngoyongoyo kakodjkeyo djaddi. Kakodjkewarre, kabirrimerlemyembun (Kuninjku).
ex.xe: The ngoyongoyo frog is a sleeping frog. It is a sleepyhead (ie. it hibernates), they rub their bellies.

sn.de: 'Sleepy', a way to refer to someone who sleeps late. Literally means 'sleeping-bad', so it can also mean 'unable to sleep'. Also a way of referring to animals which are inactive or 'sleepy' for long periods, such as the sleepy cod (Oxyeleotris lineolata) or the death adder (Acanthiphis praelongus).
A religious follower, member of the clergy, a pious person.

ex.xv: Ngudda bale yikodjngalmeng?
ex.xe: Ngaye karrkad ngakodjngalmeng kore Dalabon.

ex.xv: I was born up in the escarpment country, on Dalabon land.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kodjok! Kodjok. Oho kadedjbayeng Kodjok! Kodjok, narrarnkolo.
ex.xe: Kodjok! Kodjok. Oh for goodness sake, that dear man, it’s Kodjok! Kodjok of the Darnkolo clan.
ex.so: Bardayal Nadjamerrek [while looking at old Wubarr ceremony film footage], quoted in Neale, Margo & Thomas, Martin (eds), ‘Exploring the Legacy of the 1948 Arnhem Land Expedition’, ANU Press, Canberra, 2011

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Yikolu warde yimankan!
ex.xe: Get down from there or you'll fall.

sn.de: Return to camp after leaving a place of ceremony.

ex.xv: Rapunzel yimmudkoluyhwerrimen!
ex.xe: Rapunzel, throw down your hair!

sn.de: Lift or carry something down, take down, throw down.

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan kayime "Aa nakka wurdyaw njale kahdakarrme kore kudang nuye? Wardi kabikombakke".
