ex.xe: The mother says "Ah, what's that kid got in his mouth? It might choke him".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ng: The food etc. being choked on is the subject, and the person choking or body part is the object, so that the construction is literally e.g. ‘the food broke my windpipe.’

sn.de: An initiate or person newly introduced to ceremony.

ex.xv: Kunngey kakarrme danjbik bu ngarringeybun. Komorlo kabakaba dja dabberkk dja ngaldjalkudji ngalbu mayhmayh.
ex.xe: It has three names that we call it by. Komorlo, kabakaba and dabberrk, but they all refer to the same bird.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Cattle egret. This name refers to all of the white egrets.

ex.xv: Yoh kalawan la borlokko birringuyi kalawan nungan karrangbulurlhme, komrdawh, Bulkay.
ex.xe: Yes, they ate goanna and water pythons, and goannas, the mangrove monitor and northern snake-necked turtles there at Bulkay.

ex.xv: Konda yimray kornbayeng.
ex.xe: Come here my friend.

ex.xv: Ngayi kongibun ngudda.
ex.xe: I feel sorry for you.

sn.de: Termite mounds in country where the soil is red thus the mounds are also reddish in colour.

ex.xv: Wurdyaw wam kukabo kamang konjkonj.
ex.xe: The child has gone to the river and is catching little catfish.

ex.xv: Konjkonj kadjordmen kayimerran manmakkawarri.
ex.xe: Konjkonj [baby catfish] grow up into big catfish.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Green tree frog, also generic for all frogs.

ex.xv: Wurrmarninj kadjordmen kore kabbal.
ex.xe: The red lily grows on floodplains.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dolobbo kabirridadjke kabirrimkan kore Injalak Arts Centre kumekke kabirribimbun kabirriweykan kabenwon kunwardde.
ex.xe: They cut bark and take it to Injalak Arts Centre, where they paint it and get money for it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngahli mayh kangeyyo kulabakku kunmud ngalengarre ngalmudburlerri dja kukom kore kakombele.
ex.xe: The bird which we call kulabakku (the Pied Heron, Egretta picata) has black feathers, but white on its neck.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manbu kunmuluru ngarriyime makka ngarringeybun kundulk kore kunbalak.
ex.xe: ‘Kunmuluru’ is what we call grass in mother-in-law language.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Mandjimdjim kadjordmen kore kukku kaboyo kore mankabo manwanjdjad manlabbarl.
ex.xe: Mandjimdjim (water pandanus) grows where there is water, by rivers, creeks and billabongs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: daughter, son (address term used by F)

ex.xv: Nakonamkuyeng.
ex.xe: He is tall.

ex.xv: Nungka nawu Wurrakkak nakka nakuyengni kornnamkuyengni.
ex.xe: That man Wurrakkak was big and tall.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: A:Ngayi ngare djarre, kaluk ngamdurndeng. B:Ya, yimdurnde, yikornbayeng.
ex.xe: I'm going a long way away, but after I'll come back. Yes, my friend, you come back.

ex.xv: Wabwabmeng, konda, konda, konda kundjangmelmeng drrr murrngbakkeng.
ex.xe: He snuck up further, further, further, poised to spear and drrr he broke its bone (kangaroo). Yipee, yipee, yipee (I've speared it).

sn.de: An expression of affection used after someone is impressed with a particular action or as a term of endearment. It has no rude or vulgar connotation as the literal meaning may suggest. One informant gave the gloss 'friend'. It can also be used as an expression of happiness (eg. excitement after a successful hunt)

ex.xv: Nakkan kornkumo nuye.
ex.xe: That is his father.

sn.de: Referent term for someone else's father.

ex.xv: Dja korroko dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni mandjabu wanjh birridjuhkeyi kore kukku manlabbarl yika kore mankabo wanjh djenj ngimi birrimangi.
ex.xe: And in the past, the old people would make fish traps, put them in the water in a billabong or river, the fish would go in and them they would get them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko duninjh
ex.xe: In the distant past, in the old days, in the Ancestral past

ex.xv: Bu korroko duninjh nawu karrkkanj nakka bininjni kaluk yerre mayhmayh yimerranj.
ex.xe: A long time ago the Brown falcon used to be a man, he only became a bird afterwards.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Previously, in the past, a long time ago.

ex.xv: Burrkyak, minj korroko ngunnayi, djalbolkkime bu kerrngekkenh duninj ngunkuknan.
ex.xe: No, she hasn’t seen you before, she’s going to see you in person for the first time now.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj dja Nakodjok Benewam Djenj’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Wanjh benebidbom kured kumekbe benekinjeng rowk, benemadbom korroko, wanjh benewayhkeng benenguneng dja yikahwi bindiwonowong kohbakohbanj.
ex.xe: Then the two of them went back up home and put all of them [the fish] on the fire, waited for a while, pulled them out and ate them, and also gave some to the old people.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kuhni bu Kunkare Birrihwarlbuni’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Kumekbe benehburrinj benedjalkudji. Beneburrinj korroko. Kaluk ngalkudji djakbekkang, wanjh rlobmeng kore kured, bimarneyimeng ngalbadjan.
ex.xe: They fought there, just the two of them. They were fighting for a while. Then one of them got hurt, and ran home and told her mother.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

sn.de: For a while, for a long time.

ex.xv: Woybukkih yimarneyolyolme, yuwn mak yikowe.
ex.xe: Be honest with him, don’t mislead him.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kayakki, djalohkoweng.
ex.xe: It's nothing, I was only having you on.

sn.de: To deceive, trick, lie to someone, play a joke on someone.

ex.xv: Koyekbeh.
ex.xe: From the east, easterners.

ex.xv: Kururrk.
ex.xe: Inside (literally, in the enclosed space).

ex.xv: Kukun.
ex.xe: On the right hand side.

ex.xv: Kuwardde.
ex.xe: Escarpment.

ex.xv: Kudjarnngal.
ex.xe: Place near Manmoyi outstation, site of white clay delek in the bank of a creek. The placename literally means 'in the fork of the branch'.

sn.de: In, on, to, at. Ku- is prefixed to nouns to indicate locations.
'Bite the line!'; said after throwing in a fishing line to anticipate a fish taking the bait.

ex.xv: Korroko birrikarungi kunbalkbu dja bolkkime kubba wirlmurrng nawu balanda marnbom kabirrikarung karrbarda nawu daluk.
ex.xe: In the old days women used to dig with wooden digging sticks, but now they dig for long yams with metal digging sticks made from non-Indigenous materials.

ex.xv: Wanjh daluhdaluk kabirrimang kubba bedberre wanjh kabbal kabirrire kabirriyawan ngalmangiyi kabirrimang.
ex.xe: Then women take their turtling sticks and go out onto the floodplain to find turtles [by poking the mud with the sticks].

sn.de: Crowbar, metal digging stick, metal turtling stick. This could literally be a crowbar, or a digging stick fashioned from metal such as concrete reinforcing wire.

ex.xv: Bu mankung ngarriyime ngarringeybun nawern dja kangeyyo kunngeywern. Nabiwo kardderre kubbulak ngarringun yiwk dja mandabu.
ex.xe: We have lots of different names for different types of honey. There's nabiwo, kardderre and kubbulak, and we eat the honey and pollen sacs from all of them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh benewam beneyawani mankung, wanjh benengalkeng kubbulak kore kundulk. Benedulkngadji, wanjh benemonbuhmeng beneyiwkmey.
ex.xe: Two women went looking for honey, and found some kubbulak honey in a tree. They cut open the tree and got the honey.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Bee species and related honey. The honey is found high up in trees, and has an orange or light brown colour. The hive has a long entrance tube (kebkuyeng).

ex.xv: Nawakadj dja Nabulanj benewam djenj benehdanjbuni kubbunj benehkani.
ex.xe: Nawakadj and Nabulanj went spearing fish with a canoe.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj Dja Nabulanj Benewam Djenj’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre.

ex.xv: Kabirrikaberrkdi.
ex.xe: They are all outside

ex.xv: Wanjh nakudji yimeng njalekenh manbu mankole ngarrburriwe kamdurndeng kadjabdan kore kubodme ngarrku. Wanjh bu benebalwam djarrehwurd benenang ngalbu Ngalyod kahyo wanjh benedurndi kured.
ex.xe: One of them said “Why does the spear end up landing behind us when we throw it?”. Then when they went a little further they saw that the Rainbow Serpent was there, and they went home.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yika karrinan kabenkadjung mayh bulikki nganabbarru dja djarrang karrinan kabarndi kore kubodme bedberre.
ex.xe: Sometimes we see them [egrets] following animals like bulls, buffalo or horses, or sitting on their backs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Behind, on the back of, on the reverse side of.

ex.xv: Kumekke kunred manbelk karri kore kukun, dja kore kudjakku karri marrunj.
ex.xe: In that place there is pandanus on the right, and on the left there are palm trees (Hydriastele ramsayi).
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: On the left hand side, to the left.

ex.xv: Nawu bininj wam yerrkang kudjarrirn.
ex.xe: And he went and settled alone at the waterfall at Wulwunj, up at the place called Ngingurdulyak.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Off to the side, separately from others.

ex.xv: Nakudji nakohbanj ni Kudjekbinj / nawu kumekke kunred nuye ni / wanjh bolkkongibom / nungka nalkbom bu nang dungyibmeng.
ex.xe: An old man was staying at Kudjekbinj / because that was his country / He was feeling sorry for his land (white man has come and put an airstrip, powerhouse etc) / He was crying as he was watching the sun go down.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Burlanjni’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Estate name and name of an outstation.

ex.xv: Ngudda yikudji yimwam?
ex.xe: Did you come by yourself?

ex.xv: Ngarrikudji ngarriwam.
ex.xe: Only a few of us went.

ex.xv: Kuni kunkare nakudji bininj wam kabbal, kani bokenh mankole dja borndok.
ex.xe: One day a long time ago a man went to the floodplain, he was carrying two spears and a spearthrower.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kuhni bu Kunkare Birrihwarlbuni’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Kunkudji ngurriborrkkemen.
ex.xe: Dance one more time.

ex.xv: Mandjimdjim minj karri kore manberrk, mankudji karrinan karri manbelk manwern kore manberrk.
ex.xe: Water pandanus doesn’t grow in open forest areas, we just see lots of ordinary pandanus (Pandanus spiralis) in the open forest.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ng: Kudji is always prefixed with the appropriate prefix (man-, na-, yi- etc) for the noun being described.

ex.xv: Bonj wanjh benbom bonj benkudjihmeng, bonj, kamak.
ex.xe: Then he killed them and left them there forever, the end.

sn.de: Place and leave forever, be done with something (e.g. a painting), place forever as a 'Dreaming' as in creation times.

ex.xv: Birringuni dolek kuk yika birriwilkdengi kore kuwilk.
ex.xe: People would eat wood grubs raw, or cook them in the hot coals under ashes.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kan-kukwo!
ex.xe: Give me some money!

sn.de: Body, shape, human form (as incorporated noun).

se.re: give discount on cost of something

se.de: Knock down fruit from a tree.
Grow fruit, fruiting of a tree.

ex.xv: Bulkay djenj kukadje.
ex.xe: At Bulkay there are lots of fish.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji ngalkohbanj wam yawani mandudjmi wanjh dulkngalkeng, nang yakarrbom kukadjeh mirndeyoy kore kurorre.
ex.xe: An old woman went looking for green plums. She found a tree and saw that there were lots of them that had fallen on the ground.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Lots of, abundant, too many, in a large group.

ex.xv: "Kakkak, kamak kare kokok kukadjeh kabinan doctor?”
ex.xe: “Kakkak, is it okay if older brother goes into town to see
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 56-59

ex.xv: Ngandikurrmeng kured kore ngaye ngahyoy, dja bedman benedurndi kukadjeh.
ex.xe: They dropped us off at my home where I lived, and they went back into town.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

sn.de: City, town. Literally "where there are lots of things", such as buildings, cars, shops etc.

ex.xv: Ngahli mayhmayh kangeyyo djuwe birrikukbele kabirringeybun ‘bowerbird’.
ex.xe: This bird is called djuwe, white people call it a ‘bowerbird’.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngalbu komorlo ngalkukbele mayhmayh kani kore kabbal manlabbarl mankabo manwanjdjad dja manberrk kore kubolkwern kunred.
ex.xe: The egret is a white bird which lives on floodplains, billabongs, rivers, creeks and in open forest areas in many different clan countries.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Delek nakka kukbele nawu nguk yika duyh kabirrimang.
ex.xe: Delek (white clay) is a white substance which we collect either wet or dry.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: White person, or any white-bodied thing, e.g. animal with a white body, white substance etc. Literally ‘body-white’.

ex.xv: Warrak kakukborledme kakukmardukme.
ex.xe: The Leichhardtian Bony Bream (Fluvialosa erebi) turns its body sideways and reflects a flash of light.

ex.xv: Wanjh yimankek bu benedjobkemeninj manbu mankoleh dja wanjh benekukborledmeng beneyimerranj mayhmayh bu benemuddanginj.
ex.xe: They tried to chop down the bamboo but instead they grew feathers and turned into birds.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, pp. 64-65

sn.de: Change form by sorcery, be transfigured.

ex.xv: Manmakkawarri nakudji kukburrknang, nawu wanjh ngabukkabukkang, ngaye ngabukkabukkang, kukburrbuni manmakkawarri, kakukburrbun.
ex.xe: One [of the kids] knows what a catfish looks like, because I taught him. I taught him myself. So he got to know what a catfish looks like, he recognises them.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Recognise someone or something, know about something’s physical characteristics.

ex.xv: Bikukburriweng.
ex.xe: She pushed him down.

sn.de: Throw to the ground, cause to fall to the ground.

ex.xv: Bu yameng kukburriweng ballobmeng djudbakkeng kuyinnang yaw karrmi yahwurd.
ex.xe: When he scored a hit [on the kangaroo] and it fell to the ground, he ran up, broke its neck and spied a joey [in its pouch].
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Nawakadj Djangkang Kunj’, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: Hit an animal successfully while hunting, causing it to fall down.

ex.xv: Yikukburriweng.
ex.xe: You've really made it well.

ex.xv: Nakka yibimbom kukmak, o darrkid yibimbom kunj… Yikukburriweng, darrkid.
ex.xe: [When praising a picture we can say] “You’ve painted that figure really well” or “That kangaroo is really lifelike”. “You’ve really nailed it, it looks really lifelike”.
ex.so: Joey Nganjmirra

sn.de: Construct with skill, used as a compliment to praise the skill usually of a craftsperson or artist.

ex.xv: Wanjh nungka ngokko dokmeng kukebrok dingihdi kumhkunidi.
ex.xe: And he had already gone ahead, and was waiting there to kill them.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 36-39

ex.xv: A: Ngurrikebroknang? B: Larrk, minj ngarrinayi, kebrokyak.
ex.xe: A: Did you see him walk past before we got here? (Literally 'did you see him walking ahead'?) B: No we didn't see him, he wasn't ahead of you.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dja nawu bininj kukkang djenj, biwong Nabulanj, kinjeng benenguneng.
ex.xe: And the man took the fish, gave it to Nabulanj, cooked it and they ate it.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 19’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981.

ex.xv: Dja bikukkang bikukkurrmeng kore kuwardderurrk.
ex.xe: And he took his body and placed it in the tomb which he had hewn out of rock. [Matthew 27:60]
ex.so: Etherington, Steve, ‘Jesus doweng dja yawoyhdolkkang’, Bible Society Australia, 2011, p.28, from Matthew 27:60.

sn.de: Carry an animal that has been hunted, carry a dead body.

ex.xv: Mandjimdjim kadjordmen kore kukku kaboyo.
ex.xe: Water pandanus [Pandanus aquaticus] grows where there is water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu korroko duruk bokenh Adjumarlarl dja Omwarl benemwam karrikadbeh kukku benehboyawani.
ex.xe: In the Dreamtime the two Ancestral Dogs Adjumarlarl and Omwarl came [to Gunbalanya] from the west, looking for water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation, Adjumarlarl and Omwarl Story

ex.xv: Kukku wurdyawken.
ex.xe: Amniotic fluid.

ex.xv: Kumekke kunred manbelk karri kore kukun, dja kore kudjakku karri marrunj.
ex.xe: In that place there is pandanus on the right, and on the left there are palm trees (Hydriastele ramsayi).
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: On the right hand side, to the right.

ex.xv: Bolkkime bu wanjh, nakka wurdwurd kabirridjalbimbun manu story…  yiburrbun kahkukwarrewon, kahyurrkkuhme.
ex.xe: Now though, children will write a story… And you know, this child will muck it up, it will be all mixed up.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Ruin or destroy something, do something badly, make something ugly.

ex.xv: Ngalbu kambuk ngalkka ngalkukyahwurd minj ngalbu karndjawarra ngalkka ngalkimuk dja ngalmak bu ngarringun ngalbu karndjawarra.
ex.xe: Kambuk (a crab species) are small, not like mud crabs which are big and good to eat.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kerrngekenh balanda birrikarrmi birrinani kunwardde, kukyahwurd bindiwoni.
ex.xe: Previously, non-Aboriginal people had all the money and looked after it all, and only gave a little bit (to the Aboriginal people).
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Barlarrk, yiman marrngunj kakukyime.
ex.xe: A spotted eel-tailed catfish is similar to the ordinary Neosilurus spp. [except it has spots]

ex.xv: Ngarringeybun ken njamed bakarlbakarl, yoh nani nawu kakukyime [draws in the sand]... nungan nadjinem nuye namekke kakarung kare yinan bu Dukaladjarranj kuwarddewardde kakarung.
ex.xe: We call this plant bakarlbakarl, yes, and it looks like this [draws in sand]... it is food for the black wallaroo, it digs it up and you can see it growing in the rock country there at Dukaladjarranj where the wallaroos in the rock country dig it up.

sn.de: Look like something, have a similar form to something.

ex.xv: Benewam kore kulabbarl. Wanjh benemadjkurrmeng, wanjh benewurlebmeng.
ex.xe: They went to the billabong. Then they put their things down and went into the water.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 68-71

ex.xv: Kuluban kure njilhmi kayo.
ex.xe: Flying foxes live near freshwater springs.

sn.de: Generic for all flying foxes but also specifically the black flying fox.

ex.xv: Dja birribuyika binihbininj mak birrihdjowkeyi birrimarnbom kuluyambi, wanjh nawu nawalawalak yimeng “Ngarrngamka ngarrkukbuyikahmerrimen kinga dja durrbu ngarrbenkadjung.”
ex.xe: The other people were crossing, they had made a paperbark raft, and the younger brother said “Let’s swim and turn ourselves into a crocodile and a water goanna and follow them”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngalbu kuluybirr ngalka kadi kare kore kukku manbowinjku kore mandem karri kunbak dja mandjimdjim kadulkdjuhmiyindi.
ex.xe: The saratoga lives in fresh water, where there are water lilies and water weeds and where the water pandanus stands in the water.

sn.de: Placename, former outstation and corrupted in English to give 'Goomadeer River'. Literally 'at the silver-leaved paperbark'.

ex.xv: Anbodjub kuwarddebuldjdjarn karri darnki njilhmi yiman kayime Kumarrirnbang.
ex.xe: Anbodjub spinifex is found in the middle of the rock country close to springs, such as at Kumarrirnbang.

sn.de: Outstation community about twelve kilometres south-west of Marrkolidjban. Also an estate name or kunngeykimuk for the surrounding country.

ex.xv: Naddab ngarri. Kumekke ngarridjangkani ngaye nganedangerrinj.
ex.xe: I was at Naddab. We used to go hunting there, me and my brothers.

sn.de: There, at that place previously referred to or jointly known.

ex.xv: Kabenekurrme kore kunak kabenemudkinje ba kakurlahrayekmen.
ex.xe: The two of them singe the feathers [of the emu] in the fire so that the skin becomes hard.

sn.de: Fire, firewood, fire at hearth. Symbol or totem of the matry (kunkoymud) yarriburrik.

ex.xv: Dja bolkkime kunak manbu Balanda marnbom bu karriwurlhke karrikinje mayh dja manme. Dja korroko kundjakkorl birriburdebmi birrinami wurlhmi manbu kunak.
ex.xe: These days people use lighters made by non-Indigenous people to light fires and cook meat and other food. But in the old days people used to rub fire sticks to start fires.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kunakkenh.
ex.xe: Lighter holder (literally ‘for a cigarette lighter’. Sometimes these are woven from pandanus for sale).

ex.xv: Manbakwern.
ex.xe: Lots of water weeds.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Warradjan kangun kunbak dja mandjimdjim mandedjmad.
ex.xe: The pig-nosed turtle eats water weeds and the roots of water pandanus.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Water weed. Generic name for many kinds of submerged aquatic herbs and algae.

ex.xv: Makka kundulk ngarringeybun kore kunbalak bu ngarriyime kunmuluru.
ex.xe: If we want to say 'wood', in mother-in-law language we have to say 'kunmuluru'.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: 'Mother-in-law language'. Lexical replacement affinal kin respect register which is used with one's actual ngalkurrng (spouse's mother and her sisters) and nakurrng (spouse's mother's brothers)

ex.xv: Kunbalanda birriwokdi ngandibukkani.
ex.xe: They spoke English when they were teaching us.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: English language, non-Indigenous lifestyle or way of doing things.

ex.xv: Burarr namak mayh bu ngarringun yiman kalawan karohrok. Kunkanj dja kunbalem bu ngarringun ngadberre mayh.
ex.xe: Water goannas are good to eat, just like other goannas. We eat both the meat and the fat.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Fat and good to eat (of animals).

ex.xv: Nganedirri burldebol jukebox nganebekkang nganewam nganebayahmeng kunbang.
ex.xe: We played pool and we both listened to the jukebox and then we went and bought some beer.

ex.xv: Nadjurrk nakka bininjni rengehrey kore borledmikenh Demed mandulum bu korroko. Nungka yerrkang ngunjngehmeng wanjh yimerranj kunwardde. Bolkkime nungka karrinan djudkulmeng dja kunney nuye kore kunbard karrmeng.
ex.xe: Nadjurrk was once a man who would walk around on the other side of Demed hill, a long time ago. He sat down to rest and turned into a rock. We can still see him there, head down and elbows on knees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Break the legs of a kangaroo in order to tie them up for cooking.

ex.xv: Nahni kunbarlah nuye kumuken. Kanmadbu dja ngadjuhme nganan.
ex.xe: These are the tracks of a freshwater crocodile. Wait for me while I swim out and have a look for it.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, Biyuk biyuk story

sn.de: Slide track of crawling animals, mostly reptiles, especially crocodiles and goannas.

ex.xv: Mengerrdji birrihni kunred Kunbarlanja.
ex.xe: Mengerrdji people used to be at Oenpelli.

sn.de: Kunwinjku name for Gunbalanya, formerly known as Oenpelli.

ng: Oenpelli itself is a corruption of the original Erre name for the area, ‘Uwunbarlany’, which the Kunwinjku word derives from. It has often been spelled 'Kunbarllanjnja' based on a different orthography, however there is no need for these extra continuant consonants as the single consonant has scope over both syllables.

ex.xv: Bu benewam benekang kundjabarrk dja kunbarlkbu.
ex.xe: The two of them took string bags and digging sticks along.
ex.so: Mangiru, Faith, ‘Kakkak dja Wurdyaw Benewam Mankinjdjek’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, 1976

sn.de: Digging stick, an implement associated with women.

ng: Kunbarlkbu is more of a low country word (birriwinjku), while kunkaninj is more associated with escarpment country dialects.

ex.xv: Kabirribarndaddukkan ba kukalkid kadjalboyo kore kunjam.
ex.xe: The emu legs are trussed up before roasting to ensure juices are retained within the stomach cavity.
ex.so: Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : Indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 138

re: glands in groin and under arms, lymph nodes

ex.xv: Yiddok yibarndorrkbabang?
ex.xe: Are your glands tender?

ex.xv: Ngabarndorrklurlme.
ex.xe: My lymph nodes are swollen.

sn.de: Lymph nodes, glands in groin and under arms.

ex.xv: Dja bu bolkkime bininj nawu karrowen wanjh karlba kabirrimang kabirribiddadjkerren karlba kore kunbende kare kore kunbid.
ex.xe: Nowadays when someone dies, people take yellow (or red) ochre and paint from their wrists down to their hands with it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Minj ngarrbenngeybun yabok wardi kunbeng.
ex.xe: We don't say the names of our sisters as we find it offensive.

sn.de: Faculty of understanding, cognition and sensibility; mind.

ex.xv: Marla nakka nabang bu kanbaye dja kandong kunberd ngalengarre.
ex.xe: Scorpions are dangerous if they bite us, they strike us with their tail.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kunberl nganmarnebom.
ex.xe: He broke my arm.

se.de: Lead someone by the arm, arrest someone

ex.xv: Malamalaywi ngarridolkkan ngarrinan kunberle kayo.
ex.xe: We get up in the morning and see that there is dew.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Konhda karriyonginj kunberle kankarrmeng.
ex.xe: We slept here and got covered with dew.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalbu bonbon ngarringeybun boken mayhmayh ngalkudji ngalmudburlerri dja ngalberrekalkbele ngalbuyika ngaldjalmudbulerri.
ex.xe: There are two birds we call “bonbon” (cormorant), one has black feathers and a white chest, and the other is all black.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kabirrimarnbun nawu marebu kunbid bedberre.
ex.xe: They make pandanus mats by hand.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Birribidkurrmerreni kore kunwardde wanjh birrikuykmi kunbid bedberre delek dorrengh wanjh birribidbokyoy kunbidbok bedberre.
ex.xe: They placed their hands on the rock, then sprayed white ochre from their mouths over their hands, so there was a print of their hands left behind.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Hand, with one's hands, by hand.

ex.xv: Ngalbu karndjawarra ngalkka ngalengman kore kurrula kadjalyo. Karringun ngalkanjmak karringun kunberl dja kunbid ngalengarre.
ex.xe: Mud crabs live by the ocean. They're good eating, we eat their claws and legs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Paw, claw, etc. The 'hand' of any animal.
Button, any button-like object, especially on electronic appliances.

ex.xv: Bu karrire kore kuwarde karribidbun karringimen kore kuwarderurrk karrinan kunbidbok bedberre dabborrabbolk nawu birridowerrinj birribidbokkurrmerrinj bu korroko.
ex.xe: When we go up into the escarpment and go into caves, we see the hand stencils of the old people who have passed away, and placed their hand prints there a long time ago.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey birridulknani birrinani kunbidbok kore dulklirrhmi nuye kunbidngalanj.
ex.xe: In the old days people would go and look at the trees and see the claw marks where his [the possum’s] claws had scratched the tree.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: A distinctive mark left by the hand of a person or animal such as claw marks.

ex.xv: Kunkarrngbakmeng or kunbidkukudji mandjewk wanjh, ngarrimdurndi ngorengngalmeng, doweni wanjh.
ex.xe: So after four or five years we came back, and he got sick. In fact he was dying.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Manbu kunbidmanem makka bu ngarrihwarlbun ngarrikombukdowen kukku wanjh bu ngarribongalke kukku wanjh ngarribodudmang kunbid ngadberre bu ngarribodangkenworren kore kunbidmanembeh ngadberre.
ex.xe: When we're out hunting and we're thirsty, when we find some water we scoop it up in the palms of our hands and pour it into our mouths.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey birridulknani birrinani kunbidbok kore dulklirrhmi djebuyh nuye kunbidngalanj.
ex.xe: In the old days people would go and look at the trees and see the claw marks where the possum’s claws had scratched the tree.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngardukki kunbirrkbirrk, minj nangale kadjirdmang!
ex.xe: Leave the ribs for me (to eat), hands off!
ex.so: 'The Greedy Emu', Skinnyfish TV, 2018

ex.xv: Wanjh ngalbu Ngarrbek njilngwarreminj dja yidduy duninjh bu beneburrinj kaluk lobmeng mey kunwardde dja bibodmengerrehmeng kore kubodme ngarre wanjh kunmekbe kunu Ngalmangeyi kakarrme kunbodmengalng.
ex.xe: Echidna was very upset and threw a big rock at Long-necked Turtle and it hit her in the back. That's why the Long-necked Turtle has a shell now.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill, 'Ngalmangeyi dja Ngarrbek' in Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, pp. 32-33

ex.xv: Nakudji bininj mey mandengeyi wanjh kunmadj barnhbarnameng kore mandengeyi kubodme wanjh kunyarl mey dukkang.
ex.xe: A man got a car and put his swag up on the roof, then took some string and tied it on.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakudji balwam biboknang kahbokyo kore kunkih.
ex.xe: One of them went a bit further and saw his footprints in the mud.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine, ‘Nakudji Wurdyaw Bengwabom’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre [no date recorded]

ex.xv: Bu kunbolidj birridjareni nawu bininj dja daluk wanjh lawk bindiyilkbuni bindibolidjmarnbuni.
ex.xe: If men or women wanted scarification, they would cut each other with stone knives and make raised scars.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Cicatrice, often cause by intentional scarification to leave a design or series of cuts on various parts of the body (upper arms, chest, breasts, buttocks).

ex.xv: Kunbolkkurulk.
ex.xe: Place belonging to the Kurulk clan.

se.de: Abandon a place, leave a place for a long time.
Be boring (of a place), be destroyed (of a place).

sn.de: Placename that designates a small locality as opposed to kun-bolkngeykimuk 'large named region'.

ex.xv: Kunbonjdjek ngarrowen.
ex.xe: I'm feeling the cold.

ex.xv: Korroko bininj birrini kunred Kabbari / Nawu kunborrk birrikarmi birriborrkkeyi (Wildflower Band, Kabbari, 2009)
ex.xe: A long time ago people lived on this land Kabbari / They used to have special ceremonies, singing and dancing in that place (Wildflower Band, Kabbari, 2009)

ex.xv: Dja nawu nabiwo nakka birrinani kore kunboy birriboybakkeyi birrimangi nawu mankung yika kuwardedume birrinani birrikarungi birrimangi nawu nabiwo.
ex.xe: They would see the ‘nabiwo’ native bee variety on a termite mound, then break the mound and get the honey out. Or sometimes they would see them in a mound of earth and dig up the honey there.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Termite mound. Sections broken off can be used as cooking stones in ground ovens.
Two dots at end of the caudal area of catfish such as kurrkurrbi.

ex.xv: Karriwilkdeng kunbule karribarrhbun.
ex.xe: (When) we cook something under the ground we cover it over with ashes.

ex.xv: Ngalmangiyi kunbodmengalng ngalengarre kabirrikinje kore kunak bu kabirringun kunkanj kabirriyakwon wanjh kabirrikinje kore kunak kunbule kayimerran.
ex.xe: People cook long-necked turtles in their shells, and when they've finished the flesh, the shell goes back on the fire and becomes ash.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Burddjimey mayh.
ex.xe: It picked up the scent of an animal.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Smell, scent, smell of people which can be ritually rubbed on other people and objects.

ex.xv: Naburrkkimuk.
ex.xe: Big bodied person.

ex.xv: Kandadju kundad dja ngamarrwedoweng.
ex.xe: Give me a (turtle) leg, I'm starving.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Korlobbarr kani kore mandalkwern kundalk dja kore kukku manbowern kaboyo.
ex.xe: Antilopine kangaroos live where there is lots of grass and plenty of water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bolkkime manbu kundalk manyilk kabirribimbun dja kabirrirarrkwe kore dolobbo dja kore djurra.
ex.xe: Nowadays people use sedge grass for painting and crosshatching on bark and paper.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Grass. A general term which can refer to different types of grass, rushes, sedge etc.

ex.xv: Nakka nawu kundalk kawunghme.
ex.xe: That guy smokes grass.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Delek kurrmeng kore kundang nuye wanjh bidkuykmerrinj kore djurra wanjh kunbid nuye kahbimdi kore djurra.
ex.xe: He put white ochre in his mouth, then sprayed it out over his hand so he made a hand stencil on the paper.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Mouth (human or animal), beak of bird.

ex.xv: Yirrangbalhmen!
ex.xe: Close the door!

ex.xv: Dangwelburlurlhmeng.
ex.xe: His lip has swollen up.

ex.xv: Duh karriraray.
ex.xe: Duh let's go [duh= Balngarra clan kundangwok].

ex.xv: Yinjarrakinjemen.
ex.xe: Cook it "njarra"! [njarra= Djordi clan kundangwok]

sn.de: System of interjections and terms which are associated with an individual clan and indicate membership in a particular clan or acknowledge that the speaker is on a site belonging to the clan with which the special clan interjection is associated.

ex.xv: Wanjh njamduhkeng mey kundurddu kundiw kundayken dja mannjam.
ex.xe: Then he pulled out its innards, taking its heart, its liver, its kidneys and its stomach.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, 'Bininj Yameng Kunj', Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

ex.xv: Kare odjbel kundayken nuye kabirrinan.
ex.xe: He is going to the hospital and they will look at his kidneys.

ex.xv: Kundebi ngabenbukkabukkang kabirriburrbun.
ex.xe: I’ve been teaching them Kundebi, they know it.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngabenbekken nahni wurdwurd nawu kabirrihre minj Kundebi kabirrikarrme.
ex.xe: I hear these children going about – they don’t have Kundebi. No. They just use people's names. They don’t use Kundebi with each other, no.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Special set of extensive tri-relational kinship terms. E.g. if person A is speaking to person B about person C, then A will use a term for C which also encodes B's kinship relationship to A. In turn B will likewise use a reciprocal referent in reference to C that also encodes the three way relationship.

se.de: Use triangular or third person kinship references.
Use triangular or third person kinship references with each other.

ur: Kuninjku = kunderbi, Kune = kunderbuy, Kundjeyhmi = kundembuy

ex.xv: Badjkid kabirrimarnbun dedjdjurduhdjurduh.
ex.xe: They make baskets with round bases.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

se.de: Base of a tree or plant.

ex.xv: Merridjdjin kurredjmimken.
ex.xe: Suppository.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Bininj Kunwok dialect associated with na-djordi, na-djorrolam, na-madjdjalum, na-mok and na-wurrbbarn clans (and numerous others as well). Spoken today at Marlkawo, Manmoyi, Kabulwarnamyo and Kamarrkawan.

ex.xv: Birrinahnani Wirrihwirrihyak nawu dengelurlmeng manbik bimarneni kore kurrenge nuye.
ex.xe: They looked after Wirrihwirrihyak, whose foot was swollen because he had a splinter in his foot.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, p. 6

ex.xv: Dengekerlkdanj ngadberre.
ex.xe: Our tyre is flat.

ex.xv: Mudkinjeng wanjh njamduhkeng kunnjam, kundurddu, kundiw dja kunbalem.
ex.xe: He singed its [the kangaroo’s] fur, then took out the guts, heart, liver and fat.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 44-47

ex.xv: Wurdwurd benekilekilelh benebokenh benewam benehkarungi mankuladj. Benehkarungi mankihkimuk, benedahkendoy kore kundjabarrk.
ex.xe: Two little children went digging up spike rush corms. They dug up some big ones and put them in a string bag.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: String bag. In Kundedjwarre clan lect however kundjabarrk is a synonym for kunmadj 'basket, swag, clothes etc'

ex.xv: Kundjaberle kunj birrimangi wanjh birrimilungi.
ex.xe: They would take a kangaroo’s shoulder blade and use that to cut vegetables into thin pieces.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Lanka kure bolk-Kalarrdju kundjak djang kahyo.
ex.xe: At the place Lanka in Kalarrdju clan estate there is a sickness dreaming site.

ex.xv: Nahni manimunak kahdowen, kundjak kakarrme lead-beh, manmim shotgun nguneng.
ex.xe: This magpie goose is sick, it has disease from consuming shotgun lead [pellets].

ex.xv: Bu korroko nawu birriyungki dabborrabbolk bu manbu kunak birriworrhmi wanjh kundulk bokenh birribakkeyi birrimarnbuni kundjakkorl kunbid bedberre birriburdebmi birriwurlhkeyi manbu kunak rungi.
ex.xe: In the old days when our ancestors made fires, they would break off two sticks and make firesticks out of them. They would put one between their hands and rub and a fire would start (because of the friction against the other stick).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Firesticks, made from the wood of Premna acuminata.

se.de: ‘Leftie’, a way of referring to a left-handed person without saying their name.

ex.xv: Nanih bininj djawurrkwernminj.
ex.xe: That man has grown a beard.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu karrikinje wanjh kadjawuywayhme.
ex.xe: When we cook them, steam comes out.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, ‘Yawk yawk’ story.

ex.xv: Bininj yameng nganabbarru wanjh mey mandjawak kukyilkbom mey kundjen dja kunbirrkbirrkbokenh wanjh babburlibom kore kukarlang.
ex.xe: A man shot a buffalo, then got a knife and cut off some meat, took the tongue and two ribs and carried it all off over his shoulder.
ex.so: Nabobbob, Rose, ‘Kunbidkudji Kunwok’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Yiman kayime “base”, manbu kabirriyime Balanda bu kundjen kunwok Balanda bedberre, kabirriyime.
ex.xe: Like a “base” as Balanda say, speaking in their Balanda tongue, their language.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Alwanjdjuk nakka bedman Kundjeyhmi.
ex.xe: Alwanjdjuk is the Kundjeyhmi name (for emu).
ex.so: George Djandjomer, quoted in Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 73

sn.de: The Kundjeyhmi language, spoken in present-day Kakaku National Park.

ng: Kundjeyhmi was previously written ‘Gundjeihmi’ in that language, but now follows Kunwinjku spelling conventions.

ex.xv: Kunkanj, wirlarrk, kundjikkakurrk, djenj, dja nawern nawu namakmak kabendjordmiwe, yun ngurrbenwon kandidjdjawa dja tea makka manwarre.
ex.xe: Meat, eggs, breast milk, fish, all those good foods are what grows them [children] up strong. Don’t give them flour and tea, that’s bad.
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace, untitled book, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw barrken duninjh wanjh nungka kundjikkakurrk kabongun bu ngalbadjan kabidjikkawon kadjikkangun.
ex.xe: Very young children drink breast milk, when their mothers breastfeed them.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Paperbark dish, the ends of which are tied up with string. Used to hold liquids, ochre, or slices of yam soaking in water in order to detoxify them.

ex.xv: Ngamokdjorlok.
ex.xe: I've got an ulcer.

ex.xv: Bikarrmeng bidjorrhdukkang kondah.
ex.xe: He grabbed him and held him around the trunk, here.

ex.xv: Ngarrbendjulngmang.
ex.xe: We're getting their dust (travelling behind them on a dirt road).

ex.xv: Kadjulngdjabdi.
ex.xe: The dust is rising up.

sn.de: Mud at the bottom of water, which can rise up into the water when disturbed in a similar way to dust rising into the air.

ex.xv: Wanjh benebidbom benewam benenang mandjurlemak. Ngalkudji yimeng, "Kondah yimray ngarrni ngarrngun kore mandjurlemak."
ex.xe: Then the two of them walked up and saw a nice bit of shade. One of them said “Come here, let’s sit here and eat in this good shade”.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kuhni bu Kunkare Birrihwarlbuni’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Birridjaldjurlebom kundjurle kondah…
ex.xe: They just put up a shelter here…
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Shade, or any large tree or structure that produces shade, also tall dense forest which provides shade.

se.de: Sit or be in the shade.

ex.xv: Kadjurrhbume.
ex.xe: Waterfall.

ex.xv: Kamdjurrhre.
ex.xe: Flood water is coming up.

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalyod ngalkka kumdjalrey kore manberrk, wanjh manbu kukku kundjurrh kumdjalbokimukmeni.
ex.xe: The Rainbow Serpent kept coming inland, and the sea kept flooding in (behind her as she went).
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T, 2005, p. 70

ex.xv: Bu kabirridowen daluk bininj wurdwurd wanjh mandubang kunworr kabirrimang kabirrirurrkwolngwon kundolng dorrengh.
ex.xe: If people die, women, men or children, then people get ironwood leaves and use them to ritually cleanse their house with smoke.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kundowiken minj kankelehme.
ex.xe: Death does not scare me.
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace & Rowe, Meryl (eds), ’Karriburlume God: Kunwinjku Song Book’, Gunbalanya, 1985, p. 13.

sn.de: A man's father-in-law, a man's son-in-law.

ex.xv: Djebuyh ngarrinan kore kundulk kabarndi dja karedmarnbun kaddum kurrulk.
ex.xe: We see possums sitting up in trees, and making their nests high up in trees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Any non-traditional wooden object, eg. coffin.

ex.xv: Namarrkon dulkarrekimuk.
ex.xe: The lightning spirit is powerful.

ex.xv: Karridjobdjobke ngalengman kundad bokenh dja ngalengman kundume kunberd dorrengh dja ngalengman kundjorrh kunkodj dorrengh.
ex.xe: We cut it up [the kangaroo] with the two legs being one cut, the lower back with the tail another cut, and the torso with the head another.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Lower back. In the case of kangaroos, this merges with the upper part of the tail and is often included with the tail in a cut of meat.

ex.xv: Bu barnnangarra wanjh kundung kanwolkan kabolkwolkan.
ex.xe: During the daytime the sun gives us light, it lights up the earth.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Nahni nawu kabenehbimdi mayh bokenh, korroko benebininjni, kaluk bedda benedanginj naburlaburlanjni, kundung benedi.
ex.xe: The two animals in this painting were originally human beings, two Nabulanj skin brothers of the Kundung matry.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Sun. Symbol or totem of the matry yarriyarninj.

ex.xv: Werrk dungwam.
ex.xe: Hurry up, time is gone.

se.de: Sun is moving, time is passing.
Get too late, become too late.

sn.de: Name of the easternmost variety of Bininj Kunwok spoken south and south-east of Maningrida at the communities of Buluhkaduru, Bolkdjam, Ankabadbirri and Korlobidahdah.

ex.xv: Wularla kakayhmire kayime kaaaay, kunekke.
ex.xe: The Spectacled hare wallaby goes along calling out, it says, 'kaaaay' like that.

ex.xv: Kunmekbe ngamulewan.
ex.xe: That’s what I’m going to talk about.

ex.xv: Wanjh kunmekbeh ngalbu kurdukadji minj kadolkan dja ngalweldjumbung.
ex.xe: So that is why the emu has short wings and cannot fly.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, p. 24

sn.de: That one, in that manner, at that time, for that reason.

ex.xv: Kungorrk ngandadjkeng kunronj.
ex.xe: The water came up to my waist.

ex.xv: Yiborrahkendo kungorrk.
ex.xe: Fill the container up half way.

ex.xv: Wanjh nungka ngokko dokmeng kukebrok dingihdi kumhkunidi.
ex.xe: And so he had gone ahead in that direction, and was waiting there to kill them.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 36-39

ex.xv: Djalakkiradj dorrengh birrikunibarndi kore kurrulk birrimadbuni karlerrh kumrey.
ex.xe: They would stand on a log over the river, waiting for the Long Tom fish to come past to spear them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: With violent intent, e.g. with intention to hunt something or kill someone.

se.de: Lie in wait to hunt something, ambush.

sn.de: Ambush, wait somewhere with the intention of killing someone or hunting something.

re: language name, variety of Bininj Kunwok
sn.de: One of the language variety names of Bininj Kunwok, spoken by people in the lower Mann and Liverpool Rivers districts.

ex.xv: Wanjh kabirrikakinje bu kunka ngalengarre wanjh kabirrimang manu
ex.xe: Then they burn the spines [of the echidna], then they get a piece of flat wood and scrape the spines off.
ex.so: Narndal, Julie et. al. ‘Manme: Stories about food - Kunwinjku’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: Dja nahni kakarrme danjbik kunka yiman namardaka, dja nakanjmak bu karringun.
ex.xe: And it [the salmon catfish] has three spines like an eel-tailed catfish, and its flesh is good eating.
ex.so: Forbes, Brenda & Brennan, Queenie, ‘Nahni Djenj: Karribolkburrbun kore karrihmanamang’, Bamyili Press, Barunga, 1981

ex.xv: Yikadadjkemen, warde kabendengedjudme.
ex.xe: Cut off the spikes, otherwise they’ll poke someone in the foot.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Spines. Spikes or spines on the bodies of fish such as the three spikes on catfish and the spines of echidnas.

ex.xv: Nganekakbirlikan.
ex.xe: We're going (hunting) at night with torches.

sn.de: Night (the period of darkness between sunset and sunrise).

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk ngarrbennani nawu mayh kunkal birrikalbakkeyi wanjh birrikaldjorrhmi dja birrikalnurrngmi birrirawoni kunkal dja kunkanj dorrengh. Nawu yiman kayime kunkal kunj nganabbarru, bulikki dja mayhmayh nawu manimunak.
ex.xe: In the old days we would see people breaking open bones to get the marrow, banging the bones [on rocks, wood etc] to get the marrow out, sucking the marrow from the bones, or mixing the marrow with meat - for instance the marrow from kangaroo, buffalo, cow or magpie goose bones.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yikanem!
ex.xe: Hey, you got ears? (listen to me!)

ex.xv: Dja yika mayh nawu nabang yiman nayin kinga nawu kanbaye karridowen, dja nganabbarru nawu kanbun kunkanemdulk nuye karridowen.
ex.xe: But some animals are dangerous, like snakes or crocodiles which bite us or buffalo which hit us with their horns and we die.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu kandikanemrurrkwolkankenh.
ex.xe: Auroscope (device for seeing inside the ear with a small light).
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010, p. 55

ex.xv: Kandikanemrurrknanken.
ex.xe: Auroscope (literally: ‘that which they use to see our ear canal’)
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010, p. 35

ex.xv: Kabirrikanemrurrkkurlahbalhme.
ex.xe: They will perform tympanoplasty.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010, p. 34

ex.xv: Yiman bu nayahwurd, yika mobik, minj kawernhkanjdi nungka kadjalwohdjobke mandjawak kunwardde kunyahwurd kunkanj dja kamunkewe ba kare kakimukmen kabalemdangen.
ex.xe: If the [kangaroos] are young or skinny, without much flesh on them, he [Nakidjkidj] will just cut a little bit of meat off them with his stone knife and let them go again, so they can get big and fat.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 208

ex.xv: Bu kunkare daborrabbolk birrirey manberrk birriwarlbuni wanjh birrinani budjiked nawu kurralkwaken birribuni birringuni.
ex.xe: In the old days, when people used to go into forest hunting, they would see wild cats and kill them and eat them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: In the distant past. In the past, a long time ago, in the old days.

ex.xv: Korrokko dabborrabbolk bu birriyoy kore manberrk wanjh kundulk birridulkdadjkeyi birridulkdjabnami manbu karlang wanjh borlorl birriwarnamkurrmi yerre wanjh kunkod yika dolobbo birribarrkbuni bu birrimarnbuni kunkodbarre kore birriyoykenh.
ex.xe: In old days, when people camped out in the bush, they would cut forked branches and erect them in the ground, then put cross beams between them and cover the structure with paperbark or eucalyptus bark to make a shelter for sleeping.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunkarlewobe korroko nawu dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni kore mankaboberl birrikurrmi. Kaluk kundulk birrimangi birridjabdjabnami, wanjh yerre kundalk birrikurrmi, birrimarnbuni djaldangrurrkni kore djenj birringimi, dja birridjalni kumekke minj birribebmeninj.
ex.xe: Our ancestors used to make fenced fish traps in the narrow tributaries of rivers. They would stick a line of sticks into the creek bed, then fill in the gaps between them with grass, in such a way that there was a hole for fish to squeeze in, but they couldn't get out again and got stuck there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Stick fence in water courses used to catch fish. These are designed to let fish into a section of narrow river but not out again, or sometimes they are used to hold conical fish traps or mandjabu in place.

ex.xv: Mankung ngarrikarlkidbongun.
ex.xe: We drink the nectar from the honey (of flowers).

sn.de: Fluid from plants such as sap or the resin in orchids.

ex.xv: Yiman kabirriyime nawu kabirrire kabirribomang, mannekke manu kabirrihbonome manihmanu kunkalkkid, petrol manbu.
ex.xe: It’s like the ones who go and steal petrol, that stuff they sniff, that juice, petrol, that stuff.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Also used by some older people to refer to diesel or petrol.

ex.xv: Birrikani kured birrikinjeyi mannjam dja ngalbu burrk. Wanjh bindiwoni nawu kured birrihni. Manbu kunkalkkid makka kabirringeybun wulud.
ex.xe: They would take it [the sea turtle] home and cook it, the guts and the whole body, and share it with family in the camp. We call the juices from cooking the sea turtle “wulud”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Can refer to various bodily fluids such as amniotic fluid, synovial fluid or serous fluid.

ex.xv: Bu yekke dja wurrkeng kayimerran wanjh kunkarndum kayongen. Kukak yerrih. Wanjh bu malamalaywi ngarridolkkan ngarrinan kabolkbarrkbun kunkarndum. Wanjh ngarriyime "Aa, kunkarndum kankarrme".
ex.xe: In the seasons of Yekke and Wurrkeng, there is fog. Also at night. And when we get up in the morning and see the land covered in fog, we say "Ah, it's all foggy".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunkarndum kamre dja kukku kabokurrme.
ex.xe: The fog comes and leaves the ground wet with dew.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalyod kawehme kuluban. Bu karrinan nawern karridulubun, karringun kunkarrk. Bu karridjalburriwe, kunukka kunwarre.
ex.xe: Ngalyod the Rainbow Snake vomits up flying foxes. When we see a lot of them and shoot them, we have to cook and eat the lot, including the wing membranes. If we just chuck the membranes away, that is very bad.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 46

sn.de: Membrane, such as the membrane in bat wings and lambalk glider possums.

ex.xv: Kunkarrngbakmeng o kunbidkukudji mandjewk wanjh, ngarrimdurndi ngorengngalmeng.
ex.xe: So after four or five years we came back, and he started to get sick.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kunkarrngbakmeng kebbalhdjurri kabirrihni kore kabbal.
ex.xe: Four spoonbills standing on the floodplain.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Gabriel, 'The Kunwinjki Counting Book', Injalak Arts, Gunbalanya, 2016

ex.xv: Kaddumbeh kumboyakarrburreni dja bu kanjdji kururrk kunkayalanj yoy.
ex.xe: There was water flowing down from above, and the cave floor was sandy.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly W, ‘Kunkare Wurdyaw Djorlkmeng’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1975

ex.xv: Kumekke karrikukyibme kore kukayalanj. Djanay djang kahyo kanjdji kukurlk.
ex.xe: We sink down into the sand in that place. There is a yellow-spotted monitor Dreaming there under the earth.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kebbinjbinj nungkah.
ex.xe: He has a long/narrow nose.

ex.xv: Kabenekebrohrok.
ex.xe: Those two have the same face, those two look similar.

ex.xv: Kawk karrinan kani kore kukadjid kore kukku kaboyo kamodme djenj kamadbun kanan djenj kamre darnkih wanjh karranjbun kundang kunkeb nuye wanjh kawukme.
ex.xe: We see the Rufous Night Heron on the banks of the water, waiting quietly for fish. When a fish comes near, it spears it with its beak and swallows it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

re: grill (of a car, front of a car)

ex.xv: Maneh muddika yibimbu! 'Side way' yikukbimbu! … yikebkuyengka!
ex.xe: Draw a picture of that car! Draw it side on ... make the front of it longer!

sn.de: Bow of boat or front grill of a car.

ex.xv: Yikebkarrme?
ex.xe: Have you got a hook?

sn.de: Peg on the distal end of a spearthrower which is inserted into the end of a spear.
External entrance tunnel or tube to a native bee hive.

ex.xv: Yikebmarnbu ngarduk.
ex.xe: Fix up the fire for me (i.e. rearrange the logs to stoke it).

sn.de: End of a burning log, stick or other fuel.

ex.xv: Kebwarre.
ex.xe: This tyre valve is no good.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunkerlk kabirriyime 'ngaburrbun' la ngad kunrayek ngarriyime 'ngabengkan'.
ex.xe: The soft dialect speakers say 'ngaburrbun' but we hard dialect speakers use the word 'ngabengkan'.

sn.de: Term used by eastern Mayali speakers to describe the variety of Kunwinjku/Mayali spoken in the west,

se.de: Cook in a ground oven using pieces of antbed.

ex.xv: Manbu kunkih karrinan kubolkwern kore kabbal kayo. Bu kudjewk mandjewk kangurdme kaburnbun kunkihwi kayo.
ex.xe: We see mud in lots of areas where there are floodplains. When the rainy season stops, there is nothing but mud [in those areas].
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Wanjh nakudji balwam biboknang kahbokyo kore kunkih.
ex.xe: Then one of them went a bit further and saw his footprints in the mud.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine, ‘Nakudji Wurdyaw Bengwabom’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre [no date recorded]

ex.xv: Kunkod birrikodmangi bu kunbodbarre birrimarnbuni.
ex.xe: They would collect paperbark and make bark shelters.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra.

ex.xv: Yika nawu, wurdwurd nawu kabindikan kore kunkod kabirridirri ngalbabadjan.
ex.xe: Some of them, some of those kids, they [the parents] take them to card games where the mothers play.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kunkodbarre kunrurrk birrikodbarrebuni birrimarnbuni kore birriyoy bu Kudjewk.
ex.xe: They would make bark shelters to sleep in during the Wet Season.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Dja bolkkime minj karrinan manbu kunkodbarre dolobbo kunrurrk larrk dja kurrambalk manwern birrimarnbom nawu birrikukbele kore ngarriyo bu bolkkime yika kore tents kabirriyo.
ex.xe: But these days we don’t see shelters made from bark, there’s just lots of houses made by non-Indigenous people, or some people sleep in tents.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Bark shelter, literally ‘paperbark shelter’ but also used to refer to shelters made from other types of bark.

se.de: Make a shelter, make a bark shelter.

ex.xv: Kunkodjke bokenh ngarriyoy kumekke.
ex.xe: We stayed/slept there for three days.

sn.de: Days (lit: sleeps), effectively this word means a 24 hour period.

ng: Underlyingly -kodjke which through assimilation becomes -kodjdje and then deletion sometimes to -kodje

ex.xv: Kabirrikodjkuluborledke.
ex.xe: They are changing their minds.

se.de: Full of ideas, capricious ('too many ideas').

ex.xv: Kakodjngolbalabalahmen.
ex.xe: Cumulonimbus incas clouds are forming

sn.de: Storm cloud (cumulonimbus). These clouds are usually referred to by a verbal expression ka-kodjngolkan, literally ‘it-storm.cloud.takes’.

ex.xv: Ngalmangiyi ngalka ngalkomkuyeng dja ngarderrhwo ngalkomdjumbung.
ex.xe: The long-necked turtle [Chelodina rugosa] has a long neck, while the northern snapping turtle [Elseya dentata] has a short neck.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngakombabang.
ex.xe: I have a sore throat.

ex.xv: Bedda benedjangwarrewong namekke komnud djang wanjh warlahminj balwam kore Mangarrangki bininj nawu kumekke birrihyoy birridowerrinj rowk.
ex.xe: The two men had desecrated the Phlegm Dreaming site [by cutting the trees there to get wild honey], and so the Dreaming spread to Mangarrangki and the people living there all died.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Anburluddak kabun kongno kunkong kabun wanjh kakurrmehkrrme kawelengwirlarrkkabun.
ex.xe: She [the emu] hits the stringbark tree to knock off the bark which she places to make a nest so the eggs can be incubated.

ex.xv: Korodjardahmeng kunred kabolkngeyyo kore Manmoyi ngalengarre. Korroko dabborrabbolk birrimulewani bu ngalmekke ngalyod korodjardahmeng kumekke wanjh djang yimerranj.
ex.xe: Korodjardahmeng is the name of a place near Manmoyi. In the old days, our ancestors would tell the story of how the Rainbow Serpent got her body stuck there and became a sacred site.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Elongated winding shape, e.g. the body of a snake.

ex.xv: Dja wanjh birribuni mayh birriyimi, “Oh, nanih kakoymud Yarriburrik.”
ex.xe: As they hunted animals, they would say (for example) "Oh, this one belongs to the Yarriburrik matry”.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: System of matrilineal social categories or ‘matries’ consisting of yarriburrik (fire totem), yarriyarninj (sun totem), yarriwurrkkarr (green ant totem) and yarrikarnkurrk (rock totem). Other categories are sometimes also used which differ amongst the various dialects e.g. mandjarrakbuma (water totem, Kunwinjku dialect).

ex.xv: Bu mak manbuyika manu mak, nawu wurdyaw bininj kadjordmen kamyawurrinjmen, yikahyika kabirrire kure fs:doctor yikahyikah mak kabirrire kure kunkuk bininj.
ex.xe: Another thing is, when a young boy grows up and becomes a teenager sometimes they are circumcised by a doctor but sometimes they are circumcised in the traditional way by an Aboriginal man.

ex.xv: Yidjare bun kukkurrme.
ex.xe: Did you want me to hit you and knock you down to the ground?

ex.xv: Nganabbarru ngarridulubom kakukyo kumekke.
ex.xe: We shot a buffalo and its body is lying there.

sn.de: Body, shape, form. Most frequently used as an incorporated noun as part of other words.

se.de: Carry a body (e.g. of an animal after hunting it)

se.re: place a body, knock to ground
se.de: Place a body, kill or knock to the ground.
Look like, resemble (in body or shape).

ng: most frequently attested as an incorporated noun

ex.xv: Kunkun yibidwayhmen!
ex.xe: Lift up your right hand!

se.de: On the right hand side, to the right.

ex.xv: Bininj nawern kabirriborrkke kunkurdu.
ex.xe: Lots of people dance for public ceremony.

ex.xv: Kurdumak bu kahborrkke.
ex.xe: She dances really well.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mahni mandule karrbarda minj mandjamun yiman kayime ceremony duninjh bininj kabirriwayini dja daluk larrk kabirridjalborrkke kunkurdu. Kore yiman mulil dja wurdwurd kabindibukkan kore school.
ex.xe: The Karrbarda [Long Yam] song is not sacred like a real ceremony, men sing and women just do the dances. Like in public ceremonies, or they show it to the children at school.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Public ceremonial dancing of a large group.

ex.xv: Kurlahno karriwe.
ex.xe: We throw the skin away.

ex.xv: Kunkurlah nganabbarru birridurrkmirri morlehmorlenj dja binihbininj kunkurlah nganabbarru djirla birrikurlahbuni wanjh birrikurlahdaweyi kurrungbang birrikurlahkurrmi kurlahdayoy kurlahbukmeni.
ex.xe: Men and women used to work with buffalo hides, they would salt them and put them out in the hot sun. The hides would lie there in the sun until they dried.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Njale yikarrme kunkurlah?
ex.xe: What is your kinship subsection (skin)?

se.de: Skin an animal, salt the hide of an animal.

sn.de: Red. There is no abstract term for ‘red’, so terms which mean red are based on concrete things.

ex.xv: Ngayi Mehme kondanj, konda ngahni kukurlk.
ex.xe: I am the stubble quail, and I live on the ground.

se.de: On the ground, in the ground.

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan dja ngalyaw benewarlbuni kunkurlurrk.
ex.xe: A mother and her daughter went gathering Memecylon pauciflorum fruits.
ex.so: Ngalmakgu Nabobbob, ‘Ngalbadjan dja ngalyaw benewarlbuni kunkurlurrk’ in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

ex.xv: Yukkuyukku nawu mayh kukyahwurd nganbengdayhke ngadberre bu manme kakinje wanjh karung ba bu ngarrire ngarrimang manu manme yiman kayime manyuku, mandjurrukumarlba, kunkurlurrk dja mak manwern manbu manbarnem.
ex.xe: The firefly is a small insect, (the appearance of) which lets us know that fruit is ripening, so that we can go and gather it, for example manyuku berries (Antidesma parvifolium), mandjurrukkumarlba (Antidesma ghaesembilla) and kunkurlurrk (Memecylon pauciflorum) and all kinds of other fruits.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Memecylon pauciflorum, a tree with edible grape-like fruits.

Speech style used with those called nakurrng or ngalkurrng which includes both a special register of language used in avoidance relationships (also sometimes referred to as 'mother-in-law'language) and the style of speech used by those in joking relationships.

ex.xv: Birriburreni manbu kunyid mankimuk birrikurlbarey bu kunlon kore kunkodj yika kundad bindiyami birringorengrey yika djal bulkkidj birridoweni.
ex.xe: They fought each other in a big feud, they bled from wounds to the head and speared each other in the legs and went around injured, or even actually died.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nahni bininj mankang mandengeyi wanjh kunlon bibom bu kahngorengyo.
ex.xe: That man was involved in a car crash and now he's lying there injured.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunmadj kadjongburren.
ex.xe: He's putting on clothes.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Benewam kore kulabbarl. Wanjh benemadjkurrmeng, wanjh benewurlebmeng.
ex.xe: They went to the billabong. Then they put their things down and went into the water.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 68-71

sn.de: Generic term for bags and containers of all kinds, also bedding and other personal possessions. Often used also to refer to large pandanus fibre baskets.

ex.xv: Ankurndilinj kunkurra kabun kaworlhme kunmalaworr. (Djnj)
ex.xe: The Leptospermum tree branches sway in the breeze.
ex.so: Nadjamerrek, Lofty Bardayal, Russel, Jeremy & Garde, Murray, ‘A Preliminary List of Kundedjnjenghmi Plant Names’, NLC, Kabulwarnamyo, 2003

se.de: Carry a leafy branch as camouflage.

ex.xv: Yerre bimurrngmoyhmey bimurrngkurrmeng kore kahwodjruhrurrk ba kunmalng nuye karrurndeng kore kunred nuye.
ex.xe: After that she took his bones and placed them inside a hollow log coffin, so that his spirit could return to his homeland.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Warramurrungunjdji wam kore manberrk benmalngkurrmeng wurdwurd kore Cooper Creek, Mount Borradaile.
ex.xe: Warramurrungunjdji went through the land and placed ‘Spirit Children’ at Cooper’s Creek and Mount Borradaile.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Minj nangale kabidbun kondah, wardi kabirrimalngwakwarren.
ex.xe: Nobody is allowed to climb up here. They might lose their life [spirit].
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Clan spirit which returns to a deceased's country after death. In a Christian context this word refers to the soul.

se.re: enjoy the taste of something, like something
se.de: Enjoy the taste of something, like something.

ex.xv: Yika ngarrire kunwarddebim ngarrinan kunmayali wanjh ngarrimang.
ex.xe: Sometimes we go and look at rock art and then we get ideas [inspirations for our own paintings] from that.

ex.xv: Birrimayaliborledkeng.
ex.xe: They changed their minds.

ex.xv: Manbu kunrorre kahkarrkini Uranium, kabirridjuhke ba bu minj kundjulng kamarnburren wardi kunmayorrk kamre wanjh kadjulngdolkayhwe.
ex.xe: When there is ground that contains uranium [from the mining process], they will sprinkle the ground with water to stop [contaminated] dust being taken up by the wind.

ex.xv: Minj ngarrimendjorrmayi.
ex.xe: We haven't gained that knowledge yet.

se.de: Be able to see what someone is thinking, tell their feelings.
An expression of affection, 'my dear friend' etc. Literally 'I bite your forehead'.

ex.xv: Kodjbalabalaminj dja kunmim nuye mimkimukminj wanjh yimerranj mayhmayh ngokngok.
ex.xe: His head became flat and his eyes grew wide and he turned into a bird, the owl.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yimimdaykimuk.
ex.xe: You big eye [swear word].

ex.xv: Njale kankuknan yimimdaykimuk!
ex.xe: What are you staring at big eyes!

ex.xv: Nalkbom wanjh bimimdjuhkeng kunmimnalk ngalengarre wanjh mimmakminj.
ex.xe: She cried and her tears fell into his eyes which healed him.

ex.xv: Ngakanemmok.
ex.xe: I've got an infected ear.

ex.xv: Njale ngunbayeng? Ngadjalmok.
ex.xe: What happened to you? I've just got a sore.

se.de: Singe the fur or feathers off an animal.

sn.de: Thin piece of skin tissue (as in eardrum).

ex.xv: Nawu djenj karlarlbba nakka namak bu ngarringun dja murrngwern. Kunmurrng manwern dja kunkanj manyahwurd.
ex.xe: Bony Bream is a good fish for eating, but it has a lot of bones. A lot of bones and not much flesh.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kaluk ngamurrngname.
ex.xe: After I'll put the bones on (a painting).

ex.xv: Nadjurrk nakka bininjni rengehrey kore borledmikenh Demed mandulum bu korroko. Nungka yerrkang ngunjngehmeng wanjh yimerranj kunwardde. Bolkkime nungka karrinan djudkulmeng dja kunney nuye kore kunbard karrmeng.
ex.xe: Nadjurrk was once a man who would walk around on the other side of Demed hill, a long time ago. He sat down to rest and turned into a rock. We can still see him there, head down and elbows on knees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birringadkarungi kore kukku birribonguni.
ex.xe: In the old days, people used to dig wells to drink water from.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

se.de: Dig a well, dig a hole to find underground water.

ex.xv: Kukkurr yibolkbengkan kure kunngarlk karri.
ex.xe: Do you know that place Kukkurr where there's a cliff.

ex.xv: Ngarringeykurrmeng.
ex.xe: We gave him/her/it a name.

ex.xv: Ngalngeykuyengkuyeng.
ex.xe: She has a long name.

se.de: One's Aboriginal name, as opposed to their Balanda name or nickname.
Say the name of something or someone.

sn.de: Pandanus leaves, used as a weaving material. Specifically the central sheath of new pandanus leaves. The pandanus palm itself is called manbelk.

se.de: Split pandanus leaves in preparation for weaving them.

ex.xv: Kunngol kumwam manngolburlerri, wanjh djakduy.
ex.xe: Black clouds came in, and it started raining.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, Yawk Yawk story.

ex.xv: Ngalkordow karrbennan birriwern kabirrire kore kabbal dja yika karrbennan kaddum kungol.
ex.xe: We see lots of brolgas walking on the floodplains or flying in the sky (literally: up in the clouds).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Up in the sky, in the clouds.

ex.xv: Ngangolekwarreminj.
ex.xe: I was puffed out.

ex.xv: Nungka yimeng - bu kandikadjung wanjh kunngolek won kunkuyeng.
ex.xe: He said if you follow me, I will give you a long life.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 120

ex.xv: Nakudji nawu bininj doweng yakminj wanjh malahmalaywi birrikang birrikukdudji wanjh birrimdurndi kore kured birrihyoy. Birribolkkaruy wanjh bindikukdjuhkeng nawu namud nuye bu kunngoninj dja kunmalng nuye wanjh birriyerrkkeng kore kubuhbuburrrk bedberre. Wanjh yerre bindikukdolngbom mandubang kunmalaworr. Bu birriyakwong wanjh birribolkdudji.
ex.xe: A man passed away, and the next day they took him and buried him, then returned to their home. They made a shallow hole and performed the funeral ceremony by hosing his family down (when they got into the hole). This freed his spirit from their bodies. Afterwards they smoked the people with ironwood leaves. When they were done, they closed the hole over again.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Power, stamina, physical energy, bodily strength.

se.de: Remove the guts of an animal before cooking.
Seduce, cause to be taken with something.

sn.de: Section of a honey hive where the bees lay eggs.

se.de: Take innards of an animal, gut.

ex.xv: Nganjilngwarreminj
ex.xe: I feel sad.

se.de: Spit a long distance (this is how the archerfish knocks insects into the water).

ex.xv: Kunkerlk kabirriyime 'ngaburrbun' la ngad kunrayek ngarriyime 'ngabengkan'.
ex.xe: The soft dialect speakers say 'ngaburrbun' but we hard dialect speakers use the word 'ngabengkan'.

sn.de: Description of language dialects as 'hard'. The eastern dialects of Mayali are described by westerners as kunrayek. The Kuninjku describe the Kune dialect as kunrayek when comparing it to their own but call their own dialect kunrayek when comparing it to that spoken for example at Kunbarlanja.

ex.xv: Kukkurrmeng manu karrbarda, dja wam kunrerrng, kumdurndi wanjh worrhmeng, wilkdi manu karrbarda.
ex.xe: She put down the long yams, then went for firewood, came back and started a fire and cooked the yams under the hot ashes.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Nahni daluk boken benemdolkkang kakbi, benemrey kunronj beneboyawani.
ex.xe: Those two women came from the north, they came looking for water.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

se.de: On the ground, in the ground

ex.xv: Dolobbo birrimangi bu birrimarnbuni kunrurrk kore birriyoy.
ex.xe: They would get bark and make shelters to live in.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Birribolkngalkeng, birribolknameng, kondah birrirurrknameng. Minj mankimuk kunrurrk, kunyahwurd laik ngad bu kodbarre birribarrkbom.
ex.xe: They [white people] found this place, they set it up, then they built houses. Not really big houses, they were only small, like our little bark shelters.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Enclosed space, hole, cave, room of a dwelling, house, shelter.

ex.xv: Yo kayudyudme. Bu ngunkodjnan, wanjh kayudyudme. Bu yimolknan wanjh kunu yibun.
ex.xe: Yes, she [emu] walks around. If she sees you coming she takes off. If you can spy on her without her seeing you, then in that way you'll be able to kill her.

sn.de: In that way, like that. Maybe a shortened version of kunukka.

ex.xv: Bukka wanjh kunubewu ngamed Badmarddi bedberre.
ex.xe: Maybe that [place] belongs to Badmardi clan people.

ex.xv: Yerre birriwern bininj birrimwam birridjawam-'Baleh nawu wurdyaw Wurrakak?' Bengdubberranj 'Kaluk ngayawan namekke wurdyaw.' Dja burrbuni namekke wurdyaw yakminj. Namekke wurdyaw wanjh kunwardde. Kunubewu kahmurrngyo kumekke. Nungka nabangni, namekke Wurrakak.
ex.xe: After, a lot of people came and asked, 'Where’s that baby, Wurrakak?' 'He’s gone scrub I'll look around after for that baby.' But he knew that baby was finished. That baby is now a rock. There might be bones somewhere nearby. He was a cheeky fellow, that Wurrakak.

sn.de: That which might be, maybe, that which.

ex.xv: Yiman kayime komorlo kamdolkan kamre kore kured kayerrkan yika mak kadjalwakbun, wanjh kunuka yiman kanbengdayhke bu kabirridowen kore kubolkbuyika nawu namud kadberre.
ex.xe: For example when an egret comes flying over, landing in the camp or just circling overhead, in that way it tells us that someone in our family is going to die in another area.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, p. 58

sn.de: In that way, like that. Sometimes shortened to kunu.

re: about this, in connection with this

ex.xv: Kunukka wanjh ngambom.
ex.xe: That’s why I have rung (you on the phone), about this matter.

sn.de: In relation to this, that (just mentioned).
Season name for the very first rain of the wet season, before the wet season properly sets in.

ex.xv: Kore wurdyaw kadahkendi bu kunnjam kahni kunwalirrng ngarriyime.
ex.xe: We call the place where a baby is, inside the belly, the womb.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Daluk ngalbu kayawkan wurdyaw kore kunjam ngalengarre kunwalirrng.
ex.xe: A woman who is carrying a baby in her womb.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunj ngalbu karndayh bu yaw kayawkan wanjh kayawdahkendi kore kunwanke ngalengarre.
ex.xe: When a female Antilopine kangaroo carries her young, the joey sits in her pouch.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kabirriwaralnarren kore baddumang.
ex.xe: They look at themselves in the mirror.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu dirdko wanjh kabirriwaralnarren, yiman kayime mak kundung bu koyek dja karrikad bu kadungdi wanjh kabirriwaralnarren.
ex.xe: By moonlight people can see the shadow they cast, just like when the sun is in the west or the east.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kabirriwaralkurrme nawu mayh dja njalehnjaleh kore djurra, dolobbo, dja kuwardderurrk bu wanjh kabirrinan nawu waral kore kabirribimbun.
ex.xe: They put images of animals and different things on paper, bark and rock shelters, and then they can look at the pictures.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kawaraldi.
ex.xe: A drawing is there.

sn.de: Engraving, a drawing of a figure.
Spirit, dead person's spirit (the one that wanders around after death), although not all speakers in all dialects agree with this sense.

se.de: Place itself (of a picture). Said of rock paintings that were not painted by people, but are transfigurations of spirits.

ex.xv: Wurrakkak djareni diwirrinj kumekke kukbuyikameng kukyimerranj kunwardde.
ex.xe: Wurrakkak decided to stay in that place and turned into a rock.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Kinship karrbenmirndemornname bu wurdwurd, or dabborrabbolk kunekke karriyimowon. Yika mak karribebbebme kunwardde, kundung.
ex.xe: We put people in different kinship different groups, children and adults alike. Some of us are divided into Kunwardde or Kundung totems, etc.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Stone, rock. Symbol or totem of the matry (kunkoymud) yarrikarnkurrk.

ex.xv: Kunwardde ngandiwon.
ex.xe: They give me money.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

se.de: To be (of rocks), there are rocks.

ex.xv: Nawu mayh ngarrikinje yiman kayime manimunak dja ngalmangiyi wanjh ngarriwarlaybun dja ngarrbenwon kunwarlaykudji dja ngadman.
ex.xe: When we cook an animal, for example a magpie goose or a long-necked turtle, we cut it up, give other people a piece and keep a piece for ourselves.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Cut of meat, piece of a butchered animal.

ex.xv: Kandibekka, ngayi kunwarre ngawokdi.
