ex.xe: Listen to me, I've got something unpleasant to say.

sn.de: Something bad, bad language or a speech of harsh words.

ex.xv: Kardabaybay karrinan kore kundulk kahbarndi kahkukdayo kunwel ngalengarre kawelwarlahmen kahbarndi.
ex.xe: We see the darters up in trees, sitting there in the sun with their wings outstretched.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Take something out of the coals/ashes where it has been cooking.
In the hot coals, under the ashes.

ex.xv: Bedda karrikad Kunwinjku nawu kunkerlk kabirriwokdi, la ngad kunrayek ngarriwokdi.
ex.xe: Those people to the west speak Kunwinjku which is the 'soft' dialect but we [Kuninjku] speak the 'hard' dialect.

sn.de: Language name for dialect of Bininj Kunwok with the largest number of speakers. Kunwinjku is the main dialect spoken at Kunbarlanja, as well as outstations such as Mamardawerre, Kumarrirnbang, Kudjekbinj and Manmoyi. In older orthographic conventions the word was spelt 'Gunwinggu'.

ex.xv: Nawu dabborrabbolk birrimirndemonamerrinj wanjh bindidjawani nawu yawuhyawurrinj bu kunwirle nuyeni nawu nayawurrinj doweng.
ex.xe: The old people gathered together and asked the young men about the movements of the young man who had died [where he had been prior to his death].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kudjewk kadjalwohre, kaluk minj kawirlengurdme, ngalwohwern [...].
In the wet season they (emus) keep wandering, they never tire of walking around, stopping off here and there all the time.
ex.so: Jimmy Kalarriya, quoted in Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : Indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 15

sn.de: Wanderings, movements, comings and goings, where someone is going or has gone.

se.re: stop wandering, settle down in one place
se.de: Stop wandering around, settle down in one place.
Go around talking or calling out.
Wait for word, wait for someone to call.
Make a verbal agreement or arrangement, agree.
Obey, pay attention to what someone says.

ex.xv: Yina kaworrbaye duruk.
ex.xe: Look that dog biting the leaves.

ng: Either kunworr or manworr are acceptable in some dialects (e.g. Kundedjnjenghmi) although when incorporated into an adjectival construction the prefix is usually fv:(m)an- e.g. manworrbuyika 'a different kind of leaf'

ex.xv: Minj kabirridjare kabirrikarrme kunwoybuk. Bedman bebbehbeh kabirridjare kabirridjalle munguyh.
ex.xe: They don’t want to keep hold of the truth. They just want to do their own thing all the time.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kayime, “Yinahnarren. Wardi yiwarreworren… Wanjh ngarrbalanhmang bu kunmakmak kore kundjamunkenh kunwok kahyo, ba ngarrkarrme kunwoybuk.”
ex.xe: She’ll say, “Be careful lest you become a bad person… We would lose the goodness which is in that sacred teaching, which allows us to possess the truth.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Truth. In usage this word often implies the correctness of traditional law or other established wisdom.

ex.xv: Kunwurr ngarrowen.
ex.xe: I've got diarrhoea.

ex.xv: Ngawong. Wardi kunyid marnbuyinj.
ex.xe: I gave it to him. Otherwise it would have caused an argument.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

se.de: Get angry at someone, speak harshly to someone.
Start a fight, look for trouble.

ex.xv: Yiddok yiyidmekanjkurlbare?
ex.xe: Have your gums been bleeding?
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Yiberlyilkimuk.
ex.xe: You've got big veins in your arm.

ex.xv: Kunyil karrikurlbalobme, kakurlbadurndeng kore kunrdurddu.
ex.xe: Vein (circumlocution).
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Kunyil karrikurlbalobme kunrdurddubeh.
ex.xe: Artery (circumlocution).
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Kunyil kunrdukken.
ex.xe: Vas deferens.

sn.de: In general any thin vessel within the body.

ex.xv: Nawu kunyirrk yiman kayime djerrh nayahwurd nawu korroko birrikani dabborrabbolk bu birriwarlbuni. Wanjh kore kunyirrk bedberre kahdahkendi nawu yiman kayime lawk, ngolin, dja kunyarl.
ex.xe: 'Kunyirrk' is like a small string bag, that our ancestors used to take when they went hunting. In their string bags they would carry things like stone knives, beeswax and string.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunyirrk kabernalkan.
ex.xe: She's carrying a string bag over her shoulder.

ex.xv: Bu Kunabibi, Yabburlurrwa dja Mardayin kahyo, nawu dabborrabbolk bedberre wanjh yawuhyawurrinj kabindibukkan. Kaluk nawu dabborrabbolk kabindibengyolyolme bu kabindimarneyime "Yuwn bu ngurrikolke mahni kunyirrk ngadberre, wardi ngurridowen".
ex.xe: When there is a Kunabibi, Yabburlurrwa or Mardayin ceremony, the old people teach the young men. They instruct them by saying "Don't fool around with our ceremonial tools, or you might die".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Artefacts used during ceremony, ceremonial tools that are kept in a string bag until the ceremony when they are taken out.
Charcoal, black paint made from charcoal.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji ngalkohbanj kuni ngalkangila wanjh ngaleng kangeyyo kurdukadji kaluk ngaleng wanjh bininjni korrokko wanjh yerre mayh yimerranj.
ex.xe: There was an old lady whose skin name was Ngalkangila and now we call her emu, a long time ago she was really an old lady. [Wildflower Band song text].

ur: Kuninjku, Kundedjnjenghmi = ngurrurdu, Kundjeyhmi = alwandjuk, Kune = wurrbbarn

ex.xv: Wurdurd ngarrbenkurdunang birriborrkkeyi.
ex.xe: We watched the kids dancing.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Watch a dance, see a dance.

ex.xv: Ngarrbenkurdunani, wanjh kandibukkani, ngandimarneyimi “Kuhni ngikurduyime.”
ex.xe: We watched what they did, and they taught us, they would say to us, “Do it like this.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngalbu daluk bimarneyimeng nawu nabininjkobeng ngalengarre "Ngaye kurdunan bu ngudda baleh yikurduyime ngaye ngardduk".
ex.xe: The woman said to her husband "I can see what you're up to, you're doing the wrong thing by me". [e.g. going after another woman].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Watch someone carry out an activity, see what someone is doing.

ex.xv: Ngarrbenkurdunani, wanjh kandibukkani, ngandimarneyimi “Kuhni ngikurduyime.”
ex.xe: We watched what they did, and they taught us, they would say to us, “Do it like this.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yirrbardbard bawong nuye kunwardde dja nuye duruk dja wam warlbom kalawan dja munguyh biburrbuni ngalmekke daluk bu baleh kakurduyime kabibun.
ex.xe: Yirrbardbard left his dogs and his stones [two grinding stones essential to his “clever” business] and went hunting goannas as he thought continually about how he would carry out his revenge on the women.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Carry out an activity, do something in a particular way.

ex.xv: Kured benedurndi kore benehyoy.
ex.xe: They returned home to where they were living.
ex.so: Mangiru, Faith, ‘Kakkak dja Ngalwakadj’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Dja benemey nawu wurdyaw benekang kured.
ex.xe: Then they picked up the child and took him home.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Nakudji wurdyaw bibayeng duruk’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Benebalwam wanjh ngalkudji nang nganabbarru yimeng, "Warddaw, nanih kahdi nabang, dja kurih ngarre ngarrdjowkke kore mankabo."
ex.xe: They walked a bit further and one of them saw a buffalo. “Oh no!” she said, “There’s a dangerous animal, let’s go over there and cross the river”.
ex.so: Maralangurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 36’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

ex.xv: Kunubewu wam kuhri, minj ngaburrbun kore wam, kunubewu kuni nungka yimeng.
ex.xe: Maybe he went over there, I don’t know where he went, he might have said he was going to that place.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birrikodjbadjdjerrinj wanjh birrihkurlbawam.
ex.xe: They punched each other in the head and then they bled.

ex.xv: Kurndamen karrinan kore kubolkwern kunred. Bu karriwarlbun manberrk karrinan kabarndi kore kundulk.
ex.xe: We see frill-necked lizards in many different places. If we go hunting in the forest, we see them sitting up in trees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu korroko nawu ngad dabborrabbolk birriyoy kore kuwardderurrk. Dja yika birriyoy kore kurobbe birrikodbarrebuni dolobbo yika kundjurle birridjurlebuni.
ex.xe: In the past, the old people used to sleep in caves, or sometimes they made bark shelters or shade structures out in open areas.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk bu birrimarnbuni meeting wanjh kurobbe kore birrirey birriwokdi ba bu bindiwokbekkayi nawu birribuyika bininj.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Open area, clearing. An ecological zone characterised by a clearing, no trees and mostly grass or minimal or no vegetation at all. An open area in the bush or on an alluvial plain.

ex.xv: Birrirobbewoni manbu kunwok.
ex.xe: They announced it publicly.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

re: On the ground, in the earth.

ex.xv: Nawu duberrk karrinan kawakerren kore kurorre.
ex.xe: We see snails crawling along the ground.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Djanay kayo manberrk kare kabolkyawan kore kubolkkerlk kukayalanj kumekke kabolkkarung karedmarnbun kanjdji kore kurorre kamarnbun midj.
ex.xe: The Yellow Spotted Monitor lives in open forest areas, it looks for areas of soft sandy soil and makes a burrow for itself there under the earth.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Ngayi kuberrk ngayo, minj ngadjare mikurrambalk.
ex.xe: I'm going to sleep outside, I don't like being inside houses.

ex.xv: Bolkki nganmarneyimeng, "Ngamre kure ngudda." Kare kurrinj.
ex.xe: Today he said,"I'll come over to your place." Maybe he was lying.

ex.xv: Yun yinalkbun minj yirrowen yirrolkka yikurren.
ex.xe: Stop crying, you're not sick, get up, you're pretending.

ex.xv: Kurrih Birrangdoy bewubeh kurrih djang kumekke yirdebmeng birrangdoy mankang.
ex.xe: At Kurrih Birrangdoy there on the far side there, is a totemic site where the blue-tongued skink slipped and struck his tongue when he fell.

se.de: Place oneself (used to describe an Ancestor 'placing itself' after its travels to become djang)

ex.xv: Ngadjare ngabonan kurrula kaboyo / Dja mak kunmayorrk nganwolhme bu ngani.
ex.xe: I want to see the ocean / And feel the wind blowing on me.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

ex.xv: Ngalbu karndjawarra ngalkka ngalengman kore kurrula kadjalyo. Bu kurrula kabobidbun wanjh minj karrinan ngalbu karndjawarra. Dja bu kurrula karrurndeng kabukmen wanjh karrire kore kudjekudje nganjkarrkarr karriyawan karrimang wanjh karrikan karrikinje.
ex.xe: Karndjawarra (Mud Crabs, Scylla serrata) live near the sea. When the tide comes up, we don't see them. But when the tide goes out, we go  to the mangroves and get them and cook them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kurrung karridengerung.
ex.xe: In the build-up our feet burn.

sn.de: The 'build-up' season, very hot and humid.

ex.xv: Yika kunyarl kayarlkan djenjkenh kakukkurrurrubun.
ex.xe: Sometimes he [Djidjnguk] takes string along so he can tie the fish together.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Tie up fish in order to carry them.

ex.xv: Kurrwirluk minj karringun ngalwarre.
ex.xe: We don't eat curlews, the meat is no good.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

re: call of the bush stone curlew

ex.xv: Kurrwirluk ngalka mayhmayh ngalbu karribekkan bu kukak kawokdi kayime kurrwirluk kurrwirluk.
ex.xe: The curlew is a bird which we hear at night, calling out “kurrwirluk kurrwirluk”.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Imitation of the sound made by curlews.

ex.xv: Bu yire kururrkyahwurd, yibekkan kamak o kawarre?
ex.xe: Have your bowel motions been normal? [Lit. When you go to the toilet, does it feel okay or bad?]
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Ngarrengekuwan kore kunak.
ex.xe: I'll warm my feet by the fire.

ex.xv: Bu korroko nawu ngad dabborrabbolk birriyoy kore kuwarderurrk.
ex.xe: In the past our ancestors slept in caves.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Ceremonial grouping of the following subsections: bulanj/bulanjdjan, kodjok/kodjdjan kela/kalidjan, wamud/wamuddjan.

ex.xv: A: Kuybuk namekke ba ngarrbanbanibukkan woh.  B: Woh karribirlikan wanjh. (Kundjeyhmi)
ex.xe: A: Let's show those two the banksia cones. B: Yes, they can carry fire with it then.

ex.xv: kunkuyeng ngarrimadbom.
ex.xe: We waited for a long time.

ex.xv: Ngalngeykuyengkuyeng.
ex.xe: A long name (of a female referent).

ex.xv: Kundulk mandulkkuyeng.
ex.xe: A tall tree.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Long (of shape, form, time), tall (of things).

ex.xv: Birrikuyinbom.
ex.xe: They nearly killed him.

ex.xv: Wanjh dingihdi di::, kuyinbekkang 'mehme' yimeng, 'mehme konda mehme ah mehme, mehme, mehme', biyawam
ex.xe: Then he stood there for ages, and he could just hear the quail calling out. 'Oh quail is here, quail, quail, quail (where are you?)',....and he

se.de: Spy, just be able to see.

ex.xv: Kondah karurrkdi ngankuykmeng mandjewk.
ex.xe: There's a hole here where the rain is spraying in on me.

ex.xv: Dabborrabbolk kunkare birribidkuykmerrinj konda kure kunwardde.
ex.xe: A long time ago, the old people sprayed (ochre) over their fingers here on this rock.

ex.xv: Narangem la ngaldahdaluk namekke wanjh birriwam wanjh birriwam kure birriwurlebmeng.
ex.xe: That boy and all the girls went to where they swam.

ex.xv: Nangahnang dedjbom rowk malkno, nguneng, rdurdduno, derebadno, derebadno, nguneng bonj la wanjh kurrmeng la wam.
ex.xe: He watched, cut all the guts up, he ate the liver, the heart, the kidneys, he ate the kidneys and then he put it there and off he went.

sn.de: Lead single shot used in a shotgun.

bw: from Makassarese and Bugis l·dung 'sinker, plummet'.

ex.xv: Bonj, karridokmen ngaladminj.
ex.xe: That's enough let's go home, I'm hot.

sn.de: Become hot from exertion or exposure to the sun.

ex.xv: Ngayi nawu wurdyaw ngardduk, dja karrangh kayime konda kunred. Nakka wam kunkukbulerriken, bu birrilakkayenwong.
ex.xe: But my son, this is his mother's country here and so he went to be circumcised in the traditional way in his father's country. He went to be circumcised by an Aboriginal man.
ex.so: Margaret from Manmoyi

sn.de: A broad leaf-shaped blade made from iron or stone such as that in barrawu. The original ‘shovel spear’.

bw: possible loan from Malay lamang 'a short sabre'.

sn.de: Lambalk glider. The adoption of the Bininj Gunwok name for this species which is usually known as the sugar glider is tentative but the glider in the Kakadu and Western Arnhem Land region is genetically and physiologically different to sugar gliders in other parts of Australia.
An uncle who in fact is a father-in-law, ie. his daughter could become a second choice marriage partner.
Straight pipe for smoking tobacco. Often made from the wood of Canarium australianum.
Stone knife, quarried usually from quartz or other hard igneous rock and used for general cutting.

ex.xv: Lumaluma, ngardduk mawah, bimarneyimeng Likkanaya, 'Ngarryo kondah dja dungyibmeng, dja minj ngarrbale yungkih, dja ngarryo kondah kaluk malaywi.'
ex.xe: Lumaluma, my ancestor, said to Likkanaya ‘We’ll camp here, because it’s getting dark - we won’t go any further but instead stay here until tomorrow.’
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: One of two creation ancestor yawkyawk sisters. The other sister is Marraykka.
Term of address for novice in lorrkkon ceremony. A sister will address her brother by this term if she has to at all, after the boy has seen a lorrkkon ceremony.

ex.xv: Ngayayme, kanbodmelirrhmen!
ex.xe: I'm itchy, scratch my back!

ex.xv: Lirrkkurrmeng, birrimdurndiweng.
ex.xe: When the new moon appeared, they brought him back.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, 'Mimih' story

ex.xv: Ngamlobme murrikang mang ngudberre.
ex.xe: I'll come in the truck and pick you all up.

ex.xv: Kunburrkken karolbme.
ex.xe: The functioning of the body.

sn.de: A generic term for smaller skinks.
sn.sc: Carlia amax, Cryptoblepharus plagiocephalus, Ctenotus inornatus, Sphenomorphus douglasi, Morethia storri

ex.xv: Ngadjalkaklorrhmiyoy.
ex.xe: I only slept lightly last night, I didn't sleep well.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yirrbardbard kukborledkerrinj nayin yimerranj wanjh ngimeng kore manwodj mandulklorrk.
ex.xe: Yirrbardbard turned himself into a snake, and went into a hollow log.

ex.xv: Dulklorrkkelorrkken nakka yiman nayuhyungkih kabirriyo kore kundulk manlohlorrk kore kurrangmaye kundulk kore Ankung Djang.
ex.xe: Dulklorrkkelorrkken spirits are like creation Ancestors, they live in hollow trees, where the trees have an opening, in Honey Dreaming country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Birridulklowkmangi mandubang kundulk birridjedmi bokko manmirrh birrimarnbuni.
ex.xe: They would strip the bark from the ironwood and carve the wood into spear tips.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Peel off bark or a strip of wood from a tree, especially Eucalyptus tetrodonta.

ex.xv: Mankole ngarriyime manwern korroko bu dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni manbu kayime bokko madjawarr ngarrkidjba lulumarra.
ex.xe: There are lots of different types of spears that people used to make in the past, for example bokko, madjawarr, ngarrkidjba and lulumarra.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dabborrabbolk korroko birrimarnbuni lulumarra, yiman kayime barrawu birrimarnbuni bu mayhken birriyami. Kundulk bebbehbeh birrimangi birrimarnbuni lulumarra, wanjh yerre mankole manbu kundulk birribakkeyi wanjh birridjarlkkennami. Wanjh yerre ngolin birribelebelbmi, wanjh birrimarnbuni rayekmeni wanjh birriyami mayh.
ex.xe: In the old days our ancestors used to make shovel-nosed wooden hunting spears called lulumarra, similar to barrawu spears. They would make the spear tip from special types of tree, then break off part of another tree for the shaft, and attach it. They would stick beeswax on (to hold it together), the wax would harden and they would hunt with it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Spear type, shovel-nosed spear with a hardwood tip.

ex.xv: Wardi ngurrina, kaborrkke, ma, ma!
ex.xe: Hey you all have a look, he's going to dance, here he goes, here he goes!

ex.xv: A: La ngunemre? B: Yo wolewoleh nganemre. A: Ma!
ex.xe: A: Are you two coming? B: Yes, we'll come in the afternoon. A: OK then.

sn.de: OK, alright, a confirmation of or agreement with a proposition.

ex.xv: Nawu Nakodjok kukmaddengi nawu duruk. Minj djareniwirrinj benwoyi nawu duruk.
ex.xe: Nakodjok was hanging onto that dog, he didn't want to give it away.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wurdyaw maddi phone ngalengarre daluk. Wanjh ngalbadjan kayime "Med ngakerlkkerlkbun ngadjawan wanjh nganwon dja won."
ex.xe: The child was hanging onto the woman's phone, he didn't want to give it back. So his mother said "Wait, I'll talk it off him, he'll give it to me and then I'll give it back to you".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bonj, kanmaddeng.
ex.xe: That’s enough, you are delaying me from leaving.

sn.de: Not want to give something up, hang onto something, not want to leave something.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw kahdjare kabihmaddeng nakornkumo.
ex.xe: The boy wants to go with his father.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalwakadj bimarneyimeng Ngalkangila "Ngaye maddeng bu ngarrdjarrkre balbbara".
ex.xe: Nalwakadj said to Ngalkangila "I'll go with you, we can accompany each other".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Morruyhmorruyh ngudjbang kalobme, madjarndemed ngudjwarre kare.
ex.xe: The ring-tailed dragon runs swiftly but Gilbert's dragon is much slower when it moves.

ex.xv: Madjarndemed barra ngalero, madjandemed barra ngalero, madjarndemed barra ngalero, kabidbun kuwardde kawohbarndi.
ex.xe: [Lyrics to the Bongolinj-bongolinj song ‘Madjarndemed’.] ‘Barra ngalero’ has no meaning in ordinary language as it is said to be the language of the madjarndemed lizard. The last phrase means ‘it climbs up and sits halfway up the rock’.
ex.so: http://bininjkunwok.org.au/bongolinj-bongolinj/

sn.de: Gilbert's dragon (named after Ludwig Leichhardt's exploration companion John Gilbert), also known as the 'tata lizard' or 'bobo lizard', so named because of the lizard's habit of waving its hand. Note that increasingly, younger people are using the name madjarndemed in a more general sense to also refer to Diporiphora species (various lined-dragons).
Kind of grass used for making spear shafts.

ex.xv: Madjawarr yidadjdjemen yimarnbu mankole.
ex.xe: Cut that cane grass and make a spear.

sn.de: Spear made from cane-grass used for hunting fish or geese.
Name of a clan whose land is in the area of Nimbuwa rock.

ex.xv: Bu mahbilil kabun wanjh ngarrinan kaworlhworlhme manbu kunmayorrk mankimuk wanjh kunu ngarriburrbun bu kurrula kabidbun.
ex.xe: When there's an sea breeze, we see strong gusts of wind and we know that the tide is rising.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Cool breeze that comes from the ocean and blows inland, typically in the afternoon in the late dry season.
Agree to go somewhere, give assent to a travel proposal.

ex.xv: ngalkebmak
ex.xe: attractive woman

ex.xv: manmanjmak
ex.xe: good tasting food

ex.xv: Ngurrimak? Yo, ngarrimak.
ex.xe: Is everyone OK? Yes, we're fine.

ex.xv: Kamak?
ex.xe: Is everything OK?

ex.xv: Namak nakkan.
ex.xe: He's a good man.

sn.de: Northern mud cod, also known as spangled gudgeon.

ng: The k here is pronounced ‘g’, as it normally is in the middle of words.

sn.de: Grandmother (father's mother), father's mother's brother. FM, FMB.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngawarnyak makka yaldanj, minj ngadjare.
ex.xe: I don't want that waterlily root, I don't like it.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Birrimanjbekkang manmanjmakkayken.
ex.xe: They tasted it and it tasted great.

ex.xv: Daluk ngalmakkayken.
ex.xe: A beautiful woman.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakka bininj namakkayken.
ex.xe: He’s a handsome man.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nahni rarrk namakkayken.
ex.xe: That’s beautiful cross-hatching.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Great, fantastic, beautiful, handsome, delicious etc.

ex.xv: Ma mako yibuhmen!
ex.xe: OK, play the didjeridu!

ex.xv: Yinin, dja ngakan mako ngayawan kunj.
ex.xe: You stay here, and I'll take a gun and go and look for kangaroos.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 19’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981.

ex.xv: "Nganere djilikuybi nganedulubun, dja manimunak." ... Wanjh benemey mako, benewam benedulubuni.
ex.xe: "We're going to shoot Whistle Duck and Magpie Goose." ... So they took a rifle, and went and did some shooting.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 40-43

ex.xv: Yidjalkunire yimalakan, yiyame ankole yika mako.
ex.xe: You sneak up on it holding a branch in front of you and you shoot it or spear it (the emu).
ex.so: Jimmy Kalarriya, quoted in Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : Indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 19 (Kundedjnjenghmi)

ex.xv: Nawu malalalk nakka nayahwurd djenj kaluk kore kadjordmen wanjh kayimerran nakimuk namarnkol.
ex.xe: ‘Malalalk’ is a small fish, but when it grows up it becomes a big barramundi.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nayahwurd ngarriyime malalalk, dja nakimuk ngarriyime namarnkol.
ex.xe: We call the small ones malalalk, and the large ones namarnkol.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birrikukbele minj kabirringun nawu malalalk dja nayahwurd djenj ngad ngarridjalngun nawu malalalk dja namarnkol dja mak nawern nawu djenj.
ex.xe: Non-Indigenous people don't eat baby barramundi or other small fish [because of size restrictions on catching fish etc]. But we Aboriginal people, we just eat small barramundi, fully grown barramundi and lots of different fish.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bumabuma kabenekukrohrok malambibbi benekukyahwurd minj yiman kuluban nakka nakimuk.
ex.xe: Ghost bats and small horseshoe bats look similar, they’re both small, not like fruit bats which are large.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Small insect-eating bats of various species such as the diadem horseshoe bat and the orange horseshoe bat. Other species may be included but more research is needed to determine this.

ex.xv: Nungka Malarrk kawokdi.
ex.xe: He speaks Yolngu language.

sn.de: Term the Kuninjku use to describe those from the east, the Yolngu or those who use the term 'mala' to describe clan groupings. "Sunrise mob".
Early morning, used as a prefix on verbs.

se.de: Rising of the sun at dawn, sunrise.

ex.xv: Malayibuyika.
ex.xe: The day after tomorrow, in a number of days.

ex.xv: Bolkki kakkawarr kabebme malayi kakodjrung wanjh bonj karriyalarrme.
ex.xe: Today the ceremonial messenger arrives, tomorrow the ceremonial feast will cook and then we all go our seperate ways.

ex.xv: Ngudda yimalayibonguneng?
ex.xe: Did you drink it this morning?

sn.de: The next day, the following day.

se.de: Arrive the following day, arrive in the morning.

ng: incorporable or free standing, but can also be reduced to mala as an incorporable adverb

ex.xv: Bininj bedda birrihmalelmangi namekke wurdyaw.
ex.xe: Those people were teasing that little boy.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 30

sn.de: Make fun of, tease, not take seriously.

ex.xv: Yimankek birridjawam minj benwokmayinj wanjh birriyimeng, “Nawu bininj nahni wanjh kunubewu mam dja nuk marlwa bibengwarrewong.”
ex.xe: They tried to ask him but he didn’t answer, and they said “Maybe a mam spirit or perhaps a marlwa spirit has made him deaf.”
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunkare Nakudji Bininj Bengwarrminj’, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: Mother's father, mother's father's sister. Also the term a man uses to refer to his daughter's children. MFZ,MF,DD,DS. The term used when addressing the person in this relationship to you (vocative form) is mamamh.
Oustation community in the Goomadderr River region. Also the name of the estate or kunngeykimuk for this region.

ex.xv: Kuluban kayo kore kungarre manngarrekimuk. Yika karrinan kamarnbun kayo kore mamumu manngarre mandulkwern mankod.
ex.xe: Flying foxes live in large jungle areas. Or we also see them making their home in forests where there are lots of paperbark trees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Birringimi kore mamumu, wanjh birrimangi mayh nawu yiman kayime kedjebe dja ngalmangiyi. Dja mak kunkod birrikodmangi bu kunbodbarre birrimarnbuni.
ex.xe: They went into the paperbark swamp and collected animals like file snakes and long necked turtles. They also collected paperbark for for making bark shelters.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra.

sn.de: Cajaput paperbark, has a greenish oil with a camphoraceous odour. The word can also refer to forests and swamps with stands of these trees.

ex.xv: Namekke nadjinem manme kangun manbadbirri, yika kakolung kuwardde kakolung manbuyhbuyika kangun.
ex.xe: That black rock kangaroo eats Melodorum fruit, sometimes it comes down from the rocks and eats other kinds of food.

sn.de: Rock country tree with an edible yellow fruit.
Stem of a plant, e.g. the edible stems of waterlilies.

ex.xv: Manbu manbarlarra kundulk wanjh ngarridjeddjedmi ngarrimangi mankange bu ngarridongi dja ngarridjuhkeyi kore kukku wanjh nawu djenj dowerreni bu wanjh birrikukdarlkani wanjh ngarrikukmangi.
ex.xe: We used to chip the bark off the of the Owenia vernicosa tree, get the inner bark [by scraping it off the wood], pound that up and put the in the water. Then the fish would die and float to the surface, and we could collect them.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Kind of small to medium sized tree (4-12m).

ur: Kundedjnjenghmi = anbarlarra, Kundjeyhmi = anbarnadja, Kune = manngarnarrngh, Kuninjku = manngarnarrh, W synonym= ngukdjirrworlk

sn.de: Entrance hole to Tetragonula hockingsi bee hive.

ex.xv: Yukkuyukku nawu mayh kukyahwurd nganbengdayhke ngadberre bu manme kakinje wanjh karung ba bu ngarrire ngarrimang manu manme yiman kayime manyuku, mandjurrukumarlba, kunkurlurrk dja mak manwern manbu manbarnem.
ex.xe: The firefly is a small insect, (the appearance of) which lets us know that fruit is ripening, so that we can go and gather it, for example manyuku berries (Antidesma parvifolium), mandjurrukkumarlba (Antidesma ghaesembilla) and kunkurlurrk (Memecylon pauciflorum) and all kinds of other fruits.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wanjh ngalbu daluk dulknang, nang mandulkmakkaykenh dja nang manbarnemmak.
ex.xe: She saw that the tree was beautiful and its fruit looked delicious. [Genesis 3:6, New Living Translation]
ex.so: Genesis, Exodus 1-14 and 20, Ruth, Luke, John, Acts and Ephesians in Kunwinjku, Bible Society in Australia, 1992

ex.xv: Kubarrarndjokko.
ex.xe: In a narrow gorge.

sn.de: Gorge or narrow rift in escarpment country.
Steep or vertical cliff face, steep ridge line.
Rut, washed out rut on the road.
The entrance piece or mouth of a mandjabu 'woven conical fish trap'

se.de: Enter a gorge, pass through a gorge.

ng: incorporable as -barrarn- e.g. ngabarrarnnang 'I saw a gorge'; can take a third person singular verbal prefix and function as a

ur: Kundedjnjenghmi, Kundjeyhmi = anbedjdja, Kune = manbedjdja

ex.xv: Bu manbedje kahmerlem dja kanguybun, bu kamirrhburlerran dja kamirrhwarrawarrhme, wanjh kunukka manimunak kawirlarrkkurrme.
ex.xe: When the spear grass grows thick and flowers, then the sharp seeds turn black and fall to the ground, that’s when the magpie goose lays her eggs.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kundjikurdubuk manbelk karri.
ex.xe: At Kundjikurdubuk there is pandanus.

ex.xv: Lumaluma kakarrme manberd mankimuk.
ex.xe: Lumaluma has a large penis.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Bu mamurrng dja mulil birrimey birriwayini wanjh birrikani bedberre manberlnginj.
ex.xe: When there was an Mamurrng ceremony or a ceremonial feast, people would take their clapsticks along.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Clapsticks for musical accompaniment, usually made of ironwood (mandubang).

ex.xv: Modjdje kadjaldjordmen kore kabbal minj kadjordmen kore manberrk dja kore kuwardehwarde.
ex.xe: Spike rushes only grow on floodplains, they don't grow in dry forest areas or in rocky country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dedded karrinan ngalwern kore manberrk dja kore kungarre.
ex.xe: We see lots of lorikeets in open forest areas and in thicker jungle areas.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Open forest, savanna woodland, open plain country. Relatively flat, open and dry areas as opposed to rocky country, floodplains or areas of thicker vegetation around watercourses.

ex.xv: Ngarrihnang manberrk bidbom kinga.
ex.xe: We saw that the crocodile had climbed up and out in the open (i.e. out of the water).

ex.xv: Kaluk kumekbe nawu wurduhwurdurd birrihni kaluk birrinahnani Wirrihwirrihyak nawu dengelurlmeng manbik bimarneni kore kurrenge nuye.
ex.xe: The children were there looking after Wirrihwirrihyak, whose foot was swollen because he had a splinter in his foot.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T., 2005, p. 6

ex.xv: Nangarridj boken benewam beneyerrkang kudjurle kore manbinik karrulkdi, mandulkkimuk.
ex.xe: Two Nangarridj skin men went and sat down in the shade of a large Anbinik tree.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

sn.de: Anbinik tree, large monsoon forest tree (15-30m) which grows only in the sandstone escarpment country of western Arnhem Land and

ex.xv: Bu ngarrire manberrk ngarrinan manbu kundulk kadulkngeyyo manbirdubbirdu. Kawohdulkdjinh. Ngarridulklowkmang wanjh kukku kambobebme bu ngarribongun.
ex.xe: When we go walking in the bush, we see Melaleuca nervosa trees. Where we see a lump partway up the tree, we peel off the bark and water comes out that we can drink.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Species of Melaleuca which includes the water tree djidjerok. Water was obtained from one variety of this tree in times of drought by breaking open the side of the tree with an axe.

ex.xv: Bininj birrirey kubbunj kore kurrula birridulubuni ngalidjdjalidj manbiri dja marndingunjngunj.
ex.xe: People would go out on the sea in canoes and spear sea turtles and dugongs with harpoons.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Generic term for all sea turtles. Bininj Kunwok speakers are inland people and do not have many terms for marine species.

ex.xv: Bu ngarriwarlbun mayh yiman ngalmangiyi dja manimunak wanjh minj ngarribangmekinje nawu mayh bu manbirliwoldjenkimuk dja ngarrimadbun bu kunak kabirliwoldjenkolung dja kayirrkebakke, wanjh kunu ngarrikinje mayh.
ex.xe: When we hunt animals like long-necked turtles and magpie geese, we don't cook them while the flames of the fire are high, we wait until the flames die down and the wood is broken down into hot coals, and that's when we cook them.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wanjh bu bolkkime karrihnan nawu karrkkanj, nungka nadjawonjbeh dja mak kadjaldolkan bu kakerrkmang yiman bu yimihyimi kerrkmahkerrkmangi mankoleh. Kaluk bu kunak kabirriwurlhke, nungka kare kore kunak dja kamang nawu mayh wolbu kaluk manbu kunak wanjh makkah minj kabimang bu karung, dja kadjalwohdolkan kakerrkbawon manbu manbirliwoldjen.
ex.xe: These days when we see a brown falcon, we say he's of the Jawoyn tribe, and he still flies around as if he were dodging spears. When people burn off the bush, he flies above the fire front catching insects, but the fire won't catch him because he can just jump and dodge the flames.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Jill & Tildemann, Sonia, ‘Karrkanj Yimerranj’ in ‘Old Woman Emu and other Kunwinjku stories’, Batchelor Press, Batchelor, N.T, 2005, p. 90

ex.xv: Manbirrbbirr kanguybun yekke bu kanguymarnbun mankungken. Dja mak ngarrinan wanjh nganbengdayhke ngadberre bu yekkeburrk kayimerran.
ex.xe: Manbirrbirr trees flower during yekke in order (for bees) to make honey, and when we see them we know that it's the middle of the cool season.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Kind of shrub (1.5-5m) with pointed narrow leaves growing in clusters along stems with flowers which provide nectar for honey bees

re: generic name for various densely flowering small trees
sn.de: In Kuninjku the name manbirrbbirr is used for a number of densely flowering shrubs and small trees including Verticordia cunninghamii, yellow flowering Austromyrtus species and also Acacia platycarpa which also has dense white

ex.xv: Manu manbirrmurlu makka kunwardde birridongi nawu dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni manmirrhmak wanjh birridjarlkkenami kore mankole bu birriyami kunj.
ex.xe: To make ‘manbirrmurlu’ type spears, people used to strike stones to make sharp stone flakes, then attach them to spear shafts in order to hunt kangaroos.
ex.so: Jill Njanjmirra

sn.de: Shovel spear type with a long stone blade for the head. These may be the predecessors of the famous ‘shovel-nosed’ spears of Arnhem Land which have heads made of iron or other metal originally obtained from the Macassans. The stone blade is attached to the shaft via a socket made of fibre string ironwood resin and beeswax.

ex.xv: Bu korroko dabborrabbolk birringadkarungi birribongalkeyi kanjdji kore kurorre, wanjh birrinani bu manboburlerri wanjh kunngobarn birrimangi birridjuhkeyi wanjh bobelemeninj bu manbobele wanjh ngarribonguni.
ex.xe: In the old days when our ancestors used to dig wells to find water under the ground, if they saw that the water was dirty then they would gather some pandanus leaves and put them into the water. Then the water would become clear (the dirt would sink to the bottom) and we could drink the clear water.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bininj manbolh.
ex.xe: Traditional walking route.

ex.xv: Manbu… manbolh wam kore Pine Creek, wanjh borledmi Darwin way. Kunih yimowoni manbolh kerrngehkenh bu.
ex.xe: That road… went to Pine Creek then turned up towards Darwin. That’s where it used to go, that road.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bu karrire karrilobme mandengeyi kore manberrk dja kore manbolh, wanjh karrinan manbordokorr dulkdoweng dja dolobbo birrilowkmey.
ex.xe: When we drive in bushland or along the road, we see stringybark trees that have died because people have stripped the bark off (to make bark paintings etc).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Manbu mandjabu korroko dabborrabbolk birrimangi kunyarl kore manbornde mandedjmad kunyarl dja kore kundulk manbudbud kunyarl.
ex.xe: In the old days, people used banyan root fibres and kurrajong bark fibres to make string for fish traps.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Ngalbu kuluybirr ngalka kadi kare kore kukku manbowinjku kore mandem karri kunbak dja mandjimdjim kadulkdjuhmiyindi.
ex.xe: The saratoga lives in fresh water, where there are water lilies and water weeds and where the water pandanus stands in the water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Warradjan ngalkka ngalengman kadjalyo kare kore kubowinjku kukku minj kare kore kurrula.
ex.xe: The pig-nosed turtle only lives in the fresh water, it doesn’t go into the ocean.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu Korlobarr nakka kani kore manberrk dja kore manbowk manlabbarl.
ex.xe: The antilopine kangaroo lives in open forest, as well as swampy areas around billabongs.

sn.de: Landscape with swales (water-catching depressions), typically a string of small seasonal billabongs and alluvial watercourse margins.

re: water hole country caused by feral animals
sn.de: Country with numerous wallow holes caused by buffaloes or feral pigs.

se.de: Expansive seasonal swamp area. A retriplicated form of manbowk.

ex.xv: Yawkyawk birriwam manboyberre.
ex.xe: The girls went looking for white apple fruits.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 36’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

ex.xv: Muddika manbu mankukkurlba.
ex.xe: A red car (literally 'a car which is red').
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Manwern manbu manme ngarriburrbun manwern manme manbu minj ngarrikukngun yiman karrbarda mankinjdjek mankodjbang manbuled mankongkong dja manwern manbu minj ngarrikukngun. Manwern manme ngarriwilkdeng. Badjdjo dja mankurladj makka ngarrikukngun.
ex.xe: There are lots of (bush) vegetables that we know. There are lots of vegetables which we don’t eat raw, like long yams, cheeky yams, water peanuts, Triglochin dubia and bush potatoes. There are lot of vegetables that we cook in hot coals. Brachystelma glabriflorum and spike rush corms are two vegetable foods which we eat raw.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ng: Relates to 'man-' class nouns. For 'ngal-' class nouns ngalbu is used, and for 'na-' class nouns nawu.

ex.xv: Manbu mandjabu korroko dabborrabbolk birrimangi kunyarl kore manbornde mandedjmad kunyarl dja kore kundulk manbudbud kunyarl.
ex.xe: In the old days, people used banyan root fibres and kurrajong bark fibres to make string for fish traps.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Red flowered kurrajong. The seeds are edible and the bark is used to make string and fibre.

ur: Kunwinjku, Kunwalidjaw lect= manmarnanj, Kundedjnjenghmi = anmarnanj

ex.xv: Manwern manbu manme ngarriburrbun manwern manme manbu minj ngarrikukngun yiman karrbarda mankinjdjek mankodjbang manbuled mankongkong dja manwern manbu minj ngarrikukngun. Manwern manme ngarriwilkdeng. Badjdjo dja mankurladj makka ngarrikukngun.
ex.xe: We know lots of types of vegetables, there are lots of vegetables which we don’t eat raw, like long yams, cheeky yams, water peanuts, Triglochin dubia and bush potatoes. We cook lots of vegetables in hot coals. Brachystelma glabriflorum and spike rush corms are two vegetable foods which we eat raw.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Aquatic grass-like herb, with small edible reddish tuber. Extracted from clayish soils by hand and with digging sticks by women. The many small tubers are washed and roasted lightly before eating. They have a crunchy texture when eaten.

ex.xv: Manburrangkali kakukrohrok mandem dja ngalengman kadjordmen kore kukabo kore kuwarddewardde. Minj kadjordmen kore kabbal dja manlabbarl.
ex.xe: Manburrangkali lilies look similar to regular waterlilies, but they grow in rivers up in escarpment country. They don't grow on floodplains and in billabongs.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunkare kohbakohbanj birrihyolyolmi nakudji wurdyaw nalkbuhnalkbuni, ngalyod binguneng. Birrikaybom manburrangkali, manmekbe manu manjbekkang manmanjmak duninj.
ex.xe: The old people would tell us a story that a long time ago a boy cried and cried, and the Rainbow Serpent ate him. They had refused to give him more manburrangkali [lily corms], which he had tasted and found to have a wonderful flavour.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

sn.de: Type of water lily corms which feature in the public version of the Orphan or “Crying Boy” Dreaming story at Kabbari. The boy is said to have cried so unceasingly for manburrangkali that the Rainbow Serpent heard him, rose up and swallowed him.

ex.xv: Manburrba yima yidukkarren yiborrkkemen.
ex.xe: Get a loin cloth, tie it up on yourself and dance.

sn.de: Cloth, fabric, men's ceremonial loin cloth.

ex.xv: An-burre makka an-kimuk, makka an-yayawno, bininjken. Barrk ngaleng kaworrngun, djukerre ka-worrngun.
ex.xe: Ipomoea dunlopii is much bigger but this one I'm talking about, something people can eat, is much smaller. an-burre is for humans but the black wallaroo would eat the leaves of it.

ex.xv: An-warddewaken, bad mimih ke ka-ngun, ka-ngun ngalekke mimih, an-yong, ngan-burre, nguddah, bulanj, yi-ngeybun, karri-ngeybun mah ngan-burre.
ex.xe: It grows in the rock country but mimih eat it, those mimih (women) eat it, that bush radish tuber, Bulanj, you eastern people call it ngan-burre [manburre], well we all call it that.

ex.xv: Dja bu bolkkime nawu daluhdaluk yawkyawk minj kabirriburrbun manbu manme kabirringeybun mahni mankongkong manburre mankodjbang manbuled mankinjdjek, larrk mankudji karrbarda kabirribengkan.
ex.xe: But these days most women and girls don't know about mankongkong (Ipomoea graminea), manburre (Ipomoea dunlopii), mankodjbang (Aponogeton elongatus), manbuled (Triglochin dubia) or mankinjdjek (Dioscorea bulbifera). They only know about long yams, that's it.
ex.so: Bardayal Nadjamerrek

sn.de: Slightly woody vine climbing high in surrounding trees; very closely related to Ipomea abrupta. The leaves are narrow to broadly ovate or triangular, blade 50-150 mm long x 15-120 mm wide, sometimes with rounded spear shaped lobes at the base, petiole 25-75 mm long. The flowers are funnel-shaped, mauve to purple with darker throat, petals 65 mm to 85 mm long.The fruit is a globular capsule, 10-14 mm diameter with 4 black seeds to 7 mm long covered in long dense sinuous white to pale brown hairs to 4 mm long. The tubers or 'yams' are roasted on coals before being eaten. The name may also be applied to Stephania japonica and Decaschistia byrnesii.

ur: Kundedjnjenghmi = anyong, nganyong; Kundjeyhmi = anburre

ex.xv: Manbalmed dja mandak yirrong yimarnbun yingun karrirawon.
ex.xe: Pound the Planchonella arnhemica and the Persoonia falcata fruit together and you can eat it.

ex.xv: Kohbahkohbanj bindibukkani yawkyawk birrikarungi mankongkong, karrbarrda, mandanek.
ex.xe: The old people would show the girls how to dig up bush potatoes, long yams and arum roots.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Kind of herbaceous plant of the Arum family (as are Amorphophallus spp.) with a subterranean corm which has toxins in it that must be processed before the tuber is rendered edible. The leaves and stem are removed and the corm roasted in hot coals. It is then pounded with a stone for a long time to get the juice out, washed with water and pounded again. The corm pulp must turn from white to a black colour before it is edible. Arum plants belong to the yarriburrik matry which has fire as its totemic emblem, most likely because fire is involved in the preparation of the tubers.
sn.sc: Typhonium cochlear, Typhonium flagelliforme, Typhonium russell-smithii

ex.xv: Mani mandangkimuk manmelkmakkayken.
ex.xe: This one [didjeridu] has a wide mouth at the distal end and it has an excellent tone.

sn.de: Rough leafed bloodwood; flowers may be white, pink or red, used for making didjeridus or mako.
Small to medium sized tree (3-10m) with edible black fruit.
Spear with three-uniserially barbed prongs fitted to a shaft so that each set of barbs is at right angles to the others.

ex.xv: Kundulk manbu kunkod kahkarrme ngarrinan kunmalaworr, wanjh ngarriburrbun, yiman kayime yilbinj, mandarl, mankorrko dja mandjinh.
ex.xe: When we see the leaves of paperbark trees, we can recognise them, for example whether a tree is yilbinj, mandarl fi:(Melaleuca_viridiflora), mankorrko fi:(Melaleuca_argentea) or mandjinh fi:(Melaleuca_nervosa).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: A small, erect or straggly tree, 3-10 metres high,, also known as broad-leaved paperbark or broad-leaved tea-tree, grows along streams, in swampy areas and often in dense stands in open woodlands where the land may be seasonally flooded.

ex.xv: Warradjan kangun kunbak dja mandjimdjim mandedjmad.
ex.xe: The pig-nosed turtle eats water weeds and the roots of water pandanus.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nahni mayhmayh kangeyyo karrekuyengkuyeng karrinan kore manlabbarl manlabbarlkimuk kore mandem manwern kadi. Karrinan mandem kunworr kamelhmelme bu kare.
ex.xe: The bird called karrekuyengkuyeng (Jacana) can be found at large billabongs where there are lots of waterlilies. We see them walking over the lily-pads.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Waterlily, specifically the white-flowered waterlily and the edible corms of these waterlilies.

ex.xv: Wurdwurd birriwam Kunkanginj wanjh birrikoluy kore mandengeyi wanjh birriwam birrihdirri kabbal.
ex.xe: The children went to Kunkanginj, got out of the car and went to play on the floodplain.
ex.so: Narndal, Julie and Namarnyilk, Lois, 'Kuhni bu birriwam ngalmangiyi', Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Mandiddi, Kubumi karri.
ex.xe: There are Banded Grunter fish at Kubumi (on the Mann River).

ex.xv: Mandirnku kadulkdi kore kunred kubolkwern.
ex.xe: There are cycad trees in many different clan lands.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dja korroko dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni mandjabu wanjh birridjuhkeyi kore kukku manlabbarl yika kore mankabo wanjh djenj ngimi birrimangi.
ex.xe: And in the past, the old people would make fish traps, put them in the water in a billabong or river, the fish would go in and them they would get them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Conical fish traps woven from Trophis scandens vine.

ex.xv: Mandjad ngarrbenbukkan wanjh mandjad kabirriyime kore school, bu kabirridurrkmirri, kabirribimbun, kabirribimnan, dja baleh yarrkka.
ex.xe: We show them the right way of doing things, so they will do the right thing at school, when they’re working, writing or reading, and all those things.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: djendjad
ex.xe: One who speaks well, many languages or learns language easily.

ex.xv: Bu korroko dabborrabbolk birribakkeyi mandjakkorl kundulk manbu mandarle, manyende wanjh birrimarnbuni bokenh bu birriburdebmi, birriwurlhkeyi kunak.
ex.xe: In the old days, people used to break off dry branches from the fire stick tree, and rub one against the other in a drilling motion to make a fire.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mandjarduk karridulknan kadulkdi mandulkwern kore manberrk.
ex.xe: We see a lot of red apple trees in open forest areas.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bininj yameng nganabbarru wanjh mey mandjawak kukyilkbom mey kundjen dja kunbirrkbirrkbokenh wanjh babburlibom kore kukarlang.
ex.xe: A man shot a buffalo, then got a knife and cut off some meat, took the tongue and two ribs and carried it all off over his shoulder.
ex.so: Nabobbob, Rose, ‘Kunbidkudji Kunwok’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

sn.de: Knife (made of metal as opposed to stone).

bw: This is most likely a loan word but the origin of the loan is unknown.

ex.xv: Buluk dorrengh anbu an-djedj, Lorrkkon Kunabibi karri-bulukmang.
ex.xe: The kapok tree has down used for body decoration in the hollow log and Kunabibi ceremonies.

ex.xv: Yika kundulk ngarrinan kanguybun wanjh ngarriyime kunj kabalem, bu manbu mandjedj kundulk kanguybun.
ex.xe: Or sometimes flowers can tell us that the kangaroos are fat (and ready to hunt). That's the case with kapok flowers.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Yellow kapok bush; a slender deciduous shrub or small tree to 7 m high; flowering and fruiting when the plant is leafless. The edible fleshy taproots are collected only from small plants, usually less than 30 cm tall. They are roasted in hot coals and the outer skin peeled. Kapok wool from the seed pods is used for body decoration in certain ceremonies. Young stems can be used as firestick drills. Bark used for paint brushes.
Cold water, such as at the bottom of a deep stream

ex.xv: Mahni kunkanj mandjelmiken, yoy kore kunkedjelk.
ex.xe: That meat is cold, it's been in the fridge.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Any cold substance, eg. the air from an air conditioner.

ex.xv: Mandjewk nganbom ngadberre.
ex.xe: The rain fell on us.

ex.xv: Mandjewk kamankan nganbowon kukku.
ex.xe: The rain falls and gives me water.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ’Maburrinj (The lonely place called Maburrinj)’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

ex.xv: Bu mandjewkbubuyika ngarre bininj kabirridowkke mako manmim lead kawernmerren kore kulabbahlabbarl.
ex.xe: After a number of years, people firing shotguns constantly will lead to an accumulation of lead in the billabong.

ex.xv: Mandjimdjim kadjordmen kore kukku kaboyo kore mankabo manwanjdjad manlabbarl.
ex.xe: Mandjimdjim (water pandanus) grows where there is water, by rivers, creeks and billabongs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu ngarrire manberrk ngarrinan manbu kundulk kadulkngeyyo manbirdubbirdu. Kawohdulkdjinh. Ngarridulklowkmang wanjh kukku kambobebme bu ngarribongun.
ex.xe: When we go walking in the bush, we see Melaleuca nervosa trees. Where we see a lump partway up the tree, we peel off the bark and water comes out that we can drink.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu kawolk nakka mayhmayh nawu mudburlerri dja kawohmudbele. Kakebdjinh kore kunkeb nuye.
ex.xe: The friarbird has both dark and light sections of plumage. It has a bump on its beak.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

se.de: Strip acacia bark (usually to make string)

ex.xv: Bu kabirriwurlhke kunak karralkrung rowk wanjh mandjong bu karung darnkih kakebdowen wanjh kunmayorrk kaworlhme wanjh kamarnbun kayawoyhwurlhme.
ex.xe: When people start fires and all the grass burns, there are smouldering logs left behind, and when the wind blows them it makes them burst into flame again.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Smouldering or burning log after a bushfire has passed.

ex.xv: Mandjumbak kunrakken.
ex.xe: Calytrix achaeta is good for fire wood.

sn.de: Another kind of small sandstone habitat calytrix either easily confused with Calytrix brownii or together with it is collapsed into a super class.

ex.xv: Manbu mandjungkurrk makka kundulk, dja kunmalaworr ngarrimang bu ngarrikerribun mayh yiman kunkanj nganabbarru, bulikki, kunj dja kurdukadji. Kamanjmakwon bu ngarringun kamak rowk.
ex.xe: Mandjungkurrk is a kind of tree, and we gather its leaves when we cook animals in a ground oven, for example buffalo, bull, kangaroo or emu meat. It flavors the meat so it tastes good when we eat it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra.

ex.xv: Andjungkurrk arridarme kamanjmakmen kunkanj.
ex.xe: We use andjungkurrk leaves to flavour meat and make it taste good. [Kundedjnjenghmi]

sn.de: Kind of gardenia tree, used as a culinary herb for flavoring meat when cooking esp. in a ground oven (kunkerri).

ex.xv: Bu kudjewk karrire wanjh karrihmang manu mandjurrukkumarlba.
ex.xe: In the wet season we go and collect Antidesma ghaesembilla berries.
ex.so: Narndal, Julie et. al. ‘Manme: Stories about food - Kunwinjku’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

sn.de: Purple currant tree, kind of shrub or small tree (usually 2-3 m) which has edible dark purple berries.

ex.xv: Wanjh benebalwam benebolknang yimankek bu kungarre benebalngimeng, benenang mandolhdolh.
ex.xe: So they went and had a look around and were about to go into the jungle thicket. They saw some bush cucumbers.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, 'Djakku dja Nabulanj Benewam', Oenpelli Literary Project, Gunbalanya 1976

sn.de: Bush cucumber vine with an edible fruit available in the wet season; annual climbing or trailing herb with simple tendrils.

ex.xv: Dja bu birridoweni wanjh birrimangi kunworr mandubang birrirurrkwolngwoni kundolng dorrengh manbu kunrurrk kore yongohyoy.
ex.xe: And when someone died, then people would get leaves from the ironwood tree and smoke the place that person used to live in.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko bu ngarriyawani mandudjmi ngarrimangi ngarridahkendongi kundjabarrk.
ex.xe: In the old days when we used to look for green plums, we would put them in a dilly bag.
ex.so: Peter Carroll AIATSIS collection

sn.de: Green plum tree (taller variety, shorter variety is called fv:(m)an-wodberr).

ex.xv: Manbu karrbarda mandule dja kunborrk bu korroko nakudji nakohbanj dabbolk Nakangila Nabarrbinj marnbom.
ex.xe: An old Nakangila skin man of the Barrbinj clan made the Long Yam song and dance, a long time ago.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Bedda mandulebuyika kabirriwokdi.
ex.xe: Those people have a different accent in the way they talk.

se.de: Teach someone a song, reveal a song to someone.

ex.xv: Mandulk yiman kadulkyime mandjoh dja ngalengman manmalaworrkimuk, kadjordmen kore kukabo dja kore njilhmi. Manekke birribakkeyi dabborrabbolk bu birridjarlkkennami lulumarra.
ex.xe: Mandulk is a tree similar to mandjoh (Acacia difficilis), but with larger leaves. It grows by rivers and creeks. That's the tree that our ancestors used to break off to (make spear shafts to) attach to lulumarra type spear heads.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: A kind of Acacia tree with silky blue-green leaves, sometimes called fish poison wattle or soapy wattle. Used to make spear shafts and sometimes the leaves used as an ichthycide.

ex.xv: Benewam kore mandulum kabolkngeyyo Mankarrinjdji darnkih Warruwi.
ex.xe: They went to a hill called Mankarrinjdji near Warruwi.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Kunred ngalengarre karedmarnbun kunworr, manyahyay kundulk dja kunkurlk wanjh kamornname kadulummarnbun mandulumkimuk.
ex.xe: She (the jungle fowl) makes her nest from leaves, acacia branches and earth, gathering them to make a big mound.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: That previously referred to, that known topic of discourse (agrees with vegetable class nouns).

re: tribal name, ethnonym for Goomadeer River people

ex.xv: Korroko Manginburru bininj birrini kunred ngardduk.
ex.xe: A long time ago Manginburru people lived on my land.

sn.de: Name (or ethnonym) that includes all people with country in the Gumardir (Goomadeer) River Catchment — from rocky headwaters to coastal mudflats. This includes Kunwinjku and Mawng language clans.

ex.xv: Mahni mirridjdjin yingun ba bu ngunkurlbamarnbun dja mak wurdyaw ke kadjordmen.
ex.xe: You should take these tablets to make your blood strong and help your baby grow properly.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: This one here (agrees with vegetable class nouns).

ex.xv: Birribekkang danginj Balang birrimwokngimeng birrimanjbom.
ex.xe: When they heard that Balang was born they telephoned to express affection for him.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdurd kabirrimanjngun manbu manmanjmak manme, dja yiman kayime drink manbu kabirribomanjngun bu kabirribongun.
ex.xe: Children like like to eat sweet tasty food, and they also like to drink (soft) drinks.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kabolkmanjngun, kadjare kumekke kahdi.
ex.xe: He really likes that place, he wants to stay there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Sunday School mak ngamanjnguni manekke and nganmarneyolyolmi manbu yiwarrudj.
ex.xe: Sunday School also, I used to really like that, they would tell us about the scriptures.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bedda Nakorrkko benekabokurrmeng.
ex.xe: The Nakorrkko ancestors placed the creek there.

ex.xv: Bedda benenang kunwardderurrk wanjh benelobmeng kumekke benengimeng, dja mandjewk dedjdjingmey mankamankani.
ex.xe: They saw a cave, ran towards it and went in, just as the rain was starting to fall.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Benehbarndi kore kundulk kaddum mankarrarlhmanj manmim benehmimnguni.
ex.xe: The two of them were sitting up in the tree eating mankarralarlhmanj nuts.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Peanut tree or red-fruited kurrajong. The tree grows in rainforest and vine thickets, up to 10m tall, flowers are greenish-white in kurrung to kudjewk seasons. The name refers to both the tree and the edible seeds from the orange seed pods. There are up to 8 edible seeds in the pods which are similar in taste to peanuts.

ex.xv: Nungka barrk yika kayo kure mi-karrarndalk dja mi-ngarre.
ex.xe: Sometimes black wallaroos sleep in the spinifex and in thickets.

sn.de: Kind of rock country spinifex , 'kerosene grass'

ex.xv: Kunibidji minj kabindiberddadjdje, mankarre bedberre.
ex.xe: The Kunibidji do not practice circumcision. It is their custom.

ex.xv: Kakarrerawon.
ex.xe: He will participate in his second ceremony (lit: 3s.+ceremony+add on).

se.de: Make a law, make a decision, make a song.

sn.de: Ridge line, point along escarpment line, escarpment protrusion, coastal point, banks of river.

ex.xv: Nawu nawarlah nakka kakarrme mankimanki kore kaberdyirriyo.
ex.xe: Stingrays have a barb on their tail.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Mak bininj nawu namarndeyi kakarrme mankimanki bu kadjare kabenbun bininj. Kaburriwe wanjh kabidulubun nawu bininj wanjh kabekkarren bu kahbabang, wanjh kadowingalme.
ex.xe: A sorcerer can also use (invisible) stingray barbs to attack people. He throws the barb and it pierces the victim, who feels a pain and then begins to sicken.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu dabborrabbolk nawu nayuhyungki korrokoni birribimbuni mayh nawu bim yiman kayime kunj, ngurrurdu, ngalmangeyi dja mak djenj. Dja manme warridj yiman kayime kayawal, mankinjdjek dja njalehnjale manmebuyika manu.
ex.xe: Those early ancestors a very long time ago painted images of animals such as kangaroos, emus, long neck turtles and fish. They also painted (in rock shelters) images of vegetable foods such as long yams (Dioscorea transversa), cheeky yams (Dioscorea bulbifera) and other kinds of foods.

sn.de: Cheeky yam— so called because of toxins in the edible tuber which must first be removed by leaching. The yam is sliced thinly (traditionally with a blade made from the shoulder bone of a macropod), and placed into a string bag which is then immersed into a flowing watercourse overnight or longer. The toxin-free slices are then cooked and eaten.

ex.xv: Nahni Wakkewakken kabirriyo kore kundulk mankod kore kukabo kore manbokedjelk.
ex.xe: The Wakkewakken spirits live among the paperbark trees in the river, in the cold water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Tuberous aquatic perennial with mainly submerged leaves and edible nutty corms, 'water peanut'

ex.xv: Bu karrire kumunun wanjh mankokkarrng kanwolkan kabolkwolkan kore karrire.
ex.xe: When we are travelling in the dark the stars give us light, they light up the ground where we are walking.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kuni kunkare nakudji bininj wam kabbal, kani bokenh mankole dja borndok.
ex.xe: One day a long time ago a man went to the floodplain, he was carrying two spears and a spearthrower.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kuhni bu Kunkare Birrihwarlbuni’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

sn.de: Spear or spear shaft, more specifically a spear made with a shaft made from Arnhem Land bamboo Bambusa arnhemica.

ex.xv: Kakolhdebebme.
ex.xe: A little shoot comes up.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Shoot, sprout. New shoot sprouting out from a plant, seed etc.

ex.xv: Korroko nawu kohbakohbanj nawu morlehmorlenj birrirey birrikarungi manbu mankongkong. Birriwilkdengi mandjoleng ngandiwoni ngarringuni.
ex.xe: In the past, the old women used to go and dig up bush potatoes. They’d put them in the hot coals, and give us the cooked ones to eat.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Climbing vine with a white flower that opens between dusk and dawn. Has an edible tuber, sometimes called a “bush potato” in English. Grows amongst spear grass, often climbing up the stems.

ex.xv: Kundulk manbu kunkod kahkarrme ngarrinan kunmalaworr, wanjh ngarriburrbun, yiman kayime yilbinj, mandarl, mankorrko dja mandjinh.
ex.xe: When we see the leaves of paperbark trees, we can recognise them, for example whether a tree is yilbinj, mandarl (Melaleuca viridiflora), mankorrko (Melaleuca argentea) or mandjinh (Melaleuca nervosa).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yiddok mahni karringun mankuk?
ex.xe: Can we eat this raw?
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Mankurndalh ngarrinan mannguy bu kanguybun, wanjh darnkih bu kakukdangen mankuk manme.
ex.xe: We see the black plum tree flowering, and not long afterwards young (unripe) fruits appear.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Mankuladj kadjordmen kore kabbal. Morlehmorlenj dja yawkyawk wurdwurd kabirrire kore kabbal kabirrikarung mankuladj.
ex.xe: Spike rushes grow on the floodplain. Women, girls and children go to the floodplain to dig up the corms.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Wardurrkku nakka nakimuk nabadjan nakka, nawardurrkku, mankumirli, nabadjan rerre, wardurrkku, nabadjan rerre namekke boken, kangeyboken, nawu namekke nakimukken nawu.
ex.xe: 'Wardurrkku' is a large individual, 'wardurrkku' and 'mankumirli' is also the same. These are two names for the big barramundis.

sn.de: Very large specimen of Silver Barramundi.

ex.xv: Minj ngad karrinan nawu Nakurrurndilhba birridjalkudji kabirrinan nawu marrkidjbu nawu birrikurdang.
ex.xe: We can’t see Nakurrurndilhba spirits, only clever men with special powers can see them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Supernatural power, mainly to heal but also to be able to see spirit beings or to compose new songs through supernatural revelation.

ex.xv: Manbu mankurlurrudj makka kundulk manme kamarnbun bu Kurrung wanjh kurdukadji karrinan kare kamimngun manbu makurlurrudj manme manmim.
The sand palm (Livistona humilis) fruits in the dry season, and we see emus eating the seeds.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Mankurndalh birribarndiwirrinj kamwakemeninj birriyameninj. Manekke ngayameng wanjh barnambarl.
ex.xe: They would stand up high in the Vitex_glabrata tree and when [the emu] came wandering over [to eat the fallen fruit] they would spear it. I speared one from up in a tree, a technique called barnambarl.

sn.de: Kind of medium sized tree (7-12m) with edible black berries available late dry to wet season.

ex.xv: Nalodkimuk.
ex.xe: Fat man.

ex.xv: Yilodbakkemen.
ex.xe: Break the loaf (of damper).

sn.de: Loaf; used to describe round shapes such as damper/bread loaves, human torsos or yams.

ex.xv: Manlombelng mandulkrayek, korroko dabborrabbolk birridulkmangi birrimarnbuni kunbarlkbu wanjh birrikarungi manme.
ex.xe: The manlombelng tree has hard wood, in the old days people used to use the wood for digging sticks to dig up food.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Kind of multi-stemmed tree 4-10m high (previously classified as a Melaleuca), the flowers of which are a source of nectar for honey bees. The wood is very hard and can be used for digging sticks and spear heads.

ex.xv: Manmakmak manme
ex.xe: Healthy food.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Very good (man- class nouns), healthy (food), etc.
Wooden hooked stick used for collecting the central new shoots of pandanus trees.

ex.xv: Bu manmile ngarriyime wanjh kunukka yiman kayime nawu kunmadj ngarrimarnbun. Marebu, djerrh, badjkid, kundjabarrk. Dja bu ngarriyime mile wanjh kunukka ngarrimilekurrme nawu ngarridahkendikenh yiman kayime balangkid.
ex.xe: When we say 'manmile', we mean something woven that we're making, for example a mat, dilly bag, basket or string bag. But when we say 'mile', that means bedding that we're putting down so we can sleep in it, like a blanket.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

se.de: Weave, make woven textile, make a bed.

ex.xv: Dedjkorrk kangun barrdjungka manmim.
ex.xe: The the Australasian Grebe eats the seeds of water lilies.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nahni manimunak kahdowen, kundjak kakarrme lead-beh, manmim shotgun nguneng.
ex.xe: This magpie goose is sick, it has disease from consuming shotgun lead [pellets].

sn.de: Firearm bullets and shotgun cartridges and (by semantic extention) any small globular cylindrical or bead-like objects
Billy goat plum, kind of Terminalia tree with an edible furry-skinned fruit, grows in sandstone country in dry sandy soils.

ex.xv: Manmorlak makka kundulk dja manme kakarrme manbu ngarringun. Bu kare kanguybun kakukdangen kadjolengmen wanjh ngarrire ngarimoyhmang manbu mandjoleng kawarrawarrhme kore kurorre kukurlk.
ex.xe: The billy goat plum is a tree which has edible fruits. When it flowers, the fruits form on the tree and ripen, then we go and gather the ripe fruits which fall on the ground.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngaye Kamarrang na-Burdoh, nani Nabarlek Band ngarduk ngaye. Konda Manmoyi kabolkngeyyo.
ex.xe: I'm Kamarrang of the Burdoh clan. This is the Nabarlek band here with me, and this place is called Manmoyi.
ex.so: Quoted in CAAMA Productions (2001). Nabarlek: Manmoyi. [video] Available at: https://www.nfsa.gov.au/collection/curated/nabarlek-manmoyi [Accessed 22 Jun. 2019].

sn.de: Homeland centre/outstation in Burdoh clan estate on the Mann River.

ex.xv: Nakorrkko kabenebokyo kure Manmoyi.
ex.xe: There are footprints of the Nakorrkko ancestor heroes at Manmoyi.

sn.de: Place in Kardbam clan estate on Mankorlod creek, south of Mankorlod homeland community. It is a wide open area of sandstone along a watercourse. There are small depressions in the rock which are said to be the footprints of the Nakorrkko father and son creation ancestors.

ex.xv: Korroko kobahkobanj nawu daluhdaluk birrikani kundjabarrk wanjh birridahkendongi manngalele bu rungi manngalele kudjewk.
ex.xe: In the past, the old women would take their dillybags and fill them with white currants, when the currants ripened in the wet season.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: White currant tree, fruit of the white currant tree.

ex.xv: Nakka kunekke kunj kawarlkkayindi kungarre.
ex.xe: That kangaroo is there hiding in the bushes.

sn.de: Forest, jungle, thicket. Refers to dense forest or thickets, such as jungle areas around springs or Anbinik forest, as opposed to manberrk ‘open savanna’.

ex.xv: Birriwurlhkeng, birriwurlhkemeninj kundjahkorl bordebmeninj wurlhkeng bonj manngarre kurrmeng nawu biwurlhkeng birurrkdabkeng.

sn.de: Vegetation in a general sense; brush, kindling, leaves and sticks.

ex.xv: Manbu manngukmanj makka manme ngarringun bu ngarrikarrme kebdjirned, dja mak kala ngarrimang manbu mandulkdad bu ngarrikinje kunngobarn wanjh karlba kayimerran.
ex.xe: Cheesefruit is a fruit that we eat when we have a cold, and we also get dye from the roots, cooking them up with pandanus to make the pandanus yellow.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Cheesefruit tree with edible medicinal fruit.

re: soft food which has been pounded

ex.xv: Kabirrinjonjme manme wanjh mannjonj kayimerran.
ex.xe: They pound food into a pulp.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Soft plant material or meat which has been pounded.

ex.xv: Kunak karung wanjh manrakel kawelengbebme.
ex.xe: Fire burns (the country) and new growth will eventually come up.
ex.so: Victor Garlngarr

sn.de: Generic term for small plants, low vegetation cover or non-woody plants and new growth of woody plants.
Leafy annual shrub on margins of monsoon forests, has edible black grapes.

ex.xv: Ngad ngarrikeleminj bu birrimarnbom war... Ngarriwam Warruwi rowk, ngarrinang manwern manwelyi dja kabbala kore kurrula.
ex.xe: We were scared when the war started... We all went to Goulburn Island, and saw lots of aeroplanes, and boats on the ocean.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Birradjdja ngarringuni… ngarrikurrmi, ngarribuni wanjh yoy. Manwerrk manu rey warreka.
ex.xe: We used to eat rice…  we used to put it there and thresh it. The husks would fly off all over the place but the rice would stay where it was.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Husk, skin that has been shed, substance which has peeled off.

se.de: Peel, strip, remove the outer layer.

ex.xv: Manwodjkare karridorrorroke.
ex.xe: Let's drag the old logs.

ex.xv: Manwurrkkah birriduhdulubom kunj yo. Ngarrikarrmeng mankole nawu, bolkkime rifle.
ex.xe: They used to spear kangaroos in the midst of the fire. We had spears then but today we have rifles.
ex.so: Kalarriya

sn.de: Bushfire, bushfire used to hunt game (especially kangaroos).

ex.xv: Bu karrire baleh kore manberrk karriwarlbun karrirednan djuwe karedmarnbun kamang kundalk dja manyahyay kundulk.
ex.xe: If we go anywhere in the forest hunting we see bowerbird nests, it makes its nest by gathering grasses and acacia branches.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Generic term for the dead branches of various small woody shrubs and trees, especially acacias, which are used as kindling.

ex.xv: Berrerdberrerd karrinan kabarndi kore kundulk manyende yika karrolkan kare kubuyika mayh kayawan.
ex.xe: We see Rainbow Bee Eaters sitting on tree branches, or flying off somewhere else to look for insects.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentaton

ex.xv: Nani yina bobbidj, la ngabidbun wanjh ngarradjeng wanjh ngarradje ngayendedadjke ngayendedadjke kamankan." "Ma ma ma," bidbom wanjh yendedadjeng, yendedadjeng rowk 'wey bum' mankang.
ex.xe: You see that honey hive there, well I'll climb up and cut it, I'll cut all the branches off and it'll fall down. "Yeah OK, OK." He climbed up and cut all the branches off; 'thud', it fell down.

sn.de: Branch coming off main stem or trunk of a tree or plant.

ex.xv: Anyendewern
ex.xe: Lots of little tributaries or channels of a watercourse

sn.de: Branch or tributary of a watercourse.
Kind of sedge used for paint brushes which create the fine lines of hatching infill in painting.

ex.xv: Kore manyunkurr, adjbud kayo.
ex.xe: On the island, there is a beach.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’

ex.xv: Yiman ngad bininj, nungka wayarra mararradj kakarrme warridj.
ex.xe: Just like people, wayarra spirits have boyfriends/girlfriends too.

sn.de: Romantic partner, boyfriend/ girlfriend, secret lover.
Major regional ceremony associated with both duwa and yirridjdja moieties.
Fine cross hatching designs relating to the Mardayin ceremony.

ex.xv: Dja mak bu bininj kabirriwokngimen kondabeh kore Mardbalk wanjh dingki kabirrimlobme.
ex.xe: And if people phone Goulburn Island from here, people will come over in a dinghy [to pick them up].
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Small freshwater shrimp from the Arnhem Land plateau.

ex.xv: Manbu kundulk kadulkngeyyo mardderr ngalengman kadjordmen kore kukabohkabo, dja manbu kunmalaworr makka wanjh kamalaworrbume.
ex.xe: The silver-leaved paperbark grows by rivers, and the leaves give off a kind of haze (as oil evaporates from them in the sun).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Silver-leaved paperbark. Some Kuninjku speakers use this term as the kun-kurrng respect register term for paperbark. Some speakers say that this name is a generic term for all paperbarks which have removable useful bark.

ex.xv: Nawu marebu nakka nakimuk mat kabirrimarnbun. Daluhdaluk kabirrire kunngobarn kabirrimang dja kundulk manbu mandjarnngal kabirrikan kabirrikardmang manbu kunngobarn kahdjabdi manekke kabirrimang.
ex.xe: A “marebu” is a big mat which people make. Women go and get pandanus, they take a forked stick along so they can hook the pandanus leaves with it [and pull them down], the straight leaves that stand upright.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Pandanus mats used by women as skirts. The word also commonly refers to flat pandanus mats made for sale in recent times as decorative art objects, often coloured with natural dyes.

ex.xv: Marla nakka nabang bu kanbaye dja kandong kunberd ngalengarre.
ex.xe: Scorpions are dangerous if they bite you, they strike you with their tail.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Birridoy rowk, wanjh birrikayhmeng, "Marladj", birrimarneyimeng, "Yimray ngundiwon". Yimarnek kamkuyinwam kondanj darnkih "Ya", birrimarneyimeng, wanjh nalkiduhdurndi djalwam wanjh doweng kunmarrwe.
ex.xe: They pounded all the food, then they called him 'orphan boy' they said, "Come, they'll give you some." He came close up then "ya", they said to him [they tricked him and didn't give him the food] and so he went back crying and starving.

ex.xv: Bu mankole kabirriyamerren, bininj kabirribaye namekke marlakka ba kunyid kabenwon.
ex.xe: During spear fights, men bite these sacred dilly bags (hanging around their neck) to give them fighting spirit.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, Ngaldjordboh Story in ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Very small tightly woven sacred dilly bag worn around the neck and containing cutting implements for ritual purposes.
Name of a song set performed in Kuninjku and Kunbarlang languages. Also associated with song sets called mimih 'rock spirit' or yawkyawk 'young woman/mermaid'.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni mandjabu.
ex.xe: In the old days, people used to make fish traps.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nungkah marnbom manekke Ubarr, nungkah marnbom Yirrbardbard.
ex.xe: He created the Ubarr ceremony, Yirrbardbard created it.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Ngarrimarnbuni ngadberre lesson.
ex.xe: We would do our lessons.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Do, complete a task or activity.

ex.xv: Muddikang ngarduk warreminj, ngakan kore mechanic kabirrimarnbun.
ex.xe: My car has broken down, I'll take it to the mechanic and they will fix it.

ex.xv: Dja kore mulil kabirrikarrme kabirrimarnbun wanjh kunrodjbe kabirribarurren bininj dja daluk.
ex.xe: When they have ceremonies, men and women (sometimes) paint themselves with red ochre.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Namarrkon kamarnbun kangurdulme kamayhke dja kandong bininj.
ex.xe: Namarrkon makes it thunder and creates lightning and strikes people.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Cause, make something happen, make someone do something, make something a certain way.

se.de: Transfigure oneself, make oneself into something else.

ex.xv: Kanmarneka manbu kunyarl.
ex.xe: Bring that rope for me.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, ‘Biyuk Biyuk’ story.

ex.xv: Nja, ten dollar djalbonj, wardi kanmarneyakwon.
ex.xe: Here you are, here's ten dollars and that's enough, or you'll clean me out.
ex.so: Evans, Nicholas (ed.), How to write Kundjeyhmi, prepared for the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Gagudju Association.

ex.xv: Ngalngayeng kawarre nganmarnedoweng korroko ngarribarrkbombarrkbom. Ngurrimray karrimarnenalkbun.
ex.xe: (words to a song) My daughter has died, we have been grieving all through the night until dawn. Come all of you and let us wail for her.

sn.de: Verb prefix which expresses that an action is done for the benefit of someone else, or to their detriment. Can often be translated as ‘for’, as in ‘She brought it for me’.

re: prefix that emphasises that an action relates to a particular person

ex.xv: Kumekke bimarnebebmeng biyameng.
