ex.xe: He appeared there where she was and speared her.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 24-27

sn.de: Prefix used to emphasise that an action affects or relates to a particular person or thing. E.g. bebmeng (he appeared) vs bimarnebebmeng (he appeared before him, he turned up to see her etc).

se.de: Pray (used in Christian religious contexts only).
Explain to someone, tell someone a story.

ng: An applicative expressing a beneficiary or maleficiary role.

ex.xv: Kumekke bimarnebebmeng biyameng.
ex.xe: He suddenly appeared and speared her right there.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 24-27

ex.xv: Kabirriwarlbun kumekke nungan boywek kayo wanjh kabirrire kabirriyurrhke, wanjh kabenmunkemang wanjh kabenkadjung kukak kabenmarnebebme.
ex.xe: If people go hunting where there is a gecko, when they pass the gecko it follows after them. Then at night time, it appears.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 84, adapted by Jill Nganjmirra.

sn.de: Appear before someone, turn up where someone is.

ex.xv: Ngunmarnedjare ngunewokdi.
ex.xe: She wants to talk to you.

sn.de: Cry for a deceased or injured person.

ex.xv: Minj kandiwokbekkan bu karrbenhmarneyime.
ex.xe: They just don’t listen when we tell them.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngudda korlonj yimarneyime.
ex.xe: You call him 'korlonj' (son).
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngalbu daluk yika wurdyaw ngarrimarneyime ngalkomkudji bu benedanginj karrowen kayakmen.
ex.xe: We call a woman or girl ‘ngalkomkudji’ if her sibling passes away.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Call kin X, address someone as X.

ex.xv: Marrabbi anbalabala worrno.
ex.xe: The sand palm has flat/wide leaves (as opposed to other fan palms such as Livistona inermis) [Kundedjnjenghmi]

ng: In Kuninjku this name is a synonym for djendek, but in Kundedjnjenghmi and Kundjeyhmi ankulurrudj refers to the shorter varieties or juvenile specimens whilst the larger specimens are called anmarrabbi.

sn.de: Exchange ceremony of diplomacy which involves the final presentation of a long decorated ceremonial pole. The performers dance for their hosts each evening over a period of weeks to celebrate the rite of passage of a young boy. A small lock of the child's hair is held in a small woven bag and this or other token is also referred to as the marradjiri or in the case of the mamurrng ceremony the token is called the mamurrng.

ex.xv: Ngayi Balang nganemarrinj.
ex.xe: Balang and I got married.

ex.xv: Wanjh birriwam birrikinjeng, djolengminj, birrimarrhmey birringuneng, birriworrkminj, birridokmeng kured.
ex.xe: They went and cooked them [the long-necked turtles], and when they were cooked they broke them open and ate until they were full, and then went home.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974

se.de: Open (a door, lid, window, mouth etc.)

ex.xv: Njaleken yimarrkmang, kakurren nakkan, ngunwurrhke.
ex.xe: Why do you do what he says, he's lying, deceiving you.

sn.de: Obey, pay attention to what someone says and do what they say.

ex.xv: Ngare Marrkolidjban, bolkki ngamdurndeng.
ex.xe: I'm going to Marrkolidjban and coming back today.

sn.de: Homeland Centre in Born and Miri clan country. This is a large district name or kunngeybadjan.

ex.xv: Benewam benebom nawern ngarrbek, kalawan dja mak nabubuyika mayh. Ngahli daluk Ngalyangdoh marrmarrminj.
ex.xe: They went and caught lots of echidnas, goannas and other kinds of animals. That woman Ngalyangdoh was very happy.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 244

sn.de: To become happy, to cheer up, to get excited.

ex.xv: Namardaka nakimuk dja marrngunj nayahwurd.
ex.xe: “Namardaka” is a large catfish, and “marrngunj” is a small one.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakimuk marrngunj kukbulerri nakka duwa, dja nayahwurd marrngunj kukbele nakka yirridjdja.
ex.xe: Large black juvenile catfish belong to the Duwa moiety, and smaller white ones are Yirridjdja.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Eel-tailed catfishes but only smaller specimens. The name bikurr or namardaka refers to larger specimens.
Palm sp. The growth apex is cut out and eaten as 'cabbage'. Water containers are made from the basal sheaths of old fronds. Leaves of young plants may be eaten raw.

re: great aunt, great uncle (father's father's siblings)
sn.de: A kin term which means different things across the Bininj Kunwok dialect chain. In most dialects: 1. father's father and that person's siblings 2. a man's son's child 3. a woman's brother's son's child. Parallel patrilineal grandkin might be another way of saying this. Some Kundjeyhmi speakers call their mother's mother's brother mawah and speakers of Mayali at Manyallaluk don't use the term mawah at all but rather all parallel grandkin (father's father, father's father's sister, mother's mother, mother's mother's brother) are called kakkak.

ex.xv: Ngabenmarneyolyolme nawu ngaye ngabenbornang. Ngaldahdaluk, narahrangem ngabenmarneyolyolme about baleh birrikukyimi nawu mawahmawah kabirriyime bedda, mawah nawu kabirriyime nawu kabirriyime nawu ngaldahdaluk.
ex.xe: I’m teaching my children, daughters and sons, as I raise them I'm telling them what their forebears were like, who they refer to as “mawahmawah”. They call the women that too.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Forebears, more immediate human ancestors as opposed to mythological ancestors. Emphasis is placed on the direct patriarchal lineage [mawah = father’s father and his siblings], but the term can also be used more generally.

ex.xv: Konda nuk ngandibawong ngamayahmayahme.
ex.xe: They must have deserted me, now I am confused and lost (Words of wurrurrumi song).

ex.xv: Balanda kabirrinan kabirriyime "oh good colour" la kabirrimayahme nadjamun
ex.xe: Non-aboriginal people look (at a bark painting design) and they say "Oh good colour" but they're not aware that there is a sacred/secret meaning there.

ex.xv: Nawu bininj dja balanda kabirrimang nawu mayh wanjh kabirrikelebukwon kakelebukmen kabirrimarnbun kelebuk mayh bedberre.
ex.xe: Both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people get animals and tame them, the animals become tame and people turn them into their pets.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Animal. This word can refer to any animal.

ex.xv: Kakom mayh kabenemirrkmarren Dilebang.
ex.xe: The rainbow serpents' heads stand there facing each other at Dilebang.

ex.xv: Mayh kawokdi Mimarn.
ex.xe: There will be a ceremony at Mimarn (this location for example implies a duwa ceremony).

sn.de: Ceremony (refers normally in ceremonial context to either the Duwa or Yirridjdja major regional cermonial complexes)

ex.xv: Bulanj, yidok mayh yimelmeng?
ex.xe: Bulanj, did you stand on a snake?

ex.xv: Mayh wam.
ex.xe: He's gone hunting.

ex.xv: Mayhmak/mayhwarre
ex.xe: Good hunter/no good at hunting

sn.de: Hunting. When used together with a verb such as re (to go), mayh is used to mean 'hunting' (literally 'go for animals').

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan djurlhmeng mayhbang derrehmeng kunkudji djurlhmeng dolkkang ngalyaw bibayeng.
ex.xe: The mother poked the log with the long stick, and the snake moved and she poked it again, then it came and bit the daughter.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009. Song text by Jill Nganjmirra.

sn.de: Produce a sudden flash of light (used to refer to namarrkon, lightning man).

ex.xv: Med yirrin, warde ngunnan kornobolo.
ex.xe: Hang on, wait, otherwise the wallaby will see you.

sn.de: Wait, not yet, 'hang on a bit'

ex.xv: Yimedda kanna kondah.
ex.xe: Look around and look at me.

ex.xv: Nawu bininj meddanj bininj binang nawu nabuyika bininj kumhrey.
ex.xe: The man turned and saw another man coming.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yimedda yibolkna njale kamhre!
ex.xe: Look around and see if anything's coming!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yimarnek meddanj kure birribom, kure meddanj birribom, kure meddanj kure kune kameddan kune kayime la kune yimeng la kubolkyimeng.
ex.xe: Whenever he would turn his head, they hit him, when he turned his head the other way they hit him, this way and that way and they kept hitting him.

sn.de: Look around, turn head to one side.

ex.xv: Medjek yima kanbubuhme.
ex.xe: Get the feather fan and fan me.

ex.xv: Bu kabbal karrire wanjh kunkih karrikihmelme wanjh kandelkke kunkih.
ex.xe: When we go onto the floodplain and step in the mud, we get splashed with mud.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Kick or stand on something, touch with foot.

ex.xv: And nungka rerre yiman mimih kahmelme mak ya mankarre and bedda rerre birriyolyolmeng and dabborrabbolk and bindimarneyimeng ngurrimelmen yiman karrimelme and mimih melmehmelmeng ya.
ex.xe: People did it after in the same way mimih dance (by stomping their feet) and also songs and stories which were told to the old people/ancestors and they told them to dance just like we dance and the mimih used to dance yes.

sn.de: A dance style of men's foot stomping mimih dancing.

ex.xv: Ngaleng korlonj ngunmelme.
ex.xe: She calls you 'son'.

sn.de: To call someone a kinship term.

ex.xv: Baleh kamenmenyime?
ex.xe: What does it mean?

ex.xv: Ba bu kunubewu wanjh kakarremenmenmakmen.
ex.xe: So that maybe the meaning of things will become clear.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Knowledge, meaning, motive. This noun does not appear independently in this form but is incorporated into a wide variety of verbs.

se.de: Not understand the meaning of something, have no knowledge on a topic.

sn.de: Be knowledgable, have knowledge about a certain topic.

ex.xv: Baleh kamenmenyime?
ex.xe: What does it mean?

ex.xv: Ngarriwernhburrkburrknan, manu baleh kakarremenmenyime kore kabimbuyindi.
ex.xe: We study it to find out the meaning of what is written there.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Manih mankung ngangalkeng kure mikambe.
ex.xe: I found this wild honey in an ant mound.

ex.xv: Ngayi kuberrk ngayo, minj ngadjare mikurrambalk.
ex.xe: I'm going to sleep outside, I don't like being inside houses.

ex.xv: Mingarre
ex.xe: In the vine forest.

ex.xv: Mikurrurla
ex.xe: In the sea.

ex.xv: Mibbarr, djang Kurnumbidj dja Kulmarru bedberre.
ex.xe: The white-bellied sea eagle is a totem for people in the Kunumbidj and Kulmarru clans.

ur: Kune = damala, Kundjeyhmi = marrawuddi, Rembarrnga= makaka

ex.xv: Hat yidjongburren la ngandimidbun.
ex.xe: Put a hat on and they won't recognise us.

sn.de: Mistake the identity of somebody, not recognise,

se.de: Not recognise someone's voice, misunderstand something.

ex.xv: Benewam benehyawani kalawan midj, benebalwam benenang kahmidjdi, wanjh benemey kunbarlkbu, benehkarungi.
ex.xe: They were looking for goanna burrows, and when they went a bit further they saw one. So then they got a digging stick and dug it out.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Kalawan munguyh mak kanyiwarlbuni ngadberre kalawan kanbukkani, midj.
ex.xe: They would always take us hunting and teach us about goanna too, and the holes they dug.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Burrow or hole belonging to burrowing animals such as goannas.

ex.xv: Ngalwakadj yimeng "Ngare nganan ngalkohbanj". Wanjh Ngalngarridj ngalengmanwali yimeng "Ngamre kab mikan".
ex.xe: Ngalwakadj said "I'm going to visit the old woman", and Ngalwakadj said "I'll come along with you".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Boyenni kornkumo bimarneyimeng, "Korlonj, kab ngarre djenj, kanmikan ngarranjbun." "Yoh Ngabba, ngarray."
ex.xe: One day the father said "Son, let's go fishing. Come along with me, I'm going to spear some fish". "Sure dad, let's go".
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Beywurd dja Kornkumo Benewam Djenj’, in ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

sn.de: Accompany, come along, go with someone.

ex.xv: Kunkurrngkenh bu kabirriwokdi nawu nakurrng dja ngalkurrng kabirrimarneyimerren. Nakka wanjh kabirrimikmerren kabirriwokdi kunbalak kunwok.
ex.xe: People who call each other nakurrng or ngalkurrng use 'mother-in-law language'. They use this avoidance language, (also) called kunbalak.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Use mother-in-law avoidance register when speaking.

ex.xv: Korroko kobahkobanj birrimarnbuni djerrh dja kundjabarrk nawu milekarrkarr bu birridahkendongi mankinjdjek manmile.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors would make open weave dilly bags and string bags for putting shavings of cheeky yam into (so they could put the bags into water and soak out the yam toxins).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Open weave, lightweight textile; weaving with small hole spaces e.g. a mosquito net.

ex.xv: Kabirrimilebun kabirridahkendong kore djerrh kabirridjuhke kore kukku, mankinjdjek dorrengh.
ex.xe: They weave [a basket] and put the cheeky yam into the dillybag, and then submerge it with the cheeky yam into the water.

sn.de: Weave, make woven textile or string bag.

ex.xv: Yimilemarnbu ba ngarriyo!
ex.xe: Make the bed so we can sleep in it!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ng: Some speakers reject milebun and insist on milemarnbun.

ex.xv: Korroko kobakobanj birrimilungi mankinjdjek wanjh birrimilngdjuhkeyi kore kukku wanjh bangyakmeni wanjh birrimilngwaykeyi bu birringuni.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would cut cheeky yams into thin shavings, then put the shavings in water until the toxins leached out, then pull them out to eat.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kundjaberle kunj birrimangi wanjh birrimilungi.
ex.xe: They would take a kangaroo’s shoulder blade and use that to cut vegetables into thin pieces.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Cut into thin pieces (a vegetable etc.) by successively shaving pieces from the outside, pare, peel.

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalmangiyi ngalka karrinan karrimang kore kubolkwarlahken kunred kore kabbal kayo. Morlehmorlenj daluk nawu ngad bininj birrirey kabbal mim birriyawani.
ex.xe: We find long necked turtles [Chelodina rugosa] in wide open country, where there are flood plains. Women of our people would go out onto the floodplain looking for the small holes the turtles breathe through as they lie buried under the mud.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Breathing holes of long-necked turtles, crabs etc. During the dry season long-necked turtles can be found buried beneath the mud of floodplains, obtaining oxygen through these holes.

ex.xv: Ngad karrinjilngmak bu Dird kabolkwolkan, wanjh, wanjh karribolknan bu kukak, nungka kayawoyhmimbimen. […] Nungka kadjaldarrkid kanmarnbun karrimimbi mandjewk dja mandjewk.
ex.xe: We are happy when the moon lights up the sky, so we can see at night. The moon comes back to life [every night]. […] He never dies, he gives us life year after year.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 120

ex.xv: Korroko kumekke ni nakudji nabirl dja kukmohmokni kore kubuhbuburrk nuye dja mimbunjeni minj bolknayinj.
ex.xe: A long time ago, there was a crippled man living in the area. He had sores all over his body and was blind, he couldn’t see a thing.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngunmimdelkke yimimbudbudmen.
ex.xe: She's going to put drops in your eyes, so blink them.

ex.xv: Bu korroko bininj birridjareni bindibuni birribuyika bininj wanjh namekke bininj bolkmelmi wernkih wanjh nayin kunbebmi ngalyod. Wanjh bimarneyimi mayh yikodjbayemen namekke bininj ba kadowen. Wanjh ngalyod dja bininj nawu marrkidjbu benekuknarreni wanjh bininj minj mimburdburdmeni, warde warreworrimeni.
ex.xe: In the old days when people wanted to kill other people, that person would stamp on the ground and Ngalyod (the Rainbow Serpent) would come out. He would tell Ngalyod “bite that person’s head so they die”. Then the man, the sorcerer, would stare into Ngalyod’s eyes without blinking. If he blinked, he would ruin it [the power of the sorcery].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngurrimimbudmen!
ex.xe: Close your eyes (all of you).

ex.xv: Yiwarrudj ngarridi kuberrk rowk, wanjh ngarridanginj yiwarrudj, ngarrimimburdmi, ngandimarnedi ngadberre.
ex.xe: We had had our prayers outside. We would close our eyes and they would pray for us.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Nuye djabulhdjabulh barrk djukerre kamimburdme dja kangun.
ex.xe: That Solanum echinatum (wild tomato), is the food of the black wallaroo, which it eats with its eyes closed [because of the spikes].

ex.xv: Mimdjanj nakka djenj nawu ngarringun dabborrabobolkwi. Minj wurdurd kabirringun dja murrngwern.
ex.xe: Tarpon is a fish that only us adults eat. Children don't eat them, because they have too many bones.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu karlarlbba nakka djenj ngarringun nawu kare kore kubowinjku kukku. Boken nawu djenj nakudji nawu kukbalabala kabirringeybun kunngeybuyika mimdjanj dja nabuyika nawu kukkuyeng nakka ngarringun, karlarlbba bokenh kabenekarrme kunmurrng manwern kore kunkanj berrewoneng bu ngarringun wanjh ngarriwernhmurrngnan manbu kunmurrng.
ex.xe: Tarpon are a freshwater fish that we eat. There are two types, one with a flat body that other people call 'mimdjanj', and one with a long body that we eat. Both types have lots of bones in their flesh, and we have to watch out for the bones when we eat them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Thin spirits who live in the stone country inside cracks in the rock or caves etc. They are often mischievous and not particularly friendly. They do not venture outside of the protection of their rock environment as even a light wind can snap their fragile bones.

ex.xv: Minj nganayinj.
ex.xe: I didn't see her.

ex.xv: Bele ngankarrme minj bale ngayime ngadolkkan.
ex.xe: I’ve got a cramp, I can’t stand up.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngaye ngabolkbawong Warruwi ngawam Minjdjilang ngahni.
ex.xe: I left Goulburn Island and was living on Croker Island.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 252

sn.de: Croker Island, Minjilang (the main community on Croker Island).
Oar for water craft, often made from mangrove trees.

ex.xv: Nabulanj wam kabbal wanjh nawu djarrang dja nganabbarru mirndeyarlarrkeng.
ex.xe: Nabulanj went down to the floodplain, and made all the horses buffalo run off and disperse (as he walked near them).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Be in a group, do something as a group.

se.de: Gather together in a large group.

ex.xv: Marlkawo kamirnderri ankurlahbang.
ex.xe: At Marlkawo there are lots of ankurlahbang plants.

ex.xv: Wanjh benebokkang yimankek beneyameninj dja larrk lobmeng kore manlarrh dulkmirnderri.
ex.xe: Then they followed it [the emu] and tried to spear it, but it ran into an area with lots of cyprus trees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Be in large numbers, be, stand [of groups].

ex.xv: Birridjalmirndewernni wurdwurd.
ex.xe: There were a lot of kids there.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngalbu birndu ngalkka karrinan kore kabbal bu kudjewk dja kurrung karrolkarren karrinan mirndewern.
ex.xe: We see glossy ibis on the floodplain in the wet season, and we see lots of them flying in the build-up season.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu ngurrinan namirndewern kunj kadjirihdjiri kore kunburrk kunj, wanjh, ngurribengkan Nakidjkidj kumekke dingihdi benhkanjmangi namekke kunj.
ex.xe: When you see a big mob of kangaroos with marks on their bodies, you know Nakidjkidj has been there, taking flesh from their bodies.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 172

ex.xv: Birridulklowkmangi mandubang kundulk birridjedmi bokko manmirrh birrimarnbuni.
ex.xe: They would peel the ironwood and carve it into spear tips.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Madordak minj benmenedudjeyinj dja manbu mankole manmirrh kahdjalmirrhdi kore kundulk.
ex.xe: Madordak didn’t bury them and the spear tips are still embedded in the tree.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Cutting edge, point, sharp thing, spear head.

se.de: Have a sharp edge or point.

ex.xv: Yimborledmen kanmirrkma!
ex.xe: Turn facing me!
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

se.de: Cross someone's path, go in front of them.

ex.xv: Ngalmobik.
ex.xe: She is scrawny.

ex.xv: Yiman bu nayahwurd, yika mobik, minj kawernhkanjdi nungka kadjalwohdjobke mandjawak kunwardde kunyahwurd kunkanj dja kamunkewe ba kare kakimukmen kabalemdangen.
ex.xe: If the [kangaroos] are young or skinny, without much flesh on them, he [Nakidjkidj] will just cut a little bit of meat off them with his stone knife and let them go again, so they can get big and fat.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 208

ex.xv: Nganemodjarrkdorrinj.
ex.xe: We relate to each other by virtue of cross-cousin skewing.

sn.de: Skewing relationship of cross cousins in the same generation to become kin in adjacent generations. Thus FZD>FZ and FZS>F. This is often done between a person and their brother's wife who is a classificatory cross-cousin (FZC, MBC). Brother's wife will be addressed as berlu FZ and her brothers will be called ngabbard 'F'.

ex.xv: Kokok bibayeng modjarrkki.
ex.xe: Big brother was bitten by a crocodile.
ex.so: Title of a Nabarlek Band song, from the album 'Bininj Manborlh'.

ur: Kuninjku = kumoken, E syn.= koyo, nawulhmu, Djnj syn.= mokkorri

ex.xv: Manbu modjdje kundalk kadjordmen kabbal kore manlabbarl.
ex.xe: Spike rushes grow on floodplains, by billabongs.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kamodme.
ex.xe: He’s relaxed.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Yimodmen, warde kannan kadberre.
ex.xe: Be quiet, otherwise he’ll see us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kawk karrinan kani kore kukadjid kore kukku kaboyo kamodme djenj kamadbun kanan djenj kamre darnkih wanjh karranjbun kundang kunkeb nuye wanjh kawukme.
ex.xe: Rufous Night Herons stand on sandy banks by the water, waiting quietly until they see a fish come close. Then they spear them with their beaks and swallow them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yimodme yiman nawu bininj kahkan manme o mayh nawu kakukngorrkan, yuwn yibangmedjawan. Yidjalmodmen. Kare nungan, maydbi bu ngunburrbun ngunwon, dja bu larrk, larrk.
ex.xe: You just stay quiet if a man brings food or is carrying an animal on his shoulder. Don’t rush things and ask him. Just stay quiet. He’ll go about and maybe he’ll think of you and give you something, but if not, then it doesn’t matter.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Nawu kuhni kayime djenj nakka munguyh kadjalyo kore kubomodmiken, minj kayo kore kahborlobme.
ex.xe: That kind of fish just stays where the water is still, there aren’t any around where the water is flowing.
ex.so: Forbes, Brenda & Brennan, Queenie, ‘Nahni Djenj: Karribolkburrbun kore karrihmanamang’, Bamyili Press, Barunga, 1981

ex.xv: Nakka yina na-Mok yiman ngabolkngehngeybun kumekke kadjalre Djurrih Kawokbebme kaburnbun kumekke, na-Mok. Beh mak na-Djorrorlam karrimen yirridjdja, ya kurih kayime.
ex.xe: You see, these are all Mok clan names I have been reciting and the Mok country goes right up to Djurrih Kawokbebme and finishes there, the Mok estate. From there it's Djorrorlam clan country, yirridjdja moiety, yeah that's right.

sn.de: Name of a patriclan on the Arnhem Land plateau.

ex.xv: Ngamokdoweng.
ex.xe: My sore has healed.

ex.xv: Namorrorddoh bibidyikarrmeng bu dolkkang wohwam dja mimbayhmeng bu bolknang dja mokdoweng kore moknihmokni wanjh makminj.
ex.xe: The Namorrorddoh spirit helped him to stand up and walk, his eyes opened and he could see, his sores healed and he became well again.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Nayawurrinj bu mokdoweni, wanjh kunborlidj munguyh djaldi. Minj mak yakmeninj.
ex.xe: When the young man's cuts had healed, the scarification would remain. It wouldn't disappear.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birrimokenbawoyi kunwarre.
ex.xe: They should leave it all, its no good [i.e. intoxicating substances such as alcohol and kava].

ex.xv: Karrbennan birriwern kabirrimre moken dja djarreh kore kunred kabirrimdolkan kabirrimre kondah mandjewk kabirrimulewan bu darnkih kadjakdung.
ex.xe: We see lots of them [Little Curlews] coming in flocks from far away, they signal to us that the rains are about to start.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Mokenwarrhmeng, barrabarrhmeng.
ex.xe: The whole thing fell down and smashed to pieces.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Group, large group, whole lot, whole thing, everything.

ex.xv: Yawurrinj bu molknguni, wanjh kunukka birridungi because manekke birriburrbuni Mardayin o Ubarr o Lorrkkon.
ex.xe: If any young men ate anything secretly [ceremonially restricted foods], they would get really angry with them, because they knew that Mardayin or Ubarr or Lorrkkon ceremony.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kaluk minj bikayhmimayi dja djangkang kunj, wanjh ngalengbu keleminj. Wanjh djahdjalni ningihni, binang kamre wanjh bimarneyimeng, "Njale ngudda kunu kanmolkbawong?"
ex.xe: But he didn’t call back to her, he was off hunting kangaroos. She got frightened. So she just stayed sitting there, and when she heard him coming back she said “Why did you just sneak off (without saying anything)?”
ex.so: Gumurdul, Julie, ‘Mamamh dja kakkak benewam djenj’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh benewam beneyawani mankung, wanjh benengalkeng kubbulak kore kundulk. Benedulkngadji, wanjh benemonbuhmeng beneyiwkmey.
ex.xe: Two women went looking for honey, and found some kubbulak honey in a tree. They cut open the tree and got the honey.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yidjare kukkurrme monbuhme!
ex.xe: You want me to kill you and cut you open!

sn.de: Open up to obtain food, mostly used to refer to opening a tree to extract wild honey. Also to open up an animal by butchering it. Can be used as a threat to another person in a fight.

ex.xv: Nani nawu nayungki ngad karringeybun, bininj, yo nakka kanhnguyi nabang nabang,
ex.xe: He is someone from creation times, we call him (like that), a human form but he eats people, and he's dangerous, very dangerous, Mongerrh is like a spirit.

ex.xv: Mongerrk benbenenang daluk bokenh. Bedda benedanginj. Benehnguni mankarralarlhmanj.
ex.xe: Mongerrk saw the two women. They were sisters, and they were eating seeds from the peanut tree (Sterculia quadrifida).
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Blowfly/blowfly maggot, exceptionally large flies which follow evil spirits.

re: niece, nephew (woman calls the children of her younger sister)
sn.de: Mother's older sisters (MeZ). These sisters can reciprocally address the children of their younger sister in the same way.

ex.xv: “Bu morlehmorlenj kabirriwurlebme kumekke kunred, wanjh kabirrimerlemmen, kabirriyawmang bokenh wurdyaw.” Lumaluma bimarneyimeng.
ex.xe: “If women swim at that place, they will become pregnant, they will give birth to twins”, said Lumaluma.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Group of women, women, middle-aged women
Carry someone on one's shoulders or back. Can refer to someone carrying someone else piggyback (esp. a child), a horse carrying a person, etc.

re: pick up and carry on shoulders

ex.xv: Nawu nakornkumo bimarneyimeng wurdyaw "Yimray mornemang ba karrire".
ex.xe: The father said to the child "Come here, I'll pick you up and carry you on my back so we can go".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalkudji ngalyawk birrengedulubom kundulk minj baleh yimeninj bu rawinj dja kerlkdanj. Wanjh ngalbuyika daluk bimornemey.
ex.xe: A girl spiked her foot on a piece of wood, and was in too much pain to walk. So another woman put her up on her shoulders to carry her.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Pick someone up (esp. a child) and put them on one's shoulders or back, in order to carry them.

ex.xv: Korroko konda nawu bininj birrimorneni nawu djarrang birrilobmi djarrang dorrengh birridulubuni nawu nganabbarru.
ex.xe: In the past, the people here would ride horses and shoot buffalo while riding.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Sit on, ride on, be on top of.

re: pick up many small items from ground

ex.xv: Yerre bimurrngmoyhmey bimurrngkurrmeng kore kahwodjruhrurrk ba kunmalng nuye karrurndeng kore kunred nuye.
ex.xe: After that she picked up his bones and placed them inside a hollow log coffin, so that his spirit could return to his homeland.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Pick up many small objects from the ground, a typical example is fruit.

ex.xv: Nganemud.
ex.xe: We two are countrymen.

sn.de: Countryman, family, relalatives (incorporated noun that requires a pronoun prefix such as karri-, ngane-, etc).

ex.xv: Yimudbun werrk yiyakwon. Wanjh murrwidno yimurrwidkinje wanjh yibebke manekke yimudkinje wanjh yibebke.
ex.xe: You pluck off the feathers until finished. Then the down; you burn off the down and once you singe all the feathers then you take it out (of the fire).

sn.de: Pluck out feathers, hair or fur.

Generic term for various small dasyurid and other similar small mammals such as delicate mouse, Kakadu pebble mouse, fawn antechinus, sandstone false antechinus, grassland melomys, the common rock rat and the brush-tailed rabbit-rat. Some speakers also call some of these small mammals djirrkkinj or in Kune bob.
sn.sc: Pseudomys delicatus, Pseudomys calabyi, Antechinus bellus, Pseudatechinus bilarni, Melomys burtoni, Zyzomys argurus, Conilurus penicillatus

ex.xv: Kabirrimarnemulewarren.
ex.xe: They tell each other.

ex.xv: Nangale mulewam?
ex.xe: Who related that news?

ex.xv: Kano warde mulewan.
ex.xe: When the old people see dragonflies, they say OK, that means there are lots of fish (ready to be caught).
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Relate information, tell, inform. This word is also used to describe plants, animals or natural phenomena which ‘tell’ something about distant events or are a sign of something such as seasonal changes, the existence of a sacred site etc.
Ceremonial feast. At the completion of most large regional ceremonies, the public proceedings conclude with a large meal that everyone shares in.

ex.xv: Mahni mandule karrbarda minj mandjamun yiman kayime ‘ceremony’ duninjh bininj kabirriwayini dja daluk larrk kabirridjalborrkke kunkurdu. Kore yiman mulil dja wurdwurd kabindibukkan kore school.
ex.xe: The Karrbarda [Long Yam] song is not sacred like a real ceremony, men sing and women just dance the moves. Like in public ceremonies, or they show it to the children at school.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: A ceremony or celebration that is public as opposed to sacred.

ex.xv: Kondah kawarre, mulil. […] “Yuwn balanda yidjalmarrkebbun, kunwarre. Wardi yingan yirohrokmen,” ngayimeng.
ex.xe: It’s not good here, there’s a huge mob [of non-Indigenous people]. […] I said, “Don’t just leave it all up to those balanda. That’s no good. You should try to do it yourself.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Lots of, heaps of, a big mob of  [colloquial, extended from the idea of abundance at a ceremonial feast]

ex.xv: Kunkare ngalbadjan dja ngalyaw benewarlbom, dja kundjabarrk bokenh benebebbehmundikani.
ex.xe: A long time ago, a mother and her daughter went hunting. They each carried their own string bag, hanging at their back.
ex.so: Ngalmakgu Nabobbob, ‘Ngalbadjan dja ngalyaw benewarlbuni kunkurlurrk’ in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

sn.de: Carry a bag with the strap or string around the forehead or the neck, with the bag hanging down on the back.

ex.xv: Ngayi wanjh ngamungu.
ex.xe: Well I'm not to blame.

ex.xv: Nungka namungu birridjuhbom bu ngaye ngandidjuhbuyi.
ex.xe: They blamed that innocent man when they should have blamed me.
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace & Rowe, Meryl (eds), “Man of Sorrow” in ‘Karriburlume God: Kunwinjku Song Book’, Gunbalanya, 1985, p. 12

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw yimeng "Djak nganbayeng." Wanjh nalkbuni munguyh nawu wurdyaw.
ex.xe: The child said "An ant bit me". And he just kept on crying continually, that child.
ex.so: Dakgalawuy, Nancy, ‘Wurdyaw dirrihdirri’ in ‘Kunwinjku Stories’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

sn.de: For an extended length of time, continually. Extended (length or time).

ex.xv: Ngangadjihbun munguyh, kunubewu kebdjirned nganhmang.
ex.xe: I keep sneezing, maybe I'm getting a cold.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngad karrimunkekadjung namekke bininj.
ex.xe: We all are following after that man.

sn.de: Follow after, follow someone's leading or direction; follow the style or example of another.

se.de: Part ways, go in different directions.

ex.xv: Bolkmunun minj nganan.
ex.xe: It's a dark place, I can't see.

ex.xv: Murnubbarr djang kumekke darnki Midjuyh.
ex.xe: There is a magpie goose dreaming place there near Midjuyh.

ex.xv: Nawalabik bibom Nangordyawok bidjurddjobkeng wanjh doweng. Ngalbadjan nuye Nangordyawok durndi kore namud ngalengarre benmarneyimeng "Nawalabik nganmarneyawbom". Wanjh Nawalabik bebmeng murnungumulewarrinj. Yimeng "Ngaye ngabom Nangordyawok".
ex.xe: Nawalabik killed Nangordyawok, he chopped his neck and he died. Nangordyawok's mother went back to her family and told them "Nawalabik killed my son". Then Nawalabik appeared and confessed his deed, he said "I killed Nangordyawok".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: "Adju bokoluy?" "Larrk, kadjalborlobme manbomurrngbang".
ex.xe: "Has the water gone down (in the river)?". "No, it's still flowing very strongly".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunmayorrkmurrngbang.
ex.xe: A powerful wind.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 246

ex.xv: Lumaluma kabakbakke makka kabbala, nungka murrngrayek, nungka kadjobdjobke makka kabbala dja kabenbun birriwern bininj.
ex.xe: Lumaluma is smashing the boat, he’s a strong man, he’s breaking it into pieces and killing all the people.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 246

sn.de: Black flying fox. Associated with duwa moiety.

ex.xv: Nanih nabadjan biyawmey.
ex.xe: This is his uncle here, the one whose sister gave birth to him (or 'is in his upper adjacent generation matriline').

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to kamarrang in the eastern system.
Nabarlek (also known as the little rock wallaby).

ex.xv: Birrimwam Manawukan beh.
ex.xe: They came from Maningrida.

ex.xv: Beh karrire.
ex.xe: Let's just go over there.

ex.xv: Nabeh kahdi.
ex.xe: Him (the person just mentioned), he's just over there.

ex.xv: A: Kamarrang kahdi? B: Nabeh.
ex.xe: A: Is Kamarrang here? B: He's just over there.

sn.de: Demonstrative with gender prefix indicating both referential and locational immediacy 'that one who has just been mentioned, just over there'.

ex.xv: Bikarrebukkang nabeywurd nuye Nawamud Nadjalama.
ex.xe: He taught the song to his son, Nawamud of the Djalama clan.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Son, referent term only, used by a man (or a man’s sisters to refer to their brothers’ son).

ex.xv: Kunkareni kohbahkohbanj bokenh nabininjkobeng dja ngalbininjkobeng benekarrmi nakudji duruk nawu nabangni.
ex.xe: A long time ago, there were two old people, a husband and wife, who owned a dangerous dog.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, 'Nakudji wurdyaw bibayeng duruk' iin ‘Kunwinjku Stories’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

ex.xv: Merlbbe daluk ngalkka nabininjkobeng ngalengarre warradjangkal.
ex.xe: Merlbbe is a female agile wallaby, and her mate is the male agile wallaby, warradjangkal.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko kumekke ni nakudji nabirl dja kukmohmokni kore kubuhbuburrk nuye dja mimbunjeni minj bolknayinj.
ex.xe: A long time ago, there was a crippled man living in the area. He had sores all over his body and he was blind, he couldn’t see a thing.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Man with a physical disability, crippled man.
A type of wild honey often found in the ground, produced by native stingless bees identified as Tetragonula mellipes.
Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku

ex.xv: Namekke nadjinem manme kangun manbadbirri, yika kakolung kuwardde kakolung manbuyhbuyika kangun.
ex.xe: That black rock kangaroo eats Melodorum fruit, sometimes it comes down from the rocks and eats other kinds of food.

sn.de: Male black rock wallaroo. The female is called djukerre.
Sail-fin glass fish and other species of glassfish.
sn.sc: Ambassis agrammus, Ambassis mulleri and Ambassis macleayi.

sn.de: Look after, watch over, care for, look out for.

ex.xv: Dja nahni kakarrme danjbik kunka yiman namardaka, dja nakanjmak bu karringun.
ex.xe: And it [the salmon catfish] has three spines like an eel-tailed catfish, and its flesh is good eating.
ex.so: Forbes, Brenda & Brennan, Queenie, ‘Nahni Djenj: Karribolkburrbun kore karrihmanamang’, Bamyili Press, Barunga, 1981

sn.de: Male subsection name or ‘skin’ name of yirridjdja moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to bangardi in the eastern system.
Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to bulanj in the eastern system.
Spirit figure, nasty one, lives in the bush and spears kangaroos, but can kill humans if disturbed.
Mother's mother's brother, non-vocative form of kakkak. One's matrilineal parallel grandkin.
Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to wamud in the eastern system.

ng: There is great variation in the plural forms of this noun which dispenses with the noun class prefix. This means the plural form no longer explicitly marks gender (i.e. a group of elderly males, females or mixed gender group).
cf: kobahkobanj, kobokohbanj, kobohkobanj, kobohbanj, kohbahkohbanj, kobakohbanj

ex.xv: Nawu nayawurrinj minj kanan manbu Kunabibi, Yabburlurrwa dja Mardayin, wanjh nakka nakomyak ngarrimarneyime. Yiman karohrok ngalbu ngalyawk bu minj kanan manbu Yabburlurrwa wanjh ngalkka ngalkomyak.
ex.xe: If a boy hasn't seen the Kunabibi, Yabburlurrwa or Mardayin ceremonies, we call him 'nakomyak', and likewise if a girl hasn't seen the Yabburlurrwa ceremony, we call her 'ngalkomyak'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: An uninitiated boy, a boy who has no knowledge of a particular ceremony.

ex.xv: Kunred kunkuken Mankodbekayo.
ex.xe: Mankodbekayo is an important place.

ex.xv: Nawu Namarnkol djenj nakka wanjh nadjalkuken djenj ngadberre nawu ngarrikukburlerri dja birrikukbele.
ex.xe: Namarnkol, the barramundi, is a very important fish for us Bininj (Aboriginal people), and for non-Aboriginal people as well.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Karrire kukare kabolkkuken.
ex.xe: Let's go to the same place again, to that place we always go to.

sn.de: Important, of recognised cultural significance, important as part of tradition, traditional.

ng: requires a noun class prefix e.g. nakuken, mankuken etc; or a locative prefix e.g. kukuken

ex.xv: Nawu nakurl nakka mandjewk. Mandjewk kamre, kadedjdjingmang bu kadjakdung kurnumeleng. Nakka wanjh ngarringeybun barra dja djimurru, nawu kukku kabokurrme bu kamarnbun kaborlobme kore mankabo mak kabobarlke kore kulabbarl. Dja mak kamarnbun kundalk kundulk dja manme manwern kakukmarnbun bu kadjordmen. Dja nawu nakurl ngarrinan koyekbeh kangolburlerran kawarnamkurrme, wanjh nakka kamre bu kundalk kakekurrme rowk, kore kurorre kayo. Dja mak kayiburnbun bu kadjakdung. Wanjh nakka ngarringeybun nakurl.
ex.xe: ‘Nakurl’ is a storm. The rains start in the early wet season, and we call those rains ‘barra’ and ‘djimurru’, they make the rivers flow and fill up the billabongs. They also make the grasses, trees and many fruits grow. Nakurl are the storms that we see coming from the east, the clouds darken and make a dark horizontal bar on the horizon. It comes and knocks all the spear grass to the ground. That’s at the end of the wet season, the rains stop after that.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: The very last storms of the wet season, 'knock'em downs'.
Son-in-law (of female), mother's brother of actual or classificatory spouse, 'cousin', MMBS, MMBSSS. The address term (vocative form) is nakurrngh.

ex.xv: Bu Nawalabik bibom Nangordyawok doweng wanjh ngalbadjan nuye Nangordyawok nalkirey bu durndehdurndengi kore kakbi namud ngalengarre.
ex.xe: When Nawalabik killed Nangordyawok, Nangordyawok’s mother went back crying to her family in the north.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu namaddorl nakka mayhmayh nakimuk nungan kareddi kore kaddum kuwarde. Namaddorl nakka muddjuyh dja walakkih mudburlerri.
ex.xe: The Wedge-Tailed Eagle is a big bird which nests high up in the rocky country. Its feathers are brown and also black in parts.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: "Yoh," yimeng ngalbininjkobeng, "dja nawu wurdwurd bokenh karridjarrkre?" Kornkumo yimeng, "Burrkyak, birridin Ngalkinbalen dja Namanjmiken, dja ngarre mankung, dja kunj ngawarlbun."
ex.xe: “Yes”, said his wife, “Should we all go together, with the two kids?”. But the father said “No, they can stay with grandma and grandpa, the two of us can go looking for wild honey and I’ll go hunting for kangaroo”.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: Grandfather, mother’s father, non-vocative form of mamamh.

ex.xv: Namardaka nakimuk dja marrngunj nayahwurd.
ex.xe: “Namardaka” is a large catfish, and “marrngunj” is a small one.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.sc: Neosilurus spp., egs. Neosilurus ater, Neosilurus argenteus, Neosilurus hyrtlii, |fs{but also} Cinetodus froggatti, Anodontiglanis dahli.

ex.xv: Yimang kundjila wardi namorden karrong.
ex.xe: Get the axe otherwise the lightning will strike it. (It is said that axes left out in a storm will attract

ex.xv: Wanjh yimankek birrikuyinkelelobmerrinj ngalyod bennanganang, kunberd bendukkang rowk, namekbe namarladj dorrengh warreh.
ex.xe: Then they were about to run away in fright, but the Rainbow Serpent saw them and wrapped them all up with his tail, including the poor orphan boy.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Aa nakka bininj kabihbun namarlbbe.
ex.xe: Ah, that man is having a fit!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Malevolent spirit being. When used with the verb kabiwe, it means 'to have a fit', literally 'he/she is thrown by a bad spirit'.

ex.xv: Bininj nawu Namarndeyi.
ex.xe: The Murderer [title of a story in ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’]
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 24-27

ex.xv: Nakka namarndeyi, wardi kanbun.
ex.xe: That guy is a murderer, he might kill us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra.

sn.de: Murderer, can also imply someone who kills people by sorcery.
Silver Barramundi. Kunwinjku dialect speakers tend to use this name as a generic for barramundi. Some Kuninjku dialect speakers use it as a term for larger juveniles.

ex.xv: Namarrkon kamarnbun kangurdulme kamayhke dja kandong bininj.
ex.xe: Namarrkon makes it thunder and creates lightning and strikes people.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Lightning, lightning dreaming ancestor. On bark paintings he is drawn with hammers protruding from his body which he uses to throw and create thunder. Rock paintings of female lightning spirits have also been observed.

ex.xv: Nawu kinga dja djenj bimbom kore Kunwinjku 'xray style' dja mannjam warridj njamnameng.
ex.xe: He's painted the crocodile and fish in Kunwinjku 'xray' style, he's painted in the stomach as well.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu korroko larrwa birrimarnbuni kore kundulk dja bolkkime kabirridadjke mankole kore manbu kayingkihrurrk manekke kodj kabirriname wanjh bakki kabirrikurrme kabirrikinje kabiwungme.
ex.xe: In the past people would make pipes from wood, but now they cut bamboo, which is already hollow, put in a pipe bowl then add tobacco and smoke it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Karrimang mankole wanjh karridadname nawu dad djalakkiradj.
ex.xe: We get a spear shaft and attach prongs to it to make a fishing spear.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

se.de: Put a curse on someone, place someone under sorcery so they will die.

ex.xv: Korroko ngad namumuyak kanwong ngadberre kunmayali, manekke karrikadjung.
ex.xe: Namomoyak gave us our wisdom, so that’s what we [still] follow.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: The first humans and the spirits of the first people who died and turned into Namomoyak. They are said to be able to inhabit objects such as trees and have left ancient rock paintings in the escarpment country.

ex.xv: Yiman kabenerohrok nakidjkidj ya nakka wanjh kabenerohrok namorrorddo. Namorrorddo kabirlikan, bidngalnjkuyeng yoh.
ex.xe: Namorrorddo is similar to the spirit called 'Nakidjkidj', the same as Nakidjkidj. Namorrorddo however carries light (ie. the shooting star) and has really long claws, yes.

sn.de: Mythical creatures of a malevolent nature, namorrorddo are shooting star spirits. They have long claws and trails of white light coming from their heads. They also carry a long club called miyarrurl which they use to beat victims.

ex.xv: Ngadjare ngarrurndeng Ngardayun / kore namud kabirrini ngardduk
ex.xe: I want to go back to my home Ngardayun / where my family is staying
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

ex.xv: Mayh, namung, wurrkurduk, nawu namung. Ngeybokenh. Bu ngaye ngayime wurrkurduk bedda kabarriyime namung. Nabang kanbaye, nomo really ngarrdowen.
ex.xe: That snake, the black whip snake. It has two names. I call it wurrkurduk [in Kundedjnjenghmi] and others call it namung. It is aggressive and can bite us, but we don't die, it's only mildly venomous.

sn.de: 'The one who did it', eg. the murderer, the right one, person responsible (male).

ex.xv: Yina!
ex.xe: Look!

ex.xv: Nganan.
ex.xe: I'll have a look.

ex.xv: Nan.
ex.xe: I'm looking at you.

ex.xv: Nang.
ex.xe: He saw it./I saw you.

ex.xv: Minj nganayinj.
ex.xe: I didn't see her.

ex.xv: Nangahnang.
ex.xe: I saw you (I was watching you).

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to balang in the eastern system.

ex.xv: Nanikud ngarrikarrmi and bawurl ngarrikarrmi nawern.
ex.xe: We had goats, and lots of chickens too.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yoh, nanikud nawern, kabbal di kunukka… birrinahnani kohbakohbanj.
ex.xe: Yes, there were lots of goats. They used to be out on the plains and the old people used to look after them.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Snake (generic), although some suggest the name is species specific for non-venemous pythons. Venomous snakes can be referred to as mayhbang.

ex.xv: Bu bininj dja daluk kabirrire djarre wanjh kalukburrk kabirriyawoyhnarren bu kabirrimdurndeng kore kunred bedberre.
ex.xe: If men or women go far away, they see each other again when they return to their country.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kabenenarren.
ex.xe: Those two are 'seeing each other' (boyfriend/girlfriend).

sn.de: A man and woman 'interested' in each other, in a non-marital/extra-marital relationship, be boyfriend-girlfriend.
Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku
Name of mythological character of Kamarrang subsection, in-law of Ngurdyawok from well known Mayali myth.
Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to kodjok in the eastern system.

ex.xv: Nawu njale?
ex.xe: What's that?, About what?

ex.xv: Yibengkan kunred nawu karriwam karrinang kinga?
ex.xe: Do you know that place where we saw the crocodile?

ex.xv: Nawu korroko birringeybom dabborrabbolk.
ex.xe: It was the ancestors who called them in this way.

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalbadjan bimarneyimeng nayaw ngalengarre 'Yuwn nakka yikilekme wardi kabakme'.
ex.xe: The mother told her son 'Don't touch that or you'll break it'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karndayh bimarnemarrkwarreminj nuye nayaw. 'Baleh wam, nuk kukbengwabom.'
ex.xe: Karndayh [the female Antilopine kangaroo] was worried about her son. ‘Where has he gone, he’s just wandered off’.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 132

sn.de: Son of matriline, i.e. the male child of a woman, or the male child of a man’s sister.

ex.xv: Nayawurrinj nakka namakkaykken duninjh.
ex.xe: That boy is really handsome.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nayawurrinjni nawu kukmakkaykenhni delek manmakni.
ex.xe: He was a really handsome young man (literally 'he was like white ochre', i.e. smooth, shining etc).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu nawaran nakka nayin nawu nungan kadjalyo kore kuwardde.
ex.xe: The Oenpelli Python is a snake which lives in escarpment country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Snake (generic). Venomous snakes specifically can be referred to as mayhbang.

ex.xv: Kunred ngabolknahnan djang ngarduk nawu kurrmerrinj bakurrmerrinj nayuhyungki dabborrabbolk.
ex.xe: I am looking after this place, my dreaming which was placed here by the first [creator] ancestors. (Kundjeyhmi)

sn.de: Ancestors, the first people, the creator beings.

ex.xv: "Ngabba ngaye ngadjare kanwernhbukkan."
ex.xe: "Dad, I want you to teach me properly."
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 34’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

sn.de: Father, dad. This is the vocative term, used when addressing one's father.

ex.xv: Ngardduk ngabbard ngeyyoy Kurlamarrmarr.
ex.xe: My father's name was Kurlamarrmarr.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

se.de: Call someone by the kin term 'father'.

ex.xv: Duruk bokenh benemdolkkang benemwam koyek benehboyawani kukku wanjh benebongalkeng kukku benebonguneng benebolkngeykurrmeng Duruk Benengadbom kabolkngeyyo.
ex.xe: The two Dogs [Adjumarllarl and Omwarl] came over this way, travelling eastwards, looking for water. They found some water and drank it, and they named the place Duruk Benengadbom [which means “two dogs dug a well”].
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Dig a well, dig a hole to find underground water.

ex.xv: Nungka wanjh ngadduhkeng ngadberre.
ex.xe: He started trying to pick a fight with us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngad ngarrihni kore kudjurle ngarrihnguni mayh wanjh nakudji bininj kumwam ngadduhkeng ngadberre bu nganduy rowk.
ex.xe: We were just sitting in the shade eating some meat, when a man came up to us and started swearing at us and making trouble.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yuwn yire yimarnengadduhke nabuyika bininj.
ex.xe: Don’t you go start a fight with another man.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Make trouble, start a fight, pick a fight.

re: first cousin once removed (mother's brother's son's son)
sn.de: Uncle (mother's brother, MB), mother's brother's son's son (MBSS), mother's father's father (MFF).

ex.xv: Ngarrulkngadjeng.
ex.xe: I'm going to hit the wood.

ex.xv: Ngangadjihbun munguyh, kunubewu kebdjirned nganhmang.
ex.xe: I keep sneezing, maybe I'm getting a cold.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngangadjihbun, kunubewu ngandiyolyolme.
ex.xe: I'm sneezing, maybe people are talking about me.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu ngayi ngakilekme djang wanjh kamre, bu ngawarrewon djang, kamre karndakidj, kariddung kanngakke kadberre.
ex.xe: The water has covered the whole area.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Drown, cover with water, inundate, sink.

re: inundated, be washed away by force of water

ex.xv: Wanjh bomarnbom manbu kukku bokimukminj bobarlmeng wanjh nawu daluk bokenh benekebngakmeng.
ex.xe: [The Rainbow Serpent] made that water rise up and the two women drowned.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Be washed away by the force of water, be inundated.

ex.xv: Ngakngak nakka mayhmayh yerrih kabenekukrohrok wordword beneburlerri dja benemudbele.
ex.xe: The pied butcherbird is a bird which looks a bit like the magpie lark, both of them have black and white feathers.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Formula used to pardon oneself, for example after mentioning the tabooed name of a dead person. (Lit. ‘I’m bad bodied’). Sorry, I apologise, “I’m an idiot”, “I mucked up”.

ex.xv: Kunkare wurdyaw djorlkmeng, dja ngalbadjan kornkumo beneni kured, dja nungan wam.
ex.xe: One day a long time ago, a child ran away. His mother and father were at home, and he set off alone.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly W, ‘Kunkare Wurdyaw Djorlkmeng’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1975

ex.xv: Nakornkumo kakan wurdyaw nuye ngalbadjan larrk kare yaw larrk.
ex.xe: The father [emu] takes the chicks, not the mother, she goes off by herself without the chicks.

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to kamanj in the eastern system.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi = kamanj, Kundjeyhmi = albangardi

sn.de: Mermaid, 'having a tail like a fish', synonym for ngalkunburriyaymi, ‘mermaid’.

ex.xv: Nawu nakornkumo nuye ngalbeywurd wanjh kabenemarren nawu bininj biberrebbom. Wanjh nawu bininj kayime "Ngudda kornkumo kanwong ngalbeywurd ke. Dja wanjh djalmarnedurrkmirri mak nahnan munguyh."
ex.xe: The father's daughter married the man he promised her to. So the man said "You gave me your daughter, so I will work for you and look after you".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Daughter, referent term only, used by a man (or a man’s sisters to refer to their brothers’ daughter).

ex.xv: Warradjangkal nuye ngalbininjkobeng merlbbe.
ex.xe: The mate of the male agile wallaby, warradjangkal, is known as merlbbe.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Woman with a physical disability, crippled woman.

ex.xv: Bonj, lobmeng, kundulk bakkeng ngalbu ngalmangiyi, dja ngalu ngarrbek lobmeng kunwardde mey wanjh benehburreni.
ex.xe: And that was it, that Long-necked Turtle ran and broke a stick off a tree, and the Echidna ran and got a rock, and they were fighting.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Ngalmangiyi Ngarrbek Bimarneyawnguneng Korroko’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to kalidjan in the eastern system.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi = kalidjan, Kundjeyhmi = albulanj

ex.xv: Ngale karndayh, ngaldaluk.
ex.xe: That's a female Antilopine kangaroo.

ex.xv: Ngaldaluk narangem benewam kulabbarl. Ngaldaluk mangi barrdjungka, dja narangem djenj danjbuni.
ex.xe: A woman and a man went to the billabong. The woman was gathering water lilies, and the man was spearing fish.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974.

ex.xv: Ngaldahdaluk.
ex.xe: Women.

ex.xv: Ngaldjadmudni.
ex.xe: She was single.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngudda yingale yingeyyo?
ex.xe: What is your name?

ex.xv: Manngale ngurrimwam?
ex.xe: Which truck did you come in?

ex.xv: Kunngale birrulubom?
ex.xe: Which (part of his/her body) did it pierce?

ex.xv: Nangale named.
ex.xe: What's his name (I can't think of it).

ex.xv: Manih manngale.
ex.xe: What is this plant called?

ex.xv: Wanjh nawu kinga kumhdjalwam darnkih kore ngalmekbe daluk kore ningihni.
ex.xe: Then the crococile just came right up to where that woman was sitting.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Kabirrire kabirribekkan kangokme duruk bu kangalke, ngalekke ngarrbek.
ex.xe: They walk along and hear the dog bark when it finds one, that echidna. [The echidna is thought of as female, with a skin name of Ngalkangila.]
ex.so: Narndal, Julie et. al. ‘Manme: Stories about food - Kunwinjku’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: Ngaleng benyawmey birriwern birrikukbubuyika bininj dja mayh.
ex.xe: She [Yingarna] gave birth to lots of different people and animals.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Merlbbe daluk ngalkka nabininjkobeng ngalengarre warradjangkal.
ex.xe: Merlbbe is a female agile wallaby, and her mate is the male agile wallaby, warradjangkal.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Warradjan ngalkka ngalengman kadjalyo kare kore kubowinjku kukku minj kare kore kurrula.
ex.xe: The pig-nosed turtle only lives in the fresh water, she doesn’t go into the ocean.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Wanjh beneyerrkang ngalengman kondabeh dja ngalengman kuribeh benehbirrkani.
ex.xe: They sat down, and one of the women poked her hand in (to the log) from one end, and the other from the other end.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Herself. Used to talk about feminine nouns a way that singles them out, highlights their particular attributes, possessions or way of acting or thinking, or is reflexive. “By herself”, “she only”, “one of the women”, “as for her”, “her business”, “her property”, “her turn”, “her nature is to” etc.

ex.xv: Ngahli wam. Ngaye burrkyak.
ex.xe: She went. I didn’t.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Djirrihdiddid kakukyime yiman kaldurrk dja ngahli ngalkukyahwurd.
ex.xe: The kingfisher looks like a blue-winged kookaburra, but it has a smaller body.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: She, her. Can also be translated as ‘it’ in the case of feminine-class nouns.
Female subsection name or ‘skin’ name of yirridjdja moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to bangardidjan in the eastern system.
Female subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to bulanjdjan in the eastern system.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi = bulanjdjan, Kundjeyhmi = alkangila

ex.xv: Yabok, yabok manih ngangalkeng mankung kure mikambe.
ex.xe: Sister, sister I've found some honey here in an ant bed.

ex.xv: Djudju nganmarnengalkeng.
ex.xe: I've got a toothache.

ex.xv: Ngalih ngalkinjbarlen nuye.
ex.xe: She is his/her mother's mother.

ex.xv: Kanwo, ngaye ngalkinjbarlen.
ex.xe: Give me [some], I am [your] mother's mother.

sn.de: Mother's mother, non-vocative form of kakkak. One's matrilineal parallel grandkin.
Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to wamuddjan in the eastern system.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi = wamuddjan, Kundjeyhmi = alkodjok

ng: There is great variation in the plural forms of this noun which dispenses with the noun class prefix. This means the plural form no longer explicitly marks gender (i.e. a group of elderly males, females or mixed gender group).
cf: kobahkobanj, kobokohbanj, kobohkobanj, kobohbanj, kohbahkohbanj, kobakohbanj

ex.xv: Nawu nayawurrinj minj kanan manbu Kunabibi, Yabburlurrwa dja Mardayin, wanjh nakka nakomyak ngarrimarneyime. Yiman karohrok ngalbu ngalyawk bu minj kanan manbu Yabburlurrwa wanjh ngalkka ngalkomyak.
ex.xe: If a boy hasn't seen the Kunabibi, Yabburlurrwa or Mardayin ceremonies, we call him 'nakomyak', and likewise if a girl hasn't seen the Yabburlurrwa ceremony, we call her 'ngalkomyak'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: An uninitiated girl, a girl who has no knowledge of a particular ceremony.
Ancestral mermaid creature, the daughter of the rainbow serpent yingarna. She can be duwa or yirridjdja.
sn.sy: ngalkunburriyaymi is also described as ngalberddjenj or having a tail like a fish.

sn.de: Mother-in-law (real or classificatory), 'cousin', MMBD, MMBSSD. The address term (vocative form) is ngalkurrngh, although a man would rarely directly address his actual mother-in-law.

ex.xv: Barnangarrani daluk bokenh benekoluy kabbal, benehyawani ngalmangiyi.
ex.xe: In the middle of the day, two women went down to the floodplain looking for long-necked turtles.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew ‘Kuhni bu Kunkare Birrihwarlbuni’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Daluk ngalbu ngalmarndeyi.
ex.xe: The woman who is a murderer.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Murderer, can also imply someone who kills people by sorcery.

ex.xv: Bolkkime nawu ngalmeng.
ex.xe: Those (people) born today.

ex.xv: Kaddum beh nakka Daddjurdu nungan djal ngalmeng.
ex.xe: The Daddjurdu ['severed leg'] spirit being originates from up there [upstream].

ex.xv: Kunkarrngbakmeng o kunbidkukudji mandjewk wanjh, ngarrimdurndi ngorengngalmeng, doweni wanjh.
ex.xe: So after four or five years we came back, and he got sick [started to become sick]. In fact he was dying.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yiburrbun, minj yingudjwarremen, yiyime “O ngawunjibmeng nuye! Because yeledj nakka kahre.” … Minj yimarnewunjibngalme.
ex.xe: You know, you can’t just get tired of it and say, “Oh I’ll just give up on [teaching] him. He’s going too slow.”… Don’t start to give up on him.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Begin to, start to, become, get (of an action or condition). Incorporated into other verbs as a suffix.
'The one who did it', eg. the murderer, the right one, person responsible (female).

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh benewam kore manlabbarl benemangi ngalng. Mak kunbuyika kangeyyo marddarr.
ex.xe: Two women went to the billabong to get yabbies, called 'ngalng'. In other dialects yabbies are called 'marddarr'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Duberrk nawu doweni wanjh ngalng birrimarnbuni kunkomkenh nawu morlehmorlenj bu Wubarr yoy wanjh birrikomdukkarreni kore kukom bedberre wanjh birriyiborrkkeyi namekke duberrk ngalng dorrengh.
ex.xe: When snails die and leave their shell behind, women used to make necklaces from the shells and dance with them in the Wubarr Ceremony.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngalkodjok ngalu nganngukkarndadjkeng ngalbu ngalkka […] Ngalng karnubirr, yoh.
ex.xe: Ngalkodjok cut my umbilical cord herself, she did that. […] Yes, [with] the shell of a mussel.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Shell (of animal). This applies to crustacea, turtles, shellfish, snails, etc.

ex.xv: Nahni nawu ngalng mak manmeken ngarridahkendong.
ex.xe: A container is something for putting food into.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunbuyika ngarriyime ngalng nawu ngarrikinjeken manme dja ngarribokinjeken kukku.
ex.xe: We also use the word 'ngalng' for pots and pans, that we use to cook food and boil water.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to belinj in the eastern system.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi = belinj, Kundjeyhmi = alngarridj

ex.xv: Nayuhyungki Nawongberd, mankung ken. Nawongberd na-Wamud na-Ngalngbali.
ex.xe: An ancestor by the name of Nawongberd was associated with honey. Nawongberd was na-Wamud subsection and a Ngalngbali clansman.

sn.de: Name of a yirridjdja moiety Kunwinjku patriclan.
Female subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety. Equivalent to ngarridjdjan in the eastern system.

ex.xv: Namekke ngalwalngurru nakka bedberre djang Djordiken, kadjangdi kaddum Kodwalewale.
ex.xe: The chameleon dragon is a totemic emblem for the Djordi clan and the sacred site for it is upstream in the Kodwalewale estate.
ex.so: Terrah Guymala, http://bininjkunwok.org.au/?s=ngalwalngurru

ur: Kune = walwalngurru, Kuninjku =ngalbangurru, Kundedjnjenghmi = alwalngurru, ngalwalngurru

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and ngarradjku matri-moiety. Equivalent to kodjdjan in the eastern system.

ur: Kuninjku, Kune, Kundedjnjenghmi = kodjdjan, Kundjeyhmi = alwamud

ex.xv: Kunkare ngalbadjan dja ngalyaw benewam djarreh kore kukabo benemangi kedjebe dja ngalmangiyi.
ex.xe: One day a mother and her daughter travelled a long way to the river, they were getting file snakes and long-necked turtles.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine N, ‘Ngalbadjan dja Ngalyaw’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Oenpelli, 1975

sn.de: Daughter of matriline, i.e. the female child of a woman, or the female child of a man’s sister.

ex.xv: Ngalyawk babidbom bakukwarrawarrhkeng andjarduk.
ex.xe: The young woman climbed up and knocked down the bush apple fruit.

ex.xv: Dja ngaleng ngalbu daluk ngalyawk minj djareniwirrinj beneyuwirrinj dja nakohbanjni.
ex.xe: But the young woman didn’t want to sleep with him [Yirrbardbard], he was an old man.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngalyod kumwam kanjdjibeh kurorre benbom birriwern bininj nawu birrihyoy kumekke.
ex.xe: The Rainbow Serpent came up from under the earth and killed all the people who were there.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Rainbow serpent, daughter of the Mother One Rainbow Yingarna. The rainbow serpent is a central figure in traditional Bininj religion. She is the creator of places and is active during the wet season and is asssociated with rain and bodies of water. Rainbow serpents live in deep waterholes and rivers. Marrkidjbu are able to discern their presence and control them.

ng: The feminine prefix reflects the conception of the rainbow serpent as a  generative figure, 'the mother one'.

ex.xv: Ngalwakadj bidjawam Ngalbulanj, yimeng “Baleh ngudda yire”, wanjh Ngalbulanj yimeng “Kuhri ngamed kunred ngare Wulk”.
ex.xe: Ngalwakadj asked Ngalbulanj "Where are you going?", and Ngalbulanj said "I'm going to that place over there, what's it called, Wulk".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Whatsisname, whatshername, what's that place. For men 'nangamed' is used, for women 'ngalngamed', and for places the plain form 'ngamed' is used. For things and animals, 'njamed' is used.

ex.xv: Wanjh nawu nawalawalak yimeng ngarrngamka ngarrkukbuyikahmerrimen kinga dja durrbu ngarrbenkadjung wanjh benekadjuy manbu kubbunj.
ex.xe: Then the younger brother said “Let’s swim and change ourselves into a crocodile and a water goanna, let’s follow them”. So they followed that canoe.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngardbakan nakka kurrulawaken kayo kore kurrula.
ex.xe: Mudshells are found in seaside areas, they live in saltwater environments.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Large mangrove bivalve, also known as mudshell.

ex.xv: Nangale djirdmey manme ngarduk?
ex.xe: Who stole my food?

ex.xv: Duruk birrikomdukkang korroko 'Aboriginal' birrikomdukkang wanjh ngarlirrk ngalbu yimeng 'lerre lerre lerre'.
ex.xe: A long time ago, it was Aboriginal way to tie snail shells around the necks of dogs and they would make a sound jingle, jingle, jingle.

ex.xv: Mak Wurdanke ngarrinameng, nakka ngarribom ngarrikudjihmeng
ex.xe: At Wurdanke we made a fire drive there once and we killed a heap of male and female antilopine kangaroos.  You know Ngarridj? He lives at Kakodbebuldi. He killed so many but not with a gun, but with this (gestures indicating a spear).

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Djal anekke bani-boken kabanih-ni ngal-Wakadj, Ngarridjdjan Ngarridjdjan, Kamarrkawarn.
ex.xe: Just those two living there, ngal-Wakadj (alternatively called) Ngarridjdjan and Ngarridjdjan, at Kamarrkawarn.
ex.so: (Kundedjnjenghmi)

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of yirridjdja patri-moiety and mardku. matri-moiety

ex.xv: Mankole ngarriyime manwern korroko bu dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni manbu kayime bokko madjawarr ngarrkidjba lulumarra.
ex.xe: There are lots of different types of spears that people used to make in the past, for example bokko, madjawarr, ngarrkidjba and lulumarra.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Spear type, with multiple barbs running in a line down one side of the shaft.

re: get lots of food or game

ex.xv: Nawu daluhdaluk birriwam birringarrkmey manme. Wanjh birrimyirrurndi kured.
ex.xe: The women went and got lots of bush foods, then brought them home.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Be successful in obtaining large numbers of hunted game, fish or fruit and vegetable foods.
Us (you sing. and me), ours (for you and me).

ex.xv: Nakohbanj benmarneyimeng yawurrinj "Karrire manih karringarrnghmang".
ex.xe: The old man told the young men "Let's take this path (to get there)".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Anbarrarn yika kabarrarnwarre marrek bale karriyime karringarrnghmang.
ex.xe: Some gorges are no good to walk through, sometimes the gorge comes to a dead end and we can't find a route through it.
ex.so: Kundedjnjenghmi

ex.xv: Ngurriderrehmen ba ngangarrnghmang.
ex.xe: Move aside so I can come through.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Pass through, go through, take a particular path in order to come out somewhere else. E.g. Find a route through stone country with many dissected gorges and narrow passes.

ex.xv: Yikukdjorlokkendanj, minj baleh yingarrnghmang.
ex.xe: You're stuck in that situation now, there's no getting out if it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Get out of a situation, successfully get through a process and attain something etc.

ex.xv: Kabirrimarnengayawkmerren.
ex.xe: One man whispered to another man that they should go hunting. [It's believed that if you talk about going hunting out aloud, the prey will hear and flee].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: I, me. First person singular free standing pronoun.

ex.xv: Ngayeman ngarduk!
ex.xe: That's my own business!

ex.xv: Bu ngarrinan kinhkinh kambebme ngalbu ngalmimkimuk wanjh ngarriburrbun bu kamhngayke.
ex.xe: When we see the Morning Star rise, we know that daybreak is coming.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bangaykeng ngurridolkka!
ex.xe: It's just before dawn, get out of bed!
ex.so: Kundedjnjenghmi

ex.xv: Kabirrikodjngayke.
ex.xe: They stay awake all night until daybreak.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karringayke, njale o dedjdjumbung karridadjdje?
ex.xe: What will we do, stay up till dawn or cut things short (and go to sleep).

sn.de: Stay awake at night, until dawn breaks.

ex.xv: Nani bininj nawu nabang yimankek benbuyi nawu wurdurd, dja nabuyika bininj benngehkeng, bu biduy.
ex.xe: A dangerous man was about to hit the children, but another man saved them by hitting him.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nadjalkudji Jesus nawu kanngehkeng karriwern bininj rowk.
ex.xe: Jesus who saved all of us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karrinang yimarnek doweng ba ngalmak ngehmeng.
ex.xe: We saw her (the buffalo) and thought she was dead but she was still breathing OK.

ex.xv: Wanjh karuy manekke kunngad bonguneng ngehmeng kumekke wanjh wam.
ex.xe: Then he dug those wells, had a drink, rested there a while and went on.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 178

ex.xv: Dorothy nganewam nganehyawani Alex, kunubewu birringerrehmeng muddika.
ex.xe: I went looking for Alex with Dorothy, [we were worried] he might have been flattened by all the cars.

ex.xv: Bu kabirriyime yingerrehme, wanjh yiman kayime yingerrehme nawu njalehnjaleh, yiman dolobbo, kunmadj, wurdyaw bu kahkeyo, dja nawern nawu minj kabirridjare kabirribakke bu kabakme.
ex.xe: When people say "yingerrehme", they're talking about laying something flat, for example bark, or clothes, or putting a child to sleep, or all kinds of things that they don't want to break.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

re: to name, to say someone's name

ex.xv: Ngeywarre nakka yuwn yingeybun, wardi yibengbun.
ex.xe: Don't use that bad name (e.g. your sister's), you might offend him (the brother).

ex.xv: Marrek karringeybun namekke, nadjamun.
ex.xe: We don't say that word/name, it's secret.

sn.de: To name, to say someone or something's name.

ex.xv: Bininj nawu kabirringeydi kore Board of Directors.
ex.xe: People who are on the Board of Directors.
ex.so: Adjumarllarl Aboriginal Corporation community newsletter, 2015

ex.xv: Kunwinjku minj kangeydi kuhri, like ngawam Yirrkala, course kumekke nganewam […] yire kore wall yinan classroom and flashcard kangeydi djal bininj - yoh, bininj kunwok, kanjdji balanda.
ex.xe: There’s no Kunwinjku words on display [in the classroom here]. Now, I went to Yirrkala, we went to a course […] and if you go and look on the walls in the classroom, there are flashcards with Aboriginal language words. They have the Aboriginal language with English underneath.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Name is there [e.g. on a list], be named, be there [of words].

ex.xv: Kangeyhmiyo.
ex.xe: He lies there moaning.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngudda yingale yingeyyo?
ex.xe: What is your name?

ex.xv: Manwern manbu mandem kabebbehngeyyongohyo.
ex.xe: There’s many different types of waterlilies with different names.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra.

ex.xv: Kunred kabolkngeyyo Bobongki, manbowern dja mandjimdjimwern.
ex.xe: The place called Bobongki has a lot of water and water pandanus.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Yimngimen!
ex.xe: Come inside.

ex.xv: Ngurrimngimen karrangrurrk.
ex.xe: Come in, the door's open.

ex.xv: Yimngimiwemen!
ex.xe: Bring it through the hole.

sn.de: Insert through a hole or opening.

ex.xv: Ngalkohbanj bimarneyimeng nawu wurdyaw "Yimray ngimihwe kururrk".
ex.xe: The old woman said to the child "Come here, I'll take you inside".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Bring inside, put inside, take inside (through the door of a building etc).

ex.xv: “Bonj, wanjh, ngudda yikimuk. Ngundingimihwe.” Wanjh ngandingimihweng, la ngandibukkang.
ex.xe: “OK then, you’re a big man now, we’ll admit you.” So they admitted me (into the ceremony), and taught me.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Morlehmorlenj bindikani nawu nanikud kore kabbal birriwohrey birridalknguni. Kaluk bu wolewoleh bindikani bindingimowoni kore yard.
ex.xe: Women used to take the goats onto the floodplain to eat grass. Then in the afternoon they would herd them back into the yards.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Djenj nginjdadjkeng yawoyhbidbom nginjnameng wanjh yawoyhkoluy wanjh mey nawernken djenj.
ex.xe: The fish cut off the hook, so she went up again and put on another hook, went down [to the water] again and caught lots of fish.
ex.so: The example phrase comes from some texts Peter Carroll has deposited with AIATSIS.

ex.xv: Yoh mankole, mankole ngamarnekurrmeng. Minj mankole la barrawu, nginjno nawu.
ex.xe: Yes, it’s a spear that I’ve painted there. Not a spear but the shovel nose blade, the tip.
ex.so: Mick Kubarkku, interview with Margie West and Murray Garde, Yikarrakkal Outstation, 1994

ex.xv: Aa, nahni dulkngirrbom, darnkih dulkdoyi!
ex.xe: Ahh, he scraped that tree, he almost crashed into it! [while driving]
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Rdardah minj darnkih kabingirrbun ngalbu ngaldaluk.
ex.xe: A brother makes sure not to brush against his sister / touch her in passing.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nganabbarru kare kore kundulk dja kangirrburren.
ex.xe: The buffalo goes and scratches itself against a tree.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Scrape or rub against something, brush something, scratch something.

ex.xv: Djarridjno kabirrimang kabirringirringirrihme bimken.
ex.xe: They get charcoal and grind it for painting.

sn.de: Grind one object against another. Eg. the grinding of ochre on a stone palette to produce paint or the rubbing of sandpaper.

ex.xv: Yuwn yinalkbun bu yihngiwkme mungoyh warddi ngalyod ngunbekkan wanjh kanbun.
ex.xe: Don't cry and whinge all the time, otherwise Ngalyod will hear you and come and kill us.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Namarladj ngiwkmihngiwkmiyoy munguyh wanjh ngalyod bibekkang wanjh kumwam bu benbom.
ex.xe: The orphan boy lay there crying the whole time, and the Rainbow Serpent heard him and came and killed everyone there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karrire werrk kangokdan.
ex.xe: Let's hurry up and go, it's getting dark.
