ex.xv: Wanjh wernhdungyibmeng balngokdanj nawu namorrorddo binang nawu wurdyaw kahre wanjh kumkoluy kaddumbeh biyawdjirdmey bikang kore kunred kuwardderurrk nuye.
ex.xe: Then the sun went all the way down and it got dark, and the Namorrorddo spirit saw the child walking along, came down from above and stole him and took him back to his cave.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Owl. The name ngokngok is used as the generic term for all owl type birds, including frogmouths. However, in some contexts it is used to refer to all Ninox spp. and contrasts with other terms such as kuluyhkuluy, 'tawny frogmouth' and yerinj, 'barn owl'. In Kunwinjku this generic name is now also used for the southern boobook which was formerly known more specifically as korddol.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngaborrkkeng Mangkuldalkudj, dja minj kunkuyeng, ngangolekwarreminj.
ex.xe: I danced at Croker Island, but not for long, I got puffed out.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 138

sn.de: Get puffed out, get out of breath, have an asthma attack.

ex.xv: Birrimangi wirlmurr nawu balandakenh wanjh birridongi birribalabalawoni birrimirrhbuni … Birrimangi mankole birrinami birridukkani kunyal dja ngolin birribelbmi birrimarnbuni kunyidken birriyamerreni yika birriwarlbuni mayh.
ex.xe: They would take some metal, a non-Indigenous material, and strike it to flatten it and sharpen it… Then they would get bamboo and tie it on and stick it with beeswax, to make a spear for revenge or hunting.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bidngoreng.
ex.xe: Deformed finger (this is actually somebody's nickname).

ex.xv: Bu kunkare duninjh dabborrabbolk bu kunyid birridurreni… bindiyami birringorengrey yika djal bulkkidj birridoweni.
ex.xe: A long time ago the old people would fight when they got angry… they would spear each other, and go around injured or even actually die.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kunkarrngbakmeng or kunbidkukudji mandjewk wanjh, ngarrimdurndi ngorengngalmeng, doweni wanjh.
ex.xe: So after four or five years we came back, and he got sick. In fact he was dying.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yingorrka!
ex.xe: Put it over your shoulder!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yimngorrmang.
ex.xe: Carry it here (up on shoulders).

sn.de: Pick something up and put it on your shoulders or head to carry it.

ex.xv: Aa ngalkka ngorrmey!
ex.xe: Oh, she got some! (turtles etc).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalkudji daluk wam kabbal yawani ngalmangeyi, wanjh ngaleng ngorrmey nawern nawu ngalmangeyi. Ngalbuyika daluk ngalengman wanjh ngorrmey kurrmeng kore kukodj ngalengarre. Wanjh ngorrkani.
ex.xe: One woman went to the floodplain looking for long-necked turtles, and got lots of them. Another woman picked them up, put them on her head and carried them like that.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birringudjbang kunj nawarddeken, minj bale kayime bu dalkken kabenngudjkadjung kuwardde, kayakki, kabirringudjbawon kunj.
ex.xe: The rock country kangaroos are very fast moving and a dingo would not be able to chase them into the rocks, no, the kangaroos would leave it behind.

ex.xv: Djamun bidjorrhmayinj la lobmeng bingudjbawong.
ex.xe: The policeman tried to grab him but he ran away and escaped from him.

ex.xv: Birringudjbang kunj nawarddeken, minj bale kayime bu dalkken kabenngudjkadjung kuwardde, kayakki, kabirringudjbawon kunj.
ex.xe: Rock kangaroos are fast, if a dingo tries to chase them into the escarpment it's hopeless, the kangaroo leaves them behind.
ex.so: Quoted in ‘Ecology of Rock Kangaroos in Western Arnhem Land’, Charles Darwin University / Key Centre for Tropical Wildlife Management, 2005

ex.xv: Ngandihbimmangi munguyh, ngangudjwarreminj.
ex.xe: They were always taking pictures of me, I got tired of it.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Kurlbawarreminj ngudjwarreminj wanjh.
ex.xe: (S)he became anaemic and then got weak.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Kabaniburren wanjh kabaningudjwarremen, nungan kayerrkan kure ngalbininjkobeng, nungan kayerrkan kubuyika kuni kani. Marrek kabimarnekan kayakki.
ex.xe: The two [male black wallaroos] fight each other until they get exhausted and then one will go and sit down near the female mate and
ex.so: (Kundedjnjenghmi)

sn.de: Get tired out, become weak from lack of energy, illness or old age.

ex.xv: Kuwid, ngalkordo kure Kubumi kangukdeng kubolkkordwern kabolkwarrewon.
ex.xe: No, that’s wrong, it’s brolga from Kubumi which shits all over the place and makes a mess [sending up someone with skinny legs and shoes on who is thought to look like a brolga].
ex.so: Quoted in Garde, Murray, ‘Culture, Interaction and Person Reference in an Australian Language’, John Benjamins Publishing Company,  Amsterdam, 2013

ex.xv: Dja nawu wirlarrk nakka ngukdengi kore karrkad wadjbud.
ex.xe: And it [the sea turtle] would lay its eggs high on the beach.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Delek ngukmak.
ex.xe: Bright white ochre.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunrodjbe ngukmak.
ex.xe: Bright red ochre.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kuhni dirdngukmak dja karrire ngarrbek karriyawan.
ex.xe: There's a bright moon, let's go hunting echidnas.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nahni dolek ngukmak. Dja karridjedme ba karribebke.
ex.xe: That's a nice fresh white wood grub. Let's chop around it so we can pull it out.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

re: camp overnight or for few days

ex.xv: Karrire karridjarrkyo ngulken balbbara.
ex.xe: Let's all go and stay there together for a couple of days.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birribuyika bininj birrirey birringuni djenj namekke ngulken.
ex.xe: Other people would go and eat fish there, camping for a day or two.

sn.de: Camping overnight or for a few nights in order to gather or hunt a particular resource.

ex.xv: Minj nganguyi.
ex.xe: I didn't eat it.

ex.xv: Mako kondabeh ngad ngarrikarrme, minj bedberre walembeh,
ex.xe: The didjeridu is ours, from here and it does not belong to Aboriginal people from the south or non-Aboriginal people who have seen us and tried to copy us.
ex.so: Tom Djelkwarrngi Wood, quoted in Murray Garde, Peter Danaja and Tom Djelkwarrngi Wood, ‘Birribengwarreminj mako-ken - That Didjeridu Has Sent them Mad’, in I. Chance (ed.), Kaltja now : Indigenous arts Australia, Kent Town SA, Wakefield Press, 2000

ex.xv: Benbom bendjalngurdkeng bonj.
ex.xe: It killed them, silenced them, finished!

ex.xv: Mahni manbu mankarre skulken kamarnbuyindan ba bu yimunkewe kare skul. Bu ngudda minj yire kore ngurriwokdi dja mak minj yikadjung mankarre wanjh kabirringurdke nawu kunwardde wurdurdken.
ex.xe: The plan will include actions that you and your child’s school can take to help make sure your child goes to school every day. If you don’t go to this conference or follow the actions in your school attendance plan, your income support payments may be stopped.

ex.xv: Yingurdmen!
ex.xe: Shut up!

ex.xv: Kodjngurdmeng.
ex.xe: He was silent in thought.

ex.xv: Ngamarneyimeng ningihni kodjngurdmeng, njale bengkahbengkang, njale
ex.xe: I told her and she just sat there silently, what was she thinking, what was she thinking? (Words of a wurrurrumi song).

ex.xv: Karribekkan kangurdulme kamayhke wanjh karrinan nawu mandjewk kahdjakdung.
ex.xe: We hear the thunder, there is lightning, and we see the rain falling.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manlerrlerr kanguybun wanjh ngurrurdu kahngun.
ex.xe: The holly-leaved pea plant flowers and then the emus come and eat them.

ex.xv: Bu mandudjmi kanguybun wanjh bod kawernmerren kore kurralk.
ex.xe: When the green plums flower, there starts being lots of flies in the bush.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Manwern manbu mannguy bu kanguybun wanjh nganbengdayhke ngadberre bu kamulewan yiman kayime mayh, kukku, mandjewk, wirlarrk, mankung dja manme.
ex.xe: There are lots of flowers that when they bloom, they inform us about certain animals [being ready to hunt], about tides or rain, or eggs, honey or bush foods [being ready to collect].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Manmeyakni.
ex.xe: He/she didn't have any food.

ex.xv: Bu ngayahwurdni.
ex.xe: When I was small (a child).

ex.xv: Tuesdayni birrimwam.
ex.xe: They came on Tuesday.

sn.de: Suffix which indicates a state in the past, attached to adjectives and nouns.

ex.xv: Djahdjalni ningihni, binang kamre wanjh bimarneyimeng, "Njale ngudda kunu kanmolkbawong?"
ex.xe: She just stayed sitting there, and when she heard him coming back she said “Why did you just sneak off (without saying anything)?”
ex.so: Gumurdul, Julie, ‘Mamamh dja kakkak benewam djenj’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Ngaye ngahni Mamardawerre kaluk ngarrurrkmirri kunngobarn bu ngamarnbun.
ex.xe: I live at Mamardawerre and I work making things out of pandanus.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra, quoted in Hamby, Louise (ed.), Twined Together: Kunmadj Njalehnjaleken, Injalak Arts and Crafts, Gunbalanya, 2005, p. xiii

ex.xv: Minj ngarrbenkarrme dabborrabbolk, birridowerrinj nawu, only yikayikah kabirrini kondah dabborrabbolk nawu.
ex.xe: All the old people (who know the old ways) are gone, they're died. There are only are few of them left here.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ankorakkora nin kangun.
ex.xe: The double-barred finch eats (the seeds of) ankorakkora fi:(Solemostemon_scutellarioides)
ex.so: Nadjamerrek, Lofty Bardayal, Russel, Jeremy & Garde, Murray, ‘A Preliminary List of Kundedjnjenghmi Plant Names’, NLC, Kabulwarnamyo, 2003

ex.xv: Ningihni bu madbumadbuni, wanjh wilkdi nawu kunj.
ex.xe: He sat there waiting and cooking the kangaroo.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 12-15

sn.de: Sit for some time, sit for a long time.

ex.xv: Ningihni kumekke kured nuye. Kumekke nguneng djenj, dja njilngmakminj.
ex.xe: He stayed there at his home for some time. He ate the fish, and cheered up.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, 'Marrurda' story.

sn.de: Said when giving someone something. “Here you are”, “here you go” etc.

ex.xv: Yinjabkemen!
ex.xe: Put on lots! [Of peanut butter, jam etc onto the toast]
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakudji bininj bimarneyimeng nawu wurdyaw "Yimray ba delek barung bu njabke kore kukeb dja kuburrk ke".
ex.xe: One man said to the child "Come here so I can paint you up with white ochre, I'm going to splatter it onto your face and body".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bikebnjebkeng.
ex.xe: He plopped it onto his face.

sn.de: Plop, squirt or dollop a viscous or wet substance onto a surface, paint on thickly.

ex.xv: Birriwern kabirrinjaknjakme kumekke kururrk.
ex.xe: There's a big crowd of people chattering away in there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu njale?
ex.xe: What's up? What's that you're talking about?

ex.xv: Nuk njale.
ex.xe: I don’t know what / I don’t know why.

ex.xv: Wanjh birribarungi nawu dolobbo birribimbuni njale.
ex.xe: Then they would coat the bark with ochre and paint something on it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Minj kabirriburrbun njale.
ex.xe: They don’t know anything.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Wanjh bedman bindiwoni manme kandidjdjawa sugar tea bakki dja njalehnjale nawu bininj birridjareni.
ex.xe: And they would give them food, flour, sugar, tea, tobacco and all the things they wanted.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kunmalaworr count kabirriyime, nawu kayongoyo… minj ngad kabirrikarrmekarrme… blocks, njalehnjale.
ex.xe: They use leaves to [learn and teach how to] count because they’re lying around, our people don’t have all the things like blocks or whatever.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Whatever, this and that, all the things, things like that.

ex.xv: Ngalngarridj kumwam nganmarneyimeng,“Ngudda yidjare Batchelor yire?” Ngayimeng, “Njalekenh?”
ex.xe: Ngalngarridj came and asked me “Do you want to go to Batchelor?” I said “Why?”.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Minj nangale kare darnkih kore nungkah njalekenh wardi nadjardawo kamarnbun.
ex.xe: No-one goes close to him [Nadjurrk’s Dreaming site] for any reason, otherwise it will cause a whirlwind.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: For some reason, for any reason.

ex.xv: Ngalkangila yimeng “Ngalwamud, kab kanwo njamed nakka nawu, djenj”.
ex.xe: Ngalkangila said "Hey Ngalwamud, give me that thing - the fish".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Thing, whatchamacallit, um (when you can't remember the name). For people 'nangamed',

ex.xv: Njarlkan karri kore mankabo dja manwanjdjad. Karrire kore mankabo karrinan njarlkan kare wanjh karridanjbun djalakkiradj karrikan karrikinje kore kuwilk kuyirrke kore kunak.
ex.xe: Archerfish live in rivers and creeks. If we go to the river and see an archerfish we spear it with a fish spear, then take it and cook it in the hot coals of the fire.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Common archerfish and primitive archerfish. Associated with the yirridjdja moiety.

ur: Kuninjku = djoloborn, Kune = djamard (Kune Narayek), Kune = djedberdeh (Kune Nakerlk)

ex.xv: Kabodowerren rowk manbu kukku kukudji kukku karribongun kore manlabbarlkimuk dja kore njilhmi kaboyo kore ngarribobengkan korroko dabborrabbolk ngandibolkbukkang.
ex.xe: [In the dry season] all the water dries up, we can only drink water from large billabongs and springs, places we know to find water that the old people showed us in the past.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kabinjirrke.
ex.xe: She hates her, she doesn't want to talk to her.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmira

sn.de: Hate someone, avoid talking to someone out of hatred.

ex.xv: Nakudji kodjeyoy, bekkang duruk njokmeng.
ex.xe: A man slept and heard a dog barking.

ex.xv: Kannjokme djurn, ngalmak.
ex.xe: The Black-headed Python barks at us, it's non-venomous (lit:'good').

ex.xv: Kabirrire kabirribekkan kangokme duruk bu kangalke, ngalekke ngarrbek.
ex.xe: They walk along and hear the dog bark when it finds an echidna.
ex.so: Narndal, Julie et. al. ‘Manme: Stories about food - Kunwinjku’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: "Kanjok njale nakka?" "Nakka duruk." "Njanjanj kukmakmak."
ex.xe: “Kanjok what’s that?” “It’s a dog.” “Cute! It’s beautiful”.
ex.so: ‘Lesson 10’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

sn.de: ‘How cute', said to young babies, animals etc.

ex.xv: Djurrubuk manbu manyawwarddeyahwurd, manbu korroko dabborrabbolk birridongi manme, dja mak mayh birrimurrngdongi, bu birrimurrngnjonjmi.
ex.xe: 'Djurrubuk' is what we call the small rocks that our ancestors used to use for pounding food, or also pounding and grinding bones into a mash (so they can be eaten).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Make into a mash, ground to a pulp.

ex.xv: Kabirrihdong, kabirrinjonjwon wanjh kabirrikurrme kore "pannikin"
ex.xe: They pound it, mash it up and they put it into a pot.

ex.xv: Birrirawoni kunkanj dja kunmurrng, birridongi wanjh birrinjonjwoni ba bu birringuni kamak rowk.
ex.xe: They would mix the meat and the bones together, pound them and mash them so they could eat it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Make into a mash, ground to a pulp.

ex.xv: Nawu Nakangila wam bu warlbom wanjh kang nuye duruk bu kebburddjimak kanome kunj, kalawan dja nganabbarru.
ex.xe: Nakangila went hunting and took his dog, which has a keen sense of smell and can smell the presence of kangaroos, goannas and buffalo.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

se.de: Sniff a liquid, most commonly petrol.

sn.de: Wasp that preys on native honey bees. Culturally significant to members of the Mok clan. The wasp is said to lead humans to honey hives which after being broken open can also be accessed by the wasp. The totemic focus for this species is a Syzygium suborbiculare tree at Kabulwarnamyo outstation in the Liverpool River region. An increase ritual involves striking the trunk of the tree with an axe which is said to increase both the wasps and the honey hives they will lead humans to.

ex.xv: Marram kangun djenj dja mayh nawu nud dja nawu namak kamang kore kukku nawu kadowen dja nawu darrkid kare.
ex.xe: The whistling kite eats fish and animals that are decaying, and also healthy animals. It gets dead fish from the water, but also catches live ones as they swim around.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawu yolk nakka kayo kore manme mannud dja kore mayh nawu karrowen.
ex.xe: Maggots are found in rotten food and dead animals.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kab ngare ngakinje ngarrku. Wardi kanudmen.
ex.xe: How about I go ahead and cook this for us both, before it goes rotten?
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 64-67

ex.xv: A: "Nakka nawu kakan kunkanj." B: "Baleh nuk kakan?" A: "Nuk".
ex.xe: A: "He's carrying some meat". B: "I wonder where he's taking it?". A: "No idea".
ex.so: Narndal, Julie, Djurra 'na' 'wa', Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birringuni nawu nawaran djaying nuk ngawakwan dja bolkkime larrk.
ex.xe: Maybe people (our ancestors) used to eat the Oenpelli python in the past, I don't really know, but these days we don't.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts

sn.de: Maybe, who knows (the speaker is not sure or doesn't know).

ex.xv: Karakalkre.
ex.xe: He travels around doing sorcery.

ex.xv: Korroko ngarriyimi oh rakul somewhere kare karrinan kare kawakewake. Ngurrurdu but rakul ngahdjalyimihyimi.
ex.xe: Long ago we used to say there's a partridge pigeon somewhere there wandering around. It was actually an emu but we would refer to it as 'partridge pigeon'.

sn.de: Cross hatching style of painting on bark or body decoration for Mardayin ceremony.
Combine, make two, put together, make an addition, mix.

ex.xv: Karriraworren karriwern karrire.
ex.xe: Lets make ourselves a big group and lots of us go.

ex.xv: Bonj, kamak, kabolhrayek, yidjalay.
ex.xe: It's OK just keep driving, the ground is hard.

ex.xv: Wanjh kunu kabindibukkan mayh, kore kabirrinan kunrayek duninjh.
ex.xe: They are taught at ceremonies, and they see how hard it is.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Karrikarremenmenyime. Bu karohrok karayek yiman, yiman kayime
ex.xe: We understand the meaning of that law. It’s strict, just the same as the white people’s law.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

se.de: 'Hard', a common way to distinguish a dialect, the opposite being kunkerlk (the 'soft variety').

ex.xv: Kabbay birribelbmi rey bukmeni rayekmeni.
ex.xe: They would stick ironwood resin on [the top of the spearthrower to attach the spur], and it would dry and harden.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bininj nakudji kumdolkang kumwam rerrkang wanjh bonabonani, bonabonani kumekbe wanjh kunwarde yimerranj kunwarde yimerranj wanjh kahni rayekminj.
ex.xe: A man came up and sat down. He just sat there looking at the water, and he turned to stone. He turned to stone and he’s [still] there.
ex.so: The example phrase comes from some texts Peter Carroll has deposited with AIATSIS.

sn.de: Become hard, solid or tight, solidify. Turn to stone or other hard object. This is often used to describe Ancestors who became rocks or other aspects of the landscape in the Dreamtime.

ex.xv: Wanjh benedjalwam la benekukrayekminj benkukrayekwong djang.
ex.xe: The two (sisters) went on and turned to stone, he (Nimbuwa) turned them both to stone at that sacred site.
ex.so: Mick Kubarkku, recorded at Kubumi by Peter Cooke and Rory McGuinness, August 1991.

sn.de: Harden, tighten or strengthen something, turn to stone.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birriwokdi birrikarremarnbuni wanjh karremakni bu birriwokmarnburreni.
The old people would get together and make decisions, and they would come to an agreement about what should be permitted. They fixed their decision, and no one would break the laws they made.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Affirm or formalise a decision or law, say something firmly and with authority.

ex.xv: Baleh wam rdardah ngunehrangem?
ex.xe: Where's your little brother (parent to child)?

ex.xv: Baleh wam ngalu rdardah ngaldaluk?
ex.xe: Where'd your little sister go? (parent to child)

sn.de: Younger brother of a man, younger sister of a woman; can be used as referential or vocative.

ex.xv: Karrire ngamarrwe dowen.
ex.xe: Let's go, I'm hungry.

ex.xv: Birriwam.
ex.xe: They're gone.

ex.xv: Yimarnek kamrayi la kurrinj.
ex.xe: He was supposed to come, maybe he was lying.

ex.xv: Arrkuluk ngahre.
ex.xe: I’m barracking for the Arrkuluk team.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Support, go for, barrack for (a sporting team etc).

ex.xv: Wanjh manimunak karralkdadjdadjke karedmarnbun red ngalengarre wirlarrk kawirlarrkngukdeng.
ex.xe: Then the magpie goose goes around breaking off rushes and makes a nest for herself, and lays eggs.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bininj nakudji nawu ngaye nganeredbo.
ex.xe: A countryman of mine.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 94

sn.de: Countryman, someone from the same country as you. Requires a pronoun prefix.
The traditional owner or person responsible for a place or tract of land. Requires a pronoun prefix such as birriredweleng, 'the traditional owners’, naredweleng ‘male traditional owner’.

ex.xv: Ngalkka djal Rembarrnga wurrbbarn.
ex.xe: She [the emu] is called wurrbbarn in Rembarrnga language.
ex.so: Peter Biliss

sn.de: Language name, spoken to the east and south-east of Bininj Kunwok territory.

ex.xv: Kabenekebrohrok.
ex.xe: Those two have the same face.

sn.de: Try something out, attempt, have a go at something, test something.

ex.xv: Nawu scientist kabirrirohrokme ba bu kabirrinan manbu manwern radiation ngarre minj kabebme kore kabirrikarungbeh.
ex.xe: The scientists check to make sure there is not too much radiation from the Ranger mine.

sn.de: Investigate something in order to try and understand something.

ex.xv: Kanrohrokmeng.
ex.xe: He gathered us into a group.

ex.xv: Kamak bu yiberlrokan dja mak yidadrokan?
ex.xe: Can you move both legs and arms?
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Minj karokan.
ex.xe: He/she is unconscious [not moving].
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Benebolkdulubom benedjudmeng, benenang kunbak kahrokan, benekeleminj, benekayhmeng benewawmeng, "Wiw, wiw, njale, njale naka?”
ex.xe: They poked and prodded the ground (with their turtling sticks), then they saw the water weeds moving and got scared, they called out in fright “Ahh! What’s that?”.
ex.so: Mangiru, Hannah, ‘Kuhni Kayolyolme Bu Kabirriwarlbunkenh’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1974

sn.de: Move, wobble, shake, move a body part. By extension this can imply being conscious or awake, as opposed to unconscious or asleep.

ex.xv: Bu kabirrirurrkname kunkodbarre wanjh kunmayorrk mankimuk kamre karokayhwon manbu kururrk kamarnbun karokan.
ex.xe: When people make a bark shelter, a big wind can come along and shake it, making it move.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Make something shake, make something move, shake something.

ex.xv: Kamak rowk.
ex.xe: Everything is OK.

ex.xv: Yawkyawk benroyhmeng.
ex.xe: He was spying on the girls.

ex.xv: "Ngok-ngok-ngok." yimeng nawu duruk […] Wanjh yikang kore ngokmihngokmi, wam marnebebmeng wanjh royhmeng nang kahyo.
ex.xe: “Woof woof woof!” barked the dog […]  So he went up to where it was barking, and when he got there spied one there [an echidna].
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Kunkare Nawamud Duruk Kebkang’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1975

sn.de: Spy on someone, peek, spy (see something partially obscured or from a difficult vantage point).

ex.xv: Ngadengerung.
ex.xe: My feet are hot.

ex.xv: Karung karri.
ex.xe: It's hot (refers to an object eg. mug of hot tea).

ex.xv: Manme karung.
ex.xe: The food is cooking

ex.xv: Manwirdu karung, karrire karringun.
ex.xe: The Carallia brachiata are ripening, lets go and eat them.

ex.xv: Mahni yakirrdjdja kundulk ngarrimang wanjh wabban ngarrimarnbun bu kubba ngarrikurrme wanjh ngarribolkdjudme bu ngarrimang ngalmangeyi dja mak kedjebe.
ex.xe: We get wood from the milkwood tree and make handles from it to attach to metal sticks, and we poke the ground with them when we look for long-necked turtles and file snakes.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Handle. Refers to any handle, e.g. handle of a stone axe, knife, turtling stick, frying pan etc.

ex.xv: Wabmeng bewh kaddum Kamarrkawan.
ex.xe: She moved up to Kamarrkawan.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Bonj, djalwohdjalwam ngadjaldurrkmirranj manekke, wanjh ngayawoyhwabmeng school.
ex.xe: I went on working there [at that job] for quite a while then moved back to the school.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Shift camp to another place, move house, change location.

ex.xv: Dja kabirridjalwabme, yiman kabirriyulwabme. Kunekke yarrkka, bindibukkani bu mak baleh birriyimi birridedjbuni nawu kunj.
ex.xe: But [even these days] they still have to stalk the animal, I mean they creep up on it. All sorts of things they used to teach them so they would know how to prepare a kangaroo for cooking.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Singing of a 'clever' man, eg. sing up rain, or sing somebody for sorcery.

ex.xv: Bu korroko nawu djabbo bininjni benehni namanjmiken nuye wak.
ex.xe: Long ago the quoll used to be a man, and he lived with his grandfather the crow.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngurriwakbu djakbarl konda kayo wardi kanbaye kadberre, ngurriyime 'wak wak' ba kamak.
ex.xe: You all pass around here, there's wasps here, they might bite us. Call out 'wak wak' so it'll be OK (and they won't harm you).

sn.de: Go or pass around to the side of something.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji yimeng “Karridjowkke." "Yun." birriyimeng, "marndi karringakme dja karriwakbun ngokko dungyibmeng."
ex.xe: One woman said “Let’s cross over”. “No”, said the others, “We’ll drown, let’s turn back, the sun is already down”.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Reader 36’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1981

ex.xv: Bolkkime kabirriwakbun kore kunkukbelekenh.
ex.xe: These days they’re turning towards the white (non-Indigenous) way of doing things.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Daluk wam warlbom kore Mangulkan wanjh nang marram kahwakbun kore kukku.
ex.xe: The woman went hunting at Mangulkan and saw a whistling kite circling over the water.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

sn.de: Circle, go around in circles, go around.

ex.xv: Ngakodjwakbun ngakodjborledme.
ex.xe: I'm dizzy, my head is spinning around.

ex.xv: Kunngolwaken
ex.xe: Aeroplane (literally 'in the clouds').

ex.xv: Kunwarddewaken.
ex.xe: In the rocks.

ex.xv: Ngardbakan nakka kurrulawaken kayo kore kurrula.
ex.xe: Mudshells are found in seaside areas, they live in saltwater environments.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: River prawns, also the common Kakadu shrimp, used as a generic term for most river prawns, although Macrobrachium bullatum or marddarr (in Kunwinjku at least) is said to be darker.

ex.xv: Kadjalni kunkudji, but might be kare nungan marrek ngarrbengkan, ngarrwakwan.
ex.xe: He just stays there once, but maybe he goes around of his own accord but you and I don't know. We don't know.

ex.xv: Ken, djurlu ngawakwam.
ex.xe: Oops, I forgot the matches.

sn.de: Triangular framed fishing net, used as a hand scoop net.

ex.xv: A: Ngudda Kundjeyhmi yibengkan yiwokdi? B: Walakkih.
ex.xe: A: Do you know how to speak Kundjeyhmi? B: A little bit.

ex.xv: Kunwernhwalem.
ex.xe: A long way south.

ex.xv: Ngayemanwali.
ex.xe: My turn.

ex.xv: Moses-wali.
ex.xe: Moses' turn.

sn.de: Turn, denotes turn taking, order of participation.

ex.xv: Bindikang walk kure bindimarnerarrkwong.
ex.xe: They took those initiates to the place where they painted cross-hatching designs on them.

sn.de: Rembarrnga and Kuninjku circumcision ceremony. The name is also applied to the boys in ritual seclusion in this ceremony.

ex.xv: Wamba berdkarnkarn.
ex.xe: The wamba shark has a long thin tail.

sn.de: Generic term for three shark species; Bull Shark, Speartooth Shark and Northern River Shark.
sn.sc: Carcharhinus leucas, Glyphis glyphis, Glyphis garricki

ex.xv: Minj dabborrabbolk birriwayiniwirrinj. Ngayi ngawam Manbulukarri, ngabekkang wayarra birriwayini. Ngawam ngadurndi kure Mumeka ngadjawam Wamud nganmarneyimeng nakka kunwok wayarra bedberre.
ex.xe: The old people didn't sing (this song). I went to Manbulu Karri and I heard spirit beings singing. I went there and returned to Mumeka and I asked Wamud and he told me that the song text was in the language of the spirit beings.

sn.de: Male subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Karriwohre karrimadbun kaluk wamuddjan kamre.
ex.xe: Let's wait around until wamuddjan comes.

sn.de: Female subsection or 'skin' name of duwa patri-moiety and mardku matri-moiety.

ex.xv: Kabirridjarridjmarnbun munguyh kabirriwangbolkarren. Marrek kayakmen nayuhyungkih birrikadjurrinj. Bolkki yayawno marrek kabirribengkan wangbol kayo.
ex.xe: When they make trouble they always keep carrying out traditional revenge. It never finishes because they have followed the first ancestors (who instigated this). Today the new generation don't know that traditional revenge obligations still occur.

se.de: Carry out reprisals on each other.

ex.xv: Wanjh benewam beneyerrngmey beneworrhmeng. Wanjh benemadbuni benenjammey nawu ngalmangiyi wanjh bu njamruy wanjh benenguneng.
ex.xe: Then the two of them got some firewood and started a fire. Then they waited a little [for the fire to burn down], took out the innards of the long-necked turtle, and when the innards were cooked they ate them.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine N, ‘Ngalbadjan dja Ngalyaw’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Oenpelli, 1975

ex.xv: “Yibekka wanjh. Mayali manekke yibekka wanjh yimang manekke yiyime.”
ex.xe: “Listen now! Listen to this idea so you can understand it and do it.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yiyi! Yimarnbom wanjh.
ex.xe: That’s right! You’ve got it now.
ex.so: Quoted in Garde, Murray, ‘Culture, Interaction and Person Reference in an Australian Language’, John Benjamins Publishing Company,  Amsterdam, 2013

sn.de: A particle which suggests a logical conclusion or logically sequenced event, e.g. a consequence, suggestion based on some evidence, completion of an activity, etc. Can be translated as “now”, “then” or “so”.

ex.xv: Nawu namumuyak waralyoy kore kunwardderurrk bu nungan deleng waralkurrmerrinj kumekke.
ex.xe: The ancestor's image was there in the cave, where he placed himself as an image.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Place itself [of a spirit or painting], place one's spirit in the form of a painting. Said for example of rock paintings which are thought to have “put themselves in place” as transfigurations of Ancestral spirits, as opposed to those painted by people.

ex.xv: Kabirriwaralnarren kore baddumang.
ex.xe: They look at themselves in the mirror.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu dirdko wanjh kabirriwaralnarren, yiman kayime mak kundung bu koyek dja karrikad bu kadungdi wanjh kabirriwaralnarren.
ex.xe: By moonlight people can see the shadow they cast, just like when the sun is in the west or the east.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Look at one's own image in water or mirror, see one’s own shadow.

ex.xv: Warddaw ngalbahbang.
ex.xe: Oh my goodness she's angry.

sn.de: Oh, oh my goodness (expression of shock, fear, awe etc).

ex.xv: Bolkkime wanjh, nadjalkudji namekke, Worrgorl dja Warddjak, benebokenh namekke yerri. Duwa rowk namekke.
ex.xe: Today they are combined into one clan, Worrkorl and Warddjak [Worrkorl being extinct and Warddjak has succeeded to their estate], the two of them are a joint clan. Both of them are duwa moiety.

sn.de: Clan name of two duwa moiety clan estates, one in the middle to upper East Alligator region and another further east on the upper Kumadderr (Goomadeer) River district of the Arnhem Land plateau

ex.xv: Yibarnamen warde duruk kangun.
ex.xe: Hang it up otherwise the dog will eat it.

ex.xv: Nakka namarndeyi, wardi kanbun.
ex.xe: That guy is a murderer, he might kill us (if we’re not careful).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra.

sn.de: Otherwise, lest (apprehensional or adversative senses— usually referring to an undesirable outcome).

ex.xv: Wardi yimray yinan
ex.xe: Come over here and have a look.

ex.xv: Bu nayawurrinj kanan Mardayin, Wubarr, yika Kunabibi wanjh kabirrimarneyime "ware".
ex.xe: When a young man sees the Mardayin, Ubarr or Kunabibi ceremony, people call him "ware".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Ceremonial participant in Kunabibi, Mardayin or Ubarr ceremony.

ex.xv: Wanjh kumekke kabirriwareyo kubolkdjamun.
ex.xe: Then they stay there inside the Kunabibi ceremony at a sacred site.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Be inside the Kunabibi ceremony (often for a long time, weeks, months).

ex.xv: kunbolkwarlah
ex.xe: wide open place

ex.xv: dangwarlah
ex.xe: loud mouth

ex.xv: Warlang keb-bikibiki.
ex.xe: The ghost bat/ Hipposideros bats have a nose like a pig.

sn.de: Various bats of the family Hipposideridae but also including the ghost bat (family Megadermatidae) 1. Dusky leaf-nosed bat, 2. Arnhem leaf-nosed bat, 3. Northern leaf-nosed bat, 4. Ghost bat.
sn.sc: Hipposideros ater, Hipposideros inornata, Hipposideros stenotis, Macroderma gigas

ex.xv: Kornkumo yimeng, "Burrkyak, birridin ngalkinbalen dja namanjmiken, dja ngarre mankung, dja kunj ngawarlbun."
ex.xe: The father said “No, they [the kids] can stay with grandma and grandpa, the two of us can go looking for wild honey and I’ll hunt some kangaroos”.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Djerrh korroko birrimarnbuni manmekenh bu birriwarlbuni nawu morlehmorlenj.
ex.xe: In the past, women used to make dilly bags for gathering fruits and vegetables.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu karrire baleh kore manberrk karriwarlbun karrirednan djuwe karedmarnbun kamang kundalk dja manyahyay kundulk.
ex.xe: If we go anywhere in the forest hunting we see bowerbird nests, it makes its nest by gathering grasses and acacia branches.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Warlkkahwarlkkarrinj.
ex.xe: He used to hide himself.

sn.de: Across, horizontally in a straight line.

se.de: Place across, place a horizontal bar such as a log.

ex.xv: Nawu nakurl ngarrinan koyekbeh kangolburlerran kawarnamkurrme.
ex.xe: We see the late wet season storms darkening the clouds to the east, creating a black line on the horizon.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Place across, place a horizontal bar of some kind. E.g. resting a straight branch between two vertical forked sticks.

ex.xv: Bu wurdyaw kahdi kunjam wanjh kakukwarreworren bu kakukwarnamyo.
ex.xe: If the child someone is carrying is lying horizontally inside them, that can cause complications.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nanih ngadburrung Mirarr bedberre bedman darnki dja ngayeman bewubeh kore kawarddewarnamyo.
ex.xe: This [country] belongs to my sister and those of the Mirarr, but my country is close by, just the next place over where the escarpment lies.
ex.so: Quoted in Garde, Murray, ‘Culture, Interaction and Person Reference in an Australian Language’, John Benjamins Publishing Company,  Amsterdam, 2013

sn.de: Lie horizontally across something, in a horizontal line or bar.

ex.xv: Karldurrk kawarnmakwarnmak karrolkan kare.
ex.xe: Kookaburra is very happy as he flies around

ex.xv: Ngawarnyak ngayo kure mikurrambalk.
ex.xe: I don't want to sleep inside houses.

ng: may also be described as a predicate adjective

ex.xv: Warradjan yiman kayime manbiri, la manbowinjku kare. Kundedj karrudjerren karrabududje. Kure Mikkinj nawern.
ex.xe: The Pig-nosed turtle is like a salt-water turtle but lives in fresh-water. It buries its rear end and lays eggs in the ground. There are many in Mikkinj valley.

ex.xv: Nawarre ngawarnyak.
ex.xe: It's no good, I don't want it.

se.de: Ruin, destroy, damage, make a mistake.

ex.xv: Birradjdja ngarringuni… ngarrikurrmi, ngarribuni wanjh yoy. Manwerrk manu rey warreka.
ex.xe: We used to eat rice…  we used to put it there and thresh it. The husks would fly off all over the place but the rice would stay where it was.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kunkare bu, ngarriwam bokenh kunred, Kudjekbinj dja Djalbangurrk. Ngarridolkkang Mamardawerre ngarriwam, ngarriyonginj Djurlka, wanjh malamalaywini ngarrimunkewerrinj, birridanjbik binihbininj dja yawkyawk mak daluhdaluk manbolh manbuyika ngadman warrekah ngarriwam, dja bedman warrekah manbolh birriwam nawu binihbininj, birribebmeng kore Djalbangurrk.
ex.xe: In the past we used to travel to two different places, Kudjekbinj and Djalbangurrk. We'd leave from Mamardawerre, sleep at Djurlka, then in the morning we'd go our separate ways - the three men and the woman and girls. We'd go our own way, and the men would go a different direction and come out at Djalbangurrk.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: All over the place, everywhere, different directions.

ex.xv: Bik kabolkarung kabolkwarrehwarrewon.
ex.xe: Pigs dig up the ground and damage the country.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kenh ngawarrewong, ngabirliwarrewong.
ex.xe: Oops, I didn't light the fire properly.

ex.xv: Birrihyawani mandjawak, nawu kunkare birriwarrhkeng.
ex.xe: They were looking for the knife which they had dropped some time ago.
ex.so: Gumurdul, Julie, ‘Mawah, kanjok dja korlonjh birriwam ngalmangiyi’, in Manakgu, Andrew et. al. ‘Kabirrihwarlbun’, Oenpelli Literary Project, 1974

ex.xv: Ngalyawk ba-bidbom ba-kukwarrawarrhkeng an-djarduk.
ex.xe: The young woman climbed up and knocked down the bush apple fruit.

sn.de: Drop, throw down onto the ground, cause to fall or flop down.

se.de: Knock down fruit from a tree.

ex.xv: Yiwernhdukka warde kawarrhme.
ex.xe: Tie it securely or else it might fall down.

sn.de: Fall or flop to the ground.

ex.xv: Ngalkudji daluk warribowam kore kubolkdjamun.
ex.xe: He gave it away without realising what he was doing, it wasn't really his fault [e.g. a child giving away something that doesn't belong to them].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: "Don't take that yam, it's too small". "Whatever, I'll just take it anyway and cook it up and eat it. Doesn't matter if it's small".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Warriwarribo karringalngu.
ex.xe: Let's eat it anyway.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Do something anyway, any which way, without discernment.

ex.xv: Kanwarreboyameng.
ex.xe: He speared us [and what a bad thing that was].

sn.de: The wrong way, incorrect action, bad thing. Expresses speaker’s negative attitude towards an action.

ex.xv: Manmim kabenbirlwon. Kundad dja mak kunwel bedberre, kabennjamwarrewon warridj.
ex.xe: It disfigures their eyes (magpie geese). Their legs and wings and also their intestines (are affected).

ex.xv: Mani dirdde kukkuken dja mankung warridj.
ex.xe: This dilly bag is for water and also honey.

ex.xv: Ngaye ngabolkbawong Warruwi ngawam Minjdjilang ngahni.
ex.xe: I left Goulburn Island and was living on Croker Island.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 252

ex.xv: Nang nakimuk nayin kahyo, kelewawmeng yimeng, "Waw, waw, waw."
ex.xe: He saw a big snake was there and cried out “Waw waw waw!”
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974.

ex.xv: Wanjh wawmeng yimeng, "Waw, nganbayeng duruk.”
ex.xe: Then he cried out, “Ouch, that dog bit me”.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Nakudji wurdyaw bibayeng duruk’ in “Kunwinjku Stories”, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

sn.de: Oh, ahh, ouch, ow (expression of pain, fear etc.).

se.re: yell out in pain or fear
se.de: Yell out in pain or fear, "Ah!", "Ouch!" etc.

ex.xv: Nakudji wam djangkang nang dungyibmeng. Keleminj wayarrakenh.
ex.xe: A man went hunting and saw the sun set. He grew afraid of ghosts.

sn.de: Term used by cross sex siblings to refer to each other, including use as a kundebi term.

ex.xv: Ngurriwayarra ngurrimimdaybadjan!
ex.xe: You're all a bunch of big-eyed demons!

sn.de: A term used as an insult/swearing.

ex.xv: Ma yawurrinj ngurriwayhkemen ngurrikukkurrmen.
ex.xe: OK you young men, lift it and place the body (there).
ex.so: example 1- Lena Yarinkura (E), example 2- John Dalngadalnga

ex.xv: Manbu kukku bowayhmeng kore kunkodj ngalengarre wanjh kebngakmeng.
ex.xe: The water rose up over her head and she drowned.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nakudji kawayini, nakudji kabuhme.
ex.xe: One sings, and the other plays the didjeridu.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Wayuk kandimarnema ngabardmongun.
ex.xe: Get me some waterlily stems, I'll eat them.

ex.xv: Weng.
ex.xe: S/he threw it.

ex.xv: Yibowemen.
ex.xe: Throw out the water.

se.de: Throw oneself, thrash or flop about (fish etc).

ex.xv: Yiddok yiwehmeng?
ex.xe: Have you been vomiting?
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Mirnaliwo yawmey wurdyaw kore kurrangbeh yawwehmeng kore kuwarderurrk kore kunwardde Wurrakkak bolkkime kahwarderri.
ex.xe: Mirnaliwo [one of Wurrakkak’s two wives] gave birth from her mouth, she brought the child from her mouth in a cave where Wurrakkak rock is today.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Expel or bring forth from the mouth, give birth from the mouth (as in mouthbrooding species). This also occurs in mythological births.

ex.xv: Minj ngaweldi, minj ngarrolkan.
ex.xe: I don't have wings, I can't fly.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Murnun minj kaweldi.
ex.xe: The dugong doesn't have any wings (fins).

ex.xv: Ngalbu daluk yimeng "Nahni kunmadj weleberrk, minj ngadjongburren".
ex.xe: The woman said "Those clothes are getting saggy and wrinkled, I'm not going to wear that".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalbadjan yimeng "Nahni wurdyaw kanjamweleberrk, dja ngawon manme mankimuk kangun, ba kanjamlurlme bu kaworrkmen".
ex.xe: The mother said "That child's stomach is all sagging and empty, I'll give him a good meal to fill out his stomach again".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Saggy, drooping, soft, flaccid, wrinkled, sagging.

ex.xv: Worro ngalkohbanj merlemweleberrkminj.
ex.xe: That poor old lady's stomach is all wrinkled.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw nang manme manbu manboyberre, weleberrkminj. Wanjh minj nguyi dja bawong.
ex.xe: The child saw some white apple Syzygium forte fruits, which had gone soft and wrinkled. So she didn't eat them, she left them.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakudji bininj yimeng "Ngawam nganang nakohbanj, dja wernhkukweleberrkminj".
ex.xe: The man said "I went and saw the old man, he's really aged and his skin is has gone wrinkled and soft".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dolobbo birrikuklowkmangi, wanjh birrikinjeyi, welebmi.
ex.xe: They would take a sheet of stringybark from a tree, heat it over a fire and it would soften and flatten out.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu marrunj korroko dabborrabbolk birrimarnbuni yiman banikkin, bu kukku, manme dja mankung birridahkendongi. Kaluk bu birrinani warrhmi kore marrunj mandulkwern kadulkdi wanjh birrimangi kolng nawu birridjuhkeyi. Wanjh birribawoni kunkodjke bokenh wanjh bu welebmi manu kolng, wanjh birrirey birrimangi. Wanjh birribakbakkeyi birrimarnbuni banikkin.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors would use Hydriastele ramsayi palms to make a kind of bowl, for holding water, food and honey. When they saw that fronds had fallen off in a grove of palms, they would gather them and put them in water. They would leave them for two days, and when they got soft they would go and get them out. Then they would break bits off so only the bowl part of the frond was left.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Become soft and floppy, become pliable or flexible, become flaccid, soften and flatten out.

ex.xv: Nangale welengken?
ex.xe: Who killed it?

ex.xv: Wanjh rerre rerre ngundibukkan ngudberre karridadje ngadmanwali welengken.
ex.xe: Then next time they will show you and we will be responsible for cutting them ourselves.

ex.xv: Nungka naweleng.
ex.xe: Him, he's the one who did it.

sn.de: The responsible party, the one doing the action in topic. More specifically the person responsible for killing game.

ng: Can be used in predicative constructions with pronominal prefixes.

ex.xv: Ngalkangila ngaye nganwiddjuy bu nganwelengnameng.
ex.xe: Ngalkangila pointed at me and blamed me.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Andakdjarr kawelewelme.
ex.xe: There are aerial roots hanging down all around.
ex.so: Kundjeyhmi / Kundedjnjenghmi

ex.xv: Nawu bininj bokenh kundulk benekanjwurrkmeng nawu kunkanj nganabbarru bu benemarnbom babburli wanjh benekanjngorrkani kundulk dorrengh, kanjwelhwelmi.
ex.xe: Two men poked a piece of wood through the buffalo flesh to make a carrying stick, then carried it on their shoulders as it hung down from the stick.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngahli daluk ngarringeybun Ngaldjordboh kakarrme marlakka kawelhwelme kore kukom ngalengarre.
ex.xe: The woman we call Ngaldjordboh has a sacred dilly bag hanging from her neck.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, 'Ngaldjordboh' story.

sn.de: Hanging down, hanging down all over the place.

ex.xv: Ngalbadbulu Kunburray kure njilhmi karri, kawelewelme barrk.
ex.xe: At Ngalbadbulu in the Kunburray area, there is a spring and there are lots of black wallaroos.
ex.so: LBN (Kundedjnjenghmi)

sn.de: Hanging around everywhere, there be many in a place.
Red-winged parrot (also known as red-shouldered parrot).

ur: M, Kunwinjku = weleyhweleyh, Kunwalidjaw clan lect name= djadberlhberlh

ex.xv: Manwern nguneng dedjwarlah.
ex.xe: He ate heaps of them the greedy guts.

ex.xv: Kumekke di ngarribonguneng wanjh nungka kunmadj kurrmeng wanjh ngarriwam ngarriwern.
ex.xe: We drank tea there, and then he put his swag down and then many of us set off.

ex.xv: Yiwernhbu!
ex.xe: Give it a good whack!

ex.xv: Nawernhkimuk ngalyod.
ex.xe: A really very big rainbow serpent.

ex.xv: Manbu kukku borlobmi wernkih kore mankabo.
ex.xe: The current was flowing very quickly in the river.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bikayhmeng ngalengarre nayaw, dja minj bibekkayinj. Biyawoyhkayhmeng wernkih bu kunkuyeng wanjh kawong nawu nawaran.
ex.xe: She called out to her son, but he didn’t hear her. She called out to him again, loud and long, and so she disturbed Nawaran the Oenpelli Python.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 244

sn.de: Do something quickly, fast, loudly, hard, strongly or with force.

ex.xv: Mandudjmi karung wanjh bod kawernmen.
ex.xe: When the green plums are ripe, it is the time when there are many flies.

ex.xv: Kore kulabbarl wanjh nawu ngalmangeyi wernmerrinj.
ex.xe: The long necked turtles have bred and multiplied at the billabong.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Balanda kahdjalwernmerren dja job nungkah kahmanamang.
ex.xe: There are getting to be more and more non-Indigenous people here, and they are taking the jobs.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Increase by self propagation, increase in numbers, multiply, breed in large numbers. The subject is singular, being the group as a whole.

ex.xv: Yikahwi wurdwurd kunubewu minj kabindiwon manbu manme. Manmakmak yiman, manbu kabenkurlbawernwon dja kabenmurrngrayekwon.
ex.xe: Some people might not give kids the [right] food. Good food that is, that will give them healthy blood [“increase their blood”] and will strengthen them.
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace, untitled book, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Benewam, wanjh bonj benewernwong.
ex.xe: Those two went and so in the end they completed all the ceremonies.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Kalukburrk nayaw ngarre wernwong bu mahni yarrkka nanihnani. Wanjh kunukka kamak.
ex.xe: So consequently her son has graduated [seen enough ceremonies to lift food restrictions etc.], gone through seeing everything. That’s really good.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Birrimarnewerrhwerrhmeng Mehme barrhburrinj.
ex.xe: They raked up and Mehme covered himself over (with leaves and grass etc).

sn.de: Clear or clean an area of ground of plants and sticks, rake up rubbish etc.

ex.xv: Nangale nganmarnemadjwerrwerrhmeng.
ex.xe: Who's been rummaging through my bag.

sn.de: Clearing of clouds after a storm.

ex.xv: Nangale werrk?
ex.xe: Who will go first?

ex.xv: Yiddok muddikang makkan kabirriweykan?
ex.xe: Are they selling that car?

ex.xv: Kabirriyakwon wanjh mamurrng dja kunmadj kabirriweykan.
ex.xe: When they finish [the ceremony] they’ll hand over the mamurrng [staff] and the goods [gifts as payments].

sn.de: Hand over, transfer ownership, give gift.

ex.xv: Birriwid.
ex.xe: That other mob.

ex.xv: Ngalngale ngalkka? Kalidjan ngalekke. Ngalwid.
ex.xe: Who is that woman? That's Kalidjan. No not her (it's another person).

ex.xv: Kunred ke Mankorlord kunbolkwarre! Kuwid, kunbolkmak!
ex.xe: Your country Mankorlord it's a rubbish place! (said in jest) Hey, no it's not, it's a good place!

sn.de: A response to teasing 'hey, I don't like it'.

ex.xv: Dabborrabbolk birrikukmarnbuni djaworndjaworn yiman kayime bininj. Bu nangale doweni, wanjh nungka bolkwidjungi bedberre bu benbengdayhkeyi kore birrikukdudjengi nawu doweni bininj.
ex.xe: Our ancestors used to make djaworn-djaworn figures in the shape of people. When someone passed away, then that figure would be used to point to the place where the dead person had been buried, to let people know.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kabiwayudwayudme kawohnan kabinan kayimarnebolkwidjung.
ex.xe: He waves to him as he watches out for him and points at the place for him. (Words of wurrurrumi song).

ex.xv: Birrimdurndi kabirribolkwidnan birriyimeng.
ex.xe: They came back, they hate that place.

ex.xv: Birringuni dolek kuk yika birriwilkdengi kore kuwilk.
ex.xe: People would eat wood grubs raw, or cook them in the hot coals under ashes.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Cook under ashes, as for damper or fish.
To win over somebody, e.g. in a sporting competition.

ex.xv: Warradjan ngalkka ngalengman kadjalyo kare kore kubowinjku kukku minj kare kore kurrula.
ex.xe: The pig-nosed turtle only lives in the fresh water, it doesn’t go into the ocean.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nawinjku.
ex.xe: (Male) Kunwinjku speaker.
ex.so: Nicholas Evans, Dunstan Brown, Greville G. Corbett, 'The semantics of gender in Mayali', Language, Volume 78, Number 1, March 2002, pp. 111-155.

ex.xv: Barrk ngarringeybun nawu ngad bininj ngarriwinjku ngarrikukburlerri dja birrikukbele balanda kabirringeybun 'black wallaroo'.
ex.xe: Us Kunwinjku speakers call it 'barrk', but white people call it a 'black wallaroo'.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Grass sp. used for extracting a red dye for weaving.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk wirlam birrimarnbuni. Dolobbo birrikuklowkmangi, wanjh birrikinjeyi, welebmi. Yerre birribakbakkeyi bu birrimarnbuni yiman kubbunj. Wanjh birridjowkkeyi kore kurrula dja kore mankabokimuk kore baleh birridjareni birrirey.
ex.xe: In the old days, our ancestors used to make bark rafts. They would take a sheet of bark from a tree, heat it over a fire and it would soften up. After that they would break it and make it into something like a canoe. Then they could cross the sea and big rivers, to wherever they wanted to go.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Birridahkendongi nawu wirlarrk kore djabbilarna wanjh birrikinjeyi.
ex.xe: They would put the eggs in a billycan and boil them.
ex.so: Narndal, Julie et. al. ‘Manme’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1982

ex.xv: Mandjoh kanguybun wanjh kumuken kawirlarrkngukdeng.
ex.xe: When the acacia flowers, the freshwater crocodiles lay their eggs.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngarrbek bekkang kabihbun nawu wirlarrk. Wanjh wirlarrkngukdi ngalbu
ex.xe: The Echidna felt that the egg was ready to come out [was pressing her]. So she laid it.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Bu Ngurriborlhme Kunwinjku: Learning Kunwinjku’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1994

ex.xv: Dja bolkkime kurdburru nawu balanda marnbom wirlmurr namekke bu bolkkime karrikan bu mankung karriyawan karridulkderdme.
ex.xe: But these days we take axes made by Balanda [non-Indigenous people] from metal, nowadays when we go looking for honey and chop trees.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Korroko birrikarungi kunbalkbu dja bolkkime kubba wirlmurrng nawu balanda marnbom kabirrikarung karrbarda nawu daluk.
ex.xe: In the old days women used to dig with wooden digging sticks, but now they dig for long yams with metal digging sticks made by non-Indigenous people.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Njale ngunwirrkmeng?
ex.xe: What scratched you?

ex.xv: Dolobbo kabirridadjke kabirrimang kabirrikukkinje kabirriwirrkme wanjh kabirrimarnbun njale kore dolobbo.
ex.xe: They cut the bark off, take it and heat it on a fire, scrape off the excess outer bark then paint something on it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw barrken ngarrikukwirrkme karnubirr ngalngyahwurd duninjh ba bu kadjordmen nawu wurdyaw wanjh kakukmakmen.
ex.xe: We scratch young children [aged 3-4 months] with the shell of a small mud mussel [lightly with the back of the shell, on their stomach, back, bottom, cheeks etc] so that when they grow up, they'l be good looking.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawohwob.
ex.xe: Very light.

ex.xv: Wo, yinan kayime ngalkimuk ngaldaluk yikabeh narangem ngalyahwurd ngalwob wanjh.
ex.xe: You can see that the female (emu) is bigger and sometimes the males are smaller and lighter (in weight).

ex.xv: Bad 'tourist guide' wob makka 'tourist guide' bad makka djungkay kakarrme kunkimuk djob nawu. Kunkimuk, yiman kayime naredweleng nuye kakarrme.
ex.xe: But the analogy of the meaning of the term dungkay with a 'tourist guide' is quite superficial and trivial because the djungkay has a much more profound job. It is as significant or important as that of a traditional land owner (in the scheme of traditional land ownership issues).

sn.de: Superficial, trivial, lacking in depth and seriousness.

ex.xv: Mankordang kunworr biwodbom.
ex.xe: The 'magic man' thrashed her with leaves (to heal her).

sn.de: Hit somebody with a branch of leaves to heal them.

ex.xv: Kabiwodbun medjek dorrengh.
ex.xe: She fans her with a goosewing fan.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Aa karrihrokan. Mahni bula kabolkwodjorrhme kadberre.
ex.xe: Ahh, everything's moving. It's an earthquake [that's shaking the ground].
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yiwohdadje.
ex.xe: Cut it in the middle.

ex.xv: Kanwohkurrme!
ex.xe: Drop me off [from the truck] on the way [part way along your intended route].

re: whilst in midst of other action

ex.xv: Biwohdadkaybom.
ex.xe: He took the leg (of meat) off him (in the process of eating it).

ex.xv: Wohmankang.
ex.xe: It fell down half way (i.e. along a trajectory before it reached us).

sn.de: An action or focus that occurs in the process of another action, along the way.

ex.xv: Ngabendjalwohkan wurdurd.
ex.xe: I'll take the children [watch over them] for the time being [until you return].

ex.xv: Birriwohkanjnguneng.
ex.xe: They just ate some of the meat. (or alternatively) They ate their meat hurriedly.

ex.xv: Ngarrwohngehme.
ex.xe: Let's have a rest for a while.

sn.de: Partially, for the time being, temporarily, limitation in extent.
Not at all, not even a bit.

ng: note that this sense is only instantiated with a negated transitive verb

ex.xv: Ngandimarneyimeng kunred manih nguddangke bu yiman baleh ngarridowen wanjh
ex.xe: They said to me that this place belongs to me and that "if we should die, then you have to look after this place."

ex.xv: Bulanj yiworhnan?
ex.xe: Bulanj are you awake?

ex.xv: Mimdubbe, nomo kaworhnan.
ex.xe: He's blind, he can't see.

ex.xv: Morlehmorlenj bindikani nawu nanikkud kore kabbal birriwohrey birridalknguni.
ex.xe: The women would take the goats onto the floodplain, and they would wander around there eating grass.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Bu yaw nawu kakarrme darnkidarnki kadjalwohre bu kadjalen kadjordme wanjh balahbalay…
ex.xe: When there are chicks, she [the emu] takes them only short distances but when they grow up they travel much further…
ex.so: Lofty Bardayal Nadjamerrek, quoted in Murray Garde (ed.), Something about emus : indigenous knowledge of emus from western Arnhem Land, Canberra, A.C.T. Aboriginal Studies Press, 2017, p. 86

ex.xv: Karriwohre karrimadbun kaluk wamuddjan kamre.
ex.xe: Let's wait around until wamuddjan comes.

sn.de: Walk around, wander, travel a short distance or part of the way.

ex.xv: Mayh kawokdi.
ex.xe: The ceremony will 'speak' (make sounds indicating it is about to commence at a particular location).

ex.xv: Wokmadbuni.
ex.xe: I was waiting for you to call.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Wait for someone to call, wait for word from someone.

ex.xv: Karriwayini, karriwokmarren.
ex.xe: Let's record ourselves singing.

ex.xv: Kano 'blenk kedjed' ba nga-ben-wokmang.
ex.xe: Give me a blank cassette so I can record them.

ex.xv: Kanyawwokmang.
ex.xe: That little (microphone) records us.

sn.de: Record, normally with an audio recording device.

ex.xv: Marrek ngunwokmang, ngunmarnewokyak nawuka.
ex.xe: He can't answer you, he's gotta 'shut up' for you, your bunji [brother-in-law].

ex.xv: Med kakkak, nahni nawu Nawakadj ngadjalohwokmang.
ex.xe: Wait kakkak, I just have to answer this call from Nawakadj.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dja mak bu bininj kabirriwokngimen kondabeh kore Mardbalk wanjh dingki kabirrimlobme.
ex.xe: And if people call to Goulburn Island from here, people will come over in a dinghy [to pick them up].
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Call on the telephone, radio etc. Literally “words go inside”.
Various flying insects such as lacewings which fly at night and are attracted to light.
Food sitting as it cools (esp. after being taken from the fire).

ex.xv: Wolewoleh buyika.
ex.xe: Dday before yesterday, days previous.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey kukak bu dird bolkwolkani.
ex.xe: The old people used to go around [hunting] at night when the moon lit up the ground.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Dja bu birridoweni wanjh birrimangi kunworr mandubang birrirurrkwolngwoni kundolng dorrengh manbu kunrurrk kore yongohyoy.
ex.xe: But if someone died, then people would get leaves from the ironwood tree and smoke the place that person used to live in.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Make smoke, especially in smoking rituals when green ironwood leaves are burnt to produce smoke for ritual cleansing.

ex.xv: Yirakma ngawolngwon dolobbo.
ex.xe: Get firewood, I'm going to cure this bark.

sn.de: Cure bark with smoke to straighten it.

ex.xv: Yiwolngwo ngardduk.
ex.xe: Heat it up for me.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Heat something up on top of the coals of a gentle fire (no flame), for example food that has gone cold.

ex.xv: Yiwo.
ex.xe: Give it to him/her

ex.xv: Kan(w)o
ex.xe: Give it to me.

ex.xv: Wong.
ex.xe: I gave you.

se.de: Give each other, distribute within a group, exchange.

ng: -won can be used as a verbalizing suffix with many adjectives eg. -bulerriwon to blacken, -kuyenwon to lengthen, or -rayekwon to tighten.

ex.xv: Dedded kunmud kabirrimudmang kabirrikurrme kore djerrh wongkorr mardayin kunmadj.
ex.xe: People get lorikeet feathers and weave them into sacred dilly bags for the Mardayin ceremony.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Sacred dilly bag often woven with brightly coloured orange parrot feathers and/or strips of ceremonial cotton cloth.

ex.xv: Wordword kani kore kundulk mannguy kanguyngun dja kawokdi kayime wordword wordword.
ex.xe: Magpie larks sit in trees and eat [the nectar of] flowers, calling out ‘wordword, wordword’.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Bu kabirriwurlhke kunak karralkrung rowk wanjh mandjong bu karung darnkih kakebdowen wanjh kunmayorrk kaworlhme wanjh kamarnbun kayawoyhwurlhme.
ex.xe: When people start fires and all the grass burns, there are smouldering logs left behind, and when the wind blows them it makes them burst into flame again.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bu mahbilil kabun wanjh ngarrinan kaworlhworlhme manbu kunmayorrk mankimuk wanjh kunu ngarriburrbun bu kurrula kabidbun.
ex.xe: When there's a sea breeze, we see strong gusts of wind and we know that the tide is rising.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngalkohbanj bimarneyimeng nawu wurdyaw "Med worlhme medjek mud".
ex.xe: The old woman said to the child 'Wait I'll fan you with a goose wing fan'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngadjare ngabonan kurrula kaboyo / Dja mak kunmayorrk nganwolhme bu ngani.
ex.xe: I want to see the ocean / And feel the wind blowing on me.
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Galiwin’ku’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

sn.de: Fan someone, cool someone down, wind blows someone.

ex.xv: Wanjh benewam beneyerrngmey beneworrhmeng. Wanjh benemadbuni benenjammey nawu ngalmangiyi wanjh bu njamruy wanjh benenguneng.
ex.xe: Then the two of them got some firewood and started a fire. Then they waited a little [for the fire to burn down], took out the innards of the long-necked turtle, and when the innards were cooked they ate them.
ex.so: Garnarradj, Elaine N, ‘Ngalbadjan dja Ngalyaw’, Oenpelli Literacy Centre, Oenpelli, 1975

sn.de: Make a fire, create a blaze.

ex.xv: Manme yidjare? Bonj ngaworrkminj.
ex.xe: Do you want food? No, it's OK I'm full.

sn.de: Eat one's fill, fill up with food.

ex.xv: Kadrangkme kaworroworromkan.
ex.xe: He's drunk and staggering.

ex.xv: He had an arrest warrant out for him, that's why the police arrested him.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Karohrok bininj, bu ngad wanjh karriyime, “Yiwowarreminj ngudda.” Kunubewu ngundiwabun or ngundiyame, bu birriyimi korroko, bolkkime larrk.
ex.xe: It’s the same with our Aboriginal system. If we say, “You’ve become a criminal,” well you might be cursed or they might spear you. That's what they'd say in the past, but not now.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Nahni Kunabibi - Kunabibi yinan narayek, nabang marndi, yiwowarremen, trouble yiyime.
ex.xe: The Kunabibi ceremony – you see the Kunabibi is hard, dangerous, you can get in a lot of trouble [if you do the wrong thing during the ceremony].
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: In trouble, marked as a criminal or wrongdoer.

se.de: Be marked as a law breaker or criminal.
Break the law, make oneself a criminal.

ex.xv: Benedirri nganabbarru nganabbarru. Bu benedirridanginj, wanjh woybukkih kumbebmeng kore kunngarrebeh.
ex.xe: They played "Buffalo. Buffalo." They were just playing there when a buffalo really came out of the bush.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 20-23

sn.de: True, really. Also used as an interjection "That's true!".

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh benehmangi woyung nawu kuy kabenekan wanjh kabeneburriwe djenj nuye ba kabenemang.
ex.xe: Two women were getting long worms, taking them and throwing them to the fish (on lines) in order to catch them.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wud yirrahkendo biliken wardi ngunyilkan.
ex.xe: Put the worms in the billycan otherwise they'll slither all over you.

sn.de: Worm. Can refer to any worm, e.g. earthworm, hookworm.

ex.xv: Ngalbu karndjawarra ngalkka ngalengman kore kurrula kadjalyo. Bu kurrula kabobidbun wanjh minj karrinan ngalbu karndjawarra. Dja bu kurrula karrurndeng kabukmen wanjh karrire kore kudjekudje nganjkarrkarr karriyawan karrimang wanjh karrikan karrikinje.
ex.xe: Karndjawarra (Mud Crabs, Scylla serrata) live near the sea. When the tide comes up, we don't see them. But when the tide goes out, we go to the mangroves and get them and cook them.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nungka nawaran kabendukkan kabenbirdirdme kunj nawarddeken wanjh kawukme.
ex.xe: The OenpelIi Python can crush a rock kangaroo to death and then swallow it.
ex.so: ‘Ecology of Rock Kangaroos in Western Arnhem Land’, Charles Darwin University / Key Centre for Tropical Wildlife Management, 2005

ex.xv: Wularla kakayhmire kayime kaaaay, kunekke.
ex.xe: The Spectacled hare wallaby goes along calling out, it says, 'kaaaay' like that.

ex.xv: Wularla Yabburdurrwa ken.
ex.xe: The Spectacled hare wallaby is associated with the Yabburdurrwa ceremony.

ex.xv: Kano kalarru ngawungme.
ex.xe: Give me a cigarette and I'll have a smoke.

ex.xv: Yikah wurd ngabadwodki kunbalanda.
ex.xe: Sometimes I’ll use some English.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Makka boyehboyen wurd birrimhkarrmi, wanjh bonj, bolkkime yiman yakayakminj.
ex.xe: They used to have it not so long ago, but not now. It’s finished.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yoh. Ngaye wurd ngabenbukkabukkan nawu ngardduk ngabenyawmey… munguyh ngabendjalmarneyolyolme.
ex.xe: Yes. Up to a point I teach them, my own children… I’m always explaining things to them.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: A little bit, a limited extent.
Woman’s potential to have children, fertility.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw yimeng "Djak nganbayeng." Wanjh nalkbuni munguyh nawu wurdyaw.
ex.xe: The child said "An ant bit me". And he just kept on crying, that child.
ex.so: Dakgalawuy, Nancy, ‘Wurdyaw dirrihdirri’ in ‘Kunwinjku Stories’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

sn.de: Take someone to swim (eg. wash a baby).

ex.xv: Benewam kore kulabbarl. Wanjh benemadjkurrmeng, wanjh benewurlebmeng.
ex.xe: They went to the billabong. Then they put their things down and went into the water.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 68-71

sn.de: Take a bath or shower, swim, go into the water.
Set fire, ignite, start a bush fire.

ex.xv: Balekeno kawokdi mayh? Kaluk kawurluwurlhme karriwareyo.
ex.xe: When will the ceremony happen? After when it's burning off time, then we'll go and enter the ceremony.

ex.xv: Kabolkwurlhme bolkki.
ex.xe: Today this place is really hot.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Ngakodjwurlhme.
ex.xe: My head is really hot / I have a fever.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Ngalburlanj yimeng "Yoh wurra ngabengmidjdanj manme".
ex.xe: Ngalburlanj said "Oh, I forgot the food!"
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yoh, njale wurra ngabalyimeninj...?
ex.xe: Yes, now what else was I going to say...?
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Oh; what was it; oh that's right; oh and another thing, etc. Said when you've just forgotten something or just remembered something that you've forgotten.

ex.xv: Wurrakkak kumdolkkang kakbi kurrula beh. Nungka nawu Wurrakkak nakka nakuyengni kornnamkuyengni kumrey kaddum kore kurrula bu bolkmelmi.
ex.xe: Wurrakkak came from the sea to the north. He was big and tall and walked on the sea.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Male creation Ancestor and the rock formation he became, known in English as Tor Rock.

ur: Kunwinjku = kurdukadji, Kuninjku, Kundedjnjenghmi = ngurrurdu, Kundjeyhmi = alwanjdjuk

ex.xv: Ngalengman kanjdji manekke ngamed Wurrudakdjurle, Djalendjurle kabalkolung Marrawana kanjdji Mimarrewahwa, Mikorromolod kabale kanjdji makkan na-Wurrik ngalengman, kunyed, na-Wurrik kunyed kunu.
ex.xe: And downstream to Wurrudakdjurle and Djalendjurle and Marrawana and down to Mimarrewahwa and on to Mikorromolod and continue on to the Wurrik clan land, places in the Wurrik clan estate.

ex.xv: Wurrkengko manburluddak kakobun, mankung karringun, kawurluwurlhme.
ex.xe: In Wurrkeng season the Stringybark trees flower, we get honey and it's the time when all the bushfires burn.

sn.de: Season name, latter part of the dry season, hot weather, fires abound.

ex.xv: Nakudji bininj wam kore kukabo wanjh nang kinga red kore kukadjid, wanjh kundulk bakkeng dja bowurrkmeng wanjh nang kinga dolkang kore kukkubeh.
ex.xe: A man went to the river and saw a crocodile nest on the bank. He went and broke off a stick and poked it into the water, and saw a crocodile jump up from the water.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu bininj bokenh kundulk benekanjwurrkmeng nawu kunkanj nganabbarru bu benemarnbom babburli wanjh benekanjngorrkani kundulk dorrengh, kanjwelhwelmi.
ex.xe: Two men poked a piece of wood through the buffalo flesh to make a carrying stick, then carried it on their shoulders as it hung down from the stick.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Poke through, poke into, penetrate, pierce.

ex.xv: Nganbodmewurrkme.
ex.xe: I have a sharp pain in my back.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Dowkkeng mako ngankodjwurrkmeng.
ex.xe: He fired the gun and it (the noise) stunned me.

ex.xv: Ngankanjwurrkme.
ex.xe: I have a crushing pain.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Cause a sharp pain, stun, concuss. The object of the verb is the person being affected.

ex.xv: Wurrmarninj karri Wulk darnki Kunbarlanja.
ex.xe: The Nelumba red lily grows at Wulk near Kunbarlanja.

ex.xv: Ya, ngandibukkang wanjh ngabimbom.
ex.xe: Yes, they showed me [how to paint it] and I painted it.
ex.so: Mick Kubarkku, unpublished interview with Margie West and Murray Garde, Yikarrakkal Outstation, 1994

sn.de: Yes, thanks. Interjection which expresses happiness and gratitude when receiving something.
Major regional secret cult ceremony associated with yirridjdja moiety.

ex.xv: Yabok, nakka yina nayin nabang kawake!
ex.xe: Hey sis look there, there's a dangerous snake!
ex.so: ‘Lesson 15: Djurra ‘-ng’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre

sn.de: Sister (older or younger), used in reference and address by either male or female

ex.xv: Manbu birddurrk makka wurd manwarddeyahwurd dja manwarddebele.
ex.xe: Quartz stones are small and white.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakka ngaye ngabekkang bu ngayahwurdni.
ex.xe: l heard about that when l was only young.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: Wam djarreh wanjh mandjewk kumhwam nayahwurd wanjh yerre kimukminj.
ex.xe: He went a long way away and it started to rain a little, then the rain got heavy.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngad kabbal konda warddeyak.
ex.xe: We are plains people here, there is no stone-country here.

ng: Forms predicates or predicative adjuncts of lack. Noun prefixes are sometimes dropped, especially when suffix is used as an adverb (Evans, 2003: 148-150).

ex.xv: Kuhri koyek duninjh kumekke wanjh kunu Yingarna yakarrbom bininj dedjborrhborrhdji nawu yibarlirr ngalengarre wanjh kumekke kurrmerrinj.
ex.xe: Far in the east is where Yingarna shook the last people out of her string bag, then she placed herself there forever.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nakudji wurdyaw yakbom manbu manme. Minj djareniwirrinj nguyi.
ex.xe: The child tipped the food off his plate. He didn't want to eat it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kumboyakburreni kaddumbeh.
ex.xe: The water came pouring down from above (in a waterfall).
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly W, ‘Kunkare Wurdyaw Djorlkmeng’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1975

sn.de: Pour, tip, pour out, tip out.

ex.xv: Mahni yakirrdjdja kundulk ngarrimang wanjh wabban ngarrimarnbun bu kubba ngarrikurrme wanjh ngarribolkdjudme bu ngarrimang ngalmangeyi dja mak kedjebe.
ex.xe: We get wood from the milkwood tree and make handles from it to attach to metal sticks, and we poke the ground with them when we look for long-necked turtles and file snakes.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Milkwood tree, wood of the milkwood tree.

ex.xv: Bonj yakminj.
ex.xe: There's none left, it's all gone, 'The End' (of a story).
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly W, ‘Kunkare Wurdyaw Djorlkmeng’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1975

ex.xv: Karrimadbun kaluk mandjewk kayakmen.
ex.xe: Let's wait until the rain has finished.

ex.xv: Ngarridjuhke manekke manyawok kaluk bangno kayakmen.
ex.xe: We put that cheeky yam into the water until the poison is all gone.

ex.xv: Manme yikarrme? Kayakki, birriyakwong birridedjwarla.
ex.xe: Have you got any food? No, those greedy guts (obscene) finished it all.

ex.xv: Duwa, Yirridjdja ngabun ngayakwon / Ngaye Yirrbardbard
ex.xe: Duwa, Yirridjdja moiety people, I will kill you all / I am the taipan snake
ex.so: Wildflower Band, ‘Yirrbardbard’, from the Album ‘Manginburru Bininj’, Skinnyfish Music, 2009

ex.xv: Yimray yingun manih yaldanj.
ex.xe: Come and eat this lily.

ex.xv: “Bonj wanjh," birrimarneyimeng, “yihdjalnalkbu nguddanu, dja yibadbawong manu karrbarda dja mankung, dja yaldanj, dja manmekbe manu yihmanjburrbun mungoyh manburrangkali.
ex.xe: “Well that’s it”, they told him “You can just keep crying. You’ve turned down the long yams, the honey and the lily corms, you just can’t stop thinking about the taste of that manburrangkali lily”.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Nakudji Namarladj Ngiwkmihngiwkmirey’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1974

ex.xv: Korroko bininj birriyamerreni mankole dja birrirongmangi.
ex.xe: In the old days people used to spear each other, and (try to) dodge the spears.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nabulanj wam kabbal wanjh nawu djarrang dja nganabbarru mirndeyarlarrkeng.
ex.xe: Nabulanj went down to the floodplain, and all the horses and the all buffalo ran off and dispersed (as he walked near them).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Cause to disperse, spread out things.

ex.xv: Boyarlarrmeng.
ex.xe: The water splashed out in all directions.

ex.xv: Bu yiman bininj dja daluk kabirrikarrme kundjak wanjh kayarlarrme kore kuburrk bedberre.
ex.xe: When men or women have a disease, it spreads within their bodies.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kunmalaworr mandubang kabirrimang wanjh kabirridjangberhke kabirribolkngeyhngeybun. Wanjh kadjangyarlarrme.
ex.xe: People get an ironwood branch and swat the sacred site with it, calling out the names of places (where they want to find plentiful game). Then the djang spreads out from there (and goes to those places, increasing the animals/fish etc).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: …yimankek ngarriyarlarrmeng school ngarribawong job ngarriwam dja wanjh, djal burrkyak. Only yikah ngarrimey job, ngarrikarrmi kunkodj. And yikah nawu birridjaldjordminj, ngarribebbedjordminj.
ex.xe: … It’s like we’ve gone our seperate ways. When we left school for jobs, that was it. Only some of us got jobs, the ones who had the education. Some people just grew up, they grew up differently from us.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Disperse, spread, go in different directions.

ex.xv: Buludjirrk kakoymud yarriburrik.
ex.xe: The Black Kite is associated with the Yarriburrik moiety.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Matry name (nangarradjku) associated with the totem of fire (kunak).
Matry name belonging to the mardku moiety, associated with the totem of stone (kunwardde).

ex.xv: Yarriwurrkarr wanjh nakka kabo.
ex.xe: So the Yarriwurrkarr moiety, that's the Green Ant moiety (associated with the Green Ant).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Matry name (namardku), associated with the totem of Green Ant (kabo).
