Matry name (nangarradjku), associated with the totem of sun (kundung).

ex.xv: Yuwn yire kore kunak darnkih wardi yarrkka yirung.
ex.xe: Don't go close to the fire, you might get burnt.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bininj yarrkka karribekken Djidjnguk kahwokdi kahyime 'Wuhwu, wuhwu.'
ex.xe: We might hear Djidjnguk [the ‘Fishing Spirit’] in all kinds of places, calling out 'Wuhwu, wuhwu.'
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Might, anything, anywhere. Expresses a possibility within a range of options (might), potential within a range (anything, anywhere, anything of the sort) etc.

ex.xv: duruk yaw
ex.xe: puppy

ex.xv: Biyawmey.
ex.xe: She had a baby.

sn.de: Child, young offspring of woman or female animal.

ex.xv: Kanyawwokmang.
ex.xe: That little (thing) records our words. (Refering to a small microphone).

ex.xv: Bolkkime konda ngawokdi ngayolyolme bu nadjinem ngayolyolme bu korroko mak konda kunred kabolkngeyyo Djalbangurrk kubolkbadjan bad Makkalarl kubolkyaw.
ex.xe: I'll tell you today about the black wallaroo here in this country called Djalbangurrk which is the big place name but the small [specific] locality is known as Makkalarl.

ex.xv: Kundulk mandubang birrilawkmangi birridjedmi birrimarnbuni manberlnginj, manbadjan dja manyaw wanjh birribekkani manmak wanjh bonj.
ex.xe: They would peel the bark off ironwood branches and carve them into clapsticks, a small one and a large one, hear that they sounded good and that was it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Manbu manbadjan makka rungkal. Manu manyaw makka rarrk.
ex.xe: The large external [lines] are the outlines, the small internal [lines] are the hatching.
ex.so: Joey Nganjmirra, unpublished interview with Dan Kennedy for Artlink Magazine, 2016

sn.de: The lesser, child etc. of two things conceived of as existing in a greater-lesser, main-subordinate or parent-child relation. The greater or parent is termed ‘badjan’.

se.de: Give birth to, have a child.

ex.xv: Ngalbulanj yimeng ngare kab ngayawan nawu wurdyaw.
ex.xe: Ngalbulanj said 'OK, I'd better go and look for that kid'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Manme kayawarren. (reflexive)
ex.xe: She's looking for food.

ex.xv: Dja mak ngalbininjkobeng nuye yawkani.
ex.xe: And his wife was carrying a child [was pregnant].
ex.so: Nawirridj, Grace & Rowe, Meryl (eds), ‘Karriburlume God: Kunwinjku Song Book’, Gunbalanya, 1985, p. 5.

ex.xv: Ani djorlno, kayawkan nakka.
ex.xe: A joey in the pouch, it [the mother kangaroo] is carrying the joey.

ex.xv: Dja djurra kumek’ ngayawkakani kodjkurlumak, kuyirrk ngarduk.
ex.xe: I was carrying a little bible, in my string bag.

sn.de: Carry a child, be pregnant, carry any small thing.

ex.xv: Yawkyawk dja yawurrinj kabirrire kabirriborrkke kore disco.
ex.xe: Girls and boys go dancing at the disco.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation.

ex.xv: Ngalbu ngalyawkyawk kayawkan wanjh ngarrimarneyime bibbidj minj ngarringeybun, warddi kabikebkadjung bu kabenekebrohrok. Dja bibbidj ngarrimarneyime ba kornkumo kabikebkadjung bu kabenekebrohrok.
ex.xe: When a girl has a child, we call it 'bibbidj', we don't use it's name, otherwise it will end up looking like its mother. We call it 'bibbidj' so it will look like its father. (In Kunwinjku culture it is considered preferable that a child takes after its father in terms of looks).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Young women, for singular usually the prefix is used ngalyawkyawk.

ex.xv: Yawkyawk bokenh nawu beneberddjenjni, yimankek kundadniwirrinj.
ex.xe: There were two female water spirits, who had fish tails where legs should have been.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

sn.de: Female spirit, lives in water, said to be similar to 'mermaid', appears at night from under rock ledges in the water.

se.de: Grow from a young girl to a teenage girl.

ex.xv: Nganyawmey kunred.
ex.xe: My mother's country.

ex.xv: Biyawmey.
ex.xe: She is ‘mother’ to him/her. / He is mother’s brother to him/her.

ex.xv: Yawmey.
ex.xe: I am your mother. / I am your mother’s brother.

sn.de: Offspring of matriline (i.e. mother or mother's siblings).

ex.xv: Yuwn yiyawoyhre kumekbe.
ex.xe: Don’t go there again.

ex.xv: 'Ngabenyawoyhkukngun, kaluk ngabendjordmihwe kore kunjam.’ Kaluk yerrih nakudji mandjewk benyawoyhyawmey.
ex.xe: [Yingarna said] ‘I will swallow them all again, and grow them in my stomach’. Then after one year, she gave birth to them again.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 4

sn.de: Again (adverb which is incorporated into verbs).

ex.xv: Nawu yawurral nayin nungan kayo kore manberrk nawu nungan kurdukadji karongkadjung dja mak nabang.
ex.xe: The whip snake lives in open forest areas, and can try to attack emus. It's a venomous snake.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Young men, boys. The singular form is generally nayawurrinj, 'a young man'.

se.de: Grow from a boy to a teenager.

ex.xv: Ngayayme, kanbodmelirrhmen!
ex.xe: I'm itchy, scratch my back!

ex.xv: Ngadengeyayme.
ex.xe: My toes are itchy / I have tinea in my toes.
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

sn.de: Feel itchy. This word is also often used to describe tinea.

ex.xv: Manbelk kabirrimarnbun nawu daluhdaluk bu bolkkime yehyeng yiman nawarlah djenj kordbolbok Yawkyawk.
ex.xe: Nowadays women make all kind of things out of pandanus, [even sculptures] like stingrays, fish, frogs and Yawkyawk spirits.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngahli mayhmayh kangeyyo djuwe birrikukbele kabirringeybun bowerbird. […] Kare kamoyhmang yehyeng nawern karrurndiwe rowk kakurrmekurrme kore kunred nuye karedmarnbun.
ex.xe: That bird called djuwe, white people call it a ‘bowerbird’. […] It goes and collects lots of things and takes them back and puts them all in its nest.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Things, various things, all kinds of things.

ex.xv: Kaluk yekke kayimerran.
ex.xe: Soon it will be dry season.

ex.xv: Bu yekke dja wurrkeng kayimerran wanjh kunkarndum kayongen. Kukak yerrih. Wanjh bu malamalaywi ngarridolkkan ngarrinan kabolkbarrkbun kunkarndum. Wanjh ngarriyime "Aa, kunkarndum kankarrme".
ex.xe: In the seasons of Yekke and Wurrkeng, there is fog. Also at night. And when we get up in the morning and see the land covered in fog, we say "Ah, it's all foggy".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Early dry season, cool weather season.

ex.xv: Kumhwam yeledj yerre nganhmunkekadjungi.
ex.xe: It [the Namorrorddo spirit] was coming up slowly behind me, following me.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Yika kunubewu kabirriyime, “Oh, nanih namak teacher kadberre. Yeledjyeledj kanbukkan.”
ex.xe: And they might say, “Oh, this is a good teacher for us, he teaches step by step [slowly, at a measured pace].”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Yiyemen!
ex.xe: You should be ashamed!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yeng kahyo.
ex.xe: There's poison in it, it's a poisonous substance
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yuwn ngurrire kumekke dja yehyeng kahyo nawu nawarre!
ex.xe: Don't go there, there are bad poisonous things in there (e.g. warning kids from entering an abandoned house, where old things in bottles could be lying around).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yeng kakarrme, kundjak nawarre.
ex.xe: He's got a very serious disease.

sn.de: A serious and dangerous disease, for example cancer, mosquito transmitted disease, serious STDs, etc.

ex.xv: Nawu mayh kukyahwurd ngarringeybun yenyen nawu nungan kahmarnbun kunboy.
ex.xe: We call the small insects that make mounds "yenyen" (termites).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wanjh yerrekah kurrmeng manyaw.
ex.xe: Then afterwards, he fitted the mouth (of the fishtrap).

ex.xv: Mankare rerre yikadjung.
ex.xe: Follow the same one (road) as before.

sn.de: As before, as we know, as discussed, as established before (in combination with various other words as illustrated).

ng: locative adverb that is also used in a temporal sense.

ex.xv: Kaluk yerrikah.
ex.xe: Later on.

ex.xv: Bu wurdyaw ngudberre ngurrbenyawmang nawu ngurrbenbukka kumekbe ba ngurrbenmarneyime kunkarre, bu ngurrikimukmen bu yerrikah.
ex.xe: And when you all have your own children, you should teach them, and that’s how you will tell them the law, later when you’re grown up.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Daluk bokenh benewam benengobarnmey wanjh beneyerrkang benengorbarnyirrmi.
ex.xe: Two women went and got pandanus, then sat down and were splitting the leaves.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Yiyerrkkemen!
ex.xe: Get undressed!

sn.de: Detach, undo, untie rope, remove (eg. clothing).
Become loose, become detached, become undone (of rope, string, knots).

ex.xv: Ngamyidurndeng.
ex.xe: I'll bring it back (as opposed to ngamdurndeng, 'I'll come back').

ex.xv: Kabiyilobme.
ex.xe: He's running with her.

ex.xv: Dulkyiyoy.
ex.xe: He lay with a splinter (in his leg).

ex.xv: Wokyi dorreng karriborrkke.
ex.xe: Let's call out as we dance (make the correct sounds).

ex.xv: Kornobolo yaw mudyi.
ex.xe: A baby wallaby with fur.

sn.de: For, with. When added to verbs as a prefix, it indicates that the action of a verb relates to some person or thing already mentioned.

ex.xv: Wanjh ngarrbek dahkendoy kore yibarlirrng, kukngorrmey wam.
ex.xe: Then he put it [the echidna] in his string bag, slung it over his shoulder and went.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, ‘Kunkare Nawamud Duruk Kebkang’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, 1975

ex.xv: Nawu nayawurrinj yami kunj wanjh kunmurrng nawu kunj birrimangi birridahkendongi kore yibarlirrng. Wanjh bu yawoyhyami wanjh kunmurrng birriyawoyhdahkendongi kore murrngdahkendi nakare. Dja bu danjbik marnbuni yami, wanjh birrimurrngdahkendongi kore yibarlirrng wanjh birrimurrngkurrmi kore kuwardderurrk. Wanjh bindidjurrkkani daluhdaluk bu birringuni nawu kunj bu yami.
ex.xe: When a boy would spear a kangaroo, people would put the bones in a string bag. Then when he speared another, they would put the bones in the same bag. And when he speared a third kangaroo, they would put the bones in the bag again and deposit the bag in a cave. After that, they would invite women to eat the kangaroos that the boy speared (the first kangaroos speared by a young man are traditionally taboo for women to eat).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Large knotted string bag. This type of dilly bag is carried by male water spirits at Benebenemdi in Barabba clan estate.

ex.xv: Bu korroko nakudji nakohbanj dabbolk Nakangila Nabarrbinj marnbom manbu mandule karrbarda wayihwayini wanjh biyibawong nakangilabuyika Nadjalama balhwayini bu darrkidni.
ex.xe: In the past a Nakangila skin man of the Barrbinj clan made the Long Yam song cycle, then passed it on to another Nakangila skin man of the Djalama clan, who sang it while he still lived.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Nabangardi yolyolmi kore kunbalanda wanjh nganyibawoni ngayeman ngabenkani kore ngad karriwokdi kunwok.
ex.xe: Nabangardi would speak to them in English and he would leave it to me to take them and speak to them in our own language [Kunwinjku].
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Ngalngarridj bimarneyimeng ngalbu Ngalbangardi, yimeng "Yina ngaye wanjh kukyibawong nawu djenj dja ngalmangiyi. Bimarneyimeng "bonj yikukkarrmen ba yikinje wanjh yingun."
ex.xe: Ngalngarridj told Ngalbangardi "Look, I left the fish and the turtle for you. Keep them so you can cook them and eat them".
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Leave something for someone (leave one grammatical object with/to or for another).

ex.xv: Yibba, ngoyongoyo kakodjkeyo, kodjdjewarre kabirrimerlemyembun. Kukurlk kayo.
ex.xe: The ornate burrowing frog and other burrowing frogs sleep, hibernating, they rub their abdomens (when they sleep buried). They sleep in the ground.

sn.de: Frog which burrows into small holes in the ground which fill with water.

ex.xv: Bu yiman bininj kababang kore kuburrk nuye wanjh kabirriyibbun wanjh kadjakngurdme nuye.
ex.xe: When for example a man has some pain in some part of his body, people can rub it and the pain will stop.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Ngoyongoyo kakodjkeyo djaddi. Kakodjkewarre, kabirrimerlemyibbun.
ex.xe: The ngoyongoyo frog is a sleeping frog. It is a sleepyhead (ie. it hibernates), they rub their bellies.

sn.de: Submerge something, cause to sink down.

ex.xv: Muddikang yibmeng ngadberre.
ex.xe: Our car is bogged.

ex.xv: Yina, nakkan kumoken kayibme.
ex.xe: Look, that freshwater crocodile is going under the water.

ex.xv: Yika birriyiddungi wurdwurd, birridurreni but yika mak ngarrimakni ngarridjalni yidyak.
ex.xe: Some kids used to get angry and fight, but some of us were good and we didn’t start fights.

sn.de: Become angry at someone, chastise, speak harshly, accuse, swear

ex.xv: Baleh yimi bu yiyidmebabangni?
ex.xe: How long have you had a toothache?
ex.so: Garde, Murray (ed.), ‘Bininj Gunwok talk about health : medical terms and vocabulary for health professionals’, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation, Jabiru, 2010

ex.xv: Namekke nadjinem manme kangun manbadbirri, yika kakolung kuwardde kakolung manbuyhbuyika kangun.
ex.xe: That black rock kangaroo eats Uvaria fruit, sometimes it comes down from the rocks and eats other kinds of food.

ex.xv: Kabirriyikadjurren rowk ngalbu kurdukadji kunkanj dja kunbalem.
ex.xe: They all share the meat and fat of the emu between themselves.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

re: be in a 'company' or sharing relationship
sn.de: Be in a 'company' or sharing relationship with other groups for ownership of clan lands.

ex.xv: Wanjh bu kedjelkminj benenguneng dja yikahwi benekang kured.
ex.xe: When they [the yams from the ground oven] had cooled down they ate them, and took some of them home.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, p. 17

ex.xv: …yikahwi bu kabindiwon kunrayek, bu kabindimarnewokdi nahni nawu teacher nawu wurdyaw ngalnjilngwarre […]
ex.xe: The teacher sometimes is harsh with those kids [my grandchildren]. When teachers tell them off, a child will become very unhappy.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Karrikerriyikan ba karrikerribun karrikinje kunj.
ex.xe: Let's go for antbed so we can make a ground oven and cook this kangaroo.

ex.xv: Bale yire? Ngaboyikan.
ex.xe: Where are you going? I'm going to get water.

ex.xv: Wolehwoleh ngarriwam hospital, nakohbanj ngarriyikang.
ex.xe: Yesterday we went to the hospital, we were visiting the old man there.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Go for something, fetch, go to visit someone etc.

ex.xv: Yilbinj makka kakarrme manwern kunkod.
ex.xe: Yilbinj is a type of paperbark tree that has a lot of paperbark on it.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kundulk manbu kunkod kahkarrme ngarrinan kunmalaworr, wanjh ngarriburrbun, yiman kayime yilbinj, mandarl, mankorrko dja mandjinh.
ex.xe: When we see the leaves of paperbark trees, we can recognise them, for example whether a tree is yilbinj, mandarl (Melaleuca viridiflora), mankorrko (Melaleuca argentea) or mandjinh (Melaleuca nervosa).
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Paperbark species, bark has a multitude of uses as for other paperbark species.

ex.xv: Wud yirrahkendo biliken wardi ngunyilkan.
ex.xe: Put the worms in the billycan otherwise they'll slither all over you.

ex.xv: Nayin nganyilkang!
ex.xe: A snake slithered over me!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Aah dulkyilkang nakka darnkih dulkdoyi!
ex.xe: Ahh, he brushed that tree, he almost crashed into it!
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Bininj yameng nganabbarru wanjh mey mandjawak kukyilkbom mey kundjen dja kunbirrkbirrkbokenh wanjh babburlibom kore kukarlang.
ex.xe: A man speared a buffalo, then took a knife and cut it up. He took the tongue and two ribs and carried them over his shoulder.
ex.so: Nabobbob, Rose, ‘Kunbidkudji Kunwok’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya

ex.xv: Bu kunborlidj birridjareni nawu bininj dja daluk wanjh lawk bindiyilkbuni bindiborlidjmarnbuni.
ex.xe: If men or women wanted scarification, they would cut each other with stone knives and make raised scars.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngardbakan nakka karohrok yiman karnubirr. Bu ngarridjare kuk ngarringun wanjh kunwardde ngarridong kabarrhme wanjh ngarringun
ex.xe: Saltwater mussels are similar to freshwater mussels. If we want to just eat them raw, we hit them with a rock, they split open and we can eat them like that.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: yiman kayime
ex.xe: similar to

ex.xv: Bu kunwok Kunwinjku ngarriyime mayh ngarriwarlbun. Dja bu ngarriyime mayh ngarrire ngarribidbun karrkad wanjh nakka kore ceremony yiman Kunabibi mandjamun manbu bininj ngadberre.
ex.xe: In the Kunwinjku language, we say that we hunt mayh (animals). But when we say we’re going up to a mayh, in that case it means we’re going up to a ceremony, such as Kunabibi or another sacred event of ours.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Such as, if, such as when.

ex.xv: Yimarnek ngarayi minj ngadjareniwirrinj.
ex.xe: I should have gone but I didn't want to.

ex.xv: Wanjh yimankek birrikuyinkelelobmerrinj Ngalyod bennanganang kunberd bendukkang rowk.
ex.xe: Then they tried to run away in fear but the Rainbow Serpent was watching them and she wrapped her tail around them.
ex.so: Quoted in Carroll, Peter, 'The old people told us : verbal art in Western Arnhem Land' (Thesis), University of Queensland, 1996

ex.xv: Yimankek balhdungyibmi dja birribebmeng.
ex.xe: It was just about sunset when they arrived.
ex.so: Manakgu, Andrew, ‘Kunbalak : stories for Kunwinjku young people in Mother-in-law language, ordinary Kunwinjku and English’, Kunwinjku Language Centre, Gunbalanya, 1996, pp. 48-51

sn.de: Should have, tried to, almost did, etc. Marker that indicates something didn't happen or hasn't happened yet, but that it should/could/will/might have. Counterfactual marker to indicate the irrealis.

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw yimeng "Djak nganbayeng".
ex.xe: The child said "An ant bit me".
ex.so: Dakgalawuy, Nancy, ‘Wurdyaw dirrihdirri’ in ‘Kunwinjku Stories’, Oenpelli Literature Production Centre, Gunbalanya, 1982

ex.xv: Manbu kunngabek kunkurrng ngarriyime kunmarrwardda.
ex.xe: In Mother-in-law language, we call hair 'kunmarrwardda'.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Call, call someone something, call something a particular name etc.

ex.xv: Baleh karriyime?
ex.xe: What are we going to do?

ex.xv: Kunekke kayime.
ex.xe: That's the way it goes (it goes like that).

ex.xv: Kamak, ngurrikan 'use' ngurriyime.
ex.xe: It's OK, you take it and use it.

ex.xv: Njale kunwok ngundimarneyimeng?
ex.xe: What news did they tell you?

sn.de: An auxiliary verb used to incorporate English words.

ex.xv: Kaluk yekke kayimerran.
ex.xe: Soon it will be dry season.

ex.xv: Bu korroko duninjh nawu karrkkanj nakka bininjni kaluk yerre mayhmayh yimerranj.
ex.xe: A long time ago the Brown Falcon used to be a man, only later did he become a bird.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Become, turn into, change, become in future (time).

se.de: Change form into something else, turn into, transfigure.

ex.xv: Baleh ngayimowon?
ex.xe: How do I do this?

ex.xv: Wanjh nawu wurdyaw yimeng mamamh baleh kanyimowon.
ex.xe: And the child said “Grandpa what are you doing with me?”
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngabenmarneyime, “Yuwn bu kunih ngurriyimowon dja ngurriwernhmarnbun, bu ngaye yiman ngahyimowon. Kandibidna.”
ex.xe: I tell them, “Don’t do it that way, make it properly. Like I’m doing it. Watch what I’m doing with my hands.”
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

ex.xv: Manbu… manbolh wam kore Pine Creek, wanjh borledmi Darwin way. Kunih yimowoni manbolh kerrngehkenh bu.
ex.xe: That road… went to Pine Creek then turned up towards Darwin. That’s where it used to go, that road.
ex.so: Quoted in Etherington, Steve, ‘Learning to be Kunwinjku: Kunwinjku people discuss their pedagogy’, PhD Thesis, Charles Darwin University, 2006

sn.de: Do, go about something, go. Often used to describe the manner of doing something or moving in a general sense, as in English “It goes like this”.
Mother rainbow serpent, the mother of ngalyod, really 'biggest one'.

ex.xv: Kuhri koyek duninjh kumekke wanjh kunu Yingarna yakarrbom bininj dedjborrhborrhdji nawu yibarlirr ngalengarre wanjh kumekke kurrmerrinj.
ex.xe: Far in the east is where Yingarna shook the last people out of her string bag, then she placed herself there forever.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Female creation ancestor, who emerged from the sea to the north and travelled throughout many lands. As she went, she dropped off particular people and foods in particular areas, and instructed the people which language they should speak.

ex.xv: Kunmadj ngurriyingkimarnbu la kumurrng karrire.
ex.xe: Get your swags ready beforehand because we'll be going early.

ex.xv: Ngarre ngayingkibomang.
ex.xe: Let's go, I'll get diesel straight away.

ex.xv: Bu korroko larrwa birrimarnbuni kore kundulk dja bolkkime kabirridadjke mankole kore manbu kayingkihrurrk manekke kodj kabirriname wanjh bakki kabirrikurrme kabirrikinje kabiwungme.
ex.xe: In the past people would make pipes from wood, but now they [often] cut bamboo, which is already hollow, attach a pipe bowl then put in tobacco and smoke it.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

sn.de: Straight away, first in a series of actions, prior to or in preparation for some proceeding action, already, beforehand.

ex.xv: Yinahnarrimen wardi yiyirdebme yimankan.
ex.xe: Look out, you might slip and fall.

ex.xv: Kukyirrek.
ex.xe: Slippery body (i.e. an eel).

ex.xv: Manbak kadjordme kuronj. Manyirrekyirrek.
ex.xe: Manbak grows in the water. It is a slimey plant.

ex.xv: Kabolhyirrek wardi karriyirdebme.
ex.xe: The road is slippery, we might slip.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Kayirrek.
ex.xe: It's slimy/slippery.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: One of the two patrilineal moiety names, the other being Duwa.

ex.xv: Karnkurlkkuno, mandulum kayirriyo.
ex.xe: (The place we call) Karnkurlkkuno is a staight line of hills.

sn.de: Elongate object lying/hanging. Lie in a row or line.

ex.xv: Wurdurd, ngurrikukmarnburrimen ngurriyirriyun!
ex.xe: You kids organise yourself so you're all lying down next to each other (parallel).

ex.xv: Nawu Kune, Dangbon kayirriyo.
ex.xe: Kune and Dangbon are neighbouring languages.

sn.de: Lie in parallel, lie next to.
Make space in the coals of a fire to cook something.

ex.xv: Ngalkamarrang dja ngalkudji ngalkukbele tourist kabenehni kabihbukkan bu kabenehngobarnyirrme.
ex.xe: Ngalkamarrang is sitting with a tourist, showing her as they split pandanus leaves.

sn.de: Strip, peel or remove layer of an elongate object, most commonly pandanus leaves during the process of preparing pandanus fibre for weaving and string knotting or the inner bark of Acacia difficilis to make string or a honey sponge.

ex.xv: Karrire yiwarrudj karriburlume Ngabbard.
ex.xe: Let's go to fellowship and praise Father (God).

sn.de: Religious fellowship or celebration. This word is almost exclusively used in a Christian context.

ex.xv: Korroko dabborrabbolk birrirey manberrk birriyawani birridulknani kaddum birrinani mankung bod kahboddolkan wanjh birridulkderdmi birriwodjburriweyi birrimonbuhmi, wanjh birrimangi nawu yiwk dja mandabu birrirawoni birridahkendongi kore billycan.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would go into the forest searching [for honey], looking up at the trees. When they saw honey bees flying around they would chop down the tree and open it up, then they would get the fluid honey and pollen sacs and put them all together in a billy can.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ur: Kuninjku = yukno, yiwkno. Kundjeyhmi, Kundedjnjenghmi = anyiwk.

ex.xv: Nawu nakurl ngarrinan koyekbeh kangolburlerran kawarnamkurrme, wanjh nakka kamre bu kundalk kakekurrme rowk, kore kurorre kayo.
ex.xe: We see late wet-season storms coming from the east, the clouds darken and make a dark horizontal bar on the horizon. It comes and knocks all the spear grass to the ground.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: To be lying down (of elongate objects).

ex.xv: Manme kayo?
ex.xe: Is there any food?

sn.de: To be located in a particular place.

ex.xv: A: Bukkanj kahni nakkanj? B: Kayo.
ex.xe: A: Is he there that one [the one you should know I mean]? B: He's asleep.

ex.xv: Yiyun!
ex.xe: Go to sleep!

ex.xv: Minj yuwirrinj.
ex.xe: S/he didn't sleep.

ex.xv: Bedda benedjarrkyonginj.
ex.xe: They slept together, they had sex.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997

ex.xv: "Yoh," yimeng ngalbininjkobeng.
ex.xe: “Yes”, said his wife.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Rachel, ‘Wurdwurd Bedberre’, C.M.S, Gunbalanya, 1974

ex.xv: Nawu yolk nakka kayo kore manme mannud dja kore mayh nawu karrowen.
ex.xe: Maggots live in rotten food and dead animals.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Ngayolyolme bu namarrkon djang.
ex.xe: I'll tell a story about lightning dreaming.

ex.xv: Ngangadjihbun, kunubewu ngandiyolyolme.
ex.xe: I'm sneezing, maybe people are talking about me.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Wardi yiyolyolme bedberre Balanda.
ex.xe: Explain it for those non-Aboriginal people.

sn.de: Tell a story, relate news, talk about something, explain.

se.re: explain or relate something to someone
se.de: Explain or relate something to someone, tell someone a story.

ex.xv: Mandolngkimuk wanjh kakeyongen.
ex.xe: With all the smoke, [the baby] will go to sleep.

ex.xv: Djarnay birrimbolkyurrhkeng birrimhdjalwam birriyonginj kore muddika kahdhjowkke.
ex.xe: They came past the Goanna sacred site and camped at the crossing.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 162

sn.de: To come into a particular state (inceptive).

ex.xv: Birrikoluy kore kuronj birrihmangi manu mandem, dja birriwakwani nawu kumekbe yongohyoy kinga.
ex.xe: They went down to the water gathering waterlilies, but they didn't know there was a crocodile lying there.
ex.so: Maralngurra, Dolly, 'Ngalkudji daluk bibayeng kinga', Oenpelli Literary Project, Gunbalanya 1974

ex.xv: Bu korroko dabborrabbolk birrikarrmi yorndidj bu birriwarddedongi wanjh birrimarnbuni yiman kayime mandjawak, karramalk, barrawu bu mayhken bu birridjobkeyi dja mak bindidadjkeyi nawu lakkayen bindimarnbuni.
ex.xe: In the old days, people would strike stones to make stone knives, just like they had regular knives, stone axes or spear tips, and they used them for things like cutting up meat or circumcising young men.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Stone tipped spear or long stone tipped knife.

ex.xv: Bu ngarrbek ngarrikakyawani wanjh ngarriyorrkeyi duruk nawu birriburddjinomi dja birriburddjiburrbuni ngarrbek.
ex.xe: When we used to hunt echidnas at night, we would get together a pack of dogs that could smell out echnidnas and recognise their scent.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Djilikuybi kawirlarrkngukdeng karrkad kurralk. Wanjh nawu wirlarrk kabehbebun yayaw kabebmerren wanjh ngalbadjan kabenyorrke ngalengarre yayaw kore manlabbarl manme kabenbukkan kabirringun.
ex.xe: Whistle ducks lay their eggs in the grass up away from the water. Then when the eggs hatch, the mother gathers the chicks together at the billabong and shows them what foods to eat.
ex.so: Andrew Manakgu, Injalak Arts painting documentation

ex.xv: Kayorryorrme kuluban.
ex.xe: The flying foxes are massing together.

ex.xv: Bu kudjewk mandjewk kamankan wanjh kukku kabobarlke kore mankabo dja manlabbarl wanjh kamarnbun kaboyowyowme rowk.
ex.xe: In the wet season, the rain falls and fills up the rivers and billabongs, making all the watercourses flow.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

ex.xv: Nawu wurdyaw barrken duninjh, wanjh kukku dja kunkayalanj kabirrimang kore kaboyowyowmebeh, wanjh kabirrikangengorrombun. Ba bu kadjordmen wanjh kadjalkangemak, minj mak kakangewarrehwarremen. Yiman kukku kaborlobme kore kukange nuye.

When a child is very young, people take wet sand from underneath flowing water and rub it on its chest. That's so when the child grows up, he will always stay happy, and won't get sad and down - as if water is flowing in his heart.
ex.so: Jill Nganjmirra

sn.de: Flow of water in a stream, river etc.

ex.xv: Yowyowmeng rowk wanjh berlngdanj rowk wanjh birrimirrhkudjmey.
ex.xe: The fluid all oozed out and then the swelling all went down and then they took out the sharp splinter.

ex.xv: Yoh birriwayini yukkuyukkuh, "Yukkuyukkuh kabirlihbirlikan, Yukkuyukkuh kabirlihbirlikan, karrulkbelbme, karrulkbelbme, karrulk-belbme." Nakamarrang wayihwayini.
ex.xe: Yes they sing about the firefly, "Fireflies, they carry light, fireflies they carry light, they attach themselves to trees, they attach themselves to trees, they attach themselves to trees." Nakamarrang used to sing that.

ex.xv: Birridokmeng yungki.
ex.xe: They've gone on ahead.

ex.xv: Nani ngudjbang kabenyurrhke.
ex.xe: He's really fast, he'll beat them all.

ex.xv: Djanay birrimbolkyurrhkeng birrimhdjalwam birriyonginj kore muddika kahdhjowkke.
ex.xe: They came past the Goanna Dreaming and camped at the crossing.
ex.so: Nganjmirra, Nawakadj, ‘Kunwinjku Spirit’, Melbourne University Press, 1997, p. 162

ex.xv: Nani kabiyurrhke.
ex.xe: This one has more than that one (reference to one container having more water than another).

sn.de: Exceed in capacity, size or volume.

ex.xv: Nungka ngunyurrhkeng Kuninjku kawokdi.
ex.xe: He can speak Kuninjku better than you.

ex.xv: Ngudda yibenyurrhkeng mayh yibengkan.
ex.xe: Your knowledge of ceremony is better than theirs.

ex.xv: Yuwn yibangmeyarlkilekme.
ex.xe: Don't touch the line yet (when it's swinging).
